DOC.HEAD: Dissipating Slick Moves Into West Virginia, Ohio
DOC.TEXT: A fragmented, 20-mile-long fuel slick drifted Wednesday past steel plants and boat marinas on the Ohio River into Ohio and West Virginia, where officials said it posed less of a threat to drinking water. `It does appear to be dissipating,'' said Dave Plank, chief of technical services for the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Resources. ``As the oil moves down the river, it will pose less of a risk.'' The slick's leading edge, moving about 1 mph, was near East Liverpool, Ohio, on Wednesday afternoon, said department spokeswoman Betsy Mallison. At least 75,000 gallons of diesel fuel, gasoline and kerosene poured from a severed interstate pipeline into an Allegheny River tributary Friday following a mudslide near Freeport 35 miles northeast of Pittsburgh. The Allegheny flows into the Ohio River at Pittsburgh. Earlier this week, the spill threatened the water supplies of as many as 1 million people along the Allegheny and Ohio rivers. Early Wednesday, it passed the Beaver County community of Midland, five miles east of the Ohio-West Virginia line. The Midland Water Authority, which serves 11,700 residents in Midland, Ohioville and Industry, reopened its filter plant's intake valves at 2 p.m. at about half normal pumping volume, said chief operator Dan Zuppe. The valves were opened after state environmental officials tested the water for oil. ``The spill has pretty much passed us by,'' Zuppe said Wednesday evening. ``We're under the direction of the DER and they will give us the direction when to go back on full.'' Weirton, about 65 river miles south of Pittsburgh, was the first West Virginia town whose water supply was threatened by the spill. Ken Capozzoli, a maintenance operator at the Weirton Water Treatment Plant, said the authority would close its intakes and rely on well water until the spill passed. ``We don't really know how long the wells can supply us, but we'll do fine for the couple of days it should take for the spill to pass,'' he said. At East Liverpool, the first Ohio community on the river south of the spill, two intake valves near the river's surface were closed as a precaution, said Glenn Woodward, water superintendent for the city of 7,000 residents. Intakes deeper in the river continued to draw water Wednesday afternoon because no oil had been detected that deep, according to Woodward. ``We are anticipating it could hit anytime,'' he said. In Midland, a voluntary water conservation measure was in effect. The spill was no threat to other water systems serving Beaver County because they depend on well water, said county Emergency Management Agency Director Russell Chiodo. Several manufacturing plants _ including a steel plant in Midland, a tin mill in Aliquippa and the Beaver Valley I and II nuclear power plants _ continued drawing water directly from the Ohio for industrial use, Chiodo said. In Pittsburgh, where small traces of petroleum were detected in river water, Mayor Sophie Masloff lifted her call for water conservation. And, water authorities along the Allegheny River that had been affected by the spill were back in operation. Water conservation measures in some of those communities, however, remained in effect. In Harrison Township, the only community where the taps ran dry, about 20,000 residents were told to boil water to kill bacteria that might have grown in the system when it was empty.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Bishops Hire Public Relations and Polling Firms
DOC.TEXT: The nation's Roman Catholic bishops on Thursday announced that they have hired a major public relations firm and a polling concern for a nationwide campaign to persuade Catholics and non-Catholics to oppose abortion. The bishops are expected to spend as much as $5 million over three to five years on the effort, The New York Times said in Friday editions. ``Given the stakes _ life itself _ we can do no less,'' said Cardinal John O'Connor, Archbishop of New York, who made the announcement as chairman of the bishops' Committee for Pro-Life Activities. The firms chosen, Hill & Knowlton and the Wirthlin Group, represent two of the nation's best known and most influential political and lobbying strategists. The Wirthlin Group is a leading Republican polling operation that served Ronald Reagan during his campaign for and time in the White House. John Berard, deputy general manager of Hill & Knowlton's Washington office, said the campaign would involve neither lobbying nor electoral politics. He said it was unclear whether it would include advertising. ``We are focusing our efforts on a broad-based public education and information campaign to make the bishops better heard on abortion,'' he said. O'Connor said in his statement, ``We want this effort to unfold on peaceful grounds, without vitriol, as we work to encourage both within and beyond our faith community serious considerations of moral ends, means and achievable policy goals.'' The Catholic bishops have hired media consultants for events like Pope John Paul II's visit to the United States in 1987, but never before on the abortion issue. O'Connor said money for the campaign would be raised from private individuals or organizations and would not detract from existing programs.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Fear of Unified Germany Lessening Among Americans
DOC.TEXT: Support for the reunification of East and West Germany is growing among Americans, with two out of three Americans saying they do not fear a united Germany, according to a New York Times-CBS News poll. However, the poll published in Friday editions of the Times indicated that Americans are concerned about the economic might of a united Germany; nearly four out of 10 Americans worried that Germany would dominate the European economy. Forty-nine percent of those surveyed said a united Germany would not try to dominate Europe economically, while 36 percent believed that it would. Asked about the future of Germany, 76 percent of those surveyed said they favored unification, an increase of 6 percentage points from a similar survey in November. A majority, 67 percent, said they were not concerned that a united Germany would threaten peace, while 22 percent said they were worried it would. The telephone poll of 1,515 adults between last Friday and Monday also found strong support for economic aid to nations in Eastern Europe and Latin American that are moving toward democracy. The Times said surveys since 1971 have indicated that Americans generally opposed foreign aid by a 3-to-1 margin. But they now are about evenly split on giving aid to Eastern Europe and Latin America, the newspaper said. A majority of Americans, 51 percent, said the number of U.S. troops in Western Europe should be maintained or increased, while 29 percent said the military presence should be cut and only 10 percent said it should be eliminated. Regarding Lithuania and its efforts to break away from the Soviet Union, 39 percent said they approved of the way President Bush is handling the crisis, while 19 percent said they disapproved. Forty-one percent took the president's view that maintaining good relations with the Soviet Union was more important than Lithuania's efforts to form its own nation. The poll has a margin of error of plus or minus 3 percentage points.

DOC.HEAD: Gene Located For Crippling Disorder of Children
DOC.TEXT: Researchers today reported an advance toward finding the defective gene or genes responsible for spinal muscular atrophy, a disabling and sometimes lethal disease of children. They narrowed down the search to a particular part of one chromosome, one of the 23 pairs of threadlike structures on which genes reside. Finding the gene or genes responsible for the disease may give clues for developing treatments, researchers said. No firm numbers exist on how many people have the disease, which weakens muscles by attacking nerves that control voluntary muscles. The study included three forms of the disease that strike a total of about one in 10,000 newborns, said study co-author T. Conrad Gilliam. The acute form, the most common, appears at birth or in infancy and usually kills by age 4. Two chronic forms usually appear in early childhood with effects ranging from relatively mild muscle weakness to profound weakness and death in early adolescence. Ashley Antolak, the 6-year-old national poster child for the Muscular Dystrophy Association, has a chronic form of spinal muscular atrophy. The new study found evidence that a defective gene or genes causing the chronic forms is on chromosome number 5. It also suggests that the acute form may come from the same source or a nearby gene, said study co-author Linda Brzustowicz. Brzustowicz, Gilliam and others at Columbia University and the New York State Psychiatric Institute did the work with Theodore Munsat of Tufts University and the New England Medical Center in Boston, and others at the University of Utah Medical Center in Salt Lake City, Odyssey Biomedical Corp. in West Paterson, N.J., and scientists in Britain, West Germany and Poland. The work is reported in today's issue of the British journal Nature. It marks ``a very important first step'' toward developing treatments and preventing the disease through prenatal diagnosis and detection of people at risk for having affected children, genetics expert Robert Williamson of London University in England commented Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Seduction and Sweet Surrender: Remembering Sarah Vaughan
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Never mind the trifling banter or the continual references to the buckets of sweat that cascaded down her ample frame. None of that mattered when Sarah Vaughan seized the stage and seduced a willing audience with the moody excitement of her jazz stylings. It was always sweet surrender. She caressed a song with all the colorings of her voice, sometimes teasing with the weighty depths of low D, sometimes more direct with her pure C. Sometimes playful with inspired scat, sometimes sentimental with soft singing from her soul. Who could resist such a temptress? For those who knew and worked with Sarah Vaughan, who died Tuesday night at age 66, few could. ``I traveled around the world with her and she'd be sold out, and people wouldn't even understand the language she was singing in,'' recalled drummer Harold Jones, who worked with Vaughan for a decade and had been friends with the song stylist for 25 years. ``Sometimes I'd go up to them later and ask them why they came to the concert if they couldn't understand her, why they thought she was so great. They would say, `it was the feeling, the feeling of the way she sang.' That's how they knew she was great.'' She sang of love and life. Easy, breezy tunes such as ``East of the Sun.'' Moody, bluesy ballads like ``Easy Living'' and ``The Man I Love.'' Complicated jazz songs that ended in rollicking scat _ ``Fascinatin' Rhythm,'' ``I Remember April.'' And along the way, she always had fun. Once, at a Carnegie Hall concert in 1980, she performed Duke Ellington's ``Sophisticated Lady,'' and confessed to a startled audience that she didn't know the lyrics so she'd have to refer to the sheet music. ``I've never done it until now,'' she said with a laugh. ``This could be my first and last time _ it's not an easy song to sing. If you hear me falter _ HELP.'' She didn't. She never did. Or, if she did, no one noticed. Or no one cared. ``She was always an absolute nervous wreck before performing,'' recalled Andy Simkins, Vaughan's bassist. ``There's a certain edge you need to perform. But she would be a wreck. She was fine after she went on stage, or after she started the first set at a club. ``She was always a little girl. I always thought of her as a little sister. There was a certain naivete and, then again, she was old professional show business and had stories for days. Billy Eckstine was really her mentor. When she was depressed and nobody could get to her, she'd call for B. He was the only one who could get to her.'' Vaughan worked with Eckstine in his own band after they both left Earl Hines in 1944. Together, they ignited romance with lovely duets on jazz standards. Alone, they both produced a litany of hit romantic records. She and Eckstine reunited a few years back at the Kool Jazz Festival in New York and reprised some of those love ballads. But time had robbed them of memory, and both whipped out their glasses to glance at an occasional lyric for ``Passing Strangers,'' a song popular in England in the 1940s. ``They had known each other so long, they didn't even have to rehearse,'' said jazz producer George Wein. ``It was the warmth of love that those two had for each other, so the lyrics didn't mean anything. It was the music.'' As a soloist Vaughan eventually ran into George Shearing, then a young jazz pianist who had emigrated to the United States from Britain in 1947. She was the first vocalist with whom he worked. ``Jimmy Jones, the pianist, had a trick whereby he would stab at a chord and then hit the sustaining pedal before the vibrations were gone and instead of getting BAAHHH, he'd get BINK,'' Shearing recalled in an interview. ``It was a wonderful trick, and he and Sarah would do that to `Tenderly.' He did that prior to the last note, and then she'd do some vocals that were just incredible. ``She could hold on to great, big long notes without vibrato.'' Vaughan took that great gift and used it for popular music when she recorded ``Brokenhearted Melody'' in 1958, and later with such middle-of-the-road tunes as ``Send in the Clowns.'' The switch generated new converts for her, but saddened jazz purists. ``I don't really feel she switched over,'' said Harold Jones. ``She went in and did them and then back on the gig, she was still singing `Lush Life' and `Tenderly.''' Simkins wasn't bothered with pop sidesteps either. ``I learned a lot from her,'' he said. ``She probably taught me how to play a ballad on my instrument. ... She was always my image as to how a love song or ballad should be played.'' Vaughan never thought of herself as a pop singer or a jazz singer, or even a great singer. And as popular as she was, Jones said, she never thought of herself as having a hit song. ``To me, she was the greatest,'' Simkins said. ``What I loved was she never thought of herself as Sarah Vaughan and her trio. She always thought of herself as a quartet.'' A powerful and pleasing instrument that gave pleasure to generations.

DOC.HEAD: Exiles Wait To Return to South Africa
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: About the time Nelson Mandela went to jail 27 years ago, Lenford Ganyile fled South Africa after a violent encounter that cost him all his teeth and most of an ear. A South African policeman's rifle butt knocked out his teeth, Ganyile said, and a bayonet sliced off the ear. Ganyile, 68, has been in exile since, first in Botswana and then in Zambia, where Mandela's African National Congress set up its headquarters. In February, President F.W. de Klerk of South Africa legalized the ANC and freed Mandela. ``I am waiting for Comrade Mandela to tell me what to do next,'' said Ganyile, a respected elder on the ANC's 7,200-acre Chongela collective farm in Zambia's fertile Ngwerere district, 25 miles north of Lusaka. Although he is eager to go home, Ganyile has difficulty remembering the wife and three children he left behind. ``In the early years, I sent them letters but had no reply,'' he said. ``I was afraid they would get into trouble, so I stopped writing.'' Occasionally, he heard news of his wife from newly arrived exiles. Then he lost all contact. ``The struggle became my family,'' Ganyile said. ``I saw my ear was not there and it reminded me always that I wanted all our people to be free.'' He is one of thousands of South African exiles scattered through the world whose lives were transformed by the lifting of a 30-year ban on the African National Congress and Mandela's release Feb. 12. The ANC has said most of its exiles probably would be home by the end of 1990. ``It is a dream to me,'' said Ganyile, a veteran of the Pondo rebellion of the late 1950s, when scores of blacks were killed in riots against South Africa's official apartheid policy of race segregation. Ganyile, who spent 20 months in jail, said he was arrested for leading ANC protesters in the Pondoland region near Mandela's home in Transkei. ``We were fighting one of the worst devils on earth, the Bantu Authorities Act'' and its discriminatory laws, he said. After fleeing South Africa, Ganyile used his farming experience to teach other exiles. He is on the Chongela farm's management committee. Farm manager Leslie Ponusamy said the property, three adjoining farms owned by whites before independence from Britain in 1964, feeds about three-quarters of the 2,000 ANC members who live in Zambia. Vegetables and maize grow on the farm, and the residents raise cattle, sheep, pigs and ducks. ``We don't produce everything for a balanced diet,'' said Ponusamy, a veterinarian who was a student activist in South Africa's Natal province. ``We sell the surplus of one thing to buy other things we need.'' Young exiles are sent by ANC headquarters in Lusaka to learn practical skills on the farm. Foreign donations help finance a dairy, slaughterhouse, several workshops and an auto repair shop. ``Most of our young people interrupted their educations when they left South Africa,'' Ponusamy said. Dan Twala, 22, said he fled after being assaulted by police in 1987, during a disturbance in a black township. ``I came to join the struggle,'' he said. ``Now all I want to do is to go back to see the family.'' What will happen to the farm when everyone returns home? ``Perhaps we will give it to the Zambian government,'' Ponusamy said. ``When we no longer need it, we will leave it as a momument, some sort of remembrance, to our struggle.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Feds Say War On Drugs Failed In Capitol
DOC.TEXT: Bush Administration officials say the year-old, ``test-case'' battle against drugs in the nation's capitol has failed, The New York Times reported. Their conclusions were expected to be part of a report on the program to be released this month by William J. Bennett, the national drug policy adviser, the Times said in Thursday editions. The Times quoted unidentified federal officials as saying that Washington has failed to demonstrate a commitment to control drug abuse. Unidentified city officials in turn, blamed Bennett, saying he oversold the program and failed to back up his promises with federal funds. In January, the city's mayor, Marion S. Barry, was arrested on cocaine charges. Both city and federal officials agreed that illegal drugs remain relatively cheap and plentiful and that there has been no reduction in drug-related murders, the Times said. The administration originally promised to direct an extra $100 million to drug programs in the city, much of which was supposed to go for jail space. But the money has gone unspent because the city has been unable to agree on a plan for jail construction, the Times said. The Federal government also has had military prosecutors assist in federal drug cases, has offered money for new drug treatment centers and created a team of federal agents led by the Drug Enforcement Administration that has made scores of arrests and seized millions of dollars in assets from drug dealers, the Times said. Bennett spokesman Don Hamilton, asked Wednesday night whether the report said the drug effort in Washington had failed, said: ``I don't think that's quite so. ``I don't think we're going to say everything in D.C. is hunky-dory and we should get a ride down Pennsylvania Avenue on rose petals, but the report's not done yet,'' Hamilton said. He said Bennett's staff planned to meet Thursday morning to discuss what would be in the report, which he said would be issued next week. In October, Bennett said the drug problem in the capital had gotten worse in the first six months of the drug war. ``We picked a difficult task last April, and I never had any illusions about the challenges that lay before us,'' he said at the time.

DOC.HEAD: Tragic Results After Someone Cried Wolf
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The call, on a marine hailing frequency, was urgent and chilling: A ship somewhere on the freezing waters off Massachusetts was transmitting a last-ditch plea for help. ``This is the fishing vessel Sol E Mar,'' a male voice shouted in frenzy. ``We're sinkin'. We need help now!'' The plea rose into a scream. The transmission was abruptly cut. Then, there was only crackling static. Coast Guard radio monitors on Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard tried desperately to get the caller back to locate the ship and send help. But just over a minute after the first call, another distress signal came in. ``SOS, I'm sinking,'' a male voice said. And then he laughed. The Coast Guard officers didn't dispatch rescue planes or boats. The calls, they thought, were just part of the rising number of hoaxes. Last Friday, five days later, they discovered they were wrong. The Sol E Mar was reported missing and the Coast Guard began a search for the father and son who manned the 50-foot fishing vessel. By then, it was too late. The Sol E Mar and the two men were presumed lost at sea somewhere south of Martha's Vineyard. The search was called off Sunday night. The family grieved, fishermen along the New England coast mourned the loss of more of their own, and the Coast Guard was left wondering how to deal with hoaxers who think they are being clever by faking a call for help. ``Things might have been different,'' said Lt. Paul Wolf, the Coast Guard spokesman in Boston. ``I can't say the fake call killed them. But it certainly lessened their chances.'' Bogus distress calls were once just a nuisance to Coast Guard rescuers. Now they are considered a serious problem. ``This is the first case that I know of where it was a factor in a rescue,'' Wolf said. ``It definitely influenced the way we responded.'' In 1989, 16 hoaxes were recorded on the coast from Canada to New Jersey, and the Coast Guard responded to most of the calls, said Coast Guard Cmdr. Bill Armstrong. This year, there already have been 11 known hoaxes. ``We have limited resources, and every time we respond to a hoax, those resources aren't there for someone who may need them,'' Armstrong said. In 1986, a man was sentenced to a year in prison after he broadcast a bogus distress signal that triggered a massive sea-and-air search for a sinking yacht with 10 people aboard. Emergency responses often are hampered because of the constant chatter on radios, largely by inexperienced boaters. The problem is so acute in the Boston area, with its endless stream of seafaring radio traffic, that the Coast Guard and the Federal Communications Commission will experiment with an additional distress frequency beginning next year, Armstrong said. Lost with the Sol E Mar were William Hokanson Sr., 44, and his 19-year-old son, William Jr. The two Fairhaven men set out March 22 from Kelley's Landing for Cape Cod, hoping for a large flounder catch. Manuel Aguiar, William Sr.'s brother-in-law, said he had heard the Coast Guard tapes. He said the first call was clearly from the son, and the second was a different voice. He said the family was angry at the Coast Guard. ``They're out there to serve the public, fake call or not,'' he said. Fighting back tears, Aguiar described William Sr. as ``one of the best men in the world. He would give you anything he had.'' William Jr. was a hockey star and a good student who loved fishing as much as his father, Aguiar said. William Sr. had been fishing for 20 years, and his son started joining him at age 6, he said. ``They were very close,'' Aguiar said. ``William Senior would never have let anything happen to his kid.'' It was the second loss at sea for the Hokanson family of fishermen. In 1952, William Sr.'s father, Fritz, was lost off Nantucket on the fishing vessel Paolina. At the Seamen's Bethel in New Bedford, marble cenotaphs honor lost seafarers, from the whalers of the 1800s to present-day fishermen. ``Fritz Hokanson is remembered here,'' said Director Adolph Allerdt. ``Now, his son and grandson will be, too.'' Wolf said the Coast Guard was reviewing its actions. More detailed instructions on how to distinguish hoaxes from authentic calls are being sent to radio monitors with added urgency because of the Sol E Mar sinking, he said. Even if the fake call had not come in, the Hokansons might never have been rescued, since their boat apparently sank before they could radio their location, Wolf said. ``If I could change anything, I would have given them five more seconds on the radio,'' Wolf said. ``The Coast Guard saved 6,000 people last year,'' he added. ``I just wish we could have rescued two more.''

DOC.HEAD: Nervous Broadcasters Say Castro Hasn't Fired Back _ Yet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Radio broadcasters are increasingly worried that Cuba will retaliate for the U.S. propaganda channel ``TV Marti,'' especially since a warning shot three weeks ago that was heard as far away as Utah. Radio station operators and engineers at this week's National Association of Broadcasters convention have done much talking about TV Marti and, more specifically, about the threat that Cuba might jam U.S. radio broadcasts in retaliation. It is widely believed that Cuba has radio transmitters capable of 1 million watts or more, 20 times the strength of the strongest U.S. AM stations. TV Marti is broadcast from a balloon high above the Florida Keys, and is designed to beam a pro-democracy message into Castro's Cuba. Cuba has been jamming the Voice of America broadcasts since they started March 27 and Cuban President Fidel Castro warned Tuesday that any U.S. attempt to interfere with the jamming could lead to war. He told reporters in Havana that TV Marti was a ``gross instrument of subversion.'' The warning shot that has broadcasters worried came on March 23, four days before testing of TV Marti began. Federal Communications Commission monitors heard Cuban radio signals on six separate clear-channel frequencies on the U.S. AM radio dial, said Walter W. Wurfel, senior vice president of the NAB. Half a dozen AM stations in Florida battled with the interference, and stations in Red Springs, N.C., and Donelson, Tenn., filed complaints, Wurfel said. The interference even turned up in Salt Lake City, said John Dehnel, chief engineer at that Utah city's clear-channel KSL-AM. ``It was definitely there, no question about it,'' Dehnel said. ``And we believe it was not their highest-powered transmitter.'' ``Castro delivered his message,'' said Patrick Roberts, president of the Florida Association of Broadcasters. ``If Castro fires up his AM radio transmitters, it poses a substantial potential to interrupt and cause interference to a lot of radio stations in the United States _ perhaps 1,000 to 1,500,'' Wurfel said. Broadcasters at an NAB seminar on TV Marti heard an example of apparent Cuban jamming, taken from KSL; it blended the Mormon Tabernacle Choir with the unmistakable sounds of mariachi music. President Bush asked the broadcasters Monday to ``stand for freedom'' and support TV Marti. But NAB President Edward Fritts said his group remains concerned about TV Marti interference and Cuban retaliation. He also complained that the administration refuses to allow broadcasters any input in the TV Marti testing. ``I have an AM station in Tampa that has been interfered with since Radio Marti began'' in the mid-1980s, said Michael Osterhout, president of Edens Broadcasting, which operates WRBQ-AM. ``We've had some minor interference at night. ``I just don't believe this is a feasible way to get programming into Cuba. ... The system doesn't seem to work.'' ``We're somewhat opposed to TV Marti,'' said Thomas L. Goodgame of Westinghouse Broadcasting, chairman of the NAB's Television Board. The $22 million effort may not work anyway, and if the Cubans jam U.S. radio broadcasts, ``it's definitely not worth it,'' he said. So far, it appears that Cuba has left U.S. AM radio alone since the events of March 23. ``We are not aware of any specific, new interference to American AM broadcasters by Castro since the (TV Marti) tests began,'' Wurfel said. Broadcasters also fear that the TV Marti transmissions might bleed over and disrupt Florida TV stations _ chiefly in Tampa, where a station already broadcasts on channel 13, the same used by TV Marti, Wurfel said.

DOC.HEAD: Quartet of Democrats Jockeying for Shot at Helms
DOC.TEXT: Undaunted by shortages in money and name recognition, four eager North Carolina Democrats are jockeying for a shot at toppling conservative Republican Sen. Jesse Helms in November. With the primary election just a month away, voters so far have been spared the rough-and-tumble politicking that early on characterized the 1984 race between Helms and his Democratic challenger, then-Gov. Jim Hunt. This time around, all four Democratic challengers have been campaigning across the state to expand their appeal, but none has broken out of his regional base and into the lead. ``None of the Democratic candidates have the widespread name recognition of a Jim Hunt, but as we get closer to the primary, I think that will resolve itself,'' said state Democratic Party Chairman Lawrence Davis. ``It's been an incredibly different campaign from 1984,'' said Carter Wrenn of the National Congressional Club, Helms' political organization. In that year, neither Helms nor Hunt had a serious primary challenger, so both candidates began gunning for one another early, spending a national record $26 million on a race marked by negative campaigning and personal slurs. The main challengers in this year's May 8 Democratic primary are: _Former Charlotte Mayor Harvey Gantt, who is seeking to become the first black to win a statewide race in North Carolina. Gantt's supporters say a solid black vote, combined with his proven ability to attract white voters in his mayoral races, could help him garner 40 percent of the Democratic vote and avoid a runoff. _Southport prosecutor Mike Easley, who has developed a reputation as a drug fighter in a region whose coastal areas have been used by smugglers since pirate days. Easley has the support of many party activists who were involved in Hunt's campaigns and has campaigned on themes such as day care and the environment that are likely to attract baby boomers. _R.P. ``Bo'' Thomas, a produce broker who served nine years in the state Senate. Thomas has campaigned on a strong populist message that he says can win back ``Jessecrats'' _ conservative white Democrats who routinely vote for Helms. _Former Insurance Commissioner John Ingram, whose major campaign theme has been a plan to force insurance companies to finance a high-risk pool to make affordable health insurance available to almost everyone. Early polls show Helms ahead of all four potential challengers, a reversal from 1984 when similar surveys had Hunt in the lead. By the November election, however, Helms had hacked away at Hunt's support to take 52 percent of the vote. Helms' 43 percent approval rating also is higher now than in 1984, Wrenn said. While the noise of the campaign hasn't been as loud as in 1984, both sides say the equation for victory remains the same. Helms starts out with 40 to 45 percent of the vote and his eventual Democratic opponent can count on roughly the same amount. ``You have people who are yellow-dog Democrats who will always vote against Helms because he's a Republican,'' said Thad Beyle, a political science professor at the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill. ``And then there are others who will always vote against Helms because of his views.'' Wrenn said the outcome depends on the 10 percent to 20 percent of the electorate identified as swing voters, most of whom are registered as Democrats. ``They have to get all of their votes and a third of ours to win,'' Democratic chairman Davis said of the Republicans. ``That's the same equation we've had for the last several years.'' Beyle said Helms' tactic for reaching those voters, judging from his last campaign, is he ``gets hold of some issue well before the campaign and beats it to death.'' ``In 1984, it was the Martin Luther King holiday bill,'' Beyle said. ``In 1990, it's the National Endowment for the Arts,'' which Helms has criticized for supporting art he considers obscene. Wrenn attributes Helms' strength in the early polls to two factors: ``One, we're not running against Jim Hunt, a very popular governor. And two, all the Democratic candidates' positions are left of center, and pretty extremely left of center.'' Beyle said Helms may be starting out stronger this time because he is not yet facing an identified opponent. ``Right now, he's running against X candidate,'' Beyle said.

DOC.HEAD: Nikolais Soars With `Space Fantasy' For Kids
LaserPhoto WX8
DOC.TEXT: Modern dance pioneer Alwin Nikolais is accustomed to worldwide acclaim, but he confesses he was terrified by the squirming second-graders who attended the world premiere of his new ``space fantasy'' for children. ``Children frighten me,'' said Nikolais, a 79-year-old bachelor. ``You never can know what their reaction might be, unless you're around them a lot. I'm not around children very much, so it was doubly terrifying.'' Nikolais needn't have worried. Moments after the curtain rose Tuesday on ``The Crystal and the Sphere,'' his stage voyage through the galaxy of a child's imagination, Nikolais clearly had won the hearts of 500 local school children who packed the Kennedy Center's Terrace Theater. The kids squealed as the house lights dimmed and the rumble of thunder shook their seats. They oohed and aahed as the rising curtain revealed a 20-foot balloon rocking gently on the stage, like a strange new planet, and a 12-foot shard of crystal bathed in celestial lights. They giggled at the wondrous aliens that cavorted across the stage _ a mermaid who teasingly tied her kelp tresses to an angler's hook, a pair of fat, web-footed birds that splashed in musical mud puddles, herky-jerky androids ablaze in ultraviolet hues who disappeared in the twinkling of an eye. Nikolais did it all _ choreography, synthesizer musical score, scenery and costumes _ in creating the $20,000 centerpiece for this year's ``Imagination Celebration,'' the Kennedy Center's annual arts festival for children. His new work, performed by five hand-picked dancers from New York, is being presented nine times this week at the Kennedy Center before it travels to children's festivals at the El Centro Theater in Dallas, April 18-20, and the Orange County Performing Arts Center in Costa Mesa, Calif., April 25-26. ``The first show is a terror,'' said Nikolais, sighing happily after the curtain fell on his latest premiere. He hadn't created a dance work for youngsters since he was director of the Henry Street Playhouse in New York in the late 1940s, when his company staged a dozen popular ``dance plays'' for children. Since then, he has been cheered by audiences and critics around the world _ and received the coveted National Medal of Arts from President Reagan in 1987 _ as a modern dance visionary. In a way, Nikolais said, his work on ``The Crystal and the Sphere'' meant returning to the world of children after a 40-year absence. ``They haven't changed,'' he said. ``They're made the same way and they behave the same way. It's that I'm rediscovering them again.'' Nikolais tried to envision the unearthly creatures a child might encounter on an imaginary exploration of the planets. ``Like most artists, I have a childlike mind with a certain innocence that allows me to do things that others don't dare to do,'' he said. ``I do know that children love color, and they like motions that they don't see all the time. I thought they'd like these curious, angular body shapes, and dancers who suddenly appeared and disappeared. ``Children also like strange sounds. You don't hear them humming Beethoven's Fifth Symphony. They like the big bang, like the world's coming to an end. And what really scares them is the lights going out, and being left in the dark. That always makes them yelp.'' Nikolais' vision scored a hit with at least one member of the audience Tuesday. When the lights went up after the 45-minute show, a little girl turned to a schoolmate and asked, ``It's over already?''

DOC.HEAD: The Times' Letters Editor Reflects on 11 Years at the Mailbag
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: This is not a great age of correspondence, says the recently retired editor of The Times' venerable letters column, though the mailbags still bulge with opinions both profound and eccentric. ``There are many people who simply do not know how to put words onto paper; they have to become so used to talking on the telephone or dictating into machines and having them tidied up by their secretaries,'' Leon Pilpel said in an interview published in Wednesday's editions of The Times. ``Of the 300 letters a day, only about 8 percent are publishable. I am not talking about matters of syntax, but about importance, or meetness. ``Many of them are pretty mundane, although frequently half a dozen not very brilliant ones can be made into a very good correspondence indeed _ with a bit of judicious editing, and the specific approval of the letter-writer.'' Great debates have been waged in the sober letters columns of The Times, leavened with whimsical bits of English life, such as the sighting of the first cuckoo of spring. Pilpel, who is taking up new duties as a deputy ombudsman at the paper, joined The Times 40 years ago and became letters editor in 1979. The best letters during his tenure, Pilpel said, came during the Falklands war with Argentina in 1982, when former ambassadors and high-level bureaucrats were moved to pick up their pens. The letters columns, he said, have declined in influence. ``The amount of information, and the diversity of viewpoints made available to the public from every medium, chiefly radio and television with all their discussion programs, mean that in some ways we are just part of a more widely disseminated form of argument,'' he said. Wednesday's four columns of letters were typically diverse, running the gamut from Soviet policy in Lithuania and the late Bruno Bettleheim's theories about the docility of prisoners in Nazi death camps, to a letter from Nina E.C. Coltart of 1a Well Road boasting of next-day delivery of a first-class letter addressed ``Won, Eh? Well Rowed!'' Graham Chainey wrote from Cambridge to summarize his researches on letters to the Times regarding the Oxford-Cambridge Boat Race, which was rowed last weekend and won by Oxford. ``In January of this year I calculate that you published no fewer than 15 letters from Cambridge addresses against a miserable four from Oxford,'' Chainey wrote. ``This lead was magnificently maintained in February with a further 16 from Cambridge against three from Oxford. Only in March did the balance inexplicably swing the other way, with Oxford scoring seven published letters against five from Cambridge.'' The final tally, he determined, was Cambridge 36, Oxford 14. ``I do not, of course, offer any explanation,'' Chainey said. In the style of Times' correspondents, he signed off, ``yours faithfully.''

DOC.HEAD: Two More Companies Suspected of Delivering Parts to Rabta Plant
DOC.TEXT: BADEN-BADEN, West Germany (AP) _ Two more West German companies are being investigated on suspicion of trying to deliver parts to the Libyan plant allegedly involved in making poison gas, a televison station reported. Suedwestfunk TV said Wednesday that prosecutors in the southern city of Ulm have opened a probe of Abacaus GmbH in Ulm and Rose GmbH in Stuttgart. Investigators searched the offices of the two companies last week and seized documents, the report said. Agents also searched the home of Abacus manager Wolfgang Liebert, the television station said. The two companies are suspected of seeking to deliver parts to Libya needed to complete the chemical plant in Rabta, the report said. No actual deliveries are believed to have taken place, it said. U.S. and West German officials said earlier this year that the Rabta plant has produced limited amounts of poison gas. Libya denied the reports, insisting the plant is designed to manufacture only pharmaceuticals. A fire last month caused damage at the Rabta plant. The cause of the fire is not clear, nor is the extent of the damage. U.S. allegations that West German companies helped Libya build the plant caused a row between Bonn and Washington last year. The West German government at first denied the allegations but later ordered its own investigation. Imhausen-Chemie GmbH, a chemical company in the southern town of Lahr, is suspected of delivering key equipment to the Rabta plant. Juergen Hippenstiel-Imhausen, the former chief of Inhamusen-Chemie, was indicted last month on charges he played a major role in supplying equipment to the Rabta factory. He was arrested 11 months ago. The Suedwestfunk television report said the Abacus company ordered equipment from a Siemens facility in Karlsruhe, saying the order was on behalf of a Dutch company. The final destination of the equipment was given by Abacus as Saudi Arabia, the report said. But authorities believe the equipment was really destined for Libya, the report said. The equipment involved parts needed to complete a production guidance system in Rabta, the report said. Some components of the system are believed to have been delivered by Imhausen in 1987, it added.

DOC.HEAD: Two Convicted Leftist Terrorists Arrested Near Swiss Border
DOC.TEXT: Two men captured near the Swiss border in a car filled with weapons and ammunition have been identified as convicted members of the Red Brigades terrorist gang. Officials said they were probably preparing a major armed robbery, but had no other immediate details. Police identified the two as Enzo Fontana, 38, who was sentenced to 26 years in prison for killing a highway patrolman in 1977, and Giorgio Giudici, 40, who had served out an eight-term term for armed robbery. The two were arrested Tuesday by police, who, according to press reports, also uncovered a hideout filled with arms and explosives. Four other people suspected as accomplices escaped. Officials said they were investigating possible links to arms dealings in Switzerland. Giudici worked as a driver for a firm in Roveredo, in the Swiss canton of Ticino. Fontana was serving his term in semi-liberty, meaning he was free during the day but had to return each evening to San Vittore Prison in Milan.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Expands Northeast Service; New York Judge Says `No Strikebreakers'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Boston fire at Greyhound garage; picks up 2nd graf, `In New York ...'
DOC.TEXT: Greyhound Lines Inc. on Wednesday offered free bus trips through Easter to passengers delayed on Northeast routes in an effort to recapture business lost in the region during a monthlong drivers' strike. A suspicious fire broke out Wednesday night in Boston at a garage at a Greyhound service terminal housing about 15 Trailways buses, fire officials said. There were no injuries. Firefighters had to cut through a metal garage door to get to the fire, and had a difficult time locating its source because the 300- by 150-foot garage was filled with smoke and heat, said Boston Fire Chief Robert Dillon. The fire appeared to have been concentrated in a single bus. Trailways is owned by Greyhound. In New York City, a state judge barred the company from hiring ``strikebreakers.'' Greyhound said it would appeal the ruling. Greyhound's 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 office and maintenance workers walked off the job March 2 in a dispute over wages and job security. The country's only nationwide bus company has operated on a reduced schedule since then using permanent replacements and union members who cross picket lines. The union Wednesday accused the company of allowing ``crazies'' and ``terrorists'' to block a resumption of talks. The company called on the union to join in a news conference denouncing the violence and to cut strike benefits for union members who participate in attacks. Greyhound has said it will not bargain with the union until seven days have passed without shots being fired at one of its buses or facilities. Union spokesman Nick Nichols said the condition makes no sense. ``They basically turned this whole process over to the people they're calling the terrorists,'' Nichols said. ``There's no way, in my view, that either the company or the union can control these crazies.'' Greyhound vice president P. Anthony Lannie said in a letter to union president Edward Strait that ``absent implementation of effective measures to curb the illegal conduct, the union cannot disclaim responsibility. ``The union's conspicuous failure to implement effective measures against the violence lead to the inevitable conclusion of union responsibility for strike misconduct,'' he said. In New York, Judge Diane Lebedeff granted a union request for a temporary restraining order based on an anti-strikebreaking statute passed by New York's City Council in 1962, but never used. It prohibits a company for bringing in any workers ``for the purpose of having such person take the place in employment of employees in an industry or establishment where a strike or lockout exists.'' The judge said Greyhound's offer of a $2,000 bonus to drivers hired during the strike ``tends to corroborate the charge that strikebreakers are being used.'' Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said the ruling wouldn't affect the company much. ``It does not interfere with our basic operations ... we don't hire strikebreakers,'' he said. Dallas-based Greyhound has been rebuilding its system since the strike began, expanding mainly in the South and West. Last week, Company President Frank Schmieder said the walkout was essentially meaningless in much of the country. However, he acknowledged that the Northeast, which accounts for about 10 percent of Greyhound revenue, remained a trouble spot. Greyhound said Wednesday it was improving regional service by adding hourly departures on Fridays and Sundays from New York City to Boston, Philadelphia and Washington. It guaranteed seats would be available and buses would run on-time. ``We promise to arrive within 15 minutes of the scheduled arrival time,'' Schmieder said. ``If we don't we will give our passengers a coupon good for a free round trip on the same route.'' The guarantee covers Albany, Buffalo, Rochester and Syracuse, N.Y.; Boston; Montreal; Mount Laurel, N.J., Philadelphia; and Washington, is good only through Easter Sunday, April 15, and must be redeemed by June 15. Greyhound spokeswoman Elizabeth Hale said the company had decided to focus attention on the Northeast because of the region's level of commuter travel. Ms. Hale said 1.66 million people have taken Greyhound buses since the strike began, with 61,437 traveling by bus on Tuesday, or 46.8 percent of those who traveled on the same day last year. Percentages have been climbing slowly throughout the walkout. Greyhound has pledged not to resume negotiations with the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions until a week passes without major violence. There have been 31 shootings, including 26 at buses, 70 bomb threats and more than 100 other incidents of violence, Greyhound officials say. The union says about 60 of its pickets have been targets of violence. A striker in Redding, Calif., was crushed to death March 3 by a bus being reversed by a replacement driver. Greyhound has offered a three-year contract it values at $63 million and says it can not afford to pay more. The union says its own latest offer is worth about $40 million, but Greyhound says it would cost $180 million.

DOC.HEAD: Exhibit and Editors Explore `Paradox of the Press'
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Halaas is correct in 10th graf, bgng, The `Paradox'
DOC.TEXT: ``Putting out a newspaper without promotion is like winking at a girl in the dark _ well-intentioned but ineffective,'' said press mogul William Randolph Hearst. His quotation adorns an exhibit, ``The American Journalist: Paradox of the Press.'' It opens today at the Library of Congress and winks, in full self-consciousness, at the American press in every manifestation from feisty Hearst to feisty Benjamin Harris, America's first newsman. Harris published the first American newspaper on Sept. 25, 1690. It lasted one issue before it was closed down by the British authorities. The sole surviving copy was flown back from London for the exhibit. The show, underwritten by a $325,000 grant from the Gannett Foundation and running through Aug. 12, coincides with the 67th annual meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, whose members gathered at the library Wednesday night to celebrate the occasion. On display, behind glass: the little bedside notebook in which Washington Post reporter Bob Woodward made notes when the city desk awakened him on Saturday, June 17, 1972, to tell him to cover a break-in at the Watergate Hotel. He scratched down: ``5 men arrested ... at Demo Nat headquarters w@soph photo equip.'' Joined by street reporter Carl Bernstein, he went on to uncover the Watergate scandal that led to the resignation of Richard M. Nixon as president two years later. Nothing so dramatic appeared in ``Public Occurrences, Both Forreign and Domestick,'' Benjamin Harris' scrawny paper _ three printed pages and a blank one. It reported a suicide by hanging, the spread of a smallpox epidemic and rumors about improprieties by the king of France. Harris proposed to publish once a month (``or if any glut of occurrences happen, oftener''), but the authorities concluded that his paper contained ``sundry doubtful and uncertain reports'' and closed it down. The ``Paradox of the Press'' is what the exhibit explores _ what curator David Halaas says has been ``the love-hate relationship between the people and the news gatherers.'' ``On one hand, members of the press are seen as truthseekers and watchdogs of government; on the other hand they're seen as gossip-mongers and purveyors of slander,'' he said. On exhibit are war correspondent Ernie Pyle's typewriter; the clippings in Abraham Lincoln's pockets when he was assassinated; the hustling newsboys who learned to condense a news story into a few catchy words; the zany cartoons of Rube Goldberg such as one entitled, ``Simple Way to Light a Cigar in an Automobile Traveling 50 Miles an Hour''; a battlefield picture of a grinning, boyish, helmeted, war cartoonist Bill Mauldin; and the cluttered rolltop desk of William Allen White, editor-owner of Kansas' Emporia Gazette who came to epitomize the courageous, common-sense small town editor. And, too, a poster advertising the New York Sunday Tribune. The picture showed conductors tossing bundles of papers from a moving train onto a suburban platform. The legend: ``It has an illustrated supplement and, being a high class, dignified paper, of superb merit, is especially worthy to be read by intelligent and honest people.'' Back at the ASNE meeting, another paradox of the press was the topic of a speech given by retiring association President Loren Ghiglione. He told colleagues that journalists have become so successful _ comfortable, well-paid and suburban _ that they have forfeited their role as fighters for society's underdogs. ``We often think of ourselves as Davids, fighting the establishment, but the public sees us more and more as status-quo, establishment Goliaths,'' said Ghiglione, publisher and editor of the Southbridge (Mass.) News. ``While we say we comfort the afflicted and afflict the comfortable, we need to guard against looking at the world increasingly through the eyes of the comfortable,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: IBM Scientists Write the Corporate Initials With 35 Atoms
LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: Scientists have arranged 35 atoms to create what is probably the world's tiniest advertisement, attaining a precision that may one day lead to development of new materials and far faster computers. It took 22 hours of moving atoms one by one to create the letters ``IBM,'' researcher Donald Eigler said. The design, about 660 billionths of an inch long, is featured in a report by Eigler and Erhard Schweizer, who did the work at IBM's Almaden Research Center in San Jose, Calif. The report is in today's issue of the British journal Nature. Physicists called the work a significant step that demonstrates that individual atoms can be arranged with high precision. ``The implications are really remarkable,'' said Stuart Lindsay of Arizona State University. He called the work ``absolutely fascinating.'' Someday, that ability may let researchers build vanishingly tiny electronic components, allowing computers far faster than today's supercomputers, scientists said. Atoms may also be assembled someday into molecules to create new substances and materials, they said. The atom-hauling process was akin to tugging ping pong balls over the bumpy bottom of an egg carton. The atoms were placed with such precision that scientists could choose an individual atom on the surface as the point on which to put a second atom to build the design, Eigler said in a telephone interview. The IBM scientists arranged atoms of a heavy gas called xenon on a surface made of nickel. They used a device called a scanning tunneling microscope, which produces extremely detailed images of surfaces. It can sense atoms on a surface by passing the tip of a needle over it. The tip holds a magnet-like attraction for atoms. When the tip was brought close enough to a xenon atom, it could pull the atom across the surface. The needle had to tug hard enough to haul a xenon atom over bumpy nickel atoms on the surface, but gently enough not to lift it off the surface, Eigler said. The amount of pull was adjusted by changing the needle tip's height. Typically, the tip hovered about 10 billionths of an inch above a xenon atom. Atoms could be moved about 16 billionths of an inch per second. Once they were positioned, the tip was withdrawn. Apart from the ``IBM'' design, researchers also arranged seven xenon atoms into a chain. The work was done at about minus 452 degrees Fahrenheit, almost as cold as anything can get. That kept the xenon atoms from wandering, Eigler said. In addition, it was done in an extremely high vaccuum to keep unwanted molecules from contaminating the surface, Eigler said. The surface can be kept free of contamination for at least a month, Eigler said. Lindsay said that degree of control was impressive. Eigler said he did not know of any commercial use for placing xenon atoms on nickel. But perhaps some more useful kinds of atoms will lend themselves to the technique, he said. Such atom-by-atom placement should help scientists learn more about how atoms and molecules behave on surfaces, which might help in developing semiconductors, the building blocks of many electronic devices, he said. It may also provide a way to store perhaps 2 million times more electronic information in a given space than is now possible, Eigler said. Electronic information is now recorded in sort of a Morse code consisting of 1's and 0's, and that might be translated into the presence or absence of an atom at a particular location, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Jail Rioters Seen as Heroes by Watching Crowd
DOC.TEXT: The inmates raising their fists in defiance on the roof of Strangeways Prison may look like dangerous criminals on the evening TV news. But for many in this northern industrial city, they're working-class heroes. Crowds of supporters have lined police barricades several hundred yards from the roof of the prison, which has been under siege since a riot by hundreds of inmates Sunday morning. Inmates have continued to surrender and the number still on the loose inside early today was 20 to 25, authorities said. But the crowds outside keep growing, and hundreds of people fill the streets beside the prison. Anxious mothers, sisters and wives and other supporters have followed the actions of rebel inmates on the roof through binoculars and telephoto camera lenses, waving and shouting names or words of encouragement. The crowd is very much Manchester's under class. They are the handicapped and the unemployed, and many are poorly dressed and dirty. Some also are drunk, and there are many children, some as young as 9, sharing packs of cigarettes and lollipops. Some of those who have stood for hours in the bitter cold are former inmates. Others have never before been near the jail, but nearly all stood vigil because they supported the prisoners' demands for better jail conditions. ``It's a local jail. A lot of people in Manchester have had people in there and they know what goes on,'' said John Martin Riley, a construction worker whose brother is serving a 10-year sentence for armed robbery. Strangeways, massive and grim, was built in 1868 to hold 970 men. On Sunday, when the riot began, it held 1,648. Even prison officials have used the siege, in which at least one inmate has been killed and more than 45 people injured, to condemn gruesome prison conditions. At Strangeways, as many as three men are locked in a 5-by-7-foot cell with a bucket instead of a toilet. They get showers and a change of clothes once a week. The prisoners claim the food is poor, frequently cold liver stew and stale bread. ``It's a horrible place, ancient and nasty and I hope they burn it down,'' said Tracy Wilding, 28, a part-time secretary whose ex-husband once served time in the red-brick jail. She said the rebel prisoners were ``very brave actually. They will all be in big trouble in the end.'' On Tuesday, Manchester Evening News editor Michael Unger went inside Strangeways at the request of inmates who wanted to meet a member of the press. In a story in the Wednesday edition of the newspaper, Unger described his feelings after meeting two inmates in their small, bleak cell who wished to surrender. ``I knew they were villains but they were tragic villains,'' Unger wrote. ``John turned to me. He begged me to write and visit him whichever prison he ended up in ... then John wept.'' ``Eric had decided to give himself up. He was very sad, very low, very frightened. ... Revenge from officers (prison guards) seemed inevitable, he said. Eric, like John, thanked me before he was led away ... you couldn't help but feel sympathy,'' Unger wrote. Prisoners who surrender are given a medical checkup and interviewed by a prison inspection panel. Then they receive a shower and a hot meal and are transferred to other jails. Despite their fears and worries, family members continued to support the dangerous action by the holdouts. Patricia Lydon, a part-time hotel receptionist, kept a three-day vigil outside the jail and intently watched her 24-year-old brother, Kiern, one of the last prisoners on the roof Wednesday evening. Like many of those in Strangeways, Kiern Lydon was jailed while awaiting trial and has not been convicted of any charge. Ms. Lydon was joined Wednesday by her mother and the two women held hands as they stood in the biting cold wind. ``I came to keep him company but I wish I was up there with him,'' Ms. Lydon said. ``They're fighting for a cause.'' ``They shouldn't have to come to this to get attention,'' her mother added, ``just to get normal human conditions.''

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 10 a.m. EDT; time set by source
States Leading the Way in Economic Development
DOC.TEXT: States are inventing their own economic development policies in a ``quiet revolution'' that came because they couldn't wait for federal solutions to evolve, a private research group said today. ``The story is that while Washington (the federal government) continues to be stalemated over what we ought to do over foreign competition, the states have gone ahead and invented their own strategies,'' said Doug Ross, president of the Corporation for Enterprise Development, a research and consulting organization. Ross said the states reached a consensus over the last decade that ``we haven't seen since the Progressive Era 100 years ago, when the states led the way in figuring out how to make the transition from an agricultural to an industrial society.'' Unable to wait for new federal solutions, states ``began tailoring home-grown strategies to cure state economic ills,'' Ross said. ``States now encourage and support indigenous development _ modernizing in-state businesses, easing their expansion and product development, educating their workers and facilitating start-ups,'' he explained. ``It's a quiet revolution, one that may well have more lasting impact on the quality of our lives and the prospects for our children than any other domestic policy shift of the past decade,'' Ross added. The findings are included in the fourth annual ``Development Report Card for the States,'' financed by corporations, labor unions and private foundations. For more than 40 years, the study said, states relied on ``smokestack chasing,'' or luring out-of-state businesses with incentives and subsidies. That approach no longer was working by the late 1970s, the study found. The study pointed to ``dramatic changes in communication, transportation and technology'' that often made it possible for overseas competitors to produce goods cheaper than U.S. manufacturers could. ``Our businesses were losing market share rapidly,'' it said. ``For the first time in our history it began to look as though we would not be able to promise our children a better life than our own.'' The study said some of the new strategies and the extent of their use include: _Forty-four states are stimulating applied research through research centers and research grants. _Forty-five states help businesses commercialize new technologies or apply state-of-the-art technologies. _Thirty-five states offer non-traditional development finance instruments, like product development, seed capital and venture capital. _Forty states employ new financial mechanisms that leverage private resources to help meet business capital needs. _Forty-seven states have launched specific education reform measures. _Forty-seven states devote state resources to improving the quality and productivity of their existing work force. As a result, the study said, Rust Belt states are resurgent less than 10 years after the 1981-82 recession nearly did them in. ``Recent investments in technology, infrastructure and skill improvements as well as policy innovations in development finance and industry modernization have paid off in new economic strength for these states,'' Ross said. According to the study, the Northeast and West Coast states continue to be the nation's strongest economically although some show troubling signs, including labor shortages in the Northeast and a decline of the timber industry in Oregon and Washington. Southern states ``continue to make remarkable progress toward economic health,'' the study said, but ``there is a long uphill struggle still ahead.'' With the exception of Utah, however, the Plains and Rocky Mountain states have not recovered from the recession. ``These states need intensive care and are not getting it,'' the study said. ``The world has changed, but these states have not,'' it said. ``Without substantial change in policy and growth in competitive capacity, these states face a bleak future indeed.''

DOC.HEAD: Insurers Dispute Claims of Exorbitant Fees by Gardner Museum
DOC.TEXT: Insurance executives disputed Gardner Museum's claims that it could not afford theft insurance for the works recently stolen there. Gardner officials said the museum _ target of the biggest art heist in history _ would have to pay an amount exceeding its $2.8 million operating budget for such insurance. The theft was committed March 18, when two men dressed as policemen talked their way in and tied up two security guards. But art insurers said theft insurance is affordable even for small museums. ``I don't know why they'd make such a statement,'' said Carl Allen, chairman of Allen Insurance Associates, a Los Angeles firm that insures about 100 museums nationwide. ``Those statements are just exaggerations.'' Both Allen and Huntington Block, president of a Washington, D.C., firm that insures 285 museums, said a $100 million policy covering theft, fire and any other loss or damage would run about $150,000 annually. ``That's a pretty normal figure,'' Block said. ``I don't know where the Gardner people got the idea it would cost millions.'' The heist was estimated to be worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The thieves made off with 11 paintings and prints by Rembrandt, Vermeer, Manet and Degas and swiped an ancient Chinese vase and a gilded eagle from the flagpole of a Napoleonic flag. Museum spokesman Barry Wanger said Gardner officials reviewed the museum's insurance policies about two years ago. He said they had received widely varying cost estimates and concluded that protection against theft was too expensive. ``There were all sorts of figures being bandied about,'' Wanger said. ``It all depends on who you talk to.'' Wanger said the museum's board of trustees last week formed a subcommittee to examine the museum's security measures and insurance policies. He said theft insurance would be discussed. Earlier this week, FBI agent Paul Cavanagh said investigators continued to receive tips but weren't close to a break in the case. The stolen works were considered too well known to be sold on the open market. The outlook for their recovery is better than average because they are so familiar, but overall chances remain slim, investigators said. ``About 80 percent of stolen art is never recovered,'' said Robert Spiel, a private security consultant in Chicago and former FBI agent specializing in art theft.

DOC.HEAD: Atwater to Undergo Chemotherapy for Brain Tumor
DOC.TEXT: Republican Party chairman Lee Atwater will receive chemotherapy in addition to the radiation treatments being used to combat a brain tumor. In a statement issued Wednesday through Republican Party headquarters, Dr. Paul L. Kornblith described the tumor as ``aggressive and dangerous,'' but said Atwater was fortunate that it was ``quite small and has been detected early in its development.'' Kornblith led a team of physicians at Montefiore Medical Center in New York City who implanted radioactive isotopes into the tumor Tuesday in an effort to kill it. ``Mr. Atwater has done so well following this procedure that he will be able to be discharged from the hospital in a few days and may well be able to return to work in some degree within a couple of weeks,'' said Kornblith. ``Although it is obvious that this tumor is aggressive and dangerous, Mr. Atwater has many factors working in his favor,'' said Kornblith, who cited the fact the party chairman is only 39 and is in excellent health. The tumor, called an astrocytoma, was described as ``the most common primary brain tumor.'' ``It does not spread to other parts of the body, but can cause damage to brain tissue by pressure and by invasion,'' said Kornblith. A brain tumor undergoing unrestrained growth would cause pressure within the closed skull. This pressure would kill normal brain cells, thus bringing eventual death by destroying vital functions. Brain tumors can also spread by extension into other parts of the central nervous system and displace normal cells. During such a process, there would be a progressive loss of function as normal brain cells associated with memory, thought, muscle control and even heartbeat and respiration are lost. In addition to the radiation treatment now underway, the doctor said that ``to assure that any tumor cells peripheral to the main lesion are destroyed, he will be receiving chemotherapy as well.'' He said Atwater would receive chemotherapy orally once every six weeks and it would not limit his activities or functions. Atwater's wife, Sally, who is expecting their third child within days, accompanied him to New York. Mary Matalin, GOP chief of staff, said Atwater received numerous visitors Wednesday, but they had to stand behind a lead shield because of radioactivity. Kornblith said Atwater ``will need to be followed closely and may need to have additional therapies in the future. For the present we are delighted with his progress.''

DOC.HEAD: Broker Describes `Threat' by Marcos Associate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Trial resumes 10 a.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: A real estate broker testified that an associate of Imelda Marcos threatened him and his family after a 1981 news report revealed that the Philippine first lady was secretly negotiating for a posh New York apartment. Thomas Bryan, the prosecution's first witness in the fraud trial of Mrs. Marcos and Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, said Wednesday that Gliceria Tantoco did not accuse him of leaking the story to the New York Post. But she ``expressed regret that the information had become public and said I should fear for my life and my family,'' Bryan testified in federal court. Under questioning by Mrs. Marcos' attorney, Gerald Spence, Bryan said that he was upset by the threat but that it did not deter him from further contacts with Mrs. Marcos. Bryan, of Fairfax, Va., who was then a $27,000-a-year broker for the Sotheby's auction house, told how Mrs. Marcos and Mrs. Tantoco tried to secretly purchase the Park Avenue apartment and contents put up for sale by Leslie Samuels, a philanthropist and art collector. The so-called ``Samuels Collection'' was among the purchases that Mrs. Marcos and her husband, former Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos, made with $160 million embezzled from their homeland, prosecutors have charged. Earlier Wednesday, a lawyer for Khashoggi, once described as the richest man in the world, portrayed his client as a naive businessman who committed ``foolish acts.'' ``If this wasn't such a serious charge, this would be funny,'' James Linn said. ``It is not the sinister thing that the government makes it out'' to be. Khashoggi, 54, is charged with mail fraud and obstruction for allegedly helping the Marcoses hide their ownership in New York real estate after the Philippine government won a U.S. court order in 1986 to prohibit any further transactions involving the properties. Linn admitted that Khashoggi had signed a fake document involving the buildings, but said this was intended to help a Marcos associate, not to defraud anyone. Khashoggi was trying to head off moves by creditors to foreclose on the properties, Linn said. In explaining the Saudi financier's frequent contacts with Marcos, Linn also said Khashoggi ``fell for'' a bizarre scheme in which Marcos offered him 10 percent of a shipload of gold if he could find a ``safe port'' for the vessel, preferably in the Arab world. Marcos, who died in exile in September, supposedly intended to use the gold to finance a counter-revolution in case the Philippines fell to the communists. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is charged with racketeering, conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction. She could receive up to 50 years in prison and $1 million in fines. Khashoggi faces up to 10 years in prison and $500,000 in fines. Mrs. Tantoco, a longtime friend of Mrs. Marcos and owner of the Rustans department store in Manila, and her husband, Bienvenido Sr., former Philippines ambassador to the Vatican, also were indicted but are fugitives. Bryan testified that Mrs. Marcos offered to buy both the Samuels apartment and its contents for nearly $14 million. A corporation conrolled by Mrs. Marcos acquired the artworks for $6 million, but she lost the apartment when the cooperative's board of directors rejected Mrs. Tantoco as the purchaser.

DOC.HEAD: `Hate Crimes' Statistics Bill Wins Final Approval
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is expected to sign newly approved legislation under which the government will gather data on ``hate crimes'' motivated by race, religion, sexual orientation or ethnic roots. ``This bill is a necessary first step toward combating hate crimes in a systematic and comprehensive manner,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. The House debated the bill Tuesday night and then on Wednesday voted 402-18 to agree to minor changes made by the Senate and send it to Bush for his signature. The administration has supported the bill, which would require the Justice Department to keep data on crimes related to race religion, sexual orientation or ethnic groups. It is supported by a variety of civil rights, ethnic and police groups. The House had already approved the bill and this time consented to the changes made when the Senate passed the measure on Feb. 8. Under the measure, the government would count the crimes of murder, non-negligent manslaughter, forcible rape, aggravated assault, simple assault, intimidation, arson and destruction, damage or vandalism of property. A number of supporters said such a count is needed because of a rising tide of ``hate crimes'' on the part of neo-Nazi ``skinheads'' and other such groups, although there is no certainty that such offenses are increasing. The Justice Department reported in May 1988 that an accurate count is not available. But it said: ``These types of offenses are far more serious than comparable crimes that do not involve prejudice because they are intended to intimidate an entire group.'' Estimates of the cost of gathering the information have varied, but the Justice Department said it would have no trouble making hate crimes part of the FBI's annually published uniform crime reports. The only House member to rise in opposition to the bill was Rep. William Dannemeyer, R-Calif., who portrayed it as a concession to the gay community. ``Believe me, whether we like to accept it or not, there are persons outside this chamber who are crowing: namely, in the homosexual community,'' he told the House. Dannemeyer said homosexuals ``now have something in the law which they have sought diligently for the last 20 years, whereby they will equate homosexuality on a par with the traditional coverage of the 1964 Civil Rights Act.''

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Deliberations Enter Fourth Day
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Deliberations resume 9:45 a.m. EDT; will be led
DOC.TEXT: The jury deliberating John Poindexter's guilt or innocence on charges he covered up Oliver North's military assistance to the Contras and the U.S. role in a shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran is giving little hint of its progress. There were no notes from the jury Wednesday, the third day of deliberations. The panel of eight women and four men was resuming its work today. Poindexter is accused of conspiracy, two counts of obstructing Congress and two counts of making false statements. Each charge carries a maximum five-year prison term and a $250,000 fine. Poindexter's lawyers expressed concern over jury instructions about 5,000 messages that Poindexter erased from his computer system. Defense lawyers asked U.S. District Judge Harold Greene to clarify the instructions, but the judge refused. The destruction of the messages is included in an obstruction charge alleging the former national security adviser tried to conceal from Congress the U.S. role in the Hawk shipment. The jurors asked for copies of the messages, which were saved on a backup tape at the White House. Greene rejected the jurors' request Tuesday, saying the notes hadn't been introduced as evidence at the trial and so ``you can't have them.'' Defense attorneys said Wednesday the judge may have misled the jury into believing that it couldn't consider other evidence about the messages. Among that evidence is a stipulation _ a statement agreed to by prosecutors and the defense _ that none of the messages were from 1985, when the Hawk missiles were shipped to Iran. The inference that could be drawn is that Poindexter did not cover up evidence about the Hawk shipment by erasing the messages. The Hawk shipment is the focus of the indictment against Poindexter. Ten days after 18 missiles were delivered by a CIA proprietary airline to Iran, Poindexter had President Reagan sign a document which ratified the shipment. The document depicted U.S. involvement in an arrangement to trade arms for hostages. Poindexter tore up the document on Nov. 21, 1986, hours after telling Congress he hadn't found out about the Hawks shipment until two months after it occurred. He destroyed the document eight days after Reagan said in a nationally televised address that ``we did not ... trade weapons ... for hostages.'' The prosecution contends that Poindexter lied to Congress to hide the existence of the presidential document.

DOC.HEAD: House Seeks Reaffirmed Commitment to Lithuania
With PM-US-Soviet Bjt
LaserPhoto WX10
DOC.TEXT: The House is urging President Bush to reaffirm his commitment to Lithuania, while a group of senators warns that the issue could threaten the future of U.S.-Soviet relations. The House voted 416-3 Wednesday for a resolution calling on Bush to reaffirm his commitment to an independent Lithuania and take steps as soon as possible to ``normalize diplomatic relations'' between Washington and the Baltic republic. The resolution, which has no force of law, is similar to one passed earlier by the Senate. Thirty-one senators, in a letter to Bush, said the president should take a more aggressive stand in support of Lithuania, which is attempting to secede from the Soviet Union. ``Now is the time to inform the Soviet leadership what specific actions our government may take in response to the further use of armed force in Lithuania,'' the letter said. The congressional appeals in support of an independent Lithuania came as Secretary of State James A. Baker III raised the issue with visiting Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. Shevardnadze said afterward, ``I have no doubt we will be able to find a solution to that situation, that we will find a wise and fair solution.'' Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., met late Wednesday with Shevardnadze at the Soviet embassy. The senators had requested the meeting, and Shevardnadze said, ``I appreciate your visiting our embassy.'' Asked how his session with Baker went, Shevardnadze said the two discussed issues ``in a constructive language.'' He declined to say whether the United States had made any demands about Lithuania. The Senate letter to Bush warned that if the Soviets continue to thwart the Lithuanians' drive for self-determination and don't engage in good-faith negotiations, the issue will have ``serious negative implications for U.S.-Soviet relations.'' The letter was originated by Sens. Bill Armstrong, R-Colo., and Donald Riegle, D-Mich. Eighteen Republicans and 13 Democrats signed it. Sen. Claiborne Pell, D-R.I., chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, did not sign the letter, but accused the Soviets of turning a ``deaf ear'' on the Lithuanians. He said the tense situation could reverse progress in the U.S.-Soviet relationship. Opposing the House resolution were Reps. David Obey, D-Wis., David Nagle, D-Iowa, and George Crockett, D-Mich. Rep. Lee Hamilton, D-Ind., said the State Department did not want the resolution passed, but he said it was necessary. Meantime, Sen. Alfonse D'Amato, R-N.Y., flew to Poland intending to cross the border into Lithuania for a firsthand look at the Baltic state. ``I want to see if (Soviet President Mikhail) Gorbachev is indeed a man of peace who adheres to the principles of open borders and freedom of travel,'' D'Amato said before he left.
