Lithuania's decision last month to declare itself an independent republic has put Bush in a difficult diplomatic spot. Some people, including Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., who recently met with Gorbachev, have told the president that taking too hard a line with Gorbachev could topple him, and that would not be in Washington's best interest. But Sen. Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo., said that if Gorbachev is too weak to withstand the challenge of Lithuania, the United States shouldn't stake any future claim on him.

DOC.HEAD: USDA Economists Say Freer Farm Trade Equals Pricier Chicken
DOC.TEXT: If negotiations to liberalize world agricultural trade are successful, look for fried chicken dinners to cost a bit more. It wouldn't be much of an increase, and it's all pretty much of a guess, anyway, says the Agriculture Department. But when economists and computers get together, that's the way it goes. The department's Economic Research Service assumed in its study that ``a hypothetical one-time 10 percent increase in corn prices'' would occur if ongoing talks under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade succeed in liberalizing trade. Two computer models were set up to see what would happen to the broiler industries in the United States and Canada if producers had to pay more for corn used to feed their birds. Prices would go up in both countries, at the producer level and at retail counters, the study concluded. One of the report's authors, economist Greg Gajewski, said Wednesday in a telephone interview that the study did not forecast that a GATT settlement would boost corn prices by 10 percent. ``It's not based on past historical data,'' he said. ``And that's because there's never been such a movement to free trade.'' Gajewski said an earlier study last year showed that if the GATT talks resulted in liberalized trade, the U.S. market prices for corn _ the prices that broiler producers would pay _ could rise between 1 percent and 11 percent, a huge range of possibilities. For purposes of the study, a 10 percent increase was used. Gajewski said the main point of the study is that U.S. broiler prices would be much more responsive than Canadian prices to an increase in corn costs. In the United States _ Broiler prices at the producer level would start climbing immediately, with the monthly maximum increase of 3.9 percent occurring in the fifth month. However, prices would continue to rise at slower rates for an additional 27 months. Over the entire period, each percentage point in corn prices would lift producer broiler prices by an average of nearly 0.4 percent. At retail stores, broiler price increases would resemble those at the producer level, but the rise would be smaller. The peak monthly increase of 2.8 percent would occur in the fourth month. It would take an additional 26 months for the increases to end. In Canada _ Broiler price increases at the farm would be delayed a month but would then rise and build strength through the 15th month with a peak rise of 4.3 percent. Farm broiler prices would continue up at lesser rates for another seven months. On the retail level, Canadian broiler prices would begin increasing immediately, gaining strength through the 16th month, with a maximum monthly grain of 2.9 percent. The rise would continue more slowly for another six months. The study, described in the April issue of Agricultural Outlook magazine, showed that the Canadian broiler price increases would taper off eight to 10 months sooner than in the United States, which would have more volatile month-to-month responses. Some of the U.S.-Canada difference may be due to marketing structures, the report said. In Canada, provincial governments control broiler output through marketing quotas, and the federal government sets an import quota to help stabilize prices. Broiler production in the United States is largely unregulated, and the top 20 firms account for about 80 percent of the total output.

Some Mexican cattle are getting fast-track clearance by the Agriculture Department to enter designated U.S. feedlots because drought-shriveled pastures have been reduced to starvation levels. James W. Glosser, administrator of the department's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service, said Wednesday the agency's usual import regulations have been temporarily set aside so the cattle can be brought in. Normally, he said, imported animals and their herds of origin have to be tested and found free of cattle brucellosis and tuberculosis. The usual requirement is that imported animals must come from herds that have been tested for the diseases no more than three months before the date of U.S. entry. With the special waiver, the Mexican cattle will be able to enter approximately three months sooner. ``The drought-stricken pasture lands in parts of Mexico cannot support the cattle,'' Glosser said. ``By bringing the animals temporarily to U.S. quarantined feedlots under strict movement restrictions, we can avert starvation of the animals and still protect the health of U.S. livestock.'' Glosser said the cattle will be taken directly to quarantined feedlots in USDA-sealed trucks or rail cars. They will not be sold to any U.S. buyer and will return directly to Mexico from the feedlots. The animals will be kept apart from U.S. cattle while in the feedlots, which are mostly in Texas. There was no estimate of how many Mexican cattle may be imported under the special program, said agency spokeswoman Anita Brown.

The Corn Belt has been selected for a new Agriculture Department testing program designed to protect ground water from contamination by fertilizers and pesticides. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Wednesday the research is scheduled to begin this summer. It will be undertaken on farmland overlying aquifers in nine states: Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, South Dakota, Ohio and Wisconsin. The research is part of a government-wide water quality initiative provided in the Bush administration's budget requests, he said. Spending for all of the Agriculture Department's water quality activities this year is budgeted at $158 million, compared with $112.7 million last year, Yeutter said. The administration's request for the fiscal 1991 year that will begin Oct. 1 is for $207 million. Yeutter said about $3.7 million of this year's funds has been targeted for the Corn Belt projects.

DOC.HEAD: 6 Million Requests for Filing Extension Expected
DOC.TEXT: As many as 6 million couples and individuals are expected to ask the Internal Revenue Service for an extra four months to file their tax returns this year. The filing deadline for most Americans is April 16, but the IRS will grant an extension automatically if a taxpayer unable to file by that date mails in a Form 4868 instead. However, IRS spokesman Steve Pyrek noted Wednesday, the form must be accompanied by a check for estimated taxes owed. It's not a good idea to underestimate your taxes when you seek an extension of filing time, says accountant Saul Epstein of the Philadelphia office of Ernst & Young. ``If you underestimate, you'll have to pay interest on the unpaid amount, and if it (the unpaid amount) is more than 10 percent of your total liability, there will be an additional failure-to-pay penalty.'' In some cases, Pyrek said, an underestimate also can result in a failure-to-file penalty. The IRS expects 111 million returns to be filed this year, although not all taxpayers will meet either the regular deadline or an extended deadline. Through March 30, 60.1 million returns had been received, 2 million more than during the same period a year ago. The IRS has processed 51.5 million of those returns, 3.5 million more than at this time last year. Nearly 79 percent of returns are qualifying for refunds; 40.5 million this year for $34.4 billion. At this time last year, about 78 percent, or 37.3 million, received refunds, which totaled $30.5 billion. Nearly 3.8 million taxpayers have filed electronic returns, 270 percent above the same period of 1989 and considerably more than the IRS had forecast for the entire year. Electronic returns, filed for a fee by IRS-authorized companies, are transmitted to the IRS via telephone line. They eliminate a considerable amount of paperwork and errors and allow the agency to promise refunds in two or three weeks. Taxpayers who file paper returns between now and the deadline can expect refunds in about eight weeks. A person who filed a return at least eight weeks ago may call a computerized IRS telephone number to find out why any refund has not been received. Toll-free numbers for that service are listed in the back of the tax-form instructions. To use this service you will need to know the first Social Security number on your return, your filing status and the exact amount of the refund. The IRS said more than 10 million people have made such calls this year. While most Americans must file by midnight April 16, residents of New England and most counties of New York have an extra day. That is because April 16 is Patriot's Day, a holiday, in Massachusetts. The IRS service center to which those people file their returns is in Andover, Mass. A person whose home and main workplace are outside the United States and Puerto Rico on April 16 automatically has until June 15 to file.

DOC.HEAD: Antimissile Budget Includes Money for Unneeded Satellite
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration's 1991 budget request for Star Wars research includes development money for an $8 billion satellite that won't be part of the antimissile defense, the project director says. Air Force Lt. Gen. George L. Monahan, manager of the Strategic Defense Initiative, the official name of the antimissile program, said Wednesday that although the satellite ``no longer is an essential element'' of Star Wars, the spending is justified. Bush's 1991 budget includes $265 million to start full-scale development of the satellite. The proposed total budget for SDI in the next fiscal year is $4.5 billion. The satellite, called a boost-phase surveillance and tracking system, is important in its own right because it could replace the less capable existing satellites that provide early warning of ballistic missile launches, Monahan said. The general told the House Armed Services research and development subcommittee that $1 billion already has been spent on research for the new satellite. The total cost of developing and producing it would be about $8 billion. ``I think it's very wise to go forward with it,'' Monahan said. He added that his office is studying ways that the satellite and radar network that would be part of a Star Wars system might be restructured to save money. He told reporters afterward that he could not provide an estimate of potential savings. Many members of Congress are looking for ways of reducing Star Wars spending. Last year, the administration's funding request was cut by about $1 billion, to $3.6 billion, and support for the project appears to have eroded further as a result of historic political shifts in the East bloc since last fall. Rep. William Dickinson, R-Ala., said congressional supporters of SDI such as himself need more help from the White House if further cuts are to be avoided. ``The president's going to have to get involved,'' he said. ``He's going to have to draw a line in the sand.'' Under the Star Wars concept as recently as 1988, the boost-phase surveillance and tracking system would communicate with sensor satellites to help guide space-based weapons toward the ballistic missile targets during flight. Now, scientists have proposed building a new kind of space-based weapon, known as Brilliant Pebbles. Each weapon, or pebble, would have its own in-house tracking and sensor capability, so that it would not need to interact with separate satellites to ``see'' and home in on missiles. Monahan gave the House panel an upbeat assessment of technical progress in research on Brilliant Pebbles, which are kinetic, or non-explosive, weapons that would be permanently based in space and could be activated from a ground command center. The kinetic warhead would destroy its target simply by crashing into it. No tests of Brilliant Pebbles have been conducted, but Monahan said he believed that by late 1993 or early 1994 the Pentagon should be ready to begin full-scale development of the weapons.

DOC.HEAD: North American Cocaine Smuggling Routes Shifting To Europe
DOC.TEXT: Latin American cocaine barons stymied by Washington's war on drugs are relying more and more on European ports to get their merchandise to U.S. streets, police say. Moreover, officials say, all across Europe police seizures of cocaine have at least doubled in the past few years and the drug is challenging heroin as the narcotic of choice on the continent. Last month, the National Police Intelligence Service published figures that show cocaine seizures in the Netherlands to have risen dramatically over the past three years. Dutch police confiscated 7,700 pounds of cocaine in the first three months of this year alone _ more than double the 3,120 pounds seized in all of last year and almost three times the 1,130 pounds in 1988. Commissioner Peter Broeders of the intelligence service's Crime Information Division said drug kingpins from Colombia and other Latin American countries ``are searching for routes that are less vulnerable than the direct routes to the United States.'' Broeders, in a radio interview Tuesday upon his return from a two-week trip visiting drug enforcement agencies in the United States, attributed the shift to President Bush's $7.9 billion war on drugs. ``The tough way in which Americans are handling the drug trade from South America is forcing the drug barons to shift their supply lines, and they're doing it through Europe,'' Broeders said. Crime Information Division spokesman Peter de Waard said in an interview Wednesday that another factor in the growing drug seizures is that ``the North American market is so saturated Latin American drug barons can't sell there any more.'' Instead, they are turning to Europe, he said. On Feb. 28, police in the Dutch North Sea port of Ijmuiden seized 6,600 pounds of cocaine concealed in a shipment of frozen fruit juice. Although the cocaine's origin remains unclear, police said four of the eight suspects they arrested claimed to be Colombian nationals. Broeders said much of the cocaine smuggled into this country is believed to be going through Rotterdam, packed mostly in freight containers. Rotterdam is the biggest port in the world and Broeders said it is physically impossible to open and inspect all of the 2.5 million containers shipped through the port every year. Police seizures of cocaine across Europe reached 15,435 pounds in 1989. French police hauled in 2,000 pounds in 1989, up 58 percent from the previous year. Less than 220 pounds were seized in that country in 1982. In Great Britain, seizures more than quadrupled between 1986 and 1989, with police confiscating 935 pounds last year. Although heroin seems to be Europe's most widely used drug, cocaine is taking over. ``1987 was the last year that Dutch police hauled in more heroin than cocaine,'' De Waard said. Both drugs are relatively easy to obtain in the Netherlands, which rarely prosecutes drug abusers but concentrates on capturing traffickers. ``Drug-related crime is increasing dramatically in Holland. We are seeing more shootouts between drug gangs,'' De Waard said. Until recently, drug turf battles were relatively rare in the Netherlands, which also has experienced almost none of the violent crime associated with crack, the highly addictive cocaine derivative.

DOC.HEAD: Former President Under Treatment for Heart Ailment
DOC.TEXT: Former President Richard M. Nixon is sidelined with a heart problem but his doctor says it can be taken care of with medication and a little rest. The former president, 77, was diagnosed on Wednesday as suffering from a benign supra ventricular heart rhythm disturbance. Dr. Jeffrey Borer, a cardiologist at Cornell University Medical College in New York City, said that means signals that cause the heart to beat were being generated abnormally. ``That's not a big problem and not hard to deal with,'' Borer said. ``In these circumstances we generally control the situation with medication because the heart is beating faster than it ought to and therefore is less efficient.'' Nixon was not hospitalized. His aide, John Taylor, said the former president will recuperate at his home in Saddle River, N.J. and that he is expected to resume his full schedule when the condition is brought under control. ``He's been feeling run down since a speech he made in Miami on March 27,'' Taylor said. ``On the down side is that the president is not going to be able to go on his daily morning walk.'' Nixon will postpone an appearance on April 12 before the World Affairs Council of Boston. The former president recently published his eighth book, ``In the Arena,'' a memoir.

DOC.HEAD: Embargoed for release 10:45 a.m. EDT; time set by source
Two GOP Senators Call for Cutback of B-2, ATF Programs
DOC.TEXT: Two Republican members of the Senate Armed Services Committee today called on President Bush to limit production of the B-2 bomber and delay the Advanced Tactical Fighter as part of additional cuts in defense spending. ``We believe that the United States can meet its defense requirements with budget levels lower than those proposed by the administration,'' said Sens. William Cohen of Maine and John McCain of Arizona. Although caution is appropriate in crafting a defense policy, using the possible return of the Cold War as an excuse for delaying changes in the military is unwarranted, the lawmakers said. ``If we do not reorient our defense planning to the genuine needs of the future, we will squander a unique opportunity and waste declining defense resources,'' Cohen and McCain said in releasing their recommendations. The administration has proposed about a 2 percent reduction in defense spending in each of the next five years, but twice that amount is realistic, the GOP senators said. By their calculations, the current defense budget of about $300 billion would be reduced by about $50 billion. Cohen and McCain did not address spending on every major defense program, but did make several recommendations on big-ticket items that have come under attack in Congress. Among the proposals were limiting production of the B-2 stealth bomber while concentrating on equipping B-52 and B-1 bombers with advanced cruise missiles. Current plans call for building 132 of the radar-evading aircraft by 1996 at a cost of more than $70 billion, but Air Force Secretary Donald Rice said Tuesday that the administration is weighing alternatives to that proposal. A bipartisan group of lawmakers on Wednesday released a Congressional Budget Office report that concluded that scaling back production of the B-2 will force up the cost of a single plane to more than $1 billion. ``It confirms my very worst fears that if you stretch out the B-2 program it simply adds billions of dollars to its costs,'' said Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., a cosponsor of legislation that would stop procurement of the aircraft at the 15 planes now in production. In their recommendations, Cohen and McCain said it was unlikely that Congress would approve spending for two land-based, nuclear missiles _ the multiple-warhead, rail-garrison MX and the single-warhead Midgetman. ``While rail-basing for the MX is less expensive and probably can be deployed sooner than the small ICBM, we should actively pursue reciprocal restrictions with the Soviet Union to cut back ICBMs _ including the rail-based MX _ in favor of single-warhead missiles such as the small ICBM,'' the lawmakers said. Cohen and McCain also proposed gearing the Strategic Defense Initiative to defend against threats from nations other than the Soviet Union. The nearly $4 billion approved for the antimissile program this year should be considered the upper limit for all future budgets, they said. Regarding the nation's naval forces, the senators proposed a reduction in the overall number of ships and deferral of the Navy's version of the Advanced Tactical Fighter. In addition, many of the Air Force's modernization programs, including their Advanced Tactical Fighter, are ``inappropriate or exceed the requirements for regional contingencies, which can be met with currently deployed systems with upgrades as necessary.''

DOC.HEAD: Bill Could Allow AIDS Victims to Immigrate, Backers Say
DOC.TEXT: Legislation giving federal health officials authority to decide which diseases can be used to keep foreigners out of the country would allow AIDS to be removed as a barrier to immigration, sponsors say. The measure was introduced Wednesday by Rep. J. Roy Rowland, D-Ga., on behalf of the National Commission on AIDS. The commission, whose members were appointed by Congress and the White House, has urged elimination of the entry restriction for people with AIDS and infection with the human immunodeficiency virus, or HIV, which causes AIDS. ``There is no rationale for it,'' said Dr. June Osborn, commission chairwoman, noting that numerous international groups have criticized the restriction. ``The U.S. is being looked at with such astonished horror.'' The federal Centers for Disease Control recently recommended that AIDS be stricken from the list. That recommendation is under review by Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, but officials say his department lacks authority to remove it. The entry restriction has prompted dozens of international organizations and agencies to boycott the Sixth International Conference on AIDS in San Francisco in June. France and Switzerland also have said they won't send official delegations to the meeting. The Bush administration's position on the bill was unclear. Sources, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said Wednesday night that a decision had not been reached on whether to support, oppose or take no position on the bill. Under a law passed in 1987 by Congress, HIV infection was added to the list of contagious diseases for which foreigners can be barred from entering the country. Administration officials have said they could not eliminate the restriction because it was imposed by Congress. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., a cosponsor of the bill, said the legislation would make ``absolutely clear'' that HHS has authority to add or remove diseases from the list, based on public health considerations. ``We should let health officials make the health decisions,'' Waxman said. ``That is what we did before 1987 and that is what we should continue to do.''

DOC.HEAD: In City That Barred AIDS Boy, an Outpouring of Sympathy
DOC.TEXT: Ryan White's hospitalization has softened hearts in the town that fought to bar him from its schools, where residents recall the painful episode as an unavoidable chapter in the nation's education on AIDS. ``I don't think that anybody in Kokomo feels good about what happened,'' said Art Peirce, a longtime resident. He described Kokomo's reaction to White as one of fear. ``If it hadn't happened here it would have happened somewhere else. It allowed the nation to focus on the problem so some good did come out of it. ``That fear has certainly been modified through education and experience.'' White, 18, remained in critical condition today at Riley Hospital for Children in Indianapolis with an AIDS-related respiratory infection complicated by hemophilia. Doctors said Wednesday his condition had stabilized. White is on a life-support system that helps him breathe. He has been unconscious and heavily sedated so the life-support system would function more efficiently. His physician, Dr. Martin B. Kleiman, said patients as ill as White had recovered. ``He's holding on. His status deteriorated in the first day or two and then reached a plateau. Any patient who is critical must stabilize before he can recover and Ryan has stabilized,'' Kleiman said. Singer Elton John spent a second full day with the family at the hospital, making jokes and playing tapes of his music, family spokeswoman Carrie Van Dyke said. Calls from celebrities flooded the hospital switchboard, including one from Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., whose Senate committee on Wednesday approved a bill to spend an additional $600 million a year for two years to combat AIDS. ``This one's for you, Ryan,'' Kennedy said in a telephone conversation with White's mother, Jeannie. Residents of Kokomo said they hoped White would recover. Some reflected on the community's unsuccessful legal battle in 1985 to keep White out of school. Attorney David Rosselot, who represented the school district that tried to keep Ryan out after it learned he had contracted AIDS from tainted blood products, said he would not take a similar case today. ``I think there is a lot more knowledge available and that, coupled with the fact that the law has changed about how an AIDS child should be treated in the school system, would lead me to say no,'' he said. Rosselot defended the community's reaction. ``The only thing that was guaranteed to parents .. at that time was it was communicable and it's fatal,'' he said. ``There is nobody in this community that at some point in time hasn't said, `But for the grace of God, that could have been me or my children or my relatives,' and there is nothing except concern and sympathy for him.''

DOC.HEAD: FAA: Pan Am Security Flawed for Eight Months After Bombing
DOC.TEXT: Pan American World Airways' security at Frankfurt airport in West Germany remained dangerously flawed for more than eight months after the bombing of Flight 103, federal aviation officials say. ``All passengers flying out of Frankfurt by Pan Am are at great risk,'' said a June 1989 internal Federal Aviation Administration memo read Wednesday at a hearing by the Presidential Commission on Aviation Security and Terrorism. Investigators believe terrorists smuggled a bomb in baggage aboard Flight 103 in Frankfurt before the flight switched planes in London and blew up over Lockerbie, Scotland, killing all 259 people aboard and 11 on the ground. The seven-member commission, which has been looking into the Dec. 21, 1988 bombing, will send President Bush recommendations next month for avoiding future aviation terrorist attacks and improving government response if they occur. Top federal aviation officials testified Wednesday that the Frankfurt airport is now ``a model station.'' But they acknowledged that serious security problems persisted there until a team of airline and FAA officials flew to the airport last September and corrected the flaws. Commission Chairwoman Ann McLaughlin sharply criticized the FAA for allowing the problems with Pan Am at Frankfurt to go uncorrected for so long. ``I've never seen anything like this in my life,'' Ms. McLaughlin told FAA Administrator James Busey. Busey, who took office last July, said part of the problem was that his agency was leaderless for part of the time after the bombing. Ms. McLaughlin said that was an ``absolutely unacceptable'' excuse for failures at the airport. The FAA is responsible for overseeing security of U.S. airlines in the United States and abroad. Pan Am Chairman Thomas Plaskett told the commission that the airline followed inspection procedures approved by the FAA. The airline is contesting $630,000 in fines levied by the agency last September for security lapses related to Flight 103 and five other European flights around the same time. Alleged Pan Am security lapses in 1989 have not been the subject of FAA fines, however. FAA Associate Administrator Monte Belger and security chief Ray Salazar testified that security problems were found at Frankfurt during inspections in January, May, June and August 1989. ``If I was frustrated in June, I hit the ceiling in August,'' said Belger, who received reports of the Frankfurt inspections. He said problems included failure to properly check personnel who serviced Pan Am planes at the airport, failure to secure planes overnight and problems with ground personnel at the airport. Salazar denied sworn statements by Pan Am officials that he gave them permission before December 1988 to X-ray checked luggage as an alternative to requirements that it be matched to passengers at Frankfurt. Salazar said that procedure was a violation of FAA rules, although Pan Am was never fined for it. He said FAA lawyers advised against including the charge when fines were levied. Paul Hudson, head of one of two organizations formed by relatives of Flight 103 victims, said the FAA and Pan Am disclosures at Wednesday's hearing confirmed family members' deepest concerns about airline security. ``My daughter had no chance at all,'' Hudson said in an interview outside the hearing room after Pan Am's Plaskett testified that luggage at Frankfurt was not hand-searched and that no special procedures were used following threats against Pan Am flights to the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Urges South African President to Lift State of Emergency
LaserPhoto W9
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is urging the white minority government of South Africa and the black opposition to bend and work out a peaceful resolution of their differences. Bush called on President F.W. de Klerk on Wednesday to lift the state of emergency. And he urged blacks to renounce violence, especially against one another. ``We stand ready to support this fragile process in any way we can,'' Bush said in a speech marking the anniversary of the 1968 assassination of civil rights leader Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. ``There must be an end to the tragic cycle of violence, a task that demands great courage and resolve from all South African leaders, black and white,'' he said in a speech to the 20th anniversary dinner of the Joint Center for Political Studies. Violent repression by the government has failed, along with violence by the opponents of Pretoria's apartheid system of racial separation, Bush said. ``Most tragically, the senseless violence perpetrated by blacks against blacks has become a major impediment to rapid progress toward a negotiated settlement. All sides should follow the spirit of Martin Luther King Jr. and renounce violence,'' he said. He said de Klerk should lift the state of emergency and free all political prisoners, two of the conditions that would be required before the United States could lift economic sanctions against Pretoria. He praised de Klerk for freeing black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela and for lifting the ban on dissident political parties. He has invited de Klerk and Mandela to meet with him separately at the White House. Bush said he was encouraged ``by signs that all sides share a growing commitment'' toward negotiations to resolve the South African turmoil. He said U.S. businesses that operate in South Africa also ``must work for change.'' ``And we will make clear our strong conviction that multi-party democracy based on a vigorous free enterprise system represents the best model for any successful society,'' he said. Bush also took the occasion to talk about the legacy of Abraham Lincoln, whose Emancipation Proclamation freed the slaves. He predicted that ``the day will come, and it is not far off, when the legacy of Lincoln will finally be fulfilled at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue _ when a black man or woman will sit in the Oval Office.'' ``When that day comes, the most remarkable thing about it will be how naturally it occurs.'' Virginia Gov. L. Douglas Wilder, who was guest of honor at the dinner, predicted that victories by black politicians like himself and New York Mayor David Dinkins will become more common. ``We are not oddities. We are not aberrations. ... We are merely the extensions of those dreams,'' Wilder said in a reference to King's historic ``I have a dream'' speech.

DOC.HEAD: Former White House Aide Confirmed for Justice Post
DOC.TEXT: Former White House adviser Robert Sweet has won Senate confirmation to head the nation's $70 million juvenile justice program. Despite opposition from several interest groups, approval came Wednesday on a voice vote. Sweet, 52, figured prominently in turmoil at the Education Department eight years ago, and Sen. John F. Kerry, D-Mass., had pushed for defeat of the nomination. Kerry said in a letter to members of the Senate Judiciary Committee that Sweet's ``approach to juvenile justice is naive at best and in any case not congruent with the statutory requirements of the position to which he has been nominated.'' By law, the administrator of the Office of Juvenile Justice and Delinquency Prevention in the Justice Department must have experience in juvenile justice. Critics of the nomination _ ranging from the Washington-based liberal group People for the American Way to the National Parent-Teacher Association _ complained that he lacked the required background. Sweet replied that his experience in education fulfills the requirement. He is a former high school teacher and textbook salesman and served as an Education Department official and White House education adviser in the Reagan administration. He also was at one time the head of the New Hampshire affiliate of the Moral Majority. Some of the opposition stems from infighting at the Education Department. Former Education Secretary Terrel Bell was critical of Sweet in his memoirs, ``The Thirteenth Man.''

DOC.HEAD: Colleagues Remember Sarah Vaughan as a Singer's Singer
With PM-Remembering Sassy
LaserPhoto NY16
DOC.TEXT: Sarah Vaughan was remembered by the music industry and friends as a singer's singer whose powerful range and mastery of scat-style jazz earned her acclaim as ``The Divine One'' _ or simply ``Sassy.'' Vaughan died of lung cancer Tuesday night at her home in the Hidden Hills area of the San Fernando Valley. She was 66. ``Sarah Vaughan was a complete vocalist and musician,'' Frank Sinatra said Wednesday. ``She was an instrument and she had an incredible sense of humor. Put those attributes together and we're talking about one of the finest vocalists in the history of pop music.'' Some of her most memorable songs were ``Broken-Hearted Melody,'' ``Send in the Clowns,'' ``Misty'' and ``If You Could See Me Now.'' ``Now that she's gone, there's no one to measure great singers with,'' said entertainer and jazz buff Bill Cosby. ``Sarah was like a sister to me and I loved her very much,'' said Sammy Davis Jr., who is convalescing at his Beverly Hills home from a recurrence of throat cancer. Mayor Tom Bradley ordered flags at all city buildings lowered to half-staff through Friday. The last time flags were lowered for the death of a celebrity was a year ago, when Lucille Ball died. A moment of silence was observed Wednesday at the Apollo Theater in New York's Harlem, where Vaughan was discovered a half-century ago. Vaughan's style was formed by her early association with be-bop. She sang with Billy Eckstine, Charlie Parker and Dizzy Gillespie in the Earl Hines and Eckstine bands in the 1940s. ``There will never be another one like Sarah Vaughan,'' Gillespie said Wednesday. Her nicknames were ``The Divine One,'' ``The Divine Sarah'' and ``Sassy.'' Often, after she introduced the musicians accompanying her, she coyly introduced herself as ``Della Reese.'' Her deep, sultry voice and dramatic colorings distinguished her as the finest jazz singer of the '40s. ``Sarah Vaughan was among the most powerful, influential and soulful voices of all time, a perfectionist with an astonishing vocal range and a genius for conveying emotion through her music,'' said Quincy Jones, who first worked with Vaughan in 1957 as the arranger on ``Misty.'' ``Vocally, she was a giant singer,'' said Mel Torme. ``Had Sarah decided to go another way she would have been a great legit singer. She could have done opera, for instance.'' Colleagues also praised Vaughan's mastery of scat singing, improvising, swinging and phrasing. But she never thought of herself as a specialist. ```Why do they always call me a jazz singer? I'm just a singer,' Sarah would always say,'' said her manager and friend, Harold Levy. ``She was a singer's singer. The greatest.'' Pianist George Shearing, who worked with Vaughan in the late 1940s, said she was the first vocalist he performed with after emigrating to the United States from Great Britain. ``She's going to be very much missed in terms of being the exemplary voice in the pop field. She was the best contralto in pop,'' he said. ``She would hold on to great, big long notes without vibrato.'' Born in Newark, N.J., Vaughan studied piano from age 7 and was a church choir member and organist by 12. Her father, a carpenter, played guitar and her mother sang in the choir. In 1942, she accepted a dare _ trumpeter-trombonist Jabbo Smith claimed it was his idea _ and sang ``Body and Soul'' at an Apollo Theater amateur contest. ``I put her on and, I'll tell you, she was absolutely astounding,'' the Apollo's Ralph Cooper said Wednesday. ``She was the most unusual thing to take the stage at the Apollo.'' She made her debut with the Hines band at the Apollo in 1943, went with Eckstine a year later when he formed his own band, then sang with John Kirby's group. By 1946 she had established herself as a solo artist. Vaughan won Esquire's new star award in 1947 and the Down Beat poll as best female jazz vocalist from 1947 through 1952. She won a Grammy for best female vocal jazz performance for ``Gershwin, Live!'' in 1982. Other songs she recorded included ``You're Blase,'' ``I Cover the Waterfront,'' ``Body and Soul,'' ``Tenderly,'' ``Everything I Have Is Yours,'' ``I'll Remember April,'' ``Easy Living,'' ``I Remember Clifford,'' ``Here's That Rainy Day'' and ``Don't Blame Me.'' She recorded ``Lover Man'' in 1945 with Gillespie and Parker and ``Perdido'' with Count Basie's band. Her first husband was trumpeter George Treadwell. She also was married to professional football player Clyde Atkins, Las Vegas restaurateur Marshall Fisher and trumpeter Waymon Reed. Vaughan is survived by her 87-year-old mother, Ada, and her daughter, actress Paris Vaughan. Funeral arrangements were incomplete.

DOC.HEAD: Novello Says Localities Must Decide on AIDS Education for Teens
DOC.TEXT: Surgeon General Antonia Novello says adolescents need to be taught about AIDS, but that communities should decide for themselves how to do that. ``What is good for Iowa might not be good for New York,'' she said Wednesday during a meeting with reporters. ``You always have to take into consideration ... the state where they live, what is the morality of that particular community and what is the incidence (of AIDS) in that community.'' She said that while some parents object to AIDS education because they feel their children are not at risk, ``at least some education has to be going on.'' ``You ... at least have (to have) the data out there,'' she said, ``but you have to make sure it's done with sensitivity. ``And in the cases in which monogamy and abstention doesn't work, then the adolescent should know that the condom, in the absence of a vaccine, might be the most common available form of prevention.'' Novello said an educational AIDS brochure discussing condom use, a project begun more than two years ago at the Department of Health and Human Services, will be released soon. Critics had charged that conservatives in the department were trying to derail the publication because it discussed condoms.
DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Merge Wall Street, LaSalle Street Watchdogs
DOC.TEXT: Proposed legislation to end the turf battle between the federal agencies that oversee the stock markets and the futures exchanges would combine them into a single Markets and Trading Commission. A bill to merge the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission was introduced Wednesday, but even supporters concede it faces rough going. Meanwhile the chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the SEC, proposed a bill to curb abuses in the low cost, high risk ``penny stock'' market. The CFTC, which regulates the futures exchanges and the SEC, which oversees the securities industry, have been squabbling over which agency has authority to regulate so-called ``hybrid'' financial products with elements of both a security and a futures contract. The new agency would be phased in over a two-year period and one division would still deal exclusively with physical commodities such as metals and oil as well as farm products like wheat, pork bellies and soybeans. Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., who cosponsored the bill with Rep. Dennis E. Eckart, D-Ohio, said the legislation does not seek ``to create a super SEC or a super CFTC. It is not a takeover of one agency by the other.'' The penny stock reform bill by Rep. Edward Markey, D-Mass., would require that all penny stocks be traded through an automated quotation system.
DOC.HEAD: Poll: Cholesterol Levels Go Unchecked in Many At Risk for Heart
DOC.TEXT: Disease

Many Americans at risk for heart disease and heart attack have not had their cholesterol tested, according to a new survey. The Gallup Organization survey released Wednesday by Merck, Sharp & Dohme, a pharmaceutical company, found that 96 percent of those with a family history of heart disease agreed they should have their cholesterol tested, but 42 percent said they had never done so. Among those without a family history of the disease, half said they have had their cholesterol level tested and half said they had not. High levels of cholesterol in the blood is one of the risk factors for heart disease, as is a family history of the disease, which is the leading cause of death in the United States. Smoking is also believed to be a factor, and the survey found that 30 percent of all the men and women with a family history of heart disease are smokers, compared with 28 percent in the group without such a history. The survey found that many with heart disease in their family have taken steps in the last year or two to cut down on cholesterol in their diets. Seventy-seven percent said they read labels for fat and cholesterol content, 88 percent said they are cooking more low-fat meals, 83 percent said they were eating low-fat dairy products and 86 percent said they were eating more fish and chicken. Those with no family history of heart disease were slightly less likely to be taking such steps _ 71 percent are reading labels, 81 percent are cooking more low-fat meals, 78 percent are eating low-fat dairy products and 83 percent are eating more fish and chicken, according to the survey.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Coalition Would Be First Left-Dominated Cabinet Since 1977
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres says he has put together a parliamentary majority for a new government, opening the way for Israel's first left-dominated governing coalition in 13 years. Peres on Wednesday night asked Parliament to convene and approve his new Cabinet on Sunday, saying a major goal of his coalition would be pursuing U.S.-backed efforts to open Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. He refused to say how he had broken a 60-60 deadlock with the right-wing Likud bloc of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir in the 120-member legislature. ``I have a majority, it doesn't matter which one. ... I have a majority and hope to enlarge it,'' Peres said on Israel radio. The Labor Party leader justified the mystery by saying it was necessary to crucial negotiations still under way to bring other small parties into the government. Likud leaders immediately cast doubt on Peres' claim of a majority, meaning the war of nerves in which Likud tries to block the Labor government will go on until a vote in Parliament. ``We can paint the opposite picture,'' said Transport Minister Moshe Katsav, insisting Likud still had 60 votes. Katsav said Peres was ``exerting psychological pressure'' to win over wavering legislators. Shamir issued a statement read on television that said only, ``We did what we could to maintain this government. It was a walk on the brink.'' Israeli media said the deciding vote was likely to be a defector from Likud or a religious party. Peres also hinted at this possibility by defending the idea in a state television interview. ``The question is, defector from what?'' Peres asked.``Why for example should a minister who is for peace be ready to accept the breakdown of the peace process. Is this not defection?'' Peres, 66, a former prime minister and strong proponent of a conciliatory stance toward Palestinians, was asked to form a government after Shamir's Likud-Labor coalition fell in a Parliament vote of no confidence March 15. The government crisis was triggered by a dispute over U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III's proposals for a Palestinian-Israeli meeting in Cairo, Egypt. Peres was in favor and forced a showdown with Shamir, who was reluctant to accept Baker's ideas. Since then, Labor has tried to bring together conservative religious parties and its left-wing allies for a coalition government. Peres' fortunes turned Tuesday when the ultra-Orthodox Agudat Israel signed a coalition agreement, bringing others to the negotiating table. Radio reports said the likely defector was Avraham Sharir, a member of a disgruntled faction within Likud. Sharir, 58 a former tourism and justice minister, could not be reached for comment. Katsav insisted Sharir was not deserting Likud. Israeli newspapers said Sharir has been promised the tourism portfolio in a Peres government. Labor officials refused to comment on the reports about Sharir. The party's secretary general, Micha Harish, suggested Labor had succeeded in luring other former Likud backers, saying: ``We are talking about more than 61'' who support Labor. Other potential swing votes could come from five lawmakers in the ultra-Orthodox Torah Guardians party, which helped Peres topple Shamir's Cabinet. The wheeling and dealing among so many tiny parties also carried an additional complication, as three left-wing parties threatened in anger to refrain from joining the coalition. Amnon Rubinstein of Shinui said the notion of switching back and forth between political blocs was ``a problem that goes to the very core of Israeli democracy.'' In defense Peres noted past examples of political defections, including the late war hero Moshe Dayan, who switched from Labor to Likud in 1977 to become foreign minister in former Premier Menachem Begin's first Cabinet. ``I propose that we each examine ourselves and not preach morality to others,'' Peres said. He said his government would be ``based on two principles, the status quo on religion and secondly the continuation of the peace process.'' But Peres could have trouble making bold peace moves with only a narrow majority in Parliament that includes some conservative lawmakers. His Labor Party dominated Israeli government from the state's founding in 1948 until Begin's victory in May 1977. The party has shared power with Likud following two indecisive elections since 1984.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Down In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 28,249.06, down 193.88 points, or 0.68 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Kansas City School Desegregation Plan Still Being Debated
DOC.TEXT: Despite a federal appeals court's desegregation order, lawyers for schools in Kansas City and its suburbs are uncertain where more integrated education will result. The order issued Monday instructs a federal judge to draw up a plan for transferring students from mostly black inner-city schools to the overwhelmingly white suburbs. It orders the state to pay transportation costs and tuition for the students. Individual schools' participation is voluntary. However, if they refuse there may be further litigation. ``It would be a voluntary plan,'' Reg Rowe, a Kansas City School District spokesman, said this week. ``However, the language is very firm in the order concerning participation.'' Attorneys for the Independence, Lee's Summit and North Kansas City schools said their suburban districts may not be quick to participate. ``If a district will take a thousand kids in the fall, that would be satisfactory for all concerned,'' said Norman Humphrey, a lawyer representing the Independence district. ``But I don't know if any district can or would do that.'' A three-judge panel of the 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in St. Louis told U.S. District Judge Russell G. Clark on Monday to draw up and implement the transfer program in line with a desegregation plan he ordered in 1985. The order said the state would have to pay for up to 1,200 transfer students in the 1990-91 school year; 2,400 in 1991-92; 3,600 in 1992-93; 4,800 in 1993-94, and 6,000 in 1994-95. ``I think 1,200 is a very realistic number for the first year and another 1,200 for the next year,'' said Arthur A. Benson II, an attorney for the plaintiffs in the case, who include the Kansas City school district. ``We have surveyed the black kids, and they want to volunteer.'' Humphrey said the plan might enjoy the limited success of the Kansas City District's magnet school program, also formulated under the 1985 desegregation plan. The magnet schools have drawn about 720 mostly white students from suburban or private schools to the inner-city schools. The Kansas City district's enrollment of 34,500 students is about 68 percent black. In its ruling, the appeals panel also reinstated a discrimination lawsuit against the Independence, Lee's Summit and North Kansas City districts. The suit was filed in 1988 by Kansas City black students who applied unsuccessfully to the three suburban districts. The lawsuit had been dismissed by a federal court. The appeals ruling put the discrimination case on hold to give the suburban schools time to accept the voluntary desegregation plan.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crash Being Investigated as Murder-Suicide
DOC.TEXT: The fiery crash of a small plane may have been caused by a struggle for control of the aircraft by a passenger dying of brain cancer and bent on suicide, investigators say. ``We thought we were investigating an air accident, and it has turned into something else,'' police spokesman David Grimm said Wednesday. The twin-engine plane plowed into a Boulder neighborhood Sunday, setting a house and garages ablaze and killing pilot James Wilford ``Bill'' Layne, 56, of Aurora and his passenger, Gordon Larry Hood, 45, of Atlanta, authorities said. Grimm said out-of-state acquaintances of Hood's said he had discussed plans to commit suicide by way of a fiery plane crash over Colorado because of terminal cancer. Witnesses on Sunday said the airplane was flying erratically, then flipped on its side and dove to the ground. It was as if a struggle was going on for control of the craft, authorities said. ``Was the pilot overpowered, was the pilot shot, was the pilot stabbed? We just don't know,'' said Grimm. ``As far as we can tell right now, the pilot just happens to be the unfortunate person who got hired that day.'' Ruth Loftus of Indianapolis said in a telephone interview Wednesday that she met Hood in Indianapolis in December and that he told her about a diagnosis of brain cancer and his plans to hire a Colorado plane and ``hit the pilot over the head.'' Loftus, 32, said Hood told her the cancer was ``eating him alive'' but would not be detectable because his body would be burned badly in the crash, enabling his friends to collect insurance benefits. ``I tried to talk him out of it. He said he felt sorry for me. He wanted to leave me as one of his beneficiaries,'' she said. She said tried to call the FBI and other law enforcement agencies ``but nobody would do anything. I gave up on it.'' Investigators said one clue that remains to be checked is the mail Hood apparently dropped off in Granby an hour before the crash. Granby cab driver Pete Gallo said he drove Hood around Granby for a while Sunday, including three stops by the post office, each time to mail a package or letter. Layne worked for Intensive Air Care, a Denver charter company, and had taken Hood to Granby, about 80 miles from Denver. The crash happened on the return trip. Autopsies showed Hood and Layne died of injuries suffered in the crash and not from other causes, said Tom Faure, chief medical investigator of the Boulder County coroner's office. Police returned to the crash site Wednesday to look for a weapon or other evidence that would support the murder-suicide theory. The Cessna 421 Golden Eagle streaked over the foothills west of Boulder, slammed into a tree and destroyed a vacant house, four garages and six parked cars, engulfing a large section of the block in flames.

DOC.HEAD: Iowa House Endorses Statewide Foam Ban
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and 4th graf to CLARIFY that Senate is considered more conservative.
DOC.TEXT: The Iowa House has approved what would be the nation's first statewide ban on food packaging made of polystyrene foam. But the measure was given little chance of success in the Senate. The ban was adopted 49-46 Wednesday night. It was contained in a bill to earmark $400 million in state lottery profits for environmental programs over the next decade. Polystyrene foam containers are widely used in the fast-food industry in cups and hamburger boxes. Environmentalists say the tough, flexible plastic takes generations to break down, is not easily recyclable, takes up too much landfill space and causes litter. Environmentalist legislators were jubilant over Wednesday's vote, but some conceded the provision may eventually face rejection. The Senate is considered more conservative than the House. ``It's not going to cause major disruption in our lives and we still can't work up the courage to do it,'' said Rep. Darrell Hanson. The ban would become effective in 1991. Violations would be punishable by a $100 fine. ``It's one of the most environmentally conscious things the General Assembly has done in decades,'' said Rep. Dennis Black. More than a dozen cities and counties nationwide have enacted bans on polystyrene foam, a tough, flexible plastic. Also, a bipartisan group of congressmen has asked for the removal of such foam cups from congressional restaurants.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Bill Would Make Unsigned Editorials Illegal
DOC.TEXT: A state House subcommittee approved a bill that would make it illegal for newspapers to publish unsigned editorials and force editorial writers to disclose financial holdings. A subcommittee of the House Judiciary Committee approved the measure 4-3 Wednesday, sending it to the full committee. The bill would require editorial board members to file financial disclosure forms or face fines of up to $5,000. It would make it a misdemeanor for a newspaper to run an editorial not signed by the author. The measure clearly infringes on the First Amendment and would never stand up in court, said Barry Richard, attorney for the Florida Press Association. One of the 32 co-sponsors of the bill, Democrat Elvin Martinez, said the measure's intent was to shed more light on newspapers' role as opinion leaders. ``The real molder of public opinion is the press,'' Martinez said. ``They can take you and beat you and do anything to you, and they're immune. I think people have a right to know if their views are jaundiced by some financial interest.''

DOC.HEAD: Lava Destroys Two Homes, Threatens Others
DOC.TEXT: Creeping like a fiery dragon, lava from Kilauea Volcano vaporized two houses and oozed toward four others in a rural subdivision on Hawaii Island. Loren Lewisohn watched helplessly Wednesday as the lava advanced and ignited the house he had built in the Kalapana Gardens subdivision. ``If the lava takes away the house, nothing can take away the experience of building it,'' said Lewisohn, whose insurance made it easier to be philosophical. ``I'm gaining a lot of respect for the awesome force of nature.'' Lava crept around a support pillar and set fire to the latticework. An hour later, all that was left of Lewisohn's house were the twisted remains of its corrugated metal roof. Earlier, a house owned by John and Ruth Duff erupted in flames after the molten rock surged beneath the raised structure. Kilauea Volcano has wiped out 78 residences since it began erupting more than seven years ago. The wooden houses incinerated Wednesday were the first Kalapana-area homes destroyed by lava since December 1986. Residents of 59 homes have been ordered to evacuate. Civil defense officials said all residents of the 125-home coastal community should be ready to pack their belongings within 72 hours. The flow had entered the community on Tuesday from the west, passing within several feet of two homes. Those homes remained standing Wednesday when the lava flowed into a gulley and toward the Duff home. Ed Torrison, whose house was just 20 feet from molten rock that was filling his back yard, expected to be next. ``It's a shame to watch this sort of thing happen, but it's kind of exciting, too,'' he said. Torrison said he was going to watch the flow from his balcony until the last possible minute and take pictures as his home burned. ``I've got 12 shots left,'' he said. The flow on the west side of the subdivision had split into two fingers Tuesday night before merging Wednesday to move down a street along the subdivison's western edge. ``It's just finding low spots,'' said Reggie Okamura, a geologist with the Hawaiian Volcano Observatory. ``It's like water. It will seek the quickest route downhill.'' Okamura said the flow probably would meander in the subdivision because it is a relatively level area. Kim said the flow had no direct path toward the ocean without cutting through populated areas.

DOC.HEAD: Beleauguered Peruvians Elect New President Sunday, Famous Novelist Favored
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: Peruvians vote Sunday for the next president of their violence-torn, inflation-wracked nation. Opinion polls say their choice will be Mario Vargas Llosa, one of the world's most celebrated novelists. Apparently, the only question is whether Vargas Llosa, 54, will fall short of a majority. That would force him into a runoff against one of the eight other candidates trailing far behind him in opinion polls. Regardless of whether a second round is necessary, most pollsters predict the novelist will be writing the next five years of Peruvian history as successor to populist President Alan Garcia. Vargas Llosa addressed at least 50,000 screaming supporters in front of Lima's Palace of Justice on Wednesday night, promising to ``do away with inflation and bring peace to the country.'' He said he would ``make Peru again a country of high culture and civilization.'' The latest published surveys show Vargas Llosa, candidate of the center-right Democratic Front coalition, with support of around 45 percent _ more than twice that of his nearest competitor, Luis Alva Castro of the left-of-center governing Aprista party. The constitution requires a runoff between the top two vote-getters if no candidate gets more than 50 percent. Nearly 10 million people are registered to vote. Voting is obligatory and violators face stiff penalties, including fines equivalent to nearly half the minimum wage of $45 a month. In addition to voting for president and two vice presidents, Peruvians will fill all of the Senate's 60 seats and Congress' 180 seats. But violence has marred the campaign and threatens to overshadow the election. Guerrillas of the Maoist-inspired Shining Path have mounted a bombing and assassination campaign to try to thwart it and say they will launch election-day ``armed strikes.'' More than 18,000 people have been killed as a result of the 10-year-old insurgency, the governnment says. Half the country is under emergency rule because of the leftist rebels. Vargas Llosa entered politics reluctantly in 1987 after leading a huge public rally against Garcia's plan to nationalize Peru's banks. He advocates free-market policies and foreign investment, and promises to apply economic shock treatment to Peru's ravaged economy. Backed by a well-heeled publicity campaign, Vargas Llosa enjoyed 55 percent support as recently as mid-February. But his lead has slipped largely due to late surges by Alva Castro and independent candidate Alberto Fujimori. Fujimori, former rector of the National University of Agriculture, was virtually unknown until two months ago. Pollsters say his appeal stems from voters' mistrust of professional politicians. People planning to vote for Fujimori say they distrust the traditional conservative parties supporting Vargas Llosa, a political independent. Alva Castro, 48, became finance minister when Garcia was elected in 1985. He stuck with Garcia through the glory years of 1985-1987, when Peru had the fastest-growing economy in South America. But the free-spending policies that paid for the boom also brought the bust. Alva Castro quit, say critics, when he realized the economy was running out of steam. Last year, Peru suffered nearly 3,000 percent inflation. In the last two years the economy has shrunk by 20 percent. ``The decline in my party's government weighs on the campaign,'' Alva Castro admitted recently. But he promised ``to correct the errors that have been committed.'' Alva Castro's campaign has benefitted from an eleventh-hour spending spree by the Garcia government, which has used up much of the treasury's remaining reserves to subsidize basic services and hold down inflation. Many believe the 40-year-old Garcia wants to position himself for the 1995 race, and is trying to boost his image before he goes out. He is prohibited by the constitution from seeking a consecutive term. If necessary, a runoff would probably be held in early June. The exact date depends on how soon results are known from the first round. Ballots trickled in for weeks following the 1985 election due to poor communications with much of the country's interior. Official results were not released for nearly two months. A major concern for the Democratic Front coalition is whether it can win a majority in the Congress. Without it, Vargas Llosa will have difficulty imposing the economic austeriy measures he says are necessary. The latest surveys show 10 percent of voters remain undecided, and the candidates have been campaigning hard to win those votes in the final days. One day recently, Vargas Llosa campaigned in a Lima slum, addressed two rallies in different cities in the Andes, then flew to Trujillo, 350 miles up the coast. Owing to constant threats by leftist guerrillas, the candidates often appear with little advance notice, flying in and out of provincial towns quickly so the rebels can't plan an attack. The tactic often leaves voters equally surprised. ``They come and they go,'' said shopkeeper Rosa Casa during a recent Vargas Llosa rally in Chincha, 125 miles southeast of Lima. ``They've all been here. But Chincha still doesn't have water. Chincha still doesn't have electricity. Nothing's going to change,'' said Ms. Casa. She said she had not decided which candidate would get her vote.

DOC.HEAD: Suspicious Fire Destroys Bus at Greyhound Garage
DOC.TEXT: A suspicious fire destroyed a bus in a Greyhound garage whose door had been welded shut, authorities said. The blaze came after the company and its striking drivers blamed each other for violence during the walkout. Greyhound Lines spokesman Kevin Fry said today a flare found on a bus in the service garage by federal Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms investigators apparently caused Wednesday night's blaze, which he characterized as arson. District Fire Chief Robert Dillon said the fire was ``of a suspicious nature.'' No one was injured in the blaze, which burned about 45 minutes. The fire was one of the most serious instances of damage during the monthlong strike by 6,300 drivers. ``We will continue to operate as we have in the past,'' Fry said. ``We will not give into acts of terrorism. We will just continue to operate. Period.'' When firemen tried to open the garage's large overhead door to get at the fire, they found it welded shut, said fire dispatcher Frank Fell. Firefighters had to cut through the metal door to the 300-by-150-foot brick garage, Dillon said. Fry said a padlock was missing from the door and the lights of several of the buses were on when firemen arrived. He said 13 Trailways buses were in the garage. Dallas-based Greyhound owns Trailways. Fry had no estimate of damage to the bus and garage. Earlier Wednesday, Greyhound Vice President P. Anthony Lannie called on the union to send officers to monitor pickets and withhold benefits from members who take part in violence. ``Certainly, mere pious assertions unsupported by visible signs of union condemnation of illegal conduct cannot serve to relieve the union of its legal and moral responsibility,'' Lannie said in a letter to the union. A union spokesman repeated its condemnation of the violence but criticized Greyhound for refusing to negotiate until a week passes without shots being fired at one of its buses or garages. ``There's no way, in my view, that either the company or the union can control these crazies,'' said union spokesman Nick Nichols. ``What they've done is turn this whole process ... over to some crazy on the road who likes to take potshots at buses,'' he said of Greyhound. Greyhound has reported 31 shootings, including 26 at buses, 70 bomb threats and more than 100 other incidents of violence since the strike began March 2. The union says about 60 pickets have been targets of violence. A striker in Redding, Calif., was crushed to death March 3 by a bus driven by a replacement. In an effort to recapture business in the key Northeast corridor, Greyhound on Wednesday offered free bus trips through Easter to passengers who don't reach their destination within 15 minutes of the scheduled arrival time. Passengers will get a coupon good for a free round trip on the same route. Meanwhile, a judge in New York City barred the company from hiring ``strikebreakers.'' Greyhound said it would appeal. Greyhound's drivers and about 3,000 of its office and maintenance workers walked out over wages and job security. The company has operated on a reduced schedule since, using replacements and union members who cross picket lines. Greyhound operates the only nationwide bus system.

DOC.HEAD: 1,000 Rally for Museum Running Mapplethorpe Exhibit
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 people rallied in support of a museum threatened with prosecution for running a photography exhibit deemed smut by the city's conservative lawmen. The Contemporary Arts Center is awaiting a court hearing Friday on the artistic merit of the photos by the late Robert Mapplethorpe, whose work last year led Congress to restrict arts funding. The private museum's supporters carried signs declaring the city ``Censornati'' at the rally Wednesday. Museum curator Jack Sawyer wore a ``Censorship is Obscene'' T-shirt over his suit. Police Chief Larry Whalen, claiming nine of the 175 photographs in the show are obscene, said authorities haven't decided whether to file charges against the center when the exhibit opens Friday. It is scheduled to run for six weeks. Opponents of the show, including an anti-pornography group, said the Arts Center would affront Cincinnati's moral standards by exhibiting the photos, which include some graphic depictions of homosexuality and sadomasochism, as well as nude children. After Whalen and Sheriff Simon Leis Jr. threatened to close the show, the Arts Center sued to get a jury verdict on whether the exhibition violates community standards. On Wednesday, the center's lawyers asked for a judgment without trial. They said the entire exhibit was constitutionally protected because it is legitimate art that already has been shown in Philadelphia, Washington and other cities. The Mapplethorpe pictures led Congress last year to limit federal support for the arts after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., labeled them obscene. Mapplethorpe died of AIDS a year ago. At the rally, Clyde Jeffries, a bartender and a member of Citizens Against Artistic Censorship, gathered signatures on a petition to the city government protesting police involvement in the case. ``It's not so much the exhibit. It's that we don't want a few select individuals in the city telling us what we can do,'' Jeffries said. ``This has gone on too long. It's embarrassing.'' Cincinnati authorities are among the strictest in the nation in enforcing anti-pornography codes. They have closed all of the city's adult bookstores and movie theaters. The Arts Center's director, Dennis Barrie, said the museum expects to sell more than 3,000 tickets for the first night of the exhibit.

DOC.HEAD: Rain, Snow Fall in Plains
DOC.TEXT: A cold front brought rain and snow to the Plains early today, after up to a foot of snow fell in parts of New York. Snow fell in central Montana, while rain dampened parts of Nebraska. Snow was forecast over parts of the middle Mississippi Valley. Temperatures dipped into the 30s in the Great Lakes region. On Sunday evening, Oklahoma, Kansas and Missouri received showers or thunderstorms. Snow fell in North Dakota and Minnesota. Rain fell in parts of New York today. Up to a foot of snow fell in the Finger Lakes region on Wednesday. In western New York, 4 inches of snow fell in Rochester. Elsewhere Wednesday evening, showers and thunderstorms were widely scattered over California, Wyoming and Colorado. Temperatures again warmed into the 70s in the Northwest, tying records for the date of 75 in Portland, Ore., and 70 in Pocatello, Idaho. The high temperature for the nation Wednesday was 89 at Presidio, Texas. Marie 33 cloudy; San Antonio 63 fair. _West: Albuquerque 54 partly cloudy; Anchorage 34 partly cloudy; Boise 45 fair; Casper 35 cloudy; Fairbanks 35 cloudy; Great Falls 31 snow; Honolulu 68 fair; Las Vegas 62 showery; Los Angeles 58 partly cloudy; Medford 53 cloudy; Pendleton 46 fair; Phoenix 68 fair; Portland, Ore. 53 fair; Reno 50 partly cloudy; Salt Lake City 50 partly cloudy; San Diego 61 cloudy; San Francisco 53 fair; Seattle 48 fair; Spokane 50 fair. _International: Calgary 27 fair; Montreal 39 drizzle; Ottawa 34 drizzle; Regina 23 fair; Toronto 36 windy; Winnipeg 18 fair.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``There is nobody in this community that at some point in time hasn't said, `But for the grace of God, that could have been me or my children or my relatives,' and there is nothing except concern and sympathy for him.'' _ Attorney David Rosselot, who represented the Kokomo, Ind., school district that tried to keep Ryan White out after it learned he had contracted AIDS from tainted blood products.

``While we say we comfort the afflicted and afflict the comfortable, we need to guard against looking at the world increasingly through the eyes of the comfortable.'' _ Loren Ghiglione, the president of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, addressing the society's 67th annual meeting.
``I'm gaining a lot of respect for the awesome force of nature.'' _ Loren Lewisohn, as he watched lava from Kilauea Volcano destroy his home on Hawaii Island.

DOC.HEAD: Tiananmen Square Closed Second Time, Blocking Protests
DOC.TEXT: Police cordoned off Tiananmen Square today, a holiday honoring the dead, in an apparent bid to block any attempt to mourn protesters killed in June when the military crushed the pro-democracy movement. On the nearly deserted 100-acre square, authorized groups of flag-waving schoolchildren joined soldiers for rites marking the annual holiday, Chingming. It was the second time in a week that police kept the general public off the square, the focal point of the student-led pro-democracy movement and the country's symbolic center of power. Police guards stood at 30-foot intervals around the perimeter, police vans and jeeps were parked at strategic points and dozens of police with walkie-talkies patrolled adjacent streets. Overseas dissidents had called on Beijing students to ``stroll'' through the square on Chingming in a silent memorial to the hundreds of people killed when troops stormed the city June 3-4 to drive thousands of pro-democracy students from Tiananmen. A similar appeal to walk through the square on Sunday was blocked when authorities closed it to the public, on that occasion for ceremonies to promote support for the Asian Games to be held in Beijing next fall. Beijing schools and factories warned young people to stay away from Tiananmen and advised them against wearing black armbands or the traditional white mourning flower on Chingming. The city also issued orders forbidding group memorial activities unless authorities granted permission. Some students said they wanted to go to Tiananmen, but others said they were fearful of potential repercussions and would stay away. On the square today, children wearing the yellow caps of the Young Pioneers, a youth group that gives ideological training, participated in ceremonies around the monument to revolutionary martyrs. Red banners on the monument called on people to honor the Chinese revolution and to ``raise our Chinese spirit.'' Multicolored flags around the square gave it a festive look, but police yelled at foreigners who tried to take photographs. Premier Li Peng, asked at a news conference Wednesday about tightened security around the square, said Tiananmen is the symbol of Beijing and China and that it was ``quite normal'' for police ``to take all necessary measures to preserve order'' there.

DOC.HEAD: Guerrillas Bomb Campaign Rally, Two Children Wounded
With PM-Peru-Election
DOC.TEXT: A bomb set by Shining Path guerrillas exploded during a presidential campaign rally in the northern coastal city of Trujillo, and two children were badly wounded, police said. Police also reported seven other bombings in the country, and two people were killed and 10 wounded in one incident. Authorities say the attacks were part of the Maoist-inspired guerrilla group's campaign to sabotage Sunday's general elections. Police said they arrested a woman after the blast Wednesday near the central plaza of Trujillo, 350 miles north of Lima. Luis Alva Castro, presidential candidate of the governing Aprista Party, was speaking at the rally and asked for calm after the explosion. Some minutes later, he resumed his speech to the large crowd gathered in the plaza. The injured children were 8 and 12 years old, police said. In Junin state, the army said it will extend a day-old curfew after Shining Path rebels blew up a bus in La Oroya, 95 miles east of Lima. Two passengers were killed and 10 wounded in the attack. Guerrillas also bombed the homes of two congressional candidates in Huancayo, 120 miles east of the capital, police said. No one was hurt in the blasts, which police said were aimed at the candidates of President Alan Garcia's center-left Aprista Party and the right-of-center Democratic Front coalition. In other attacks near Huancayo, rebels bombed a highway bridge and blew up a section of railway, police said. In Huaraz, in the Andes 190 miles north of Lima, the guerrillas bombed buildings housing the local offices of the national Food Board, police said. Two other bombs exploded simultaneously in the city but caused no damage. Police said the Shining Path had called an ``armed strike'' for this weekend in the towns along the eastern side of the Cordillera Blanca mountain range in Ancash province. The rebel group previously called ``armed strikes'' in the provinces of Junin and Ayacucho and in Lima in an attempt to sabotage the general elections. The term ``armed strike'' carries the threat of death for anyone who defies the call. The Shining Path launched its armed insurgency against Peru's elected governments in 1980. The government says more than 18,000 people have died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Parking Prima Donna Runs Up $171,746 Tab
DOC.TEXT: A woman who owes the city $171,746 in unpaid parking tickets has vanished without a trace after accumulating an average of 2{ parking tickets a day over a 38-month period, officials say. Records from the Parking Violations Bureau show that Silvia Matos racked up 2,800 tickets between Dec. 31, 1984, and Feb. 28, 1988. Despite intensive credit checks and efforts to track her down, collection agents have yet to pocket a penny from the elusive Ms. Matos, said PVB director Tom McEnery. ``It's a cold trail,'' he said. Matos, an apparent whiz at navigating Big Apple bureaucracy, eluded authorities by registering her car under 19 addresses and 36 license plates, the New York Post reported today. A 1988 law allows the state Department of Motor Vehicles to suspend the registration of anyone with 25 or more unanswered tickets.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Order Reunion of Brothers
DOC.TEXT: A judge has refused to order a reunion of two young brothers separated by their adoptive parents. Juvenile Court Judge Arthur N. Hamilton on Wednesday declined to order the parents to allow an 11-year-old returned to state custody last year to visit his 8-year-old brother, still with the adoptive parents. Hamilton instead transferred the request to the Circuit Court's chancery division, which he said was the more appropriate forum. Cook County Public Guardian Patrick Murphy had sued to let the boys see each other. He said they had been apart since the 11-year-old went to a group home just before Thanksgiving. The lawsuit also seeks $50,000 in damages for the older boy. The boys were adopted in 1984. The lawsuit says the parents, called Joseph and Pamela Doe, returned the older boy to state custody because he hadn't ``bonded'' well with them.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Don't Rule Out Agent Orange-Cancer Link
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 15th graf prv, ``About 11 xxx to delete reference to amount
DOC.TEXT: Government scientists, who a week ago announced that a study found no link between Agent Orange exposure and a rare form of cancer among Vietnam veterans, say the herbicide cannot be ruled out, either. The chief investigator for the Selected Cancers Study said Wednesday that the findings don't eliminate an Agent Orange connection. ``The study does not rule out that Agent Orange may cause cancer,'' Dr. Edward Brann of the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta told the House Veterans Affairs Committee. Asked about this afterward, Brann added: ``Agent Orange may cause cancer. We don't know from this study.'' In a summary of the study released last week, CDC said: ``We found no evidence that the increased risk of NHL (non-Hodgkin's lymphoma) might be related to exposure to Agent Orange in Vietnam.'' The summary noted the study's determination that sailors with the least exposure to Agent Orange were more prone than ground troops to get the disease, and that veterans from the region that included the area of highest use of the herbicide had a lower risk. ``These data, along with evidence from other studies regarding the likelihood of Vietnam veterans' exposure to Agent Orange, make it quite unlikely that the increased risk of NHL among Vietnam veterans results from exposure to herbicides,'' it added. Brann and CDC Director William L. Roper told lawmakers that the study must be seen in the light of other scientific research. Still, members of the panel questioned the reliability of the study in the 12-year-old debate over Agent Orange. Brann himself said he did not approve of one major question veterans were asked to determine whether they had been exposed to the herbicide, which was sprayed on jungle areas in Vietnam to deny cover to the enemy. Veterans were asked if they had been in defoliated areas.
