Interpretations of the CDC study by scientists, veterans organizations and the Department of Veterans Affairs have varied widely because the new report looked only obliquely at Agent Orange exposure. The original intent of the study was to look at Agent Orange and its relationship to various cancers on the assumption that 25 percent of Vietnam veterans were exposed to the herbicide. CDC later changed course, however, deciding that the ``results of several studies'' make the premise of 25 percent exposure ``unlikely.'' The study found a 50 percent higher risk of non-Hodgkin's lymphoma in all Vietnam veterans compared with the overall male population, but no significantly higher risk for five other cancers. The VA last week decided to award disability payments to those veterans as a result. Agent Orange were sprayed in Vietnam from 1965 to 1970, according to the VA. The herbicide has two active phenoxy ingredients, but the prime suspect is another ingredient, dioxin, with which it was contaminated. Dioxin is known to cause cancer in laboratory animals. More than 36,000 of the nation's 2.6 million Vietnam veterans have requested benefits based on claims they suffered diseases attributable to Agent Orange. Only three of those veterans have been granted disability payments _ for a skin condition known as chloracne. Roper said the Air Force's ``Ranch Hand'' study of the people who flew the Agent Orange spraying operations and handled the barrels of the herbicide puts the new study in the right perspective. He said the men in that study were known to have been exposed to dioxin, yet have not developed cancers. But Rep. Douglas Applegate, D-Ohio, said that study ignored the ground troops who ``ate, breathed, drank and sometimes slept in Agent Orange.''

DOC.HEAD: Hong Kong Reacts to Basic Law, Nationality Package
DOC.TEXT: Despite China's ratification of a new constitution for Hong Kong, the territory appeared more interested today in the unveiling of a proposal to allow 50,000 households to emigrate to Britain. The British government on Wednesday announced details of the plan, which paves the way for an estimated 225,000 Hong Kong Chinese living in its colony to be granted the right to live in Britain. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher has supported the plan by saying Britian has a ``solemn duty'' to the colony before it reverts to Chinese rule in 1997. But the proposal faces stiff opposition and possibly defeat in Parliament. Its unveiling grabbed more media attention in Hong Kong than the Chinese legislature's vote Wednesday to approve the Basic Law by which Beijing will govern the territory after the change in sovereignty. While the final draft of the Basic Law was reached several weeks ago, details of the nationality package were previously unknown. The intense interest in the emigration proposal also seems to indicate residents are increasingly looking to a future outside of the territory once it becomes part of Communist China. The respected Ming Pao Daily News ran the entire text of the emigration selection procedure on its front page, and some newspapers included tables that explained the point system under which passports would be alloted to people holding key positions in Hong Kong. The plan ``would go some way to alleviating Hong Kong's emigration problem by giving key people confidence to stay in Hong Kong,'' the Hong Kong government said in a statement. Officials estimate about 1,000 people emigrate each week, including many of the colony's best educated. The legislature's Special Working Group on Nationality issued a statement expressing disappointment over the limited scope of the package. But it also acknowledged that ``any measure designed to encourage people to remain in Hong Kong would go some way toward reducing the brain drain.'' It added that London had ``the moral responsibility to provide a safe and secure future for the entire population of Hong Kong.'' Several newspapers also commented on the Basic Law, which is designed to guarantee that the territory can maintain its capitalist system for 50 years and enjoy a ``high degree of autonomy'' after 1997. The constitution has been widely criticized for not being democratic enough and for an anti-subversion clause that is viewed as a means for Beijing to assert political control over the territory. ``Hong Kong people have not been that enthusiastic in the Basic Law from the very beginning. Its promulgation just marks the end of the drafting era,'' an editorital in the Chinese-language Hong Kong Economic Journal said. The Sing Po Daily News said in an editorial that it was ``barely acceptable.'' Political commentator Lo Chi-kin said the final promulgation of the law had little impact on the colony. ``The whole process of the drafting work ... reflected that the Chinese leaders were not prepared to give way to a general call for greater democracy here,'' he said. ``People here believe that it is futile to speak on the Basic Law as Beijing has the final say anyway.'' The colony's Legislature, which functions primarily as a debating forum on public issues, on Wednesday urged China to make the law more democratic. The new constitution provides for a 60-seat legislature in which one-half of the members would be directly elected by the year 2003. It also sets up a complicated voting system that gives appointed legislators power to veto controversial bills.

DOC.HEAD: Mom Persuades Baby Food Giant to Produce for One Customer
DOC.TEXT: A mother persuaded Gerber Products Co. to resume production of a line of baby formula for one customer _ her severely handicapped son. ``We feel (it) is morally and ethically correct'' to make the product for Raymond Dunn Jr., a retarded 15-year-old allergic to almost everything except Gerber's meat-based brown liquid formula, George Puvis, a Gerber vice president, said in Thursday's New York Post. Gerber also said it will provide the formula for free to the boy. Raymond was born with an abnormally small brain and weighs only 31 pounds. His mother, Carol Dunn of Yankee Lake, in the state's Catskills region, had campaigned for five years to assure the boy's food source. In 1984, Gerber announced it would stop making the formula because of reduced demand but sent Dunn its stockpile, which she said would have run out in June. After much pleading from Dunn, Gerber agreed to resume production.

DOC.HEAD: Coming Soon to a Theater Near You: The `Love You to Death' Couple
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, ``I Love ...' to fix `less' to `fewer.'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY9
DOC.TEXT: Hollywood loved the twisted tale of the Totos, that fun couple whose murderous marriage came to light in 1983. Boy meets girl; boy marries girl. Husband fools around; wife tries to kill him. Wife does time; husband takes her back. ``I Love You To Death,'' the film based on the Totos' tale, premieres today; a non-fiction book subtitled ``The True Story'' will be in bookstores soon; and Fran and Tony Toto, in their 25th year of marriage, are making the rounds of talk shows to be asked how can they still be together after no fewer than five botched attempts on Tony's life. A trip-wire at the top of the porch steps failed to trip him as he stepped out. A boy waiting in the bushes with a baseball bat ran off. A wire rigged to Tony's car's gasoline tank failed to spark an explosion. A gunshot to the head failed to kill him. A gunshot to the chest missed his heart; sleeping pills merely slowed his metabolism and helped him survive. The movie couple, Kevin Kline and Tracey Ullman, play the story for laughs, a black comedy with a happy ending. The story ``was amazing to me,'' said director Lawrence Kasdan, whose movies include ``Body Heat'' and ``The Big Chill.'' ``It made me laugh, and the way it ended touched me. The guy was so full of life that you couldn't kill him, and their love was so strong that you couldn't kill that.'' The truth is remarkably similar to the script, but with some crucial differences _ for instance, in real life there was no mother-in-law instigator. The happy ending is true. Last week, Fran Toto, 46, sat in her living room, bouncing her second grandson on her lap, watching a TV show about the movie and giggling at William Hurt and Keanu Reeves playing drug-addled amateur hit men. ``The way we can laugh about it now is so that we don't get crazy,'' she explained. The reality, she said, was ``very scary.'' In the same house, in 1983, Fran was talking to real-life amateur hit men about how to get rid of Tony's body. He had just been shot in the heart _ or so they thought until he walked into the room. ``What's going on?'' Tony asked the startled conspirators. That's what the cops wanted to know, too. Two days later police, tipped off about the strange goings-on at the house, went inside, hustled Tony off to the hospital and arrested Fran. She pleaded guilty to solicitation to commit murder and reckless endangerment and served four years in prison. Anthony Bruno, a young man who worked at the Totos' pizza shop, pleaded guilty and went to prison, as did druggie cousins Ronald and Donald Barlips. Tony spent 12 days in the hospital, then bailed out his wife. He had lived to forgive. ``I was the bad guy, I made a mistake,'' said Tony, 44, who says his adultery was astonishingly frequent. ``I did not deserve to get shot, of course. ``It was not my time to go. God gave me another chance to live. After 12 days, I walk _ miraculous, I walk. Nothing wrong with me, thank God. Now what do I do now? Walk away from my family and say forget about it? No, no, no, no. If I could bring my family back together, I'm gonna try. And now we're happy.'' For her part, Fran said, ``I don't even really think I really deep down wanted to kill him. It was something that just happened.'' ``The moral is to be faithful,'' said Tony, who still carries a .25-caliber slug in his skull. ``Don't cheat on your spouse, be honest with each other, and learn to communicate with each other.'' ``I think we'll save a lot of marriages.''

DOC.HEAD: Edward Carlson, Former United Airlines, Westin CEO, Dies At 78
DOC.TEXT: Edward Carlson, who worked his way from bellhop to the chairman of hotel and airline chain UAL Inc., has died of cancer at age 78. Carlson, who died Tuesday night in a Seattle hospital, was among Seattle's best-known civic boosters and was credited with the idea for the city's trademark Space Needle, built for the 1962 World's Fair. The idea came from a revolving hotel Carlson saw in Stuttgart, West Germany. He joined UAL Inc. in August 1970, when United Airlines merged with Western International Hotels, now Westin Hotels. Carlson had headed the hotel chain since 1960. He retired as UAL's chief executive officer in 1979 and as chairman in 1982. He retired altogether in 1983, after a year as chairman of the executive committee of UAL. Carlson was born in Tacoma on June 4, 1911, and moved with his divorced mother and sister to Seattle after completing grade school. He entered the hotel business in 1928, working part-time as a bellhop at the Benjamin Franklin Hotel in Seattle while studying at the University of Washington. In 1946 he became the assistant to the president of Western Hotels, then a regional hotel chain based in Seattle.

DOC.HEAD: Government Proposes Outlawing Capital Punishment
DOC.TEXT: The government said today that it would introduce legislation to outlaw capital punishment, which has not been carried out in Ireland since 1954. Abolishing the death penalty was an element of a coalition deal between the Fianna Fail Party and the small Progressive Democrats party that allowed Prime Minister Charles Haughey to form a government after elections last summer. Current Irish law provides for the death sentence for treason and for the murder of a member of the government, a diplomat, a foreign head of state, or a police or prison officer on duty. The proposed legislation would prescribe a mandatory sentence of 40 years for those offenses, with a possibility of release after 26 years and eight months. Attempted murder of a policeman or prison officer would carry a mandatory sentence of 20 years. The bill, published today, will be introduced in Parliament when it reconvenes April 25. It is expected to pass overwhelmingly. ``The government is satisfied that the death penalty should now be finally removed from the statute book and be replaced for treason and capital murder by a realistic custodial penalty which will reflect the particularly heinous and serious nature of these offences and act as a deterrent,'' said Justice Minister Ray Burke. The last person executed in Ireland was Michael Manning, who was hanged for the murder of a 65-year-old woman. Twelve policemen have been murdered on duty since 1970. Although some convicts in those cases were sentenced to death, their sentences were commuted to 40 years in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Milwaukee Alderman Holds Rally to Organize Black Militia
DOC.TEXT: A black alderman's proposal to create a new Black Panther organization drew an estimated 300 people to a public meeting, where uniformed men guarded doors and kept some white visitors from entering. Alderman Michael McGee carried a slingshot in a pistol holster at his waist as he told a cheering, predominantly black audience Wednesday night that he didn't want to have to use violence to get society to acknowledge the economic needs of the inner-city poor. The meeting, on the 22nd anniversary of the murder of Martin Luther King Jr., was the first held by McGee. Earlier this year he proposed assembling a militia, modeled and named after the Black Panthers, to enforce his demands for jobs for blacks. The Black Panthers was founded in Oakland, Calif., in the late 1960s as a radical self-help and self-defense organization. It spread to other cities before desintegrating because of arrests, violent deaths and manipulation by police and FBI agents. Mayor John O. Norquist has accused McGee of encouraging street violence and said he should resign from the Common Council if he continues to do so. A small group demonstrated outside the elementary school gymnasium during the meeting. McGee and several men at the meeting wore visored caps and dark-colored uniforms with yellow patches displaying roaring panthers on the shoulder. ``We are going to fight crime first,'' McGee said. People ``may not listen to the cops but they'll listen to us.'' ``This is the weapon I'll use,'' he said, pulling the slingshot from his holster. White people attempting to enter the gymnasium were questioned by door guards. A white Milwaukee Sentinel reporter was denied admission but black reporters from the Sentinel and The New York Times, and a white radio station reporter, were admitted. John J. Peterburs, public schools business manager, said McGee was allowed to use the gymnasium with the understanding it would be open to the public. Officials said McGee wouldn't be allowed the privilege a second time.

DOC.HEAD: Medical Experts Skeptical of Interferon Results in AIDS Patients
DOC.TEXT: Medical experts expressed skepticism about reports that a licensed drug alleviated AIDS patients' symptoms after it was prepared in a novel way. Researchers said data is too inconclusive to embrace the results reported on Wednesday by Dr. Joseph M. Cummins, head of the Amarillo Cell Culture Co. Inc. Cummins said that alpha interferon given to patients in a wafer form in small amounts ``has reduced the symptoms of a person suffering from AIDS.'' A veterinarian, Cummins said he began experiments with interferon to treat illnesses in cattle. He offered a pure form of the drug to Dr. Davy K. Koech, the director of the Kenyan Medical Research Institute in Nairobi, for use on AIDS patients. ``Dr. Koech was desperate enough to try something new,'' Cummins said Wednesday. ``And he is reporting positive results with every patient he has treated.'' In the current issue of Biotechnology Newswatch, Koech reported that within days of taking oral alpha interferon all of his 99 AIDS patients in the test group developed an appetite. Fever, diarrhea and fungal infections and other symptoms subsided, the report said. Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, head of the National Institutes of Allergy and Infectious Disease in Bethesda, Md., said Wednesday the results from Africa were ``astounding and very difficult to believe,'' but ``you have to keep an open mind.'' Dr. Sidney Wolfe, director of the Health Research Group in Washington, D.C., said there is not enough data on the tests to make an opinion. Cummins agreed that more tests need to be done. ``People don't have to believe it, but let's test it,'' he said. ``We need to see if it's a true and natural way to treat AIDS.'' Koech's research showed interferon led to a significant increase in the number of CD4 lymphocytes, the white blood cell destroyed by the HIV virus, which causes acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Alpha interferon has been scrutinized for its antiviral activity since its discovery more than 30 years ago. The U.S. Food and Drug Administration has approved alpha interferon to treat Kaposi's sarcoma, a cancer that occurs commonly among people with AIDS. But the drug has not generally been tested in pill form because of the belief it would be destroyed by stomach acid. Koech prepared the drug in wafer form so that small doses could be absorbed through the mouth. Cummins said a veterinarian called him last year seeking interferon ``to treat a big dog for leukemia.'' Cummins later learned the man had AIDS and was using the interferon to treat himself. The man agreed to talk to The Associated Press upon condition of anonymiity. The 47-year-old man said interferon was keeping him alive. ``I contracted AIDS along with three other people who split infected blood during a transfusion,'' he said Wednesday. ``They are both dead and I am still here.'' The man, who said he was diagnosed with AIDS three years ago, said the drug stimulated his appetite, boosted his low CD4 count and eradicated fever blisters. Dr. Jordan U. Gutterman, an interferon expert at the M.D. Anderson Center in Houston, said Wednesday that Cummins' use of interferon to treat animals with leukemia produced ``some intriguing results.'' ``We are going to start studies ourselves with interferon for cancer treatment,'' Gutterman said. ``More studies need to be done to provide confirmation for the results being reported.''

DOC.HEAD: Sikh Extremists Attack Mourners of Batala Bomb Victim
DOC.TEXT: Sikh extremists shot and killed three Punjab policemen who were returning from the funeral of a constable who died in a bombing that claimed at least 29 lives, United News of India said today. Six other policemen and several relatives of the constable were wounded in Wednesday night's attack near Tetherke in Punjab state's Batala district, the news agency said. At least 29 people, including the constable, were killed Tuesday when a bomb blamed on militant Sikh separatists exploded in Batala while Hindus were parading through a crowded vegetable market on a holiday that celebrates the birthday of a Hindu god. The death toll of 29 was given Wednesday by Punjab State Police Chief K.P.S. Gill, who said earlier police reports of 36 victims were incorrect. But Indian newspapers and news agencies today gave death tolls as high as 40. Gill said at least three more people were killed by Hindus who rioted after the bombing. Batala, a predominantly Hindu town, has been a frequent target of Sikh militants who want to establish a separate nation in Punjab, a prosperous northern farming state where they hold a slight majority. The industrial town of 120,000 people is 25 miles northeast of Amritsar, the center of the separatist movement and the site of the Golden Temple, the Sikh faith's holiest shrine. Gill said Tuesday's bombing probably was masterminded by Dharam Singh, a top leader of Babbar Khalsa, the strongest and oldest of the Sikh radical groups. He said Singh was behind at least 10 other bombings in the Batala area in recent months. Sikh extremists, whose violent campaign for a separate homeland started in 1982, have killed more than 540 people in Punjab so far this year, authorities say. Nationwide, Sikhs account for 2 percent of the population. Hindus form 82 percent of India's 880 million people. Militants among the Sikhs, whose faith is rooted in both Hinduism and Islam, say Hindus discriminate against them culturally and politically.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Embassy Fires 200 Lebanese Employees
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Embassy has fired 200 of its remaining 350 Lebanese employees _ effective next month, a newspaper reported today. ``It is my unfortunate duty to inform you that the embassy will no longer require your service effective May, 5, 1990,'' said a statement signed by the Beirut embassy's administrative counselor, Harold T. Burgess. The photocopied notice was reproduced by the newspaper Ad-Diyar. The statement said the staff was cut ``to reduce the cost of embassy operations.'' ``It is the firm intention of the United States government to return its American staff, when conditions permit, to the level that existed prior to Sept. 6, 1989,'' the statement said. On that day, Ambassador John McCarthy and his remaining American staff were evacuated from Lebanon after hundreds of angry Christians demonstrated near the embassy against Washington's policy in Lebanon. The statement said all fired employees will receive their final salaries and severance pay in accordance with their contract with the embassy. In the event the embassy resumes full operations, ``employees with records of loyal service and demonstrated skills will be given strong preference for rehiring,'' it said.

DOC.HEAD: State Changes Policy to Settle Lawsuit With Gay Foster Parents
DOC.TEXT: The state has agreed to change its policy on foster children placement to settle a lawsuit filed by a homosexual couple who contended that the policy was discriminatory. The new policy proposal makes parenting experience, not marital status, the key factor in placement decisions, state Human Servics Secretary Philip Johnston said Wednesday. ``This agreement is a victory for children, because it will serve their best interests,'' Johnston said. The lawsuit was filed in Suffolk Superior Court in 1986 by Donald Babets and David Jean, a homosexual couple from Boston who had two young brothers taken away by state officials. The men claimed the state's policy irrationally and arbitrarily presumed that a traditional family setting of a husband and wife was the best placement for every foster child. The policy change makes parenting experience the key factor in placement decisions. It also says sexual orientation, marital status, race, sex, religion, economic status, education and ethnic background can all be weighed in a social worker's decision. The policy will continue to encourage social workers to look first to placing a child with relatives. About 23 percent of the 8,455 children placed in foster care are currently placed with relatives. Anthony Doniger, an attorney who represented Babets and Jean through the Civil Liberties Union of Massachusetts, said he was pleased. ``The changes that the government has agreed to make in this policy now returns the system to what it was before this whole controversy was created,'' he said. The policy under dispute called for trying to place foster children in a traditional setting of a married couple with parenting experience. Couples without parenting experience or a single person with experience were given second priority. The third and final group included individuals without parenting experience.

DOC.HEAD: Eleven Deaths Blamed on Unusual Form of Strep Bacteria
DOC.TEXT: State health officials say the deaths of 11 Denver-area residents are now being blamed on a rare, virulent form of strep related to bacteria that cause strep throat. The connection between strep and the 11th death was recorded Wednesday as health officials planned more studies on the unusual strep, including a determination of who might be at risk of contracting it. Anyone with strep symptoms should see a doctor to prevent the infection from progressing to a severe form of the disease, state and federal health investigators said. Common strep symptoms are a sore throat, swollen glands and fever. The severe form of strep is characterized by a sudden onset of a very high fever, chills, shock and low blood pressure. There also may be skin or muscle infections and pneumonia, the investigators said. Usually strep bacteria cause sore throats or skin infections. The severe form, known as group A streptococcus bacteremia, gets past the body's primary defenses and enters the bloodstream. Strep can be treated with penicillin. Much of the severe strep information collected by the Centers for Disease Control has come from Denver, said Dr. Ben Schwartz, an epidemiologist in the CDC's respiratory disease branch in Atlanta. In addition to Colorado, investigations also are being conducted in parts of Alabama, Arizona, California, Maryland and Ohio, where severe strep clusters have been reported. Nationally, cases of severe strep have occurred at a rate of five per 10,000 population per year. Forty severe strep cases have been reported since Sept. 1, Schwartz said.

DOC.HEAD: Expelled Hard-Line Leningrad Chief Reinstated to Party
DOC.TEXT: A former Politburo member expelled from the Communist Party in a scandal over the purchase of a Mercedes has returned the car and received his party card back, Tass reported. Yuri Solovyov, former Leningrad party chief and non-voting member of the party's national Politburo, was demoted last summer after a humiliating election defeat, then ousted from the party in February for violating party ethics. The 64-year-old Solovyov was reinstated at a meeting of the Leningrad regional Communist Party following ``numerous requests from Communists'' and an outpouring of public opinion, Tass said Wednesday. In a February account on his expulsion from the party, the newspaper Izvestia said Solovyov purchased a ``luxurious Mercedes'' in December for ``a practically symbolic price.'' The sensational Leningrad television program ``600 Seconds'' broadcast a report showing Solovyov's name on an auto registration list, and he was expelled at an emergency meeting of the Leningrad party committee a day later. A Tass report at the time implied that Solovyov had abused his position to obtain the car, a Mercedes 280-S. The model was last produced in 1985 and cost about $23,000 without taxes in West Germany. Members of the Communist Party elite long have enjoyed special privileges such as foreign cars and special food allotments, but President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has launched a drive to eliminate such favors. Ordinary Soviets must wait years to purchase domestic cars or pay a vastly higher black-market price. Solovyov was reinstated after participants at last week's party meeting proposed that he return the car _ now described as a ``second-hand Mercedes'' _ to the shop, and he agreed, Tass reported. Tass quoted Solovyov as saying his expulsion from the party was a ``horrible injustice and one of the excesses of the system that has always been a nutrient medium for puppets.'' At the time of his demotion, Solovyov, one of many conservatives in the Leningrad party, was criticized for failing to implement reforms. However, in its account of his reinstatement to the party, Tass quoted him as acknowledging the ``radical changes'' in the Soviet Union and endorsing the new executive presidency that Gorbachev has assumed. ``I have long believed that a multiparty system can exist in Soviet society,'' he was quoted as saying. ``Let there be two, three or even more parties, but it is important that they should channel their activities into creation, rather than into the struggle for power.'' In March 1989 balloting for the national Congress of People's Deputies parliament, Solovyov failed to win a seat even though he was the only candidate on the ballot. More than half the voters crossed off his name. He was replaced as regional party leader by Boris Gidaspov, considered by reformers to be using his base in Leningrad to try to unite Communist Party conservatives.

DOC.HEAD: Slovak Leader Wants Future Independence for His Republic
DOC.TEXT: Czechoslovak Vice Premier Jan Carnogursky said in an interview published today that he wants his republic of Slovakia to become an independent nation eventually. ``Europe is headed towards integration. When it becomes a reality one day, we would like to join it as an independent subject,'' Carnogursky said in comments to the trade union daily Prace. Asked what he thought of Slovak independence, Carnogursky avoided a direct answer, suggesting that extremely close economic ties make it virtually impossible for the two republics to separate immediately. ``Right now, Slovakia does not even have what it takes,'' he said. But asked about Slovakia's role in a possible future European federation, he made it clear independence is the ultimate objective. ``You must admit it would be absurd for one federation to join another federation,'' he said. Carnogursky's comments come during a time of renewed ethnic tensions between Czechs and Slovaks, triggered by a recent parliamentary dispute over the country's name. Slovaks, who make up one-third of the country's 15.5 million people, demanded a hyphenated version _ Czecho-Slovakia _ to strengthen their national identity. Most Czechs consider the demand an example of petty nationalism. To reflect the nation's recent pro-democracy revolution, the national Parliament on March 30 changed the country's name from the Socialist Republic of Czechoslovakia to the Czechoslovak Federative Republic. In a compromise between the two republics, Parliament allowed the people to write the new name of the country either as the Czechoslovak Federative Republic or the Czecho-Slovak Federative Republic. Nevertheless, 20,000 people demonstrated in the Slovak capital of Bratislava to demand an independent Slovak state. Czechoslovak President Vaclav Havel, who is a Czech, and the premiers of both republics have expressed opposition to the idea of secession. Carnogursky, the leader of the Slovak Christian Democratic Movement, opposed an open campaign for independence. ``We clearly distance ourselves from the demonstration. I speak here naturally on behalf of the whole Christian Democratic Movement,'' the newspaper quoted him as saying. ``We are going to insist on the hyphen, but everything must happen on the basis of the (Czechoslovak) republic, a reasonable agreement and without separatist tendencies.'' Carnogursky's movement on Tuesday formed a coalition with the Czech People's Party and the Czech Christian Democratic Party, signaling his desire to work with Czechs who share his group's politics. The ambitious alliance was the first to formally link Czech and Slovak parties in campaigning for national elections June 8 that will decide the shape of the government for the next two years. They will be the first free elections in Czechoslovakia in more than four decades.

DOC.HEAD: Peggy Lee Wins Judgment Against Disney in `Lady and the Tramp' Suit
DOC.TEXT: Singer Peggy Lee won a summary judgment against Walt Disney Productions in a lawsuit in which she claimed Disney needed her approval before releasing the videocassette version of ``Lady and the Tramp.'' Lee provided voices for four characters and co-wrote songs with Sonny Burke for the 1955 animated classic. Los Angeles Superior Court Judge William Huss granted a request for the judgment establishing Disney's liability in the case, Daily Variety reported Wednesday. Neil Papiano, Lee's attorney, said the court will schedule a trial to determine damages. Lee is seeking $12.5 million. Disney has sold about 3.2 million cassettes of the movie at a wholesale value of $45 million to $50 million, Daily Variety said. Theatrical rentals have totaled about $40.25 million. Lee argued that her contract with Disney, which gives her the right to participate in ``transcriptions for sale to the public,'' covered the videocassette release. Huss' decision could affect similar contracts drawn before the emergence of videocassette technology. The paper said a Disney spokesman declined to say what steps Disney might take in the case. The studio cannot appeal until the damages trial is completed, but it can seek a writ of prohibition that could prompt an appellate court to review the summary judgment.

DOC.HEAD: Telescope Testing Completed, Shuttle Mission Still on Schedule
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with telescope tests completed, other procedures begun. Pickup 5th graf `Testing was...' SUBS 7th graf pvs `Because the...' to include first reference to Diller and SUBS 13th graf pvs, `One Atlantis...' to restore dropped word `of.'
DOC.TEXT: NASA technicians finished testing the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope today, keeping pace for Tuesday's launch aboard space shuttle Discovery. ``We're working under a tight schedule,'' NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham said today. ``But there's really nothing right now to indicate the 10th can't be met.'' Further delays in preparations, however, would force a postponement of the 8:47 a.m. liftoff, NASA said. Technicians completed a check of the Hubble's systems and scientific instruments Wednesday. Overnight, they finished readying the telescope's computer system for launch. On completion of the telescope tests, technicians started routine pre-launch procedures, placing explosive devices on the shuttle's solid rocket boosters, external tank and the orbiter itself to be used in the event of a serious malfunction, Buckingham said. Cooling propellants also were to be loaded today into the orbiter's storage tanks. Testing was interrupted Monday by a power outage at Kennedy Space Center that knocked out air conditioning and forced the shutdown of heat-sensitive computers. Work resumed Tuesday using a backup power system. An unrelated mishap resulted in possible damage Wednesday to one of shuttle Atlantis' fuel cells. The extent of damage was not known, but it was not expected to affect Atlantis' next flight, in July, said NASA spokesman Dick Young. Because the tests on the Hubble telescope were longer than expected, the deadline for completion was moved from midnight Wednesday to this morning. To give itself extra time, NASA rearranged launch preparations, said George Diller, another NASA spokesman. Bill Taylor, the telescope's chief engineer, said technicians were being ``extra cautious.'' ``We're doing a look-twice and then another look again to make sure everything's going right,'' Taylor said. The telescope is NASA's most expensive unmanned spacecraft. Discovery's five astronauts are scheduled to put the telescope into orbit during a five-day mission. The Hubble will orbit 380 miles above Earth for 15 years, free of atmospheric distortion. It will be capable of detecting objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory. Astronomers will be able to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling to Earth for 14 billion years. One of Atlantis' fuel cells probably was damaged because excessive pressure was exerted when the unit was being prepared for removal for repairs, NASA said. Fuel cells provide electrical power through a reaction between liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen. Atlantis returned to Kennedy Space Center last month after a secret Pentagon mission to put a spy satellite into orbit. One of the fuel cell unit's 96 individual cells had failed a voltage test during a post-flight checkout.

DOC.HEAD: Arab Foreign Ministers Urge Creation of Nuclear-Free Middle East
DOC.TEXT: Iraq and three other Arab countries called today for the establishment of a nuclear-free Middle East and urged the international community to pressure Israel to sign the Non-Proliferation Treaty. On Wednesday, Iraq's foreign minister, Tariq Aziz, said his country would destroy its supply of chemical weapons if Israel did the same and signed the 1968 treaty designed to limit the spread of nuclear weapons. Aziz made his remarks in a closed meeting of Arab foreign ministers in Amman, an official at the talks told The Associated Press. The Arab offer comes three days after President Saddam Hussein of Iraq said his nation possessed sophisticated binary chemical weapons and threatened to destroy ``half of Israel'' if his country were attacked. The disclosure followed the arrest in London last week of several people accused of attempting to smuggle U.S.-made, nuclear bomb triggers to Iraq. Baghdad has denied that it is trying to build an atomic bomb. In reaction to the arrests, the European Parliament called today on the 12 member states of the European Community to ban the export to Iraq of all ``material essential for the production of weapons of mass destruction and for their delivery.'' The resolution called for a meeting of the U.N. Security Council to discuss ``the threats posed by the Iraqi regime to world security.'' The resolution stated that the arrests in London ``confirm the Iraqi regime's intention of equipping itself with nuclear weapons, despite having signed the International Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.'' In today's meeting in Amman, the foreign ministers of Egypt, Jordan, North Yemen and Iraq issued a communique calling for a nuclear-free Middle East and the prohibition of chemical weapons. ``Our countries, all of them signatories of the Non-Proliferation Treaty, are keen to keep the Middle East region a nuclear-free zone,'' the communique said. Israel is widely suspected of being the Middle East's sole nuclear power. The four countries called on the ``international community to pressure Israel to abide by the international will and join the global nuclear disarmament accord.'' The 22-year-old pact requires participating nations to agree that nuclear energy and research will not be used for military purposes. The Arab ministers also said that ``all kinds of destructive weapons, including nuclear, chemical and biological, should be prohibited in order to guarantee regional and international security.'' But they defended Iraq's production of chemical weapons saying that ``in light of the continuous chemical and nuclear ... threats which the Arabs confront, it was necessary to defend ourselves.'' An Israeli Foreign Ministry spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said there was ``nothing new'' in the statement. ``It is a position they have expounded for some time,'' he said. In an unusual interview published today in an Israeli newspaper, Syrian Foreign Minister Farouk al-Sharaa echoed the Arab ministers' offer for disarmament. ``If there was a sincere desire for peace and security, then Israel should agree to declare the Middle East an area clear of all destructive weaponry,'' Sharaa told the mass-circulation Hadashot newspaper. Syria is one of Israel's most implacable foes and Syrian officials generally avoid all contacts with the Jewish state.

DOC.HEAD: Five Shot to Death, One Wounded at Suspected Crack House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout with ages of some of the victims, more details on the slayings, survivor in critical condition, worst multiple slaying in 19 years.
DOC.TEXT: Five people, including three teen-agers, were found shot to death inside a suspected crack house and a sixth was critically wounded, police and witnesses said. The shootings occurred about 11 p.m. Wednesday, said police Deputy Chief James Younger. He said police called to the scene found the six. Four of the victims, ages 15, 16, 20 and 32, were dead at the scene, said Officer John Leavens, a police spokesman. Another in his late teens died at Detroit Receiving Hospital, where a sixth victim was in critical condition this morning, Leavens said. Police did not know the age of the survivor and the hospital refused to provide any information beyond his condition. Police said a woman, accompanied by two armed men, knocked on the front door of the house, which Younger called a suspected crack house. When a man let her in, her companions rushed in and forced the boys and men to walk to the second floor. Ordered to lie down, the six were shot in the head with automatic and semiautomatic weapons, police said. Four died instantly; two others were shot while trying to flee and were found in the basement. The attackers then ran back to a car with a second woman at the wheel and fled, police said. There were no immediate arrests, Younger said. The incident was the city's worst multiple slaying since 1971, when three men and four women suspected of drug trafficking were shot in an apartment, according to The Detroit News.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Legislature Passes Tough Drunken Driving Bill
DOC.TEXT: A tough drunken driving bill that provides for on-the-spot confiscation of licenses in certain cases passed the Legislature and is awaiting the governor's signature. Gov. Richard Celeste needs time to study the bill, but ``he certainly believes in getting drinking drivers off the road,'' his press secretary, Heidi Findley, said Wednesday. The Senate passed the bill 32-0 on Wednesday, a few minutes after the House approved it 87-9. Drivers who refuse to take a blood-alcohol test or those with previous drunken driving convictions who register more than .10 on alcohol tests can have their licenses confiscated by arresting officers. ``I think we truly have the most innovative law in our country,'' said Rep. Marc Guthrie, the bill's House sponsor. He said it will help curb traffic deaths. Last year, more than 500 people were killed in traffic accidents in Ohio, and 8,000 were injured. The bill requires a license suspension of at least 90 days for a first offense and increases in steps that range up to three years for a fourth offense. It provides that judges may not grant driving privileges for workers for at least 15 days on a first offense, 30 days on a second and 180 days for a third. It leaves the maximum fine for a first offense at $1,000, but increases the assessment for a second offense from $1,000 to $1,500. The fines for a third-time offender will be $2,500 and fourth-time, $10,000.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS Los Angeles-dated item on Christian in Names in the News, a0425, to UPDATE with comment from publisher in 4th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Marc Christian, Rock Hudson's ex-lover, has filed a $22 million libel suit claiming a book portrayed him as a psychotic criminal. Marc Christian, who won $5.5 million from the Hudson estate a year ago in a landmark AIDS lawsuit, said in the Superior Court suit filed Wednesday by celebrity lawyer Marvin Mitchelson that he was shamed by the book's depiction of him. The Tom Clark and Dick Kleiner book ``Rock Hudson, Friend of Mine,'' released last month, referred to Christian as ``a criminal, a thief, an unclean person, a blackmailer, a psychotic, an extortionist, a forger, a perjurer, a liar, a whore, an arsonist and a squatter,'' the suit said. In addition to Clark and Kleiner, the suit names New York-based Pharos Books as defendants. Martha Clarke, a spokeswoman for the publisher, said today, ``the book speaks for itself'' and that the company would have no other comment. A jury ruled in 1989 that Hudson committed ``outrageous conduct'' for concealing his AIDS diagnosis from Christian, his lover for two years.

DOC.HEAD: Aoun and Geagea Accept Another Cease-Fire
DOC.TEXT: Fighting died down today after Gen. Michel Aoun and warlord Samir Geagea accepted a cease-fire called by clergymen who said the warfare threatened Christians' ``very existence.'' Police said overnight howitzer and mortar duels between the rival Christian forces killed two people and wounded three in east Beirut and north of the city before the big guns fell silent at daybreak. But sharpshooters of Aoun's army and snipers from Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia continued to skirmish in the 310-square-mile Christian enclave. In Moslem west Beirut, President Elias Hrawi said he would heed Geagea's appeal that the president's 22,000-man, mainly Moslem army led by Gen. Emile Lahoud take over army barracks in the enclave. But it was not believed he had the firepower to dislodge Aoun, nor were there any signs that Syria's army in Lebanon would back a foray in the Christian enclave. The inconclusive showdown for mastery of the enclave, normally home for about 1 million Christians, has killed 841 people and wounded 2,298 since it broke out Jan. 30. Numerous cease-fires have been declared and broken. Police say at least one-fourth of the enclave's population has fled to safer areas in Lebanon and neighboring countries to escape the savage fighting that has inflicted damage estimated at $1 billion. Aoun's television station, located in Beirut's eastern suburb of Hazmiyeh, resumed its broadcasts late Wednesday night after repairing the antenna that was hit early in the evening during fierce artillery exchanges with Geagea's men. The station was off the air for five hours. Geagea and Aoun, in separate statements, said they accepted a cease-fire in line with the plea from 20 Maronite Catholic clergymen who met Wednesday with Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir at his seat in Bkirki, north of Beirut. In their peace bid, the 16th cease-fire call in the 66-day confrontation, the clergymen told Geagea and Aoun their war threatened the Christians' ``very existence in Lebanon and the Orient.'' The Maronite clerics said continued fighting between Aoun's 19,000 troops and the 6,000 militiamen of Geagea would ``finish off the Christians.'' ``The Christians' fate should not be decided by two guns confronting each other and spreading horror, death and destruction,'' the clergmen said in their statement, copies of which were delivered to Geagea and Aoun. The statement was released after Geagea called on Lahoud to ``take over all the army barracks in Lebanon.'' Geagea, in a radio interview, said he was fully prepared to hand over three army barracks in the Kesrouan and Byblos provinces dominated by his militia north of Beirut to Lahoud ``within the framework of a comprehensive plan that puts all army barracks in Lebanon under the command of Gen. Lahoud.'' ``I urge Gen. Aoun to hand over his barracks to Gen. Lahoud,'' he added. Aoun, Geagea, Hrawi and Lahoud are Maronites, the main Christian sect that has controlled key government posts, parliament, the army command and the judiciary since independence from France in 1943. Aoun has rejected Hrawi's Nov. 24 election as president by Lebanese legislators meeting under Arab League auspices. He complains the peace plan under which Hrawi was elected does not contain a specific timetable for the withdrawal of Syria's 40,000 troops in Lebanon as part of a peacekeeping mandate. Aoun contends the Syrians abrogated that mandate by siding with the Moslems. Aoun has refused to withdraw from the shell-wrecked presidential palace in Beirut's eastern suburb of Baabda and also maintained control of the adjacent defense ministry offices in Yarze. This has forced Hrawi and Lahoud to set up temporary headquarters in Syrian-policed Moslem west Beirut.

DOC.HEAD: Prisoners Hold Out in Devastated Prison
DOC.TEXT: About 25 prisoners held out today for a fifth day inside the devastated Strangeways Prison, and the government said it would conduct an inquiry into the causes of one of Britain's worst prison riots. Barry Cuttle, a member of the negotiating team trying to persuade prisoners to surrender, said between 20 and 25 inmates remained on the loose inside the 122-year-old prison. Ivor Serle, a prison guard and chairman of the local branch of the Prison Officers' Association, predicted there would be no swift end to the rebellion. ``They're cold and they're desperate, but they're determined to stay,'' Serle said. The Home Office said two more prisoners surrendered today and more than 25 inmates surrendered Wednesday. Terry Bone, deputy director of the north region of the Prison Service, told reporters Wednesday that the negotiating team would ``persist in our patient negotiations to bring this dreadful event to a successful conclusion.'' He said the prisoners still holding out had food and water but no heat or light. Prisoners apparently set a fire overnight as the temperature dropped below freezing and requested help when the fire got out of control, the Home Office said. ``Firemen were called and were able to direct a hose towards (the fire) and put it out without making contact with the prisoners,'' said a Home Office spokesman, speaking on condition of anonymity. A prison guard who apparently suffered a heart attack while on duty during the riot died today, the Home Office said. The guard, Walter Scott, 46, was an administrator and not directly involved in combating the riot, officials said. One prisoner, Derek White, died in North Manchester Hospital on Tuesday of injuries received at the hands of other inmates when the riot began Sunday, officials said. White, 46, was awaiting trial on charges of indecently assaulting three children. There were unconfirmed reports of other casualties. Across from the prison, crowds of supporters lined police barricades surrounding the prison, waving and shouting words of encouragement to the defiant prisoners. A Home Office minister, meanwhile, confirmed that prison authorities had been warned about a possible uprising at the Victorian, red-brick prison and that they had taken precautions on Sunday. ``Rumors of riots do abound in jails,'' Home Office Minister Earl Ferrers told the House of Lords. ``It is always difficult to decide when it is a fact or a rumor. On this occasion, action was taken as thought appropriate by the governor.'' Home Secretary David Waddington told the House of Commons that a senior judge would lead an inquiry, which would begin after the last prisoner had surrendered. The riot began Sunday when prisoners overpowered guards during a prison chapel service. They seized their keys and used them to gain access to other parts of the prison. In the mayhem in that followed, the rioters smashed fittings, hurled roofing tiles on guards and started fires throughout the prison. Prison governor Brendan O'Friel told reporters Wednesday that more than 1,500 inmates were caught up in violence and vandalism. Strangeways was built in 1868 to hold 970 men. It held 1,648 prisoners before Sunday's riot.

DOC.HEAD: National Council of Churches Criticized For Prayer For Peace
DOC.TEXT: The National Council of Churches has come under fire for a prayer for Middle Eastern peace that is branded by some religious leaders as a pro-Palestinian political statement. The National Council of Christians and Jews, based in New York, said the seven-paragraph ``Prayer from Jerusalem'' appears ``extremely provocative.'' ``It recalls the worst uses of the Christian holy week as a club against Jews,'' said conference official Elliott Wright. The clamor stems from references which critics say appear to accuse Israel of denying Palestinians their civil and human rights and to blame the Jewish state for the violence of the Palestinian uprising. ``We see there is no peace and that people remain in agony and suffering,'' the prayer reads in part. ``Free them from oppression, restore to them the right of life and to independence in their own land, just as other nations enjoy this right.'' The NCC, an umbrella group of 31 Protestant and Orthodox churches, had distributed the prayer to its members for reading in churches this Sunday, which is Palm Sunday. The prayer was prepared by the Middle East Council of Churches, a coalition of 24 Orthodox, Catholic, and Protestant churches in the Middle East. Rabbi James Rudin, director of the American Jewish Committee's office of interreligious affairs, labeled parts of the prayer ``malicious slander.''

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Soldier Injured As Truck Runs Down Patrol
With PM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: Israeli soldiers shot and killed a 16-year-old Palestinian today when they fired on youths protesting in the West Bank city of Ramallah, hospital officials said. In the West Bank city of Nablus, a Palestinian plowed his truck into an Israeli army foot patrol, injuring at least one soldier, the army said. Youths began stoning the soldiers after the incident, and troops opened fire, wounding at least four Palestinians, Arab witnesses said. Eleven other Palestinians were reported shot and wounded in other, scattered clashes with troops in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. The wounded included a 2-year-old boy hit in the head with a rubber bullet, Arab doctors said. Mustafa Ali Jaro died of a wound to the head from one of the rubber-coated steel balls used by the army for riot control. He was shot during clashes in the main square of Ramallah, six miles north of Jerusalem, Arab reporters said. The army confirmed the shooting and said Jaro, from the nearby Jalazoun refugee camp, was evacuated to a local hospital. In Nablus, the truck with a blue West Bank license plate careened into the army patrol near the Askar Palestinian refugee camp on the city's northern edge. ``It seems it was on purpose, that it was an attack,'' said an army officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The condition of the injured soldier was not immediately known. Palestinian witnesses said the driver of the truck escaped but soldiers captured a passenger. Immediately afterward, soldiers opened fire with rubber and plastic bullets on stone-throwing youths, the witnesses said. Doctors at Al-Ittihad Hopital said four people were hurt, including two 14 year olds struck with rubber bullets. The army sealed off the area and clamped a curfew on the Askar camp, ordering its 8,000 residents to stay in their homes, Arab reporters said. The death in Ramallah brought to 671 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the 27-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza. At least 202 other Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs during the revolt, most as suspected collaborators with Israeli authorities. Forty-three Israelis also have been slain in the violence. In the Gaza Strip, meanwhile, Palestinian activists forced the closure of the municipal government building in Khan Yunis to protest the army's sealing the main mosque in the southern town, Palestinian reporters said. Soldiers welded shut the mosque door Wednesday night, but it was broken open by town residents today, the reporters said. They said soldiers then resealed the door. A military spokeswoman said the army was checking the report of trouble at Khan Yunis' Great Mosque. Three other mosques have been ordered closed in the Gaza Strip because the army claims they are centers of revolt against the occupation. A dispute between two Palestinian factions erupted into violence in the West Bank village of Awarta near Nablus. Residents said six houses belonging to activists in PLO Chief Yasser Arafat's Fatah faction were set ablaze in the village by masked youths from the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine on Tuesday night. However, Popular Front activists said the group set the fires at the homes of suspected collaborators with Israel and then forced the owners from the village. The Popular Front has been urging Fatah to use harsher tactics against the Israelis in the uprising. The latest dispute was over each group painting over slogans sprayed on walls by the rival faction.

DOC.HEAD: Weakened Fuel Spill Passes Ohio And W.Va. Cities
DOC.TEXT: A West Virginia city shut down its water intakes on the Ohio River and two Ohio cities intensified treatment of water from the river as a fuel spill flowed slowly downstream today. At least 75,000 gallons of diesel oil, gasoline and kerosene spilled into an Allegheny River tributary upriver from Pittsburgh on Friday, forcing Pennsylvania cities along the river to shut water intakes. The Allegheny and Monongahela rivers meet in Pittsburgh to form the Ohio River. At East Liverpool, Ohio, water superintendent Glenn Woodward said the worst of the spill appeared to have passed by his city Wednesday. He said fuel concentrations peaked around 3 p.m. at 14 or 15 parts per billion. That was down to a normal level of 4 ppb early today. The city treats about 3 million gallons of river water a day, Woodward said. In Steubenville, Ohio, 25 miles downstream from East Liverpool, Assistant Public Works Director Bill Fabian said the spill had apparently arrived, but lab tests of the water were not completed this morning. Two water intakes near the river's surface were closed at East Liverpool. Those deeper in the river remained open to draw water for the city of 7,000 people. ``It's here, but you can't tell it by sight or smell. We started accelerated treatment of water at 3 yesterday afternoon and will continue until Sunday to make sure we get the leading and tail edges of it,'' Fabian said. Across the river in Weirton, W.Va., workers shut down the water intake pump Wednesday, said Ken Capozzoli, a maintenance operator at the city water treatment plant. ``We don't really know how long the wells can supply us, but we'll do fine for the couple of days it should take for the spill to pass,'' Capozzoli said. Downtstream in Wheeling, W.Va., city workers prepared to mix activated carbon with river water to absorb any remaining fuel. ``They had pretty good luck using the carbon to remove the oil up in Pittsburgh,'' said Phil Kowalski, supervisor of Wheeling's water plant. ``We don't anticipate that people will notice any difference. We may have to slow down our treatment process, but the reservoirs will pick up the slack and there shouldn't be any drop in pressure.'' The water supplies of some communities on the river will not be affected by the spill. Wellsville, Ohio, about six miles south of East Liverpool, draws its water from a reservoir fed by springs, said Mayor Nunzio Lombardozzi. In Beaver County, Pa., the Midland Water Authority's treatment plant reopened its intake valves Wednesday, said Dan Zuppe, the chief filter plant operator. The system was operating at about half its normal pumping volume, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Military Coup in Smallest Autonomous Homeland
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers in South Africa's smallest nominally independent homeland today overthrew the homeland's government, according to a radio report. There were no immediate reports of fighting or casualties in Venda. Singing and dancing in the streets greeted news of the coup against President Frank Ravele, the South African Press Association reported. The deputy chief of the Venda Defense Force, Gabriel Ramushwana, announced the coup over Radio Thohoyandou and told everyone to go home and return to work on Monday. He did not mention the fate of Ravele. The government has been beset by mass protests in the past few weeks and several demonstrations were dispersed by police firing guns. Some deaths were reported then, but details were sketchy. The protesters demanded an investigation into allegations that some Cabinet members participated in ritual murder and withcraft, and demonstrators have also demanded that the 2,500-square-mile republic be reincorporated into South Africa. Venda is the third of South Africa's four nominally independent homelands to suffer a military coup in the past two and a half years. The fourth, Bophuthatswana, survived an attempted coup in February, 1988, after the president, Lucas Mangope, was rescued by South African police. South Africa also has six tribal homelands that have refused to accept independence, which is not recognized by other countries and deprives the homelands' residents of South African citizenship, residential, pension and work rights. Venda is located in the far northeast corner of South Africa, adjoining the Kruger National Park, with a small strip of South African territory separating it from the Zimbabwe border.

DOC.HEAD: Timber Industry Predicts Dire Consequences if Report Implemented
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 13th graf, `The U.S...', to explain that recommendations will be considered by wildlife service.
DOC.TEXT: The timber industry predicts economic catastrophe if the government follows recommendations to save the northern spotted owl from extinction by reducing logging in the Northwest's old forests. ``What we've been presented today is a program that forces a very stark choice between owls and people,'' said Mark Rey, executive director of the American Forest Resource Council in Washington, D.C. ``It obviously provides a maximum advantage for the owls with significant impacts on the people.'' A panel of government scientists said logging must stop in a large section of federal forests if the northern spotted owl is to be saved. The stands of old trees in the Northwest are the primary habitat for the owl. The committee on Wednesday recommended a reduction of about 25 percent in the allowable cut of timber in national forests and a 30 percent to 40 percent reduction on Bureau of Land Management lands. John Hampton, president of Willamina Lumber Co. and chairman of the Northwest Forest Resource Council, said initial estimates indicate up to 60,000 jobs in the Northwest would be lost as a direct or indirect result. ``Some 4 to 5 million acres will be set aside under the recommendation for owl habitat at an estimated cost of $95 million (in timber) for each pair of spotted owls,'' he said at a news conference. The American Forest Resource Council estimated 9,000 jobs would be lost in the region. Hampton said his group's best hope is to get the Bush administration and Congress to consider the impact implementing the recommendation would have on the industry. The Oregon Lands Coalition, a pro-industry group, condemned the environmentalists who have fought logging. ``The preservationists have done their deadly work,'' coalition Chairwoman Valerie Johnson said. Environmentalists were elated by the report. ``This confirms what environmentalists have been saying for a number of years,'' said Larry Tuttle of The Wilderness Society, ``that the spotted owl is in grave danger and by extension therefore the ancient forest is also in grave danger.'' The panel's recommendations are expected to weigh heavily in the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service's decision on whether to list the owl as a threatened or endangered species. Such a designation would mean further restrictions on logging in old-growth forests that provide the bulk of timber harvested in the region. A decision on designating the owl a threatened species is expected by June 23. In Forks, Wash., Jerry Leppell, president of the American Logger Solidarity Committee, said one government study estimated that a 30 percent cutback in logging would lead to 1,000 lost jobs and 800 families leaving the town. ``We all like spotted owls,'' he said. ``There's no problem with spotted owls. The gripe we've got is with preservationists. I think they're overeducated and they drive through and judge us within three hours instead of living here all their life.''

DOC.HEAD: Michael Jackson Visits White House
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: Michael Jackson took top billing over the Bush-Gorbachev summit for a brief time this morning. President Bush welcomed the rock star to the White House, posing for photos with the flamboyantly dressed Jackson in the Rose Garden. The picture taking occurred shortly after the White House released word of the May 30-June 3 summit meeting between Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev. No one seemed really sure why Jackson had been invited. ``I just wanted to welcome Michael Jackson here. And, named artist of the decade, and he has a tremendous following,'' Bush said before making his first public remarks about the summit. ``He does good work in what we call the `points of light' concept. I just wanted to bring him out here and officially welcome him to the White House once again. ``Glad you're here, sir,'' Bush said, turning to the recording artist, who laughed and grinned as Bush made a few comments to reporters about the upcoming Soviet summit. Jackson, his black hair cascading in curls to his shoulders, was resplendent in black and red _ snug black slacks with red stripes down the sides, a black braided short jacket emblazoned with a red arm band, and black gloves. He wore sunglasses, black boots with ornate silver trim, and a silvery bauble pinned to his chest like a medal. He chatted with Bush as they walked from the Oval Office to meet photographers, but did not speak to the assembled media. Mrs. Bush and the Bushes' daughter-in-law, Margaret Bush, then walked Jackson down the driveway to the residence quarters of the White House. White House press aide Jay Allison said Jackson is interested ``in the whole program'' that Bush calls the ``Points of Light'' idea for getting people involved in community service. Allison did not know specifically why Bush invited him to the White House. Jackson is to receive an Entertainer of the Decade award from the private Capital Children's Museum in Washington. He will be the guest of honor tonight at a fund-raising reception to benefit the museum.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Session Only Beginning of Building Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 11 grafs to UPDATE with office of president created, old Communist Presidium abolished. Pickup 6th pvs, `If de...'
DOC.TEXT: The first non-Communist Parliament in East German history convened today and began replacing four decades of Stalinist rule with a democratic government. In the hall where Communist lawmakers once meted out edicts, lawmakers chosen in the nation's first free elections on March 18 began the process of forming a government that could be the country's last before unification with West Germany. ``Forty years of difficult times have ended in this moment,'' said Lothar Piche, 63, the eldest member of the new Parliament, as he called the session to order in the Palace of the Republic. ``God support our German fatherland.'' The 400-member Parliament was expected to empower Christian Democrat leader Lothar de Maiziere to build a new government and to decide whether to form a commission to investigate allegations that some new Parliament members worked with the dreaded secret police. In its first action, the 390 new leaders who attended the session elected physician Sabine Bergmann-Pohl, a Christian Democrat, as president of the Parliament. Among those seeking the post were outgoing Communist Premier Hans Modrow, who leads a rebuilt pro-democracy party that finished a distant third in the March elections. He finished third in the voting for Parliament president, behind Social Democrat Reinhard Hoeppner. The Parliament also created an office of president to be a ceremonial head of state, as East Germany's new government was being shaped to mirror that of West Germany's. Dr. Bergmann-Pohl is to serve as head of state until a president is elected by Parliament. De Maiziere will likely be the premier, or prime minister. Dr. Bergmann-Pohl called on lawmakers to work with their counterparts in West Germany to merge their nations and to bring the capital of a single Germany back to a united Berlin. The Parliament also formally abolished the old Communist Presidium, the Council of State. De Maiziere will lead talks in the coming days on forming a new Cabinet. If de Maiziere is successful in bringing together the disparate political groups, Parliament will then reconvene on April 11 and vote on his Cabinet nominations, said Martin Kirchner, a high-ranking Christian Democrat. De Maiziere leads a Christian Democrat-led conservative alliance that has been trying to form a coalition with the left-leaning Social Democrats and a smaller group of liberal lawmakers. His Alliance for Germany won the most seats in the March 18 elections. But it needs a broad coalition to ensure the two-thirds vote needed in Parliament to enact constitutional changes required for unification. Kirchner predicted that a government may be formed quickly ``so that this nation is no longer devoid of government.'' Backroom political wrangling and charges that newly elected lawmakers had ties to the secret police of the ousted Communist regime have taken the steam out of the reunification process. A Communist-led caretaker government that followed the ousted regime of hard-liner Erich Honecker in October has been running the country. The Alliance for Germany favors rapid reunification while the left-leaning Social Democrats favor a more gradual pace, with each East German state to decide independently on a merger. Nevertheless, swift reunification is demanded by voters, who backed de Maiziere's coalition overwhelmingly after he promised a quick merger as a means to Western prosperity. Even acting Social Democrat party leader Markus Meckel said Wednesday he favors reunification ``as quickly as possible.'' The negotiations quickened this week after West Germany's central bank said it was recommending a 2-1 conversion of East German marks to West German marks as part of a currency union. East German parties united in opposition to that proposal, calling for a direct 1-1 conversion to ease the withdrawal pains of unemployment and high prices as East Germany sheds its socialist system. West Germany said Wednesday it wants a pact on monetary union by early next month, but the East Germans are expected to be tough negotiators once serious talks begin. De Maiziere's opposition to the West German Bundesbank proposal raised his stature with the smaller parties, which have often described him as a puppet of West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. But the Social Democrats still are opposed to the more conservative elements in de Maiziere's alliance. Much of the wrangling has been over the distribution of Cabinet posts in a new government. The Social Democrats, who favor more emphasis on environmental and social issues, have asked for the education, foreign and labor ministries.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Urges Congress to Give Pentagon More Leeway
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New material, editing throughout with Cheney announcement on budget management, other additional details.
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney urged Congress today to give the Pentagon more leeway to manage its budget, contending that less intense congressional oversight would save money and improve defense programs. ``We can do much to improve defense management by ourselves. We could accomplish far more with the cooperation of Capitol Hill,'' Cheney said in a statement. The defense secretary's recommendations were contained in a 41-page policy paper sent to Congress today. It recommended many changes in the way the Defense Department manages its programs and personnel, as well as changes in the congressional budget-writing process. Among Cheney's recommendations was one that Congress appropriate defense spending for two-year periods instead of every year. That would help stabilize Pentagon programs by forcing more clear-cut choices on spending priorities, the report said. ``If next year's budget debate is only a few days away from the end of this year's debate, there is no reason to accept a negative decision as final,'' the report said. On Wednesday, Cheney announced the Pentagon was reassessing the need for the Navy's Seawolf nuclear attack submarine and the Arleigh Burke-class destroyer in light of disarmament moves and political changes under way in the Soviet Union. In a speech to the American Society of Newspaper Editors, he said the move meant the Pentagon was determined to readjust American defenses in response to global changes. ``As circumstances change, we will adjust the kinds of naval forces we need,'' Cheney said. ``We are now looking at a smaller Navy than we were in the early 1980s.'' The United States should not, however, give up its global maritime superiority, he said. ``We'll need to control the seas regardless of what happens in Moscow,'' Cheney said, in part because the American economy is being more interwoven with the world economy and thus is increasingly dependent on the free flow of goods on the seas. The defense secretary earlier ordered reviews of other major new weapons systems, including the Air Force's B-2 bomber, the Army's new light helicopter and the Strategic Defense Initiative research on an antimissile defense. He said results from those reviews will be completed within the next few weeks. Meanwhile, two Republican members of the Senate Armed Services Committee today called on President Bush to limit production of the B-2 and delay the Advanced Tactical Fighter as part of additional cuts in defense spending. ``We believe that the United States can meet its defense requirements with budget levels lower than those proposed by the administration,'' said Sens. William Cohen of Maine and John McCain of Arizona. The administration has proposed about a 2 percent reduction in defense spending in each of the next five years, but twice that amount is realistic, the GOP senators said. By their calculations, the current $300 billion defense budget would be reduced by about $50 billion. Cheney gave no details of the Navy program reviews. A department spokesman, Bob Hall, said today the internal review would reconsider whether the Seawolf subs and the Burke destroyers meet the Navy's requirements, taking into account such factors as maritime strategy, cost, schedules and performance. The administration is proposing to cancel many smaller weapons systems and plans to cut about 50,000 men and women from the 2.1-million-member armed forces in 1991. The Army and Air Force have taken the brunt of the reductions, but Cheney's remarks to the newspaper editors indicated the Navy's share of the pain may grow. A scaling back of the Navy's attack submarine fleet already was in the wind. Last month, Vice Adm. Daniel Cooper told a House panel that budget constraints would limit deployments to fewer than 80 by the year 2000. The goal has been 100 by that date. The first Seawolf nuclear attack submarine is scheduled for completion in mid-1995. It is designed to be quieter and have more weapons, greater speed and more capability to kill Soviet subs than the existing Los Angeles-class attack sub. The Navy is planning to buy 12 Seawolfs at an average projected cost of $1.57 billion apiece. The Seawolf has been criticized for being too expensive, but Adm. Carlisle Trost, chief of naval operations, wrote recently that the sub ``is required in order to ensure that we maintain an acceptable level of risk in the face of the continuing modernization of the Soviet submarine force.'' The Burke guided-missile destroyers are to replace the Adams and Farragut class destroyers that were built in the 1960s. The Pentagon claims the Burke ships will be the most advanced and powerful destroyers ever built. They are to be equipped with the high-tech Aegis aircraft tracking system and sophisticated missiles. The Navy plans to buy 33 of the destroyers at an average projected cost of $820 million apiece. The Navy is scheduled to take possession of the first destroyer in February 1991. Eight of the new ships are under construction and the Navy in February awarded contracts valued at a combined $1.1 billion to build two more.

DOC.HEAD: French Inventors Win Prize For Drawing Pen for the Blind
LaserPhoto GEV1
DOC.TEXT: A drawing pen for the blind and partially blind won the grand prize today at the annual Geneva Invention Fair. The two Frenchmen who developed the pen originally intended it to be used as a tool for teaching blind youngsters computer science. But Jack Sagot, a special education teacher in Paris, and Gerard Pavard, a teacher of handicapped children near the city of Nantes, eventually developed it for general use by the blind in drawing, graphics and the production of documents in the Braille alphabet. The pen has a special ink that forms a slight relief, or ridge, after drying for a few minutes. The raised patterns can easily be detected by people who touch them, the inventors say. The drawing paper can be heated to heighten the relief for children just starting to read Braille, Pavard said. Fair organizers claimed the invention is the biggest breakthrough in the field since the 1829 invention of Braille, which uses patterns of embossed dots to signify letters. An international jury at the weeklong fair chose the pen as top entry among some 1,000 inventions from 25 countries. It was not immediately clear if the inventors would receive a cash prize.

DOC.HEAD: Doctorow Wins PEN@Faulkner for `Billy Bathgate'
DOC.NOTE: For Release 6:30 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Author E.L. Doctorow is winner of the PEN@Faulkner Award for best American fiction published in 1989 for his eighth novel, ``Billy Bathgate,'' the Folger Shakespeare Library announced Thursday. Doctorow, 59, a professor at New York University, will receive a $7,500 cash prize at an awards ceremony May 12 at the library, which administers the awards. Four finalists will receive $2,500 each. Doctorow's award-winning novel is about a young man from the Bronx who becomes the protege of the infamous 1930s gangster, Dutch Schultz. Doctorow previously had won the National Book Critics Circle Award for ``Billy Bathgate'' and ``Ragtime'' and the National Book Award for ``World's Fair.'' The PEN@Faulkner Award was founded by American writers 10 years ago to pay tribute to novelist William Faulkner, who used his Nobel Prize money to encourage other writers. The award is associated with the American branch of PEN, the international writers' organization whose name is an anacronym for poets, playwrights, editors, essayists and novelists. The four other nominees who also will be honored at the May 12 ceremony are Russell Banks, Molly Gloss, Josephine Jacobsen and Lynne Sharon Schwartz.

DOC.HEAD: Coalition Set to Fight Excise Tax Hike
DOC.TEXT: The highway, tobacco and alcohol industries opened a campaign Thursday against using higher federal excise taxes to reduce the budget deficit. Raising taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, beer, wine and liquor would impose an unfair burden on lower-income Americans, the Coalition Against Regressive Taxation told a news conference. A study prepared for the coalition by the Peat Marwick Policy Economics Group concluded that lower-income families already pay five times as high a share of their income on excise taxes as higher-income Americans do. ``If there is to be a tax'' for deficit reduction, said Thomas J. Donohue, president of the coalition and of the American Trucking Associations, ``then all the companies and all the citizens should share in that tax.'' Although President Bush says he opposes any tax increase for deficit reduction, several members of Congress are urging higher excise taxes for that purpose. For example, Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, has outlined a comprehensive plan that includes higher taxes for gasoline, beer, wine and cigarettes, as well as increased income taxes and a one-year freeze on Social Security benefits. The Peat Marwick report said that while a $20-billion-a-year boost in excise taxes would raise the tax burden of the average American by 1.9 percent, the one-third of people with the lowest incomes would see a 6.5 percent increase.

DOC.HEAD: Humanities Chief Echoes Call Against Grants Censorship
DOC.TEXT: The head of the federal program that distributes federal aid to libraries and for scholarly work told a Senate panel Thursday that the controversy over arts financing has hindered her agency's work. ``The system we had in place before was much more satisfactory,'' Lynne V. Cheney told the Labor and Human Resources subcommittee on education, arts and humanities.
