In his 1989 Christmas message, he spoke of the need for ``special protection and care (for children) including the correct legal protection both before and after birth.'' Vatican Radio on Thursday praised King Baudouin for refusing to sign the bill into law. In an introduction to a news report, the radio station said the king made a ``noble and courageous choice'' that was dictated by his ``very strong moral conscience and his undisputible sense of statehood.'' The Roman Catholic Church opposes abortion in all circumstances, and Pope John Paul II has campaigned continuously against it. There has been no comment from the pope on the king's move.

DOC.HEAD: Senator D'Amato Plans to Test Soviet Blockade of Lithuania
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alfonse D'Amato said Thursday he will test a Soviet blockade of Lithuania by trying to enter the breakaway Baltic republic on a visa issued by the nation's independent government. D'Amato, a New York Republican, said he has an invitation to visit Friday from Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis. He said he expects to be accompanied to the border, 185 miles from Warsaw, by a high-level Lithuanian government delegation. D'Amato said he will try to cross the border with a Lithuanian visa despite the fact that the Soviet Union does not recognize the republic as an independent nation. The Soviet Union has ordered Western diplomats out of Lithuania, evicted foreign journalists and forbidden traffic at the single Polish-Lithuanian border crossing. It is Lithuania's only direct land access to the rest of Europe. The steps were taken in an effort to force Lithuania to retract its declaration of independence made March 11. The United States never recognized the forced incorporation of Lithuania into the Soviet Union in 1940, but it also has not recognized Lithuania as an independent state. It has urged negotiations between Vilnius and Moscow. In Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater commented on D'Amato's trip and said: ``We're always concerned about members of Congress and others getting too involved in foreign policy. ``But on the other hand, he is a senator who has an important message to deliver. He represents a broad constituency and has every right to make that trip and deliver his message.'' Congressmen, including D'Amato, have been urging President Bush to give Lithuania more support. Some U.S. politicians have suggested sanctions if force is used against the republic. ``We'll find out about glasnost,'' D'Amato said when asked what he thought Soviet KGB border troops would do when he reached the border. ``We'll find out if they are really for peace, or if this is a case of saying one thing and doing another,'' he said. If blocked, he pledged ``to raise the question as to why they would be turning back a United States senator who has come at the invitation of the elected representatives of the people of Lithuanian.'' He criticized Western news organizations for withdrawing their correspondents from Vilnius after being to ordered to do so by the Soviets. D'Amato is the junior Republican on the Senate Intelligence Committee and also serves on the Appropriations Subcomittee on foreign operations. He is not considered one of the Senate's leading voices on foreign relations. Before he left Wednesday, D'Amato tried to deflect suggestions that the trip was designed to counteract problems at home. D'Amato's public opinion ratings have slipped dramatically since the Senate ethics committee began looking into allegations he used his influence to steer federal Housing and Urban Development money to friends and political supporters. ``Now, if every time I do something that's not associated with HUD, you're going to say `Oh, you're doing that because it's not associated with HUD,' that's silly,'' he told reporters Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Jury Rejects Deli Owner's Claims Against Actor Paul Newman
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with verdict reached; no pickup; ADDS byline
DOC.TEXT: A jury today rejected a delicatessen owner's claims that he was promised a slice of actor Paul Newman's gourmet food companies. The Superior Court jury deliberated just five hours over two days before deciding that Newman never promised Westport deli owner Julius Gold 8 percent stock in the companies, Newman's Own Inc. and Salad King Inc., for the help Gold said he provided in launching the businesses in 1982 and 1983. ``It's just tragic, all of this energy and time could not have been spent in more charitable pursuits, but that's the nature of the beast,'' Newman said moments after the verdict was announced. Newman showed no emotion as the decision of the six-member jury was announced. He shook hands with his attorneys and his partner, author A.E. Hotchner, before leaving the courtroom. Gold sat dejectedly without moving for 15 minutes after the verdict was announced and appeared despondent over the verdict. But he said he would not appeal. ``I'm disappointed,'' Gold said. ``I brought the case because I thought I was wronged. I realized I was dealing with an uphill battle, going against a celebrity of world status. Also, the charitable thing was a hard thing to overcome.'' Hotchner was elated by the verdict, calling it a vindication of his friend and business partner. ``Newman's never stiffed anyone in his life,'' Hotchner said. ``If anything, he's overly generous to people.'' Newman, who attended the highly publicized trial almost daily since it started March 20, claimed that Gold's only participation in getting the companies started was to sell some of the dressing in his store. Newman and Hotchner started Newman's Own on a whim, beginning with salad dressing that Newman originally made in the basement of his Westport home. The product line was later expanded to include spaghetti sauce, popcorn and lemonade. All profits _ $28 million to date _ have gone go to charity. The Westport-based companies had a record $42 million in sales last year, up from $36 million in 1988. An earlier trial ended in a mistrial in 1988 when the jury mistakenly received depositions that had not been admitted as evidence.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Full-Speed Ahead On Monetary Union
With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: West Germany said Thursday it was moving ahead with plans to replace the nearly worthless East German currency with the mighty Western mark by summer, amid uproar over the proposed exchange rate. Finance Minister Theo Waigel confirmed newspaper reports that under the proposed currency union, East Germany would relinquish control of monetary policy to the West German central bank, Bundesbank. ``Naturally, sovereignty over monetary policy in this currency union will lie completely with the Bundesbank,'' Waigel told reporters. Waigel said government ministers were studying a 50-page draft proposal for replacing the East German mark. He said West Germany would like basic agreement on the contract by next month and establishment of the common currency sometime this summer. Merging the German currencies is crucial to plans for rebuilding East Germany's battered economy and to West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl's hope for a speedy unification of the states. But East Germans are outraged by a Bundesbank recommendation that they get one West German mark for every two East German marks. According to the proposal, a 1-1 conversion rate would apply only on limited amounts of savings. Thousands of people rallied in East German cities Thursday to underscore demands for a 1-1 exchange rate. The East Germans say a broad 2-to-1 rate could lead to impoverishment. How the German currency union will be worked out is also worrying other European countries. A senior Dutch banker said this week that ``irresponsible'' promises by Kohl to East Germans about the terms of monetary union have driven European interest rates to ``absurdly'' high levels. France, Italy and European Economic Community officials have been pushing for quick creation of a common EEC currency and central bank. A number of West European countries have expressed concern the unification process might distract West Germans from the EEC's stated goal of closer European integration. Waigel said Bonn hoped to offer a finished proposal to East Germany by mid-April, but that depended on when a new East German government was formed. Negotiations are under way in East Berlin on forming a coalition government, following East Germany's first free elections on March 18. ``We expect there will be negotiations (with East Germany) after Easter, at the latest,'' Waigel said. Waigel said the Bundesbank's recommendation for a 2-to-1 conversion rate was not discussed by the government ministers Thursday. The Bundesbank has said a general 1-to-1 swap for East German marks could doom many East German industries and businesses, not only by increasing the value of their debt, but by boosting the purchasing power of East Germans who might then start buying superior West German products. The West German government says it is examining the Bundesbank proposal, but has not disclosed what it will offer East Germany. Handelsblatt, a widely respected West German financial newspaper, said the government would choose a 1-to-1 rate for wages and pensions and increase the amount of savings that can be exchanged at that favorable rate. But even if wages and pensions are converted at 1-to-1, corporate debt and other business-related aggregates will still be exchanged at a 2-to-1 rate, the newspaper said.

DOC.HEAD: Launch on Schedule, Telescope Tests Completed
With AM-Hubble Reunion, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: NASA finished testing the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope aboard Discovery and started final pre-countdown work Thursday, raising the space agency's hopes for a timely launch next week. It is the most comfortable NASA officials have felt about Tuesday's launch date since a power outage interrupted the testing Monday, said George Diller, a spokesman for the space agency. ``Basically, the work's done. We're just down to the things you can't do before now anyway,'' Diller said. ``We're essentially on or near schedule on all of that work. I'm really not aware of anything that's unusually shaky,'' he said. The countdown is scheduled to begin Saturday afternoon. Early forecasts show an 80 percent chance of weather favorable for launch Tuesday, with the weather worsening slightly during the next two days. Functional testing of the telescope and shuttle was completed early Thursday, and the launch pad was cleared of all non-essential personnel for final preparation of the payload and orbiter. Technicians were in the middle of the 52-hour test when a power outage at Kennedy Space Center knocked out air conditioning and forced the shutdown of heat-sensitive computers. Testing resumed Tuesday evening and had to be completed by Thursday morning for the mission to stay on schedule. As soon as the testing ended, technicians began the routine procedure of placing explosive devices on the shuttle's solid rocket boosters, external tank and the orbiter itself to be used in the event of a serious malfunction, said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. Power was turned off to the telescope and shuttle so that the hazardous work could be performed. Charging of the telescope's nickel-hydrogen batteries also was halted and was to resume. The telescope's batteries will be charged until the shuttle's payload bay doors are closed two days before launch. The 24,250-pound, 43-foot-long telescope, named for the late American astronomer Edwin P. Hubble, is the most expensive unmanned spacecraft ever built by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. It originally was scheduled for launch in 1983, but was delayed due to technical problems and the 1986 Challenger explosion. Discovery's five astronauts plan to deploy the telescope on the second day of the five-day mission. The Hubble will orbit 380 miles high for 15 years, enabling astronomers to study stars and galaxies so distant that their light has been traveling to Earth for 14 billion years. It will be capable of detecting objects 50 times fainter and with 10 times greater clarity than the best ground-based observatory.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Promises to Pursue Peace Despite Coalition Composition
DOC.TEXT: Labor Party leader Shimon Peres, criticized for forming a coalition dependent on defectors from the right-wing Likud bloc, reaffirmed Thursday that he will be able to pursue the peace process if he is prime minister. Peres said that once installed, his government would ``without question'' approve U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker's plan for convening Palestinian-Israeli talks in Cairo. ``We say the government will be based on the peace policy of the outgoing Cabinet,'' Peres said on Israel radio. ``But we will permit the continuation of the process ... to renew the peace process.'' Leftists feared Peres could have trouble making bold moves since his majority in parliament would be thin and dependent on conservative religious factions and hawks who had crossed party lines. Peres met in Tel Aviv with leaders of three left-wing parties who were critical of his tactics in trying to form a new government. They control 10 seats in the parliament, or Knesset, and some threatened to withhold support vital to Peres. Amnon Rubinstein, leader of the Shinui (Change) faction which has demanded sweeping election reform, said the notion of switching back and forth between political blocs was ``a problem that goes to the very core of Israeli democracy.'' Peres told President Chaim Herzog on Wednesday he had succeeded in piecing together a ruling coalition. But Labor leaders have refused to divulge the names of the prospective defectors who have promised support. Peres said secrecy was necessary to woo other supporters. He is believed to have only 61 or 62 members of the 120-seat Knesset pledged to support his leadership. The announcement came two weeks after he was assigned to replace Likud Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. Shamir lost a no-confidence vote March 15 in a crisis triggered by dispute over Baker's conditions for holding Palestinian-Israeli talks. Peres forced the showdown with Shamir, who was reluctant to accept Baker's proposals on forming a Palestinian delegation. Parliament officials were expected to set a voting date on the proposed new government for either Sunday or Wednesday. If Peres succeeds, it would be the first time since 1977 that the left-of-center Labor ruled without sharing power with Likud. According to Israeli media, the key defector is Likud legislator Avraham Sharir, whom Shamir dumped as tourism minister after criticism that Sharir spent too much time on junkets abroad and padded government payrolls with cronies. Labor promised Sharir, 67, he would return to the tourism post or be named transport minister in a Labor-led government. Sharir's Tel Aviv home was placed under special police surveillance Thursday after his family received telephone threats, Tel Aviv police spokeswoman Ahuva Ivri said. The liberal daily Haaretz newspaper said Labor has left open other Cabinet jobs for potential defectors. It said two religious parties, the National Religious Party and the Torah Guardians, were being offered the Education and Interior portfolios respectively if they support Labor. The Finance Ministry was held for Yitzhak Modai, head of a disgruntled Likud breakaway group. Likud leaders mounted intensive efforts to court Modai and other potential defectors, promising seats in the next parliament. Army radio said Modai's breakaway group was even offered a 2.5 million letter of credit signed by a wealthy party contributor as a guarantee that the promise of future parliament seats would be fulfilled.

DOC.HEAD: Consumers Borrowed More in February Than They Repaid
DOC.TEXT: Americans took out $3.4 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in February, but the pace slowed because of slackening demand for car loans, the government said Thursday. The Federal Reserve said consumer credit increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 5.7 percent, down from January's revised 6.4 percent pace. The January rate was reported last month to have been 5.9 percent. Consumer credit, which includes all consumer loans except mortgages, was up 7.3 percent in December. Automobile loans advanced in February to a seasonally adjusted $889 million in February. That represented an annual rate of 3.7 percent, less than half the 8.4 percent jump in January when sales incentives were reinstated. The incentives continued in February, but consumer response failed to keep up. Without incentives, auto loans had fallen 0.4 percent in December. Credit card debt rose $485 million, 2.9 percent at an annual rate, slightly faster pace than January's 1.8 percent gain but much slower than the 23.7 percent rate during the December holiday shopping period. Bank and credit union loans not secured by real estate were up 12.1 percent, an increase of $2.04 billion, after gains of 9 percent in January and 3 percent in December. Borrowing for mobile homes continued its recent downward trend, off $2 million or 0.1 percent. With the exception of a 2.8 percent gain in September, mobile home credit has fallen each month since February 1989. The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of February at $723.7 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Study That Finds AZT Slows Onset of AIDS Is Published
DOC.TEXT: An often-cited study that shows the experimental drug AZT can delay the onset of AIDS in people with the HIV virus appeared in Thursday's New England Journal of Medicine. ``Now, we have something to give people,'' said Dr. Anthony Fauci, director of the Office of AIDS Research of the National Institutes of Health. ``It's important for people who feel they have been exposed to HIV to get tested to determine if they are infected.'' The study, whose preliminary findings were first released last August, formed the basis of the federal Food and Drug Administration's decision last month to allow physicians to prescribe the drug for patients who are infected with the human-immunodeficiency virus but have not developed symptoms of the disease, researchers said. Although the study's conclusions were known, the data had not been published until Thursday. Fauci on Wednesday discussed the clinical trials after addressing the Johns Hopkins Conference on AIDS, a three-day gathering of 650 scientists from across the country. ``This is a strong mandate for increased testing,'' said Dr. John Bartlett, chief of AIDS service at the Johns Hopkins Hospital, one of the 32 medical centers that participated in the study of 1,338 patients. Researchers hailed the results not only as good news for those infected with the virus that causes AIDS, but also for those who have placed themselves at risk of contracting the virus. With early detection, people may stand a better chance of staving off the disease, they said. Over a two-year span, fewer patients who were given AZT progressed to the full-blown stage of the disease than patients taking a placebo, the study found. Despite the encouraging results, researchers said patients must be observed longer before it can be determined if the drug actually lengthens the life of infected people. The study's lead author was Dr. Paul Volberding of the University of California at San Francisco. In the study, the 1,338 subjects were divided into three groups of nearly equal size. One group received a placebo, one received a small dosage of AZT and the third received a higher dosage of AZT. AIDS developed in 33 patients taking the placebo, 11 taking the smaller dosage and 14 taking the higher dosage, the researchers reported. The drug is manufactured by the Burroughs Wellcome Co. of Research Triangle, N.C. It was first sold in 1987, when the company received FDA approval to market it for people with full-blown AIDS and advanced cases of AIDS-related complex.

DOC.HEAD: Arafat Seeks Help in Drawing Israel to Negotiating Table
DOC.TEXT:
PLO chairman Yasser Arafat asked Italian officials on Thursday to help him persuade Israel to negotiate a settlement with the Palestinians. Italian political leaders who met with Arafat said he described 1990 as a do-or-die year for the Arab-Israeli peace process. ``Arafat explained clearly that 1990 is either a year in which the peace process truly opens, or else it can lead to a new terrible spiral of war,'' said Giorgio Napolitano, an Italian Communist Party official. Arafat said earlier in Paris that he would like to meet with Shimon Peres, the Israeli Labor Party leader who is working on forming a coalition government. Before leaving Paris for Rome on Thursday, Arafat told the Europe One radio station he would meet with Peres at the French presidential palace. ``The peace process is blocked because of problems in another camp,'' said Arafat in the radio interview, referring to Israel. But ``if Mr. Peres can assure himself a majority, at that moment things could move.'' Arafat said he also expects to hold more talks with former President Jimmy Carter. They met twice in Paris, and Carter praised what he said were the PLO leader's efforts to advance peace in the Middle East. DOC.HEAD: Impeached Judge Reinstated to Law Practice In Federal Court
DOC.TEXT: Former U.S. District Judge Harry Claiborne, who was convicted of tax evasion in 1984 and later impeached, has won a legal battle to resume practicing law in federal court. U.S. District Judge Robert Broomfield of Phoenix said Wednesday he was adopting a Nevada state bar disciplinary board's recommendation that Claiborne be reinstated. Claiborne, 73, was convicted of failing to report more than $106,000 on his 1979 and 1980 tax returns. He was removed from his lifetime post Oct. 10, 1986, after the U.S. Senate convicted him on three of four articles of impeachment. Claiborne claimed at his impeachment hearing that he was the victim of prosecutors he had offended while on the bench. He served 17 months of a two-year prison term and resumed his law practice in state court shortly after he was released. Broomfield had denied Claiborne permission to practice in federal court in September 1988, but allowed him to apply again last September. ``I am very happy about it,'' Claiborne said Wednesday. ``I certainly intend to go back to practicing in federal court but I don't have anything lined up yet because I had to be careful not to encourage people to wait around for me.'' The disciplinary board said Claiborne ``has built up a reservoir of good deeds; and for whatever transgressions he may have committed in the past, Harry Claiborne has by any standard paid the price.''

DOC.HEAD: Groups Urges States to Abandon Crusades for Mandatory Record Labels
DOC.TEXT: Two national groups pressing for voluntary warning labels on records urged state legislators Thursday to drop crusades for mandatory labels in light of an industry effort to alert consumers to explicit lyrics. Tipper Gore, president of the Parents' Music Resource Center, said lawmakers in 13 states had promised to abandon their efforts to require labels on music with graphic lyrics about sex and violence. Bills are pending in six states, she said. The center ``has never believed that legislation is the answer. Today, we are asking state lawmakers to give the voluntary system a chance to work,'' Gore said. Six major record companies said last week they plan to create a uniform voluntary labeling system to identify explicit recordings. Gore and Ann Lynch, president of the National PTA, said that would strengthen a labeling agreement their groups had reached with the industry in 1985. Companies were not complying with that agreement in many cases. ``The key difference is the uniform standard they are going to use,'' Gore said. Asked if a standard alone will result in a wider use of the labels, she replied: ``We take the industry on good faith that they really do mean to seriously address the problem. We take them at their word and we believe they will do the job correctly this time.'' At least one state legislator said he would reintroduce his bill next year if the record industry doesn't improve. ``We hope for a positive outcome,'' said Tom Susman, a member of the West Virginia House of Delegates. ``If not ... then it will be up to the legislators to look at this issue again.'' States where lawmakers have promised not to pursue or revive mandatory labeling bills include Arizona, Iowa, Maryland, Oklahoma, West Virginia, Tennessee, Alaska, Illinois, Kansas, Minnesota, New Mexico, New York and Rhode Island, Gore's group said. Similar bills are pending in New York and Rhode Island, as well as Missouri, Florida, Delaware and Pennsylvania, according to the National Association of Recording Merchandisers. Gore's group and others have expressed concern about music that they believe encourages violence, suicide, drug use, sexual promiscuity, bigotry and devil worship. Susman said the record labeling system would be comparable to the guidance parents receive from film ratings. Gore said her group has never favored censorship and denied that it inspired state legislators to propose mandatory labeling. She gave parents and teachers credit for spurring the latest industry plan. However, record merchandising industry executives last week indicated that pressure from state legislatures was at least partly responsible for their decision to standardize and try to broaden the labeling system. The music industry has been lobbying hard in state capitols to kill the bills. Companies creating the new system are Warner Brothers, MCA, CBS, Capitol-EMI, RCA and Polygram. Representatives of the Recording Industry Association of America were scheduled to meet with state legislators Friday in Washington to discuss the size, content and placement of the new stickers. The association represents companies that produce more than 90 percent of the records sold in the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Reauthorizes Vocational Training Program
DOC.TEXT: The Senate unanimously approved legislation Thursday reauthorizing a special program of federal grants to help states and localities provide vocational education programs. By a 96-0 vote, senators authorized spending roughly $7 billion through fiscal 1994 for the grants. ``I believe this bill is an excellent piece of educational policy,'' said Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., chairman of the Labor and Human Resources Committee. Under revisions to the existing federal grant program, funds will be more precisely targeted to the neediest groups, including non-English speaking young people. Kennedy said he was pleased that the bill, a version of which already has been approved by the House, ``greatly strengthens provisions to ensure that the handicapped, disadvantaged and those with limited English proficiency are adequately served.''

DOC.HEAD: Mental Health Facilities Still Shunned
DOC.TEXT: One in three American adults say they or someone in their family have sought help from a psychiatrist or a psychologist, according to a survey released Thursday. Yet, the survey also found among those polled widespread opposition to putting any kind of mental health facility or housing for people with mental illness in their neighborhoods. Miles Shore, director of the Robert Wood Johnson Foundation's program on chronic mental illness, said he was encouraged that nearly 90 percent describe mental illness as a serious health problem, and many believe it can be treated. But he said the survey points out a contradiction in what he called the ``not-in-my-back-yard,'' or NIMBY, phenomenon. ``On the one hand, people do object to siting these facilities in their `back yard.' On the other hand, over half recognize that mental illness can improve and that keeping up a normal life _ which includes community living _ will help with that improvement,'' he said. The survey found that 74 percent of those polled believe correctly that anyone can become mentally ill and that mental illness can be cured, and 53 percent believe that keeping up a normal life in the community will help a person with mental illness get better. But two in three believe there is a lot of stigma attached to mental illness, according to the survey, which was commissioned by the foundation. It also found that those with higher incomes were more likely to oppose placing mental health facilities in their neighborhoods. Members of families with income of more than $50,000 were twice as likely to oppose these facilities in their neighborhoods, and the strongest opponents tended to be older, well educated, professional men who were married and owned a home in a large city or a suburb of a large city, Shore said. The foundation's program on chronic mental illness commissioned the study to help in its efforts to encourage acceptance of housing for people with mental illnesses. The study was based on telephone interviews with 1,300 adults between Dec. 1 and Dec. 11, 1989. It was funded by the foundation, the American Psychiatric Association, the National Institute for Mental Health and the PEW Charitable Trusts.

DOC.HEAD: Americans' Affect On World Environment Enormous, Expert Says
DOC.TEXT: One American does 20 to 100 times more damage to the planet than one person in the Third World, and one rich American causes 1,000 times more destruction, a population expert said Thursday. ``The most serious population problem in the world is right here in the United States,'' said Paul Ehrlich, Stanford University professor of population studies. ``The most common misperception of the population problem is that it's a problem of poor Indians who don't know how to use condoms,'' he said. ``Actually, the problem in the world is that there are too many rich people.'' Ehrlich and other environmentalists spoke to about 1,200 students, teachers, garden-club members and corporate executives at a conference on solving global environmental problems. He said the current world population of 5.3 billion is 1.8 billion more than in 1968 when he first prophesied the problems of overpopulation in his book ``The Population Bomb.'' He and his wife, Anne Howland Ehrlich, who co-wrote the current book, ``The Population Explosion,'' say this decade will be the turning point for global environmental problems. ``If we don't see some real action in this decade, it will probably be too late to avert some very serious problems'' including inadequate food production, global warming, species extinction and deforestation, said Mrs. Ehrlich, associate director for the Center for Conservation Biology at Stanford. Ehrlich railed against highly developed nations like the United States that he claims consume too much of the world's resources. ``The birth of a baby in the United States is something on the order of 20 to 100 times more disastrous for the life support systems of the planet as the birth of a baby in poor countries like Bangladesh or Venezuela,'' he said. Most developing countries fall within the range, with Bangladesh among the poorest and Venezuela among the richest Third World countries, Mrs. Ehrlich said. She said she and her husband based the figures on 1987 statistics compiled by the United Nations on per capita commerical energy consumption, an index used by environmentalists to measure damage to the Earth. ``If it's a (rich) baby, it could be a thousand times more,'' Erlich said. ``Actually, the problem in the world is that there is much too many rich people. ... It's not how many people you have but how those people behave.'' People who drive gas-guzzling luxury cars, air-condition their homes and live from what Ehrlich calls ``high-intensity-the-hell-with-tomorrow agriculture'' do far more environmental damage than subsistence farmers, he said. But he was not promoting the idea that Americans should adopt a peasant lifestyle. In highly affluent Sweden, the average person uses about 60 percent as much energy as consumed by the average American, Ehrlich said. ``We are super consumers and very unselective, and we're extraordinarily incompetent and sloppy with our technologies,'' he said. Several environmentalists at the conference echoed Ehrlich's assessments on overpopulation and his claim the world is running out of time to find solutions. ``You cannot address the problems soon enough,'' said George Woodwell, president of the Woods Hole Research Center in Woods Hole, Mass. ``We are driving the Earth into impoverishment. We are living on its capital,'' he said. ``We're eating up the standing stocks of trees and nutrients and soil in the process of feeding the current 5.3 billion people on Earth. In doing that, we make the Earth less capable of supporting people in the future.'' In terms of global warming, the United States, with about 5 percent of the world's population, produces 25 percent of the world's output of carbon dioxide, believed to contribute to the greenhouse effect, said Peter Raven, director of the Missouri Botanical Garden and professor of botany at Washington University in St. Louis. ``Chicago puts out as much carbon dioxide as China,'' he said. ``It's a peculiar world. The people at the top are consuming far, far more than a vast number of people at the bottom.'' The environmentalists suggested couples have no more than two children, buy efficient appliances and cars and organize politically. ``The bright side is we know societies can change very rapidly when the time is right,'' Ehrlich said. Woodwell said President Bush could lead the nation in that effort. ``We can only hope one Bush will experience a rapid greening this spring,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dump Protesters Make Mounted Charge At State Troopers; Dozens Arrested
Laserphoto BF1
DOC.TEXT: Ten protesters on horseback charged a column of state troopers Thursday as state officials tried to inspect the proposed site of a dump for low-level radioactive wastes. Police wrestled two riders off their horses as troopers advanced on foot on the dumpsite. One rider appeared to have been knocked unconscious briefly, but was revived and led away under arrest. No troopers were reported injured. By mid-afternoon Thursday, 37 protesters had been arrested, according to the Allegany County Sheriff's Department. Most were charged with disorderly conduct and released after being issued court appearance tickets. Six elderly protesters were arrested after they handcuffed themselves to a chain stretched across a one-lane bridge leading to the dump site in Caneadea, which is about 65 miles southeast of Buffalo. ``I remember Allegany County when it was so clean and so beautiful,'' said one of the protesters, Ermena Barber, of Friendship. ``We've got to go back to those days even if we've got to give up a lot of things to do it.'' About 30 state police officers were trying to escort three officials from the state Low-Level Radioactive Waste Siting Commission past harrows, plows, hay wagons, and other farm equipment blocking the road to the dumpsite. ``It's a long walk for nothing, but I'm not going to have a riot for a walk over some land,'' state police Lt. Charles McCole told his officers. It was the commission's fourth attempt since December to inspect potential dump sites in Allegany County. It was the first attempt at an inspection since state Judge Jerome Gorski issued a restraining order forbidding protesters from blocking the commission. Federal law requires states to have a place to store low-level radioactive waste by 1993.

DOC.HEAD: New Minimum Wage Won't Adversely Affect Food Stamp Recipients
DOC.TEXT: Low-income families that receive food stamps will keep most of those benefits despite an increase in the minimum wage, a senior Agriculture Department official said Thursday. ``Every case is different, but most food stamp recipients will keep at least 64 cents in benefits for each dollar they gain in wages,'' said Assistant Secretary Catherine Bertini, who oversees USDA food and consumer services. ``The food stamp program is not an alternative to work,'' she said in a statement. ``We want to encourage people to work, earn money and support themselves and their families.'' The federal hourly minimum wage rose to from $3.35 an hour April 1 and will increase again next April 1 to $4.25 an hour. Food stamp benefits are allocated on the basis of several factors, including household size and net income as determined by deducting expenses for such items as housing, utilities and day care. Bertini cited an example of a family of three claiming the maximum deduction for housing, earning $580 per month in wages and receiving $207 in food stamps. Under the new minimum wage law, the family's earnings would increase by $78 to $658 per month, while food stamp benefits would be reduced by $19 per month. That would total $787 per month under the old minimum wage and $846 under the new, a net gain of $67 per month, she said. ``The gain in wages more than makes up for the loss in food stamps,'' Bertini said. ``In fact, for each new dollar earned with the new minimum wage, this household would keep 76 cents in food stamp benefits.'' More than 19 million people get benefits under the food stamp program, which is estimated to cost $14.8 billion this year.

DOC.HEAD: Prime Minister of Nepal Resigns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with background, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The prime minister resigned Thursday following six weeks of pro-democracy demonstrations across the Himalayan kingdom, highly placed sources said. The sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said a formal announcement of the resignation of Prime Minister Marich Man Singh Shrestha would be made soon by King Birendra. They said Shrestha, prime minister since 1986, submitted his resignation Thursday night. At least 16 people have been killed in confrontations between demonstrators and police since Feb. 18, when two banned political groups _ the Nepali Congress Party and a coalition of left-wing parties _ began agitating for a return to a multiparty democracy in one of the oldest monarchies in the world. The first sign that there were differences in the government over the handling of the pro-democracy movement came when Shailendra Kumar Upadhyaya resigned Friday as foreign minister. Upadhyaya said he was resigning because he considered it ``immoral'' to stay in a cabinet headed by the prime minister. Upadhyaya said he had advised Shrestha to hold talks with the agitators, ``but he did not listen to me. My advice to him went unheeded.'' On Sunday, King Birendra shuffled Shrestha's cabinet, dropping nine ministers. Although no reasons were given for the reshuffle, well-placed observers said it was to remove dissent within the government. The government has not shown any signs of holding talks with the agitators despite the momentum the movement is gathering daily. At least 3,000 telecommunication workers defied a government ban on strikes and walked off their jobs on Thursday. Employees at 13 other government and semi-government corporations also struck. This week, airline pilots, lawyers, doctors, teachers and engineers have stopped working, expressing support for the pro-democracy movement. The agitators are demanding an end to a 29-year-old royal decree banning political parties. Power in Nepal is shared by the monarch and a partyless Rashtriya Panchayat, or National Assembly. One-fifth of the assembly's 140 members are nominated by the king and the rest are elected, but members are not allowed to belong to any political party or propagate political ideology. A two-year experiment with a Western-style democracy ended in 1961 when Birendra's father, King Mahendra, dismissed the government of the Nepali Congress Party, accusing it of mismanagement and corruption.

DOC.HEAD: Humpback Whale Trapped in Nets Off Virginia Coast
DOC.TEXT: A humpback whale was found tangled in fishing nets off the Virginia coast Thursday morning, but the huge mammal apparently either freed itself or drowned before officials could rescue it. ``It may be that he broke free from the net. He appeared to leave the area rapidly,'' said Mark Swingle, a curator at the Virginia Marine Science Museum. The museum, along with the Virginia Institute for Marine Science, organized the rescue operation. The whale was spotted in the Atlantic Ocean just off this resort city, near Rudee Inlet, said museum Director C. Mac Rawls. The whale slowly drifted south, dragging nets and anchors along with it, Rawls said. Rescue boats lost sight of the whale shortly before noon. Rawls said a diver rescue was considered, but it could be dangerous. ``Because this animal is so strong, it could knock the diver into the nets and entangle him,'' he said. The whale apparently became entangled in shad nets, which are strung up and down the shallow coastal waters of the area. Swingle speculated the whale may have been in shallow water feeding on fish. The 35-foot-long whale was a young animal that probably weighed around 30 tons, Swingle said. A humpback whale washed ashore last weekend several miles farther south of where the entangled whale was seen Thursday. Tissue from that whale has been sent to the National Marine Fisheries Service for analysis. It also appeared to have been entangled in a net.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Lithuanian Letter to Gorbachev
With AM-Soviet-Baltics
DOC.TEXT: The Lithuanian Parliament late Thursday approved a message to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Gorbachev appealed to the Lithuanian government Saturday to renounce its declaration of independence and the message was meant as a response. The following is the text of the letter transmitted by the Lithuanian Supreme Council in Russian and translated by The Associated Press: U.S.S.R. Moscow The Kremlin President of the U.S.S.R. M. Gorbachev Deeply esteemed President, Your appeals to the Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania and the people of Lithuania were met with genuine attention and the desire to understand your point of view. We realize that Lithuania's determination to rejoin the family of independent states creates concerns for the Soviet Union and for you personally, esteemed president. You correctly assess the situation as complex, demanding well-based discussions and acceptable decisions. We value highly your efforts aimed at the peaceful solution of problems, however certain questions connected with your position are not quite clear to us. Lithuania, as before, is prepared for honest dialogue, but this should not be accompanied by the willful actions of your Armed Forces. Therefore, we propose to hold soon initial bilateral consultations with the goal of clarifying the positions of both sides on the questions that interest them. You know that the problem of Lithuania has not been created by Lithuania. Lithuania is only realizing its basic right. The Supreme Council of Lithuania is prepared to discuss through dialogue the essence and letter of the acts and resolutions taken by the Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania from the point of view of international law and the U.S.S.R. Constitution as well. You also know that Lithuania proposes and intends to maintain the existing economic, cultural and humanitarian ties with the U.S.S.R. We believe that you, esteemed President, will prefer a political solution of the problem to all others. In view of this, the Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania once again affirms its readiness to enter a dialogue and discuss measures of establishing new relations between our states. The Supreme Council of the Republic of Lithuania On behalf of Chairman V. Landsbergis Vilnius April 5, 1990

DOC.HEAD: Military Coup in Smallest Autonomous Homeland
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The military in the nominally independent homeland of Venda overthrew the government Thursday and said the area should be reincorperated into South Africa, radio reports said. Col. Gabriel Ramushwana, 48, deputy chief of the Venda Defense Force, announced the coup in a broadcast over Radio Thohoyandou. He said the government of President Frank Ravele had been corrupt and unstable, and the country had been plagued by lawlessness, boycotts and human rights violations. The independent South African Press Association confirmed the report and said there was singing and dancing in the streets of Venda as news of the coup spread. The government-run South African Broadcasting Corp. said Ravele and his Cabinet resigned. It said nothing about a coup. Ravele's government was the target of mass protests in recent weeks that shut down schools, transportation and government services. The protesters demanded that the 2,500-square-mile republic be reincorporated into South Africa. This would allow Venda residents to receive the benefits that go with South African citizenship. They also demanded an investigation into allegations some Cabinet members participated in ritual murder and witchcraft. Several of the demonstrations were dispersed by police gunfire and there were reports of casualties, although the exact number is uncertain. Ramushwana made no mention of Ravele's fate. He told everyone to go home and return to work on Monday. Friday is a national holiday in Venda and the rest of South Africa. The coup occurred Thursday morning, said a Venda businessman who spoke on condition of anonymity. By noon, telephone connections had been cut and roadblocks were set up on all routes out of the homeland. There were no immediate reports of fighting or casualties. There are four nominally independent homelands in South Africa, and three have experience military coups in the last 2{ years. An attempt at a coup in Bophuthatswana failed in February 1988 after the president, Lucas Mangope, was rescued by South African police. Residents of the tribal homelands are denied South African citizenship and the residential, pension and work rights that accompany the citizenship. The homelands are not recognized as independent by any other nations. South Africa also has six tribal homelands that have refused to accept independence. Ravele was not among the homeland leaders expected at talks Thursday in Cape Town with South African President F.W. de Klerk. Only the non-independent homelands were to have been represented. Venda is in the far northeast corner of South Africa, adjoining Kruger National Park, with a small strip of South African territory separating it from the Zimbabwe border.

DOC.HEAD: Political Power Struggle Brings Cries For Reform
With AM-Israel-Politics
DOC.TEXT: Israelis are increasingly demanding electoral reforms as cases of politicians offering favors for support to form a coalition government become more blatant. ``There is a complete breakdown in trust,'' said law professor Uriel Reichman, who is leading the reform campaign. ``Politicians are using their power to enhance their own political ambitions by bribing parties and legislators.'' Examples abound. _Hours before he left the Finance Ministry last month, Labor Party leader Shimon Peres gave $3.5 million to religious institutions belonging to an ultra-Orthodox faction he hoped would support his bid to become prime minister. _The rival Likud offered a $2.5 million guarantee to ensure its promise of a new Cabinet post to Economics Minister Yitzhak Modai, who had threatened to defect to Labor. The money did not reach the $10 million Modai demanded. _Both Labor and Likud, archrivals in the race to form a government, adopted a last-minute budget amendment March 30 giving $110 million to religious institutions, triple last year's allocations. Israelis are used to a certain amount of dealmaking in coalition negotiations, as Israel's political system often makes small parties the kingmakers between the two major parties. But the desperate steps taken by both the left-leaning Labor and the right-wing Likud have brought an unprecedented call for reform. Newspaper editorials, student groups, women's groups and even some politicians have urged a change in the system. The most dramatic appeal has come from two army reserve officers who began a hunger strike Thursday in a park opposite Parliament. The same day, Peres announced he had succeeded in piecing together a ruling coalition to replace the one that collapsed over disagreement on Middle East peace moves. The strikers have since been joined by eight others in their fast. They met with thousands of well-wishers and collected 25,000 signatures calling for electoral reform. Ohad Limor, a lieutenant in the army reserves, said he joined the hunger strikers after parliament approved the extra funds for the religious parties. ``When I heard this, I said `That's it, no more.' This is not something you see on television. This is my life,'' said Limor, 25, sitting on a beach chair outside a tent. Most of those opposed to the current political system have only vague notions about what should replace it. ``But there is nothing that could be worse than what we have now,'' Limor said. Reichman, who says he has support from 68 Israeli mayors, made three demands _ direct election of the prime minister, direct election of at least half the legislators and adoption of a bill of rights. The current system has Israelis voting for parties, not individual candidates. Any party capturing 1 percent of the total vote in the country wins a seat in the 120-member Knesset. Reichman's Public Committee for a Constitution for Israel and other protest groups called a rally in Tel Aviv for Saturday, and a wide range of organizations have urged members to attend. Likud, facing the possibility of a Labor-led government, jumped on the bandwagon Thursday. It offered to set up a transition government with Labor to legislate reform, including the direct election of the prime minister. The reformers' chances for success are up against a long history of broken promises from legislators who benefit from the existing, unbalanced system. But Reichman and others were optimistic that the tide could not be turned back. ``This is a critical moment in the history of the country. There is hope that from the present chaos a new chapter in our history will be written.''

DOC.HEAD: Leona Asks Judge to Dismiss State Charges
DOC.TEXT: A tearful but defiant Leona Helmsley vowed Thursday, ``I am not going to jail,'' after her attorneys asked a judge to dismiss state income tax evasion charges against her. The 69-year-old self-proclaimed hotel queen was convicted last year of federal income tax fraud and sentenced to four years in prison, but is free on bond pending appeal. She still faces state charges that she, her husband and two former employees falsified $3 million worth of business and tax records from 1982 to 1986. Mrs. Helmsley sat quietly through the proceedings in Manhattan's state Supreme Court. But surrounded by reporters as she left the courthouse, she again protested her innocence. ``Enough is enough,'' she said in a hoarse voice, occasionally choked by tears. ``I am not going to jail. I've done nothing wrong. ... My only crime is that I'm Leona Helmsley. For that I'm guilty.'' Her attorney, Sandor Frankel, told Justice John A.K. Bradley that his client has already been ``enormously punished'' by the federal prosecution. He also argued that the state charges constituted double jeopardy. The federal indictment contained at least 10 charges specifically dealing with state income taxes, he said. ``The government should not be able to take multiple bites out of the human hide,'' he said. Assistant Attorney General Alfredo Mendez said that the 188-count state indictment contained many other charges not prosecuted by federal authorities. ``It is in fact in the interest of justice that New York tax cheats be brought to justice,'' he said. The judge asked Frankel, ``If I dismiss the indictment, would not the public conclude that there's one law for the rich and another for the poor?'' ``The fact that we're here, judge,'' Frankel replied, ``isn't that saying there is one law for the wealthy, well-known and vilified and another for everyone else?'' Frankel also asked Bradley to allow a pretrial hearing to establish whether the indictment originated through a ``tainted chain'' from testimony Mrs. Helmsley gave under a grant of immunity in a separate 1985 investigation of sales tax fraud. Her attorneys maintain that leaks to the media a year later about her testimony prompted Mrs. Helmsley's enemies to contact reporters about other activities, which led to the state and federal investigations. Bradley said he would rule on the motions on May 17. Mrs. Helmsley faces up to four years in state prison if convicted. Her husband, Harry, 80, was found mentally incompetent to stand trial in federal court and wants to have the state charges against him dismissed on the same grounds. An April 30 court date was set to address that issue. In December, Mrs. Helmsley rejected an offer to serve a prison term concurrently with her federal sentence in exchange for pleading guilty to evading $750,000 in state income taxes. The two former executives, Joseph V. Licari and Frank J. Turco, have accepted similar deals.

DOC.HEAD: Military Says 659 Killed in Insurgency in First Quarter of 1990
DOC.TEXT: At least 659 people were killed in the first three months of 1990 in violence resulting from the nation's Communist insurgency, the military chief said Thursday. Armed forces chief Gen. Renato de Villa said that from January to March, 365 Communist rebels, 179 soldiers and 115 civilians were killed in ambushes or clashes. In the latest incident, rebels shot to death an army captain and wounded his wife in a Manila suburb Thursday, officials said. They identified the officer as Capt. Leodegario Regis and said he was commanding officer of the Capital Command's long range unit, an elite weapons and tactics team. Military authorities blamed Communist assassins for the killing of about 30 soldiers and officials in the capital this year. On Wednesday, Communist rebels ambushed and killed nine troops on Mindanao island, 640 miles southeast of Manila, an army report said Thursday. One guerrilla was also killed in the attack, and three rebels and two government soldiers were wounded, the report said. The rebels, who have been fighting for 21 years to establish a Communist state, have threatened to intensify operations in urban centers, including Manila. In another development, the military said Thursday that a lieutenant colonel sentenced to 12 years in prison for trying to topple President Corazon Aquino had escaped. Air Force officials said imprisoned Lt. Col. Rodolfo Calzado never returned after he was permitted a temporary leave from a Manila stockade Feb. 25. Officials did not say why he was allowed to leave. Capt. William Cacacho, an air force spokesman, said Calzado was convicted for his role in a January 1987 coup attempt. Cacacho said the report of the escape was withheld until Thursday so as not to jeopardize the search. The coup attempt in January 1987 was the third bid to topple Mrs. Aquino, who took power in 1986. The latest and bloodiest attempt was in December.

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: Don't Be Fooled by `Psychobabble'
DOC.TEXT: Prosecutors urged jurors Thursday not to let sympathy or ``psychobabble'' prevent them from finding a college student guilty of first-degree murder in the drowning of her newborn in a dormitory toilet. Claire Moritt showed no expression as the state used its summation to attack the defense argument that she was legally insane, out of touch with reality and had no memory of being pregnant or even giving birth. ``To allow your sympathy, your anger, psychobabble theories to enter into your deliberations increases the chances of turning in an unjust verdict,'' said Assistant State Attorney Stephen Crawford. ``Just apply your common sense _ apply the obvious facts.'' Meanwhile, Circuit Judge Richard Lazzara dismissed a juror after a customer in a downtown lunchroom overheard her telling her sister-in-law about the case. He then sequestered the jury until a verdict is reached. The case was heard by 16 jurors and will be decided by 12 members. The jurors had not been told which of them were alternates. In his closing arguments, Crawford recounted in detail the morning of Oct. 23, 1989, to prove the 18-year-old Hillsborough Community College student from Hollywood gave birth in her dorm room and made a conscious decision to kill her baby son. Using a chalkboard, diagrams and a photograph of the dead 6-pound, 9-ounce infant, Crawford told how a roommate awoke to the sounds of a baby crying. When roommates finally entered the bathroom, they found Ms. Moritt kneeling and the baby stuffed in the toilet headfirst, wrapped in bloody towels and sheets. Defense attorney B. Anderson Mitcham tried during his final arguments to discredit the prosecution's case one witness at a time. He noted discrepancies in the testimony of the roommates about whether there were towels and sheets covering the baby. He said the medical examiner ``blew'' the autopsy and questioned why the bloody linen was never tested for blood type. ``Did the prosecutor prove his case beyond and to the exclusion of a reasonable doubt? I think not,'' Mitcham said. If convicted of first-degree murder, Ms. Moritt would automatically be sent to prison for life without possibility of parole for 25 years because the prosecution did not seek the only other penalty _ the electric chair.

DOC.HEAD: So Many Issues, So Little Time
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union have seven short weeks to put together a summit package of nuclear weapons cutbacks and to find common ground on German unification and ways to awaken the sluggish Soviet economy. But as Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze plodded past the midpoint of this week's heavy pre-summit agenda, the outlook for meeting the May 30 deadline with solid accomplishments was uncertain. In fact, the summit may turn out to be less of a ceremonial signing event than a working session for President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``It's going to be a working visit, no time for sightseeing,'' is the way Gennadi Gerasimov, the spokesman for the Soviet foreign ministry, described Gorbachev's trip here. Whatever reasons Gorbachev had for advancing the summit _ it was initially planned for the second half of June _ the effect is to put additional pressure on negotiators grappling with three of the most complicated arms control treaties in history. And officials on both sides suggested on Thursday chances of finishing the accord to cut long-range nuclear missiles by the time Gorbachev comes here to see Bush are virtually nil. The most optimistic projection is that Baker and Shevardnadze, and negotiators meeting in Geneva, will be able to reach agreement by May 30 on the key issues and leave the details to be mopped up after the summit. ``Taking into account it's in seven weeks,'' Yuri Nazarkin, the chief Soviet START negotiator, said, ``it's impractical, I think, to expect it's going to be signed at the summit. But definitely, all the major issues should be resolved, making the treaty ready for signing'' later on. Similarly, a senior U.S. official said: ``It depends in some part on what we're able to do here. The desire was to resolve all the major issues by the summit meeting, and looking realistically toward completing and signing a treaty later in the year.'' That could mean a second Bush-Gorbachev summit by the end of 1990, but no Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty before then. There are knotty problems confronting the ministers and the negotiators. Among them: how to limit cruise missiles aboard planes, submarines and surface vessels, and how to verify the cutbacks are being implemented. The outlook is somewhat better for Bush and Gorbachev to be able to approve protocols for monitoring underground nuclear test explosions. On the third arms control front, the two sides are in tentative agreement to slash their chemical weapons stockpiles to 20 percent of the current U.S. level. But Sergei B. Batsanov, a Soviet negotiator, said there was no agreement yet on two big issues _ how to dispose of weapons and when to end production. The White House had left setting a precise summit date to the Soviets. Taking a flexible approach, Bush wanted Gorbachev to set his own timetable, The Soviet leader has a date June 19 in Moscow to take up creation of a Communist Party for the republic of Russia as well as the big Soviet Communist Party Congress beginning July 2. Evidently, he wanted more time between the two sessions than holding a late June summit with Bush would allow. As a result, U.S. and Soviet officials will have to hurry their consideration of the kind of economic assistance the Bush administration might extend to the Soviet leader for his perestroika program of restructuring the Soviet economy. That could mean anything from technical advice to trade credits. Congress will have to be sounded out, as well. Pushing up the summit also shortens the time for the Soviets to find a peaceful solution to their problems with breakaway Lithuania and to work out a formula on German unification. Tensions in either area could cloud what Bush and Gorbachev hope will be another milestone in improving superpower relations.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Barry Schweid has covered U.S.-Soviet diplomacy for The Associated Press since 1973.

DOC.HEAD: Group Again Threatens to Kill Swiss Hostage in Lebanon
With AM-Hostages
DOC.TEXT: A group threatened Thursday for the second time to kill a Swiss hostage in Lebanon unless two Lebanese jailed in France and Switzerland were freed. The threat was phoned to a Western news agency in Nicosia by a man who said he was speaking for the Action Group for the Release of Hariri. Authenticity of the call could not be verified. The group was unknown until March 9 when they called the news agency office and threatened to kill either Elio Erriquez, 23, or Emmanuel Christen, 33, Swiss Red Cross workers who were kidnapped Oct. 16 in the south Lebanon town of Sidon. The caller demanded the release of Mohamed Hariri, jailed for life in Switzerland for air hijacking and murder, and Anis Naccache, serving a life sentence in France for an attempt to assassinate an Iranian emigre leader in Paris. They gave March 12 as a deadline. The same caller said Thursday, ``We did not execute one of the Swiss hostages because of his past humanitarian work in Sidon.'' This time, unless the Lebanese pair are released, he said, ``We will execute the first hostage after the blessed month of Ramadan.'' He referred to the Moslem holy month scheduled to end about April 26, depending on the sighting of the new moon. ``Our demands are clear, which is the release of fighter Mohammed Hariri and fighter Anis Naccache,'' the caller said. He spoke Arabic with a south Lebanese accent. After the first call, the International Committee of the Red Cross and the Swiss foreign ministry expressed doubts about the authenticity of the threat. There are 18 Western hostages in Lebanon, including eight Americans. Longest held of the hostages is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was taken five years ago March 16.

DOC.HEAD: Suhrheinrich Nominated To Appeals Court
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday he will nominate U.S. District Court Judge Richard F. Suhrheinrich to the 6th Circuit Court of Appeals in Cincinnati. Suhrheinrich, 53, of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich., has been a federal judge for the eastern district of Michigan since 1984. If confirmed, he would succeed Albert J. Engel on the appeals panel.

DOC.HEAD: Abortion Rights Groups Campaigns on Campuses Across Country
DOC.TEXT: An abortion rights organization on Thursday began a national campaign to register college students to vote against abortion foes. Hollywood actors handed out leaflets at Harvard Square in Cambridge, Mass., and at Columbia University in New York. Nearly 100 students attended a political gathering at a city college in Santa Monica, Calif., where they heard a call to activism. ``You are part of a generation that grew up without the fear that a crisis pregnancy, an unwanted pregnancy, could threaten your health in a back alley abortion,'' said Kate Michelman, executive director of the National Abortion Rights Action League. The campaign planned events at about 40 colleges Thursday and Friday. In Massachusetts, actors Judd Nelson, Howard Hesseman and Elizabeth Pena stood outside a subway stop and handed out leaflets to passersby urging them to register and vote pro-choice. Between 40 and 50 people were registered, said Joyce Cunha, associate director of MassChoice, an affiliate of the national group. The actors were emissaries from the Hollywood Policy Foundation Center, the non-profit arm of the Hollywood Women's Political Action Committee. Cunha said students were a key part of the pro-choice movement, which she said had been too complacent before last year's U.S. Supreme Court decision allowed states to restrict abortion rights. ``This is a right they've always had. I think that's part of why we want to help them to educate their peers to understand that the right is in jeopardy,'' she said. In New York, actress Martha Plimpton urged 1,000 students at Columbia to vote against candidates who want to outlaw abortion. ``I had no idea until recently I had to fight for this right,'' she said. At Santa Monica City College, Michelman said abortion was an issue in all 50 states as well as U.S. territories, referring to a restrictive law recently enacted in Guam. The governor of Idaho last week rejected an abortion restriction law in that state. ``The political landscape has radically changed in this country,'' she said. ``A woman's right to reproductive freedom has been threatened.'' Students and college staffers who attended the talk in an art building lecture room indicated they had not realized the scope of the issue. ``I think I'm ready to be involved,'' said Tina Feiger, a college staff worker. ``But I think what we need are specifics, what races to work on.''

DOC.HEAD: Food Reaching Famine Victims In Sudan
DOC.TEXT: An agreement between Sudan and rebels has allowed needed food to be delivered to starving people in the country's famine-struck southern region, lawmakers and officials said Thursday. James Cheek, the U.S. ambassador to Sudan, joined Reps. Frank Wolf, R-Va., and Tony Hall, D-Ohio, in outlining the resumption of Operation Lifeline Sudan. ``The resumption of Operation Lifeline Sudan will save hundreds of thousands of lives, and I congratulate the Sudanese government, the Sudanese People's Liberation Movement, the world donor community and the non-governmental relief agencies who were able to make this happen,'' Wolf said. Operation Lifeline recognizes the neutrality of humanitarian relief and ensures that all transport flagged by the United States will be allowed to more freely.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Study Shows Most Felony Defendants Released While Awaiting Trial
DOC.TEXT: Two-thirds of defendants charged with felonies in 39 of the nation's largest counties were released from police custody pending court action, the Justice Department said in a study released Thursday. The sampling of 11,063 felony cases filed in February 1988 showed that 66 percent of the defendants were released on bail, bond or their own recognizance while awaiting trial or ther dispositions of their cases. The study showed that 31 percent were held in jail pending trial because they were unable to post bail. Another 4 percent of the defendants were ordered held without bail following their arraignments. The statistics, gathered from local courts by the Justice Department's Bureau of Justice Statistics, was intended to be a sampling of the disposition of felony charges in 75 of the nation's largest counties. The study tracked the felony cases from initial filing to disposition in courts in 39 local jurisdictions, including the District of Columbia. Of the defendants accused of violent offenses, 59 percent were released on bail or their own recognizance. Sixty-one percent of murder defendants were kept in custody, while 39 percent were released on bail or personal recognizance. Twenty-six percent of murder suspects were ordered held without bail, 35 percent could not post enough money to obtain their release. Among accused rapists, 55 percent were released while 45 percent were detained pending disposition of their cases. Fifty-two percent of robbery defendants were released as were 66 percent of those accused of assault. Seventy-two percent of defendants charged with sale or possession of illegal drugs were released from custody while awaiting trial, the study said. Bail is requested by prosecutors to guarantee that a defendant will appear in court for subsequent proceedings and does not necessarily reflect the seriousness of the charges against the defendant. To determine if there is a risk of flight, judges traditionally consider whether the defendant has strong ties to the community, through relatives or friends. Some jurisdictions, such as the District of Columbia, have preventive detention statutes that allow defendants charged with serious crimes to be held without bail. The statistics gathered in the study indicate that defendants previously convicted of violent offenses were less likely to be released on bail than suspects who had records of other types of offenses. Only 33 percent of defendants who already had been convicted of violent felony crimes such as rape or murder were released on bail. By contrast, 62 percent of defendants with prior felony drug convictions were released on bail. According to the study, 76 percent of those released on bail appeared for all court proceedings while 24 percent missed a court date. Of the defendants for whom bench warrants were issued, 16 percent were eventually returned to court and 8 percent were fugitives after one year. Besides the District of Columbia, the data was collected from cases in Maricopa County, Ariz., Los Angeles, Orange, Sacramento, San Bernardino, San Diego and Santa Clara counties in California; Broward, Dade, Duval, Hillsborough, Palm Beach, Pinellas counties in Florida, Fulton County, Ga.; Honolulu, Hawaii; Cook County, Ill.; Suffolk County., Mass.; Wayne County, Mich.; St. Louis, Mo.; Essex County, N.J.; Bronx, Erie, Kings, Monroe, New York and Queens counties in New York; Hamilton County, Ohio; Allegheny, Montgomery counties in Pennsylvania and Philadelphia, Shelby County, Tenn.; Harris and Tarrant counties in Texas and Dallas, Salt Lake, Utah, Fairfax County, Va., King County, Wash., and Milwaukee, Wis.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Senators Call for Cutting Bush's Military Plan
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS 2 grafs of Nunn comment following 21st graf pvs, bgng, `It was.' Edits for transition.
DOC.TEXT: Two Republican senators accused President Bush and congressional leaders Thursday of reacting too slowly to changes in Eastern Europe and urged cuts in the U.S. nuclear arsenal. Frustrated with the administration's fiscal 1991 defense budget and with proposed adjustments circulating on Capitol Hill, Sens. William Cohen of Maine and John McCain of Arizona recommended a leaner framework, including cutbacks for the B-2 Stealth bomber and land-based nuclear missiles. They propose keeping military spending basically stable over the next five years compared to the administration's recommendation of modest increases of 2 percent or less each year _ less than the probable rate of inflation. Following the senators' plan would mean cutting about $50 billion from proposed military spending during the five years, said Cohen and McCain, both members of the Senate Armed Services Committee. The GOP senators' call for a comprehensive defense strategy and further reductions in spending came on the heels of a series of congressional attacks on Bush's military budget and increasing opposition to the administration's favored strategic weapons. Asked on Thursday whether colleagues shared the two senators' sentiments, regarding the defense budget, Cohen said there were several Republicans and Democrats on the Armed Services panel ``who have yet to identify themselves.'' ``Is it a majority yet, I think not,'' Cohen said. ``A majority in a month or two, perhaps.'' McCain said at the senators' news conference, ``Unfortunately, the administration and our leadership here in Congress has failed to come up with a comprehensive plan.'' He and Cohen discounted Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's position that this is a transitional year and the Bush administration should wait before making major cuts in the Pentagon budget. ``By waiting another year ... we run the risk of having numbers plucked out of the air arbitrarily and then being forced to cut and paste our defense structure to meet budget numbers,'' Cohen said. Asked about the pace of Pentagon recommendations for change, McCain said, ``Bureaucracies respond with incredible glacial-like speed.'' Cheney, when told of the Cohen-McCain proposal Thursday, defended his own as ``a responsible plan that does in fact respond to the developments we've seen in the world in the last six months.'' He also said that while no decision has been made to submit a revised Pentagon budget for 1991, the results of major aircraft reviews may lead to piecemeal proposals to further reduce 1991 spending. ``There may be some decisions ... that you'll want to feed into the '91 budget process.'' He said the department would make decisions ``within the next few weeks.'' Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Armed Services Committee, complained recently that the Bush budget had several major blanks that Congress would fill if the administration didn't. Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, has criticized the Pentagon spending plan for its ``disconnects,'' what he sees as its failure to account for the rapid changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union. And on Wednesday, a bipartisan group of senators renewed their plea for canceling the B-2 bomber. They released a Congressional Budget Office report concluding that stretching out the program over a longer term would push the cost of each plane to more than $1 billion. Under the Cohen-McCain plan, the program to build 132 of the stealth aircraft at a total cost of more than $70 billion would be curtailed. Cohen, however, said he favors canceling the plane. McCain, a proponent of the B-2 last year, said he favors limiting production but indicated he could go either way on killing the program. Both senators acknowledged that the radar-evading plane is in serious trouble in Congress. ``It was in trouble long before our statements,'' McCain said. Later in the day, Nunn said the B-2 bomber faces considerable opposition and either the per unit cost or the total number of B-2 bombers has to be cut for the program to fly. ``Any time you have a weapons system start showing up on `Saturday Night Live' and in the cartoons, you know it's got problems. The B-2 is in that category,'' said Nunn, a proponent of the plane. McCain and Cohen also predicted that Congress will not support two land-based, nuclear missiles _ the multiple-warhead, rail-garrison MX and the road-mobile, single-warhead Midgetman. In their proposal, they called for negotiating with the Soviets a trade for the MX while continuing development of the smaller Midgetman missile. ``I feel we should look toward dramatic restructuring of our strategic capability'' to a two-pronged system rather than three, McCain said, ``composed of strategic aircraft capability and our submarine Trident forces.'' The senators also proposed a reduction in the overall number of ships, deferral of the Navy's version of the Advanced Tactical Fighter and a review of the Seawolf attack submarine program. Cheney said Wednesday that the Pentagon is taking a close look at the plan to buy the Seawolf. The submarine program, according to McCain, is in trouble in Congress. Cohen later added that a consensus is developing within the Senate Armed Services Committee and possibly the House Armed Services Committee to change the defense strategy. ``We have to reshape our forces whether we like it or not,'' he said. ``The answer is this is the reality. We've got to make the best of that reality.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Asks Judge for Dictionary
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Updates with jury's deliberations complete, request for dictionary.
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in the Iran-Contra coverup trial of former national security adviser John M. Poindexter provoked courtroom laughter Thursday by asking for a dictionary. The jury failed to reach a verdict in its fourth day of deliberations. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene summoned prosecutors and defense lawyers to the federal courthouse to discuss how he should handle the jury's request. Laughter broke out in the courtroom when the judge read the jury's note, which said, ``We need a dictionary please.'' Prosecutor Dan K. Webb told Greene he had no objection to giving jurors a dictionary unless they wanted to look up a legal term already defined in the judge's instructions. Turning to defense lawyer Richard Beckler, Greene asked: ``You have some Supreme Court cases on that?'' Beckler said he opposed giving the panel a dictionary. But the defense lawyer didn't object to Greene's proposal to send the jury a note offering to provide a definition of a common word. The judge said he didn't want to send jurors a dictionary because ``the next thing you know they will look up conspiracy and they'll know more than we do.'' After a 10-minute recess, during which Greene sent a note to the jury, the judge took the bench. Struggling to suppress a laugh, he read the jury's reply to his note: ``The definition we required before is no longer needed.'' The jury's request interrupted an otherwise uneventful day of deliberations. The jury has been sequestered since Tuesday after two jurors reported receiving telephone calls from reporters. Poindexter, a retired Navy rear admiral who served as then-President Reagan's top national security adviser from late 1985 until the unraveling of the Iran-Contra affair in November 1986, is charged with five felony counts. Poindexter, 53, is accused of conspiring with former aide Oliver L. North and others to make false statements and destroy documents to obstruct congressional inquiries in 1986 about both elements of the Iran-Contra affair. He is also accused of obstructing Congress and making false statements by assuring lawmakers that the National Security Council staff was not covertly helping arm the Nicaraguan rebels when such assistance had been banned by law. The indictment also charges that Poindexter lied to Congress on Nov. 21, 1986, when he said he did not learn of U.S. involvement in a 1985 shipment of Israeli Hawk missiles to Iran until two months after it occurred. The panel of eight women and four men is considering three weeks of testimony, including videotaped testimony from Reagan, and reviewing nearly 100 exhibits.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney Proposes New Measures to Cut Officer Corps
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 5 grafs after 14th graf, bgng: Cheney said xxx to UPDATE with comment from Nunn.
DOC.TEXT: The Defense Department asked Congress Thursday for new powers to reduce the officer corps, including authority to demote some officers to enlisted status if they refuse a transfer from active duty to the reserves. The department also proposed reducing its oversight of defense contractors as a cost-saving measure and called on Congress to give the Pentagon more leeway in managing its budget.
