The proposals were contained in a pair of reports to Congress that Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said were aimed at improving Pentagon management, limiting wasteful spending and improving relations between the department and Congress. Donald Atwood, the deputy defense secretary, said the department needs wider authority to reduce the officer ranks in order to maintain a balanced force as troops are demobilized. The force will shrink by at least 90,000 people over the next two years, he said, and more cuts are likely in the years beyond. He did not say how many officers might be cut. Atwood said the personnel proposals, which include incentives for officers to voluntarily leave the service, seek to avoid harming morale in the all-volunteer force. ``These are people who have decided to make the military their career, and we need to have the flexibility to let them leave with honor, with dignity and with some kind of a financial benefit,'' Atwood told a news conference. The department recently proposed to Congress that enlisted personnel who are forced out of the service be given severance pay. Currently only officers qualify for severance benefits. Atwood also said the Pentagon was seeking legislative authority to reduce its monitoring of contractors' work. He said this would make the defense acquisition process more like a commercial business and thus more cost effective. He said current law forces the Pentagon to use more inspectors and auditors of suppliers' work than is necessary to ensure the work is performed properly. ``We almost have to assume there's a dishonest atmosphere out there'' among contractors, he said. ``We believe that by reducing the degree of inspections and audits that we put on these contractors, we can save money and we feel we'll get better products.'' Cheney, speaking at the same news conference, said that while the Pentagon could improve its own management system, Congress was partly to blame for inefficiencies in the department. In a 41-page policy paper sent to Capitol Hill on Thursday, Cheney decried the ``tyranny of the annual budget review'' by Congress. He said the six major committees that deliberate on the defense budget every year should dwell more on overall military goals and less on the particulars of individual weapons programs. Cheney said the congressional budget writers give the Pentagon sometimes contradictory instructions and require too much paperwork to justify budget requests. He recommended that Congress appropriate defense money for two-year periods instead of every year. Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, gave high marks to Cheney's proposal, saying ``this overall thrust will be well received on Capitol Hill.'' Nunn said he will join Sen. John Warner, R-Va., ranking GOP member on the Armed Services panel, in presenting Cheney's package as legislation in the Senate. ``I think Secretary Cheney is absolutely correct when he says that what we've got to have is cooperation not confrontation between the Department of Defense and Congress,'' Nunn told a news conference. ``I also agree and have said things very similar to what he said about Congress' role should be broad policy and not getting into every detail.'' Nunn said his committee has done its best on crafting a two-year defense budget but he said ``until we get an overall budget by the White House that gives us the second year of numbers other than defense ... there is no hope of getting a two-year defense budget authorized and appropriated.'' Cheney reacted coolly to a proposal Thursday by Republican Sens. William Cohen of Maine and John McCain of Arizona to cut spending on the B-2 stealth bomber and land-based nuclear missiles as part of additional reductions in the 1991 defense budget. ``The budget we've sent up there is the one we think is the right one,'' he said, adding later that the department might recommend further cuts later this year after the completion of internal reviews of major aircraft programs, including the B-2.

DOC.HEAD: IRS Returns Property of Redd Foxx
DOC.TEXT: Comedian Redd Foxx got a truckload of personal property back from the Internal Revenue Service, but a gift watch from Elvis Presley, other expensive jewelry and eight cars will be auctioned to pay back taxes. The comedian, who made his mark as a junk man in the 1970s TV series ``Sanford and Son,'' is facing both the ire of the IRS and a bankruptcy court. Not long after Foxx said he had been ``whitelisted'' and ``whiteballed'' by racism in the the IRS, the agency countered with allegations that he spent $373,000 of his $500,000 take from the film ``Harlem Nights'' on ``wine, women, song and gambling.'' Agents raided his home in November to seize his property, and Foxx was left with only a bed. Estimates of his tax bill have ranged from $750,000 to $2.9 million. Foxx filed for bankruptcy in 1983, but his tax problems continued to mount. Efforts to sell his personal property at auction were halted in February when the question was raised whether the bankruptcy court or the IRS had jurisdiction over the property. Foxx said he was pleased with the return of the personal items Wednesday, but declined further comment. ``Mr. Foxx has made a psychological break from those items and is simply happy to have his personal property back,'' Foxx's attorney, Marc Risman, said of the items to be auctioned. Risman said a repayment agreement had been worked out with the IRS, which has been taking his weekly paycheck, estimated at $20,000. The Las Vegas resident now performs at the Hacienda Hotel. Risman said Foxx would make installment payments on current and past taxes and will get to keep enough money to cover his living expenses.

DOC.HEAD: Indiana Senator's Plan Gets Cool Reception In Northwest
DOC.TEXT: An Indiana congressman called Thursday for the creation of a National Ancient Forest Reserve System to protect old forests in the Pacific Northwest, but lawmakers from the region said they don't appreciate his help. ``The ancient forests of Washington, Oregon and California are not less a part of our natural heritage than the Grand Canyon, the Everglades or Yosemite,'' Rep. Jim Jontz, D-Ind., said. ``These great forests of the Northwest are truly a national treasure.'' Jontz was joined by the leaders of five environmental groups in unveiling his proposal to identify significant areas of ``ancient forests'' and designate reserve areas that would be ``managed and protected to maintain the biological integrity of the ancient forest ecosystem.'' Jontz' proposal was endorsed by the National Audubon Society, the Sierra Club, The Wilderness Society, the National Wildlife Federation and the Ancient Forest Alliance. Logging and road-building activites would be prohibited within the designated areas under the proposal. The congressman's involvement in the debate over the Northwest's timber supply crisis has drawn criticism from politicians in the region, who view him as an outsider with no sympathy toward the economic impact on timber-based communities of his proposal. ``All I will say is that I know that Indianans are experts on overcutting the forests because a couple of centuries ago they completed the job in their own state so now they are bringing their expertise to Oregon,'' Rep. Les AuCoin, D-Ore., said. Sen. Bob Packwood, R-Ore., said he was not familiar with Jontz or his proposal. ``I think I'll introduce a bill to break up all the dams on his private rivers,'' the senator quipped. Jontz said he should not be viewed as an outsider. ``These are national forests. As national forests, all of us have a stake in their future,'' he said. Under Jontz' bill, the secretaries of agriculture and interior would have 45 days to produce maps targeting areas of ``ancient and associated forests'' to be protected. In addition to housing trees as old as 250 to 1,000 years old, the characteristics of ancient forests include a mixed canopy conifer, certain numbers of live species of trees and a certain density of snags and down logs, he said. Associated forests would be defined as forest and lands which are not ancient forests but ``are still necessary to retain the integrity of the ecosystem,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Undercover Police End Sting Against Upscale Prostitution
DOC.TEXT: Federal agents raided high-priced call girl escort services around the country, culminating a two-year, $2.5 million money-laundering sting, authorities said Thursday. ``These are not street-level hookers. The average receipts were for $800 to $1,000 an evening,'' said Maurice Dettmer, chief of criminal investigations for the Internal Revenue Service. The raids on more than 40 escort services late Wednesday and early Thursday culminated what investigators called the nation's largest concerted attack on upscale prostitution. The probe targeted escort services that accept credit cards, Dettmer said. Agents created phony businesses in Atlanta and in Tampa to process and disguise more than 25,000 credit-card receipts for escort services from 23 cities in 15 states, he said. The businesses, given the name Sunset Enterprises, often disguised the credit-card charges for copying services or converted the charges to cash or loans for escort services or massage parlors, authorities said. The $2.5 million in charged payments represented only about one-quarter of the $10 million to $12 million the escort services took in in gross earnings, Dettmer said. Agents charged a 13 percent to 18 percent fee, said Tampa police spokesman Steve Cole. Typically, a call girl would collect $500, the escort service $300 and the agents $200, Cole said. Local authorities said the clients included politicians, entertainers, athletes, business executives using company credit cards, doctors, lawyers and clergymen, but they gave no details of the clients. ``We expect a lot of bosses and wives will be looking through receipts this evening to see if they say Sunset Enterprises, not to mention nervous businessmen,'' Cole said. Federal and state agents armed with warrants searched the escort-service companies for records of prostitution activities, income and expenses, and names of customers and their credit card charges, said U.S. Attorney Robert Genzman. ``Also sought was evidence relative to alleged money-laundering activities by escort-service operators to conceal an estimated $10 million in gross earnings in alleged credit-card fraud,'' Genzman said. Authorities recently made three arrests in California and one each in Fort Lauderdale, Atlanta and Dallas during the investigation. After the raids, more arrests were expected, authorities said. They said federal money-laundering and tax-evasion charges could be expected. State racketeering and organized crime charges also could be filed. ``If there are substantial amounts of charges for escort services on a corporate or business credit card that would be a strong likelihood there's been false tax deductions and they may hear from the IRS,'' said Dettmer. Agents used the telephone directory to find escort services that accepted credit cards. ``The reason they take credit cards is because businessmen traveling have company credit cards, companies then deduct it as a business expense,'' Dettmer said. Most escort services would pay to disguise credit-card charges as going to a copying service, said an agent who worked on the operation in Savannah, Ga. The sting began in Tampa on a small scale and grew like a spider web, Cole said. As word spread, agents in the storefront contacted the IRS after they were bombarded with laundering requests from as many as 100 companies. Agents then sent out letters soliticing business, Cole said. The escort service would send charge slips to the Tampa office. Agents would make up another slip in the name of Sunset Enterprises and send it on to the bank. The bank would send the money to Sunset and the agents in turn would pay the escort service with checks that looked like tax-free loans.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Ponder $500,000 Reward in Mail-Bomb Probe
DOC.TEXT: The FBI and other federal agencies investigating bombings that killed a U.S. judge and a civil rights lawyer are considering offering a $500,000 reward, a law enforcement source said Thursday. The decision on a reward for information leading to the arrest of a suspect has not been made pending coordination among the various federal agencies involved in the case, said the source, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. The Dec. 16 murder of Circuit Judge Robert S. Vance also being investigated by the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms and U.S. postal inspectors. The U.S. Marshals Service, which is responsible for protecting federal judges, may also contribute to a reward fund, if one is established, said the source. Vance, a member of the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals, was killed by an explosion when he opened a package sent to his home in suburban Birmingham, Ala. Two days later, a similar bomb killed a Savannah, Ga., city councilman and civil rights lawyer, Robert Robinson. Package bombs that law enforcement officials say are similar to the ones that killed Vance and Robinson were found and defused at the offices of the 11th Circuit Court of Appeals in Atlanta and the Jacksonville, Fla., chapter of the NAACP. Officials had considered offering a reward several months ago, but rejected the idea at the time because they did not want to give the appearance that the investigation had reached an impasse. Investigators are also trying to find the source of a series of anonymous letters, dating back to one sent last August, to news organizations threatening violence against the 11th Circuit.

DOC.HEAD: Wendy Lee Gramm Retained as Commission Chairwoman
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday he will retain Wendy Lee Gramm as chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission. Mrs. Gramm was named to the commission in 1988, and previously served as administrator for information in the Office of Management and Budget. If confirmed by the Senate, her term will run until April 13, 1995. Mrs. Gramm is the wife of Sen. Phil Gramm, R-Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Bizarre Airport Siege Ends with Soldier's Escape After 3 Days
DOC.TEXT: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti (AP) _ A bizarre three-day siege at Haiti's international airport ended Thursday when a soldier who threatened to blow up an empty American Airlines jet jumped from the plane and escaped into a field of grass outside the main air terminal. Pvt. Gerald Pierre, 20, who commandeered the Airbus A300 in an apparent attempt to desert the army, vanished into the darkness at about 1 a.m., according to Radio Haiti Inter. Officials offered no explanation for how Pierre escaped police and soldiers guarding the airport, leading to speculation the army allowed him to flee to peacefully resolve the affair. ``The Army High Command conducted the operation. They haven't given their report yet,'' said Alfred Mentor, the Information Ministry director. The army had no immediate comment, and it was not known whether a search for Pierre was underway. Haiti-Inter, whose reporter witnessed the escape, said Pierre leaped from the plane in the early morning dark and raced across the tarmac toward a field of high grass near the terminal. Soldiers and police were guarding the airport but had not surrounded the 10-foot-high perimeter fence, and Pierre could have fled over an unguarded portion of it. Officials reopened the airport Thursday. It was closed Wednesday after Pierre reportedly fired a machine gun in the direction of a Haiti Trans-Air flight shortly after it landed on a flight from Miami. The U.S. Embassy said American Airlines would send investigators to examine the jet before it left the airport. Pierre had allowed passengers and crew members to leave the New York-bound Flight 658 on Monday shortly after seizing the jet. On Tuesday, he threatened to blow up the plane unless he was flown to United States, Radio Haiti-Inter said. Radio reports said Pierre, who also was an airport security guard, was carrying grenades and the machine gun when he took control of the U.S. plane. Pierre was trying to desert after being reprimanded by an officer for alleged insubordination, the reports said. He had served in the army two years. Radio Metropole said military authorities had offered Pierre immunity from prosecution if he surrendered and resigned from the army.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Around Western Plains And Great Lakes
DOC.TEXT: Snow extended from the Rockies to the western Plains on Thursday, snow showers fell around the Great Lakes, and thundershowers peppered the southern Plains with hail. Overnight and into Thursday morning, snow showers extended over sections of the Rockies and into the Plains. Overnight snowfall in Nebraska included 3 inches at Imperial and Kimball and an inch at Scottsbluff and Sidney. By early afternoon, snow fell over much of western Kansas, southwestern Nebraska, eastern Colorado and from southeastern through northwestern Wyoming. Rain extended from the remainder of Kansas to southeastern Missouri. Snowfall during the 6 hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 5 inches at Boulder, Colo.; 2 inches at Cheyenne, Wyo., and Lafayette, Colo.; and 1 inch at Denver, Fort Collins, Colo., Hill City, Kan., and Limon, Colo.. Afternoon snow showers were scattered over north-central New York state and from Upper Michigan to northern and east-central Lower Michigan, changing to rain from southeastern Lower Michigan to northeastern and central Indiana. Thundershowers were scattered over central Texas, western Arkansas and eastern Oklahoma. Thunderstorms produced half-inch diameter hail at Ashdown, Ark., and north of Van Buren, Ark. Small hail fell in parts of Oklahoma. Melbourne, Fla., tied its low-temperature record for April 5 at 44 degrees. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 19 degrees at Houghton, Mich., to 84 at Brownsville, Texas. The low for the Lower 48 states was 10 at Warroad, Minn.

DOC.HEAD: Lucky Lindy's Widow Authorizes Biography
DOC.TEXT: Author A. Scott Berg will write a biography of Charles A. Lindbergh, authorized by the pioneering aviator's widow, the Putnam Berkley Group announced Thursday. ``Impressed by the thoroughness, objectivity and compassion of his previous works, Anne Morrow Lindbergh has granted A. Scott Berg complete access to the heretofore restricted Charles A. Lindbergh collections at Yale University and the Missouri Historical Society,'' said Mrs. Lindbergh's attorney, James W. Lloyd. The 83-year-old widow of the man who first flew solo from the United States to France also granted Berg access to her personal papers. The permission is valid until the year 2000. Access to the Lindbergh collections by other researchers will be restricted while Berg completes his biography, the publisher said. ``Charles Lindbergh has been idolized and demonized ... and the truth remains to be revealed,'' said Berg. ``In the end, I feel a great life story will emerge _ one whose values are not only timely but also timeless.'' G.P. Putnam's Sons will publish the Lindbergh book in hardcover in the fall of 1997. A paperback edition will be issued by Berkley Books the following year. Berg graduated from Princeton University in 1971 and spent the next seven years expanding his senior thesis on Maxwell Perkins into the biography, ``Max Perkins: Editor of Genius,'' which won the American Book Award. His most recent book was the bestseller ``Goldwyn: A Biography,'' published last year.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Says Korean Companies Sold Military Goods To Unfriendly Nations
DOC.TEXT: A House Armed Services subcommittee on Thursday accused South Korean companies of violating U.S. contracts by selling military parts and weapons to unfriendly nations. Members of the investigations subcommittee made the charges as they urged the Bush administration to negotiate a strict contract with the Asian nation on a proposal to allow Korea to manufacture parts for and assemble FA-18 jets. Lawmakers expressed concerns that South Korea might sell the aircraft parts to Iran. ``They are selling to unfriendly countries for a lousy buck,'' Rep. Nicholas Mavroules, chairman of the subcommittee, said in a statement. ``When you negotiate this contract, make sure you get a tighter provision with tighter controls to prevent more diversions.'' The Massachusetts Democrat cited hearings last year in which it was revealed that Korean companies had sold M-16 rifles manufactured under a coproduction deal with the United States to unfriendly countries despite a ban on such sales. The names of the nations are classified. Mavroules said Thursday that Korean companies have been caught violating other coproduction contracts. In addition, he said the Asian nation has refused to allow U.S. officials access to the M-16 plant since the subcommittee's revelations last year. Rep. Larry J. Hopkins of Kentucky, ranking Republican on the panel, said: ``We have trusted them. We have caught them. And now we are preparing to sign another deal with them.'' The subcommittee held a closed-door hearing on Wednesday on the coproduction plan for the fighter which calls for the South Korean Air Force to acquire 120 FA-18 jets. Under the plan, Korea would buy the first 12 jets directly from the U.S. manufacturer, McDonnell-Douglas. The company would then supply kits to Korea to assemble the next 36 fighters. Korea would assemble the final 72 with many of the components made in Korea. The Navy estimates that the total value of the fighter coproduction contract for the United States is about $3 billion, some $400 million less than if all 120 aircraft were built in the United States. In releasing a statement on the hearing, the panel did not identify the unfriendly nations, but it include a page from the Daewoo Corp. annual report for 1988 which showed that the company had sales offices in Libya, Iran and Iraq. Mavroules said those nations have been the principal buyers of Korea's military exports from a number of Korean companies, including Daewoo. ``Isn't it in their interest to prove to us that they have cleaned up their act?'' Mavroules said of South Korea.

DOC.HEAD: Packwood Wants Economic Hardship Weighed In Spotted Owl Flap
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Bob Packwood said Thursday a special provision of the Endangered Species Act could allow logging to continue in the forests where the northern spotted owl lives, even if the bird is declared threatened or endangered. Lawmakers in the Pacific Northwest are concerned that efforts to save the owl from extinction will have a disastrous impact on the regional economy because large tracts of federal forests could be put off limits to loggers. Packwood, R-Ore., said in an interview Thursday the special provision in the act, allowing a committee to consider possible economic hardship, may provide a way to continue logging. ``When the Fish and Wildlife Service decides on the listing, it is allowed to consider only biological factors. But this special committee can also consider economic factors,'' Packwood said. The special committee would consist of the U.S. secretaries of agriculture, interior and army, the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisors, the head of the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Administration and one individual from each of the states effected. ``They would have the power to set aside the listing. In essence, they could allow whatever economic activities to continue, even if the species is listed,'' Packwood said. ``They would have to be sure to try not to affect the species. But they would have the power to allow the continuation of logging if they decided the payments to schools, the jobs of mill workers and the economic viability of Oregon are more important than the owl,'' he said. A request for the convening of the committee can be made by the governor of a state effected, a federal agency involved in the case or an ``interested party,'' Packwood said. ``I don't know if I qualify as an interested party, but I don't think we would have any trouble finding someone to make the request. I'm going to call the governor of Oregon and talk about this,'' he said. Brock Evans, vice president of the National Audubon Society, said he doubted the special committee process would have any impact if the Fish and Wildlife Service decides to list the owl as threatened or endangered _ a decision due by June 23. ``We've said all along that the more public attention we get, the better off we are. We can't wait for this to become a national issue. I can see it now, the Today Show and everyone else would be running programs on us,'' he said. Evans said a report issued Wednesday by a government panel of scientists leaves no question that logging must stop across a large section of national forests in order to save the spotted owl. ``I think the science is overwhelming now. If a special extinction committee ruled against it, it would be clear that it was a blatant political act,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dozen Arrested in Raids Aimed at Basque Group
DOC.TEXT: Police arrested a dozen people and seized explosives, rockets and grenades in raids aimed a Basque terrorist group believed responsible for 29 murders, investigators said Thursday. Police identified only two of the suspects, all French, arrested in the raids Wednesday and Thursday. They were Frederic Haramboure, 36, and Jacques Esnal, 39. Both are suspected by Spanish authorities of plotting a car bombing with Frenchman Henri Barot, who was arrested Monday in Seville, Spain, with a car loaded with 660 pounds of explosives, police said. The raids on the southwest French Atlantic coast near the Spanish border included Bayonne, Saint-Jean-de-Luz, Urrugne and Guethary. They netted nearly nine pounds of explosives, three assault rifles, three machine-pistols, two handguns, three rockets and four grenades. Police claim Haramboure, Esnal and Barot belong to the Abertzalis terrorist group, which has strong links to the ETA movement that seeks independence for Spain's Basques. Spanish authorities believe the group is responsible for 29 deaths since 1978, among them two judges, three generals, a vice admiral and 11 soldiers, police said. ETA is not active in the Pyrenees regions of France, though members often cross the border to take refuge with sympathizers. At least 10 other people were held for questioning in what police described as the largest anti-ETA operation carried out on French soil in a decade. ETA, whose initials stand for Homeland and Liberty in the Basque language, has killed more than 600 people since 1968 in its campaign for independence for the three-province Spanish Basque region.

DOC.HEAD: Conyers Writes Pentagon About Unisys Computers
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of a House panel called on the Pentagon to stop accepting orders of computer hardware and software from the Unisys Corp. that may not meet specifications. ``It appears that Air Force personnel may have improperly waived, ignored or postponed compliance with technical requirements of the contract,'' Rep. John Conyers Jr., D-Mich., said in letters dated March 29 but released Thursday. Conyers' House Government Operations Committee has been investigating the Air Force contract with Unisys for 250,000 of its Desktop III computer systems after receiving allegations of mismanagement. The eight-year contract is estimated at more than $1.5 billion, said a committee staffer who requested anonymity. In a letter to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, Conyers urged that the Air Force tell the company not to ship products or accept orders until specific actions had been taken. Among those steps is requiring Unisys to correct all functional test demonstration deficiencies within a reasonable time and according to the contract's provisions. In addition, Conyers said, the Air Force should restest each corrective action by Unisys to ensure compliance with the contract.

DOC.HEAD: Emergency Crews Pack Up as Fuel Spill Dissipates
DOC.TEXT: Emergency crews packed up their gear and city water officials in West Virginia and Ohio breathed easier Thursday as a fuel spill in the Ohio River dissipated to nearly undetectable levels. ``It's evaporating and emulsifying to the point where we're not actively monitoring it anymore,'' said Jeanne Ison, a spokeswoman for the Ohio River Valley Water Sanitation Commission. ``Our crews are on their way home.'' The diluted spill is all that remains of at least 75,000 gallons of diesel oil, gasoline and kerosene that spilled into a tributary of the Allegheny River above Pittsburgh last Friday, forcing western Pennsylvania cities to close water intakes. The Allegheny and Monongahela rivers meet in Pittsburgh to form the Ohio River. Officials in Toronto, Ohio, and Weirton, W.Va., near the Pennsylvania border said they planned to keep river water intakes closed until Friday afternoon. Both towns shut down their water filtration plants Wednesday in anticipation of the spill. ``We're running on wells, 100 percent now,'' said Larry Coxen, foreman at the Weirton water treatment plant. ``We don't want to take any chances. We're meeting all our demands and we'll probably go with the wells another day just to make sure.'' Across the river in Steubenville, Ohio, officials mixed activated carbon and chemicals with river water to remove any remaining petroleum. ``So far, we haven't picked up anything that's noticeable, even before the water is treated,'' said John West, an operator at the Steubenville plant. ``We're operating normally. There's not a whole lot of concern here ...'' Twenty-five miles upstream, at East Liverpool, Ohio, two water intakes near the river's surface remained closed to avoid floating or suspended oil. A deeper intake remained open to draw water for the town of 7,000. Officials at Wheeling, W.Va., about 25 miles downstream from Weirton, canceled an emergency planning meeting that had been scheduled for Thursday. ``To be honest, I haven't even talked to anybody about the spill in two days, that's how concerned we are,'' said Conrad Slanina, Wheeling's acting public works director. ``We don't anticipate any problems at all.'' ``It's gotten to the point where we can just have water plants check it for us,'' said Chris Norman, an environmental engineer at the Cincinnati-based Ohio River sanitation commission, which oversees pollution control on the river. ``The organic matter in the water has dissipated so much that it's easily treatable, but it does still need to be treated,'' Norman said. ``There should be no worry about drinking water and little concern about the spill's effect on wildlife.'' Pennsylvania officials on Thursday were assessing the damage to fish, insects and wildlife. Thomas J. Qualters of the State Fish Commission said authorities recovered about a dozen dead fish along the spill's path. He said more fish could have been killed but have not yet floated to the surface. The impact could be much more serious if the spill interfered with spawning, which occurs at this time of year for various species, said Qualters. Most Pennsylvania towns affected by the spill have returned to normal. Water conservation measures remained in effect in six Pennsylvania communities and residents of Harrison County, the only area where taps went dry, were still being advised to boil water as a precaution. Guillermo Cole, a spokesman for the Allegheny County (Pa.) Water Department, said tests conducted Wednesday indicated the water is nearly back to normal. But health officials were concerned about globs of oil that could get into some intakes.

DOC.HEAD: Groundwater Tests To Be Conducted In Nine States
DOC.TEXT: The Corn Belt has been selected for a new testing program designed to protect groundwater from contamination by fertilizers and pesticides, Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter said Wednesday. Yeutter said the research, scheduled to begin this summer, will be undertaken on farmland overlying aquifers in nine states: Iowa, Kansas, Minnesota, Missouri, Nebraska, North Dakota, South Dakota, Ohio and Wisconsin. The research is part of a government-wide water quality initiative provided in the Bush administration's budget requests, he said. Spending for all of the Agriculture Department's water quality activities this year is budgeted at $158 million, compared with $112.7 million last year, Yeutter said. The administration's request for the fiscal 1991 year that will begin Oct. 1 is for $207 million. Yeutter said about $3.7 million of this year's funds has been targeted for the Corn Belt projects. C. Richard Amerman of the department's Agricultural Research Service said the sites were selected because corn and soybeans are grown extensively, using relatively large amounts of agricultural chemicals. Amerman, who is executive secretary of USDA's working group on water quality, said researchers ``will evaluate the environmental and economic impacts of various farming practices'' on underground water supplies. ``We also will develop and implement new farming practices,'' he said. ``In each area, we'll seek advice from farm, community, agribusiness and environmental representatives.'' Amerman said the project ``should have broad national significance'' because information from it can be applied to other parts of the country.

DOC.HEAD: De Klerk, Mandela Meet, Set New Date for Power-Sharing Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with Mandela quotes, details. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CPN1
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela agreed Thursday on a new date for formal talks between the government and the African National Congress on giving blacks a share of political power in South Africa. De Klerk and Mandela, freed Feb. 11 by the president after 27 years in prison, met for three hours but said the time and place for talks to replace a canceled April 11 meeting would be announced later. The two did not appear together afterwards. Instead, at separate news conferences, de Klerk said he objected to the ANC pressuring some tribal homeland leaders not to meet with the government earlier Thursday while Mandela said ``nothing could be further from the truth'' than charges of ANC intimidation. Next Wednesday's talks were to have been the government's first meeting with a delegation of exiled and internal ANC leaders, but the ANC canceled to protest against police firing on demonstrators, killing at least 11 protesters. De Klerk said he was considering appointing a judicial inquiry into the March 26 shootings in Sebokeng, south of Johannesburg, and that an investigation had begun. Mandela said the inquest being presided over by a white judge was not conducive to gaining the black community's confidence. He said an inquiry commission should include credible black leaders. De Klerk said they also discussed the widespread political violence in the country ``frankly and clearly. ... I had the impression that there is a general agreement that violence had to come to an end and that there was a need for creating an atmosphere in which normal political processes could take place.'' Mandela said ``solid progress'' had been made in a ``cordial and productive'' atmosphere. The talks were intended to discuss black factional violence that has left hundreds dead in recent weeks, and to help prepare for formal negotiations on a new constitution to give blacks a share of power in South Africa. Earlier Thursday during an impromptu news conference, de Klerk said, ``I don't have a problem finding anyone to sit down with me. I just have a problem with those who want to sit down and who don't want to allow others to sit down with them.'' Mandela and other ANC leaders have called for unity among all black political factions in order to present a solid front at eventual negotiations with the white-minority government. De Klerk said some homeland leaders had been pressured not to come and ``that choice was not voluntary in any sense of the word.'' However, every homeland leader that the government-run television interviewed Thursday night denied being pressured by the ANC. Mandela said he spoke to three of the homeland leaders after they had told him of their decision not to meet with the government. De Klerk told reporters that during his meeting with Mandela, ``I made the point that no one should inhibit discussions which need to take place on the widest possible scale.'' In addition to Mandela, de Klerk had been scheduled to meet with six homeland leaders, but four did not show up. However, many South African officials and observers believe the ANC canceled the meeting because of internal disagreements about how to proceed with negotiations. De Klerk and his Cabinet have repeated that they want all currently recognized leaders to participate in negotiations. But the ANC does not recognize the legitimacy of homeland governments and their leaders. It says the plan of dividing black South Africans into 10 tribal areas deprives them of their citizenship, land ownership and work rights and leaves the majority of the country for whites. Four of the 10 homelands have accepted independence, but they are not recognized as independent by other countries. Those leaders were not invited to the talks. Of the six who were invited, two showed up: KwaZulu chief minister Mangosuthu Buthelezi and Qwaqwa chief minister Kenneth Mopeli. Buthelezi heads the Zulu tribe's conservative Inkatha movement and is seen as Mandela's main black rival. Meanwhile in Venda, the smallest of the so-called independent homelands, there was a report of a coup Thursday over the issue of independence. A radio announcement in the homeland said Frank Ravele, president of Venda, was overthrown in a military coup. The deputy chief of Venda's Defense Force, Gabriel Ramushwana, said he wanted the homeland reincorporated into South Africa and staged the coup.

DOC.HEAD: District Police Chief Says Federal Anti-Drug Efforts Failing
DOC.TEXT: The federal initiative to stem drug abuse and related violence in the nation's capital has failed, the city's police chief said Thursday. A spokesman for federal drug policy coordinator William J. Bennett also said one lesson learned from the year-long effort was that ``civic resolve'' is needed to make any anti-drug program a success. A senior spokesman for Bennett later backed away from that comment, saying Bennett doesn't believe Washington residents lack the resolve needed to reduce drug abuse. Isaac Fulwood, the District of Columbia's police chief, acknowledged that the special anti-drug effort announced a year ago by Bennett has not lived up to expectations. ``I think there's enough blame to go around for everybody,'' Fulwood said. ``I would say everything has failed right now because we haven't turned it around. Victory won't be declared until we stop the murders.'' However, City Administrator Carol B. Thompson said: ``We think we have made great strides in addressing the problem.'' The federal government originally promised to direct an extra $100 million to drug programs in the district, primarily for additional jail space. That money has gone unspent because the city has failed to agree on a plan for jail construction. The administration also assigned military prosecutors to district drug cases, offered money for new drug treatment centers and established a special Drug Enforcement Administration team. Bennett spokesman David Robb said Thursday that one of the lessons learned from the special effort was that ``lack of civic resolve on the part of citizens in any city can block efforts'' to control the drug problem. But Don Hamilton, Bennett's main spokesman, later disavowed Robb's comment. ``It is not the view of the office or of director Bennett that there is any lack of resolve on the part of the citizens of the District or anywhere else'' to combat drugs, Hamilton said. ``We don't believe there is a lack of citizen resolve.'' Robb had cited the district's failure to find a site for a pre-trial detention center that Bennett pushed a year ago when he announced the intensified battle against drugs. ``Everyone needs to play a part in this,'' Robb said. ``That's the lesson that you learn from D.C.'' Robb and Hamilton both refused to confirm or deny whether the 12-month report on federal efforts to curtail Washington's drug problem will say it's been a failure, as The New York Times reported. ``We have committed ourselves to report on both successes and failures every six months,'' Robb said. Bennett and city officials said a news conference to announce the update has been scheduled for April 13. There have been 127 homicides in the nation's capital so far in 1990. The city recorded a record 438 in 1989. Authorities have blamed more than 60 percent on drugs. Unidentified federal officials told the Times that Washington has failed to demonstrate a commitment to control drug abuse. The sources blamed Bennett, saying he oversold the program and failed to back up his promises with federal funds, the newspaper reported. Both city and federal officials agreed that illegal drugs remain relatively cheap and plentiful and drug-related murders have not abated. ``We need to improve the lines of communication,'' Fulwood said. Fulwood said the city has made progress in expanding community-based street patrols and other anti-crime programs. Hamilton said the report was not completed. ``I don't think we're going to say everything in D.C. is hunky-dory and we should get a ride down Pennsylvania Avenue on rose petals, but the report's not done yet,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dixon Asks Bush To Explain Why Executive Order Not Issued
DOC.TEXT: Sen. Alan Dixon, D-Ill., asked President Bush on Thursday to explain why he has not issued an executive order ensuring that Chinese students would not be sent home against their will. ``I am quite concerned about recent statements from the White House spokesman, Mr. (Marlin) Fitzwater, concerning your promise to issue an executive order protecting the Chinese students in this country,'' Dixon said in a letter to Bush. Fitzwater said Wednesday that Bush did not issue the order covering the students _ as he said in January he would _ and relied instead on a directive by Attorney General Dick Thornburgh. That directed the head of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to protect the Chinese students, many of whom did not want to return home after last June's crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators. But Dixon said Bush should issue the executive order as promised. If Bush does not take such action, Dixon said he will introduce legislation to protect the students as their visas to study in the United States expire. Similiar legislation became a target of controversy earlier this year. Congress passed it, but it was vetoed by Bush. The House overrode the veto, but in the Senate the override effort fell short of the necessary two-thirds majority.

DOC.HEAD: Fierce Shelling Kills 14, Shatters Truce in Lebanon
DOC.TEXT: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with new fighting ends brief cease-fire. No pickup

Savage shelling broke out at sundown Thursday between rival Christian forces, leaving 14 people dead, east Beirut ablaze and shattering a brief cease-fire requested by church leaders. Flames lighted the night sky. Huge clouds of smoke obscured much of the embattled Christian enclave north of the capital as shells and rockets rained down from mountaintop and coastal positions. ``Hundreds of cars are smoldering and dozens of apartment buildings as well as hospitals and churches are burning. Nothing is being spared,'' said a police spokesman, who gave the toll as 14 dead and 27 wounded. ``Thousands of families in east Beirut and Jounieh are in basements and bomb shelters seeking refuge from the mad bombardment.'' Police said the four-story building housing renegade Gen. Michel Aoun's radio and television stations in east Beirut's Hazmiyeh district was burning after taking a barrage of phosphorous bombs. Both stations went off the air. Aoun's gunners targeted the Voice of Lebanon radio station and the Lebanese Broadcasting Corp. TV station, outlets of the Lebanese Forces militia of his rival Christian military chief, Samir Geagea, the spokesman said. ``We're taking a lot of shells but so far we're all okay,'' said an announcer over Voice of Lebanon. The station's 14-story building is in east Beirut's Ashrafiyeh district. Lebanese Broadcasting's TV station in the Christian port of Jounieh, 12{ miles north of Beirut, said shells fell near its buildings but it was not hit. A salvo set off fiery explosions at a Lebanese Forces ammunition depot in Jeita near Jounieh, said the police spokesman, whose name cannot be used under standing rules. The struggle for control of the Christian enclave has killed 855 people and wounded 2,325 since it began Jan. 30, and inflicted $1 billion worth of damage. The violence broke a lull of a few hours after Aoun and Geagea told their fighters to abide by a truce called by Maronite Catholic clergymen. It was the 16th cease-fire in the fighting _ and the shortest. Twenty Maronite church leaders under Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir warned that the Geagea-Aoun war was threatening the Christians' ``very existence in Lebanon and the Orient.'' Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi told an agricultural delegation that visited him in Moslem west Beirut his government was prepared to take over control of all army garrisons in the Christian enclave. But he did not indicate he was ready to order his 22,000 predominantly Moslem troops, under Gen. Emile Lahoud, to force their way into the Christian enclave. Hrawi's address was broadcast by several radio stations. In what appeared to be a call to Aoun's troops to give up their loyalty to the general, Hrawi said, ``I hope that the military in the eastern areas will be true to its oath of maintaining loyalty to Lebanon ... not to individuals.'' Because of the confrontation, about 250,000 people _ one-quarter of the Christian enclave's original 1 million population _ have fled the region to seek refuge in safer areas of Lebanon and in neighboring countries. Aoun, Geagea, Hrawi and Lahoud are Maronites, the largest Christian community in Lebanon. The Maronites have traditionally controlled key government posts, the army command, and judiciary since independence from France in 1943. Hrawi was elected by Lebanon's parliament that also adopted a peace plan last year giving Moslems a 50 per cent share of power. Aoun balked, and refused to accept Hrwai's presidency and Hrawi's dismissal of him as army commander. The clergymen called the cease-fire hours after Geagea said he was prepared to hand over to Lahoud the three army camps in the Kersrouan and Byblos provinces controlled by his militia north of Beirut.

DOC.HEAD: Report: EGerman Police Tapped Kohl, WGerman Officials' Phones
With AM-East Germany
DOC.TEXT: The former East German secret police eavesdropped on the telephone conversations of Chancellor Helmut Kohl, President Richard von Weiszaecker and at least 10,000 other West German officials, a newspaper reported Thursday. Cabinet ministers, businessmen and the leadership of the armed forces also had their phones tapped, the conservative West German daily Die Welt said in an article released to news media in advance of its publication Friday. The outgoing Communist-led government ordered the hated secret police, known as Stasi, dissolved in December following a peaceful revolution that ousted dictator Erich Honecker. There were numerous demonstrations and violent takeovers of secret police buildings by angry citizens. The Stasi force once had 85,000 paid agents and more than 100,000 informers among East Germany's 16 million citizens. The huge eavesdropping operation was performed with powerful transmitters and computers stationed in East Germany and neighboring Czechoslovakia, the newspaper said. The computers were programmed to recognize certain numbers and could even pick up calls placed from telephones with secret numbers, Die Welt said. The article cited unidentified Western security officials as saying the folders with the secret numbers must be kept from falling into the hands of the Soviet KGB. The Stasi's special monitoring service was saved from dissolution by the army, which continued to monitor the West German telephone calls despite growing links between the two German states and during East Germany's free elections last month, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Authorizes Aid, But Leaves Without Appropriating The Money
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Thursday approved legislation authorizing U.S. aid to the new democratic governments in Panama and Nicaragua, but President Bush's deadline for action on a more important money bill for those countries slipped by without a vote. On a voice vote, the Senate approved a measure that would permit spending of up to $470 million this year to aid Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua. It also included $30 million for Africa and $70 million to pay costs of resettling Soviet Jewish emigres in the United States. The new spending would be paid for through cuts in the Pentagon budget in what amounts to the government's first application of a ``peace dividend'' from reduced East-West tensions. To provide aid to the two Central American countries, Congress must first authorize the aid programs, then pass separate legislation appropriating the money for them. Bush had sought completion of the entire cycle by Thursday, but Congress left for a 12-day Easter recess without doing so. The House has passed a $2.4 billion money bill that includes $420 million for Panama and $300 million for Nicaragua, but companion legislation to authorize the spending is mired in the Foreign Affairs Committee. The Senate passed its authorizing bill on Thursday, but will not act on the crucial money legislation until it returns to Washington on April 18. Aid proponents have argued that the two countries' economies, battered by U.S. trade sanctions and by military action, need quick infusions of aid to stabilize the new democratic governments and to demonstrate the benefits of democracy. ``We need to make sure democracy has a chance to take root and flourish,'' said Sen. Christopher Dodd, D-Conn. ``That's not going to happen if people find they are no better off tomorrow than they were yesterday.'' Administration officials said they now hope the aid measure can be completed by the time Nicaraguan President-elect Violeta Chamorro is inaugurated, on April 25.

DOC.HEAD: Castet's Furry Fashion Surprises
DOC.TEXT: Frederic Castet charged back into the fashion arena with several shows in his new fur and fashion shop this week. After 20 years as fur creator at Dior, Castet bowed out when new management came in over two years ago. Now, with backing from banks and friends, he has launched his own firm and boutique in the fashion district near the Champs-Elysees. And he's feeling bullish about furs, because France is a country where animal-rights campaigns are relatively modest. Many Frenchwomen are proud to wear coats from ``unendangered'' species, such as sable, fox or mink. In any case, Castet has covered all the options. He's patented a soft new fake fur called ``Castiss,'' which he uses cleverly in everything from white greatcoats to linings for mink. It looks a lot like sheared raccoon, beaver or even seal, depending on how Castet uses it. The show-stoppers were cartoon mink coats _ colorfully cut to show an Eiffel Tower in homage to France, a Statue of Liberty for the United States and a cheery tribesman for Africa. They were reminders of Castet's command of the leather-and-fur medium. He was the first to introduce ``pictures'' in mink coats at Dior some 15 years ago. But there was lots more to point up the talent of this creator from Toulouse in the south of France. The line also included beautifully cut trouser and short skirts suits in fine gabardine or cash wool, tulip-draped silk dresses, and several ensembles splashed with Castet's optimistic logo, a sunflower. Even more surprising were the cute young numbers such as leather shorts fringed in Tibetan lamb, topped by an organza blouse. If he has overall fashion versatility, it's not surprising. Castet started training very young following World War II with the Chambre Syndicale couture school, garnering a first prize. He then went on to work in general design creation for Balenciaga and Christian Dior. But his forte is still fur. His shortie coats or blouson styles, his ``sunray'' effects in 1940s-style minks, are given a snappy update and have peppy appeal for all ages. And the ``marquetry'' effect that Castet does in bands of dark Saga mink are nothing short of miraculous. After a show, Castet said that in spite of assistance, he'd really ended up doing everything himself. ``I need a vacation,'' he said, looking forward to a visit south. For those interested in Castet fashions, the prices are on the average level for luxury couture ready-to-wear, a couple of thousand dollars for a suit ensemble. Castet's coats vary tremendously, from about $1,000 or less for a Castiss fake leopard model blouson or flared coat to over $130,000 for the most elaborate sable creation. The shop also offers more affordable accessories, bracelets, belts, earrings based on the ``golden triangle'' or sunflower themes.

DOC.HEAD: Museum Heading Into Court as Controversial Exhibit Opens
LaserPhoto CS4
DOC.TEXT: A museum planning to exhibit sexually graphic photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe has signed up hundreds of patrons in the 10 days before Friday's opening, the director said. The 175-photograph exhibit includes nine pictures of nude children or homoerotic and sadomasochistic sex acts. It has prompted a police investigation and opposition from anti-pornography groups. Director Dennis Barrie said he expects 3,000 ticketholders to attend the opening, which is restricted to members of the Contemporary Arts Center. The exhibit opens to the public Saturday. ``We're going to have to regulate the flow into the gallery,'' Barrie said Thursday. ``We've handled about 1,000 people in here at once, but that was our maximum.'' About 400 people have paid $25 to $150 to become museum patrons in the last 10 days, Barrie said. In a normal 1{-week stretch, the museum would be lucky to sign 10 members, he said. The Arts Center sued city and county law enforcement officials, seeking a decision on whether the exhibit violates local obscenity standards. A hearing on the city's request to dismiss the lawsuit was scheduled for Friday before Hamilton County Muncipal Judge Edward L. Donnellon. Assistant City Solicitor Karl P. Kadon III said he intends to argue that the lawsuit is based on ``hypothetical facts'' because police haven't taken any action against the museum. An attorney for the museum, Marc Mezibov, said the lawsuit is justified because of the public dispute over the exhibit and police threats of criminal charges. Attorneys for the Arts Center on Wednesday filed a motion in the lawsuit for a judgment by Donnellon that the entire exhibit is constitutionally protected because it is art, despite the sexually graphic pictures. If Donnellon does not grant a judgment, the case would go to trial. In a supporting affidavit, Bruce H. Evans, director of the Dayton Art Institute, said the exhibit demonstrates Mapplethorpe's skill as a photographer as well as the range of emotional reaction his works produce. ``It can be, for example, the breathtaking sense of simple beauty of a human figure or floral still-life or ... a gut-wrenching sense of disgust to acts of human sadism,'' Evans said. Mapplethorpe, who was born in Floral Park, N.Y., died of AIDS in March 1989 at the age of 42. Kadon said he couldn't comment on the request because he hadn't received a copy. Police Chief Larry Whalen has called the photographs criminally obscene but has not said whether police plan to file charges. Whalen did not return telephone calls Thursday seeking comment. More than 1,000 museum supporters staged a demonstration Wednesday protesting police involvement in the dispute. Barrie, the director, said he was surprised at the breadth of popular support. ``We hear it from people in grocery stores and on elevators,'' he said. ``I'm not exaggerating. I get on an elevator and total strangers tell me, `Keep the faith.'''

DOC.HEAD: Two Americans, Sherpa Guide Killed in Himalayan Climb
DOC.TEXT: Two Americans and their Sherpa guide died in an avalanche more than halfway up the world's seventh-highest mountain on the Nepal-Tibet border, the Tourism Ministry said Thursday. Charles Schertz, 35, of Pittsburgh, Nancy Jackson of Federal Way, Wash., and Nima Wanchu, 41, were found buried in the snow March 27 by other members of the American Manaslu Expedition, according to the Tourism Ministry and Dan McConnell, spokesman for the Seattle-based team. Nepalese officials said Jackson's passport said she was 43, but McConnell said she was 34. McConnell said two others escaped the accident, which occurred at the 15,510-foot level of Mount Manaslu, a 26,775-foot mountain in the Himalayan range. It is one of the Himalaya's lesser climbed peaks because of its remoteness. Climber Steve Steckmyer, 39, of Seattle, escaped the direct path of the avalanche, while another Sherpa was partially buried but pulled himself out. Steckmyer stayed behind to look for his teammates while the Sherpa descended to get help and ran into the other climbers, who were coming up from the base camp with gear, McConnell said. Poor communications delayed news of the deaths, said the Ministry of Tourism, which serves as a clearinghouse for Himalayan climbs. ``We are shocked and shattered by the loss of our good friends, Nancy, Charlie and Nima Wanchu in this tragic accident,'' team leader Don Goodman said in a news release. Goodman, of Mercer Island, Wash., flew to Katmandu, Nepal, and said the remaining members of the 12-person team abandoned the climb and would be returning home after the bodies are cremated at a monastery near Manaslu. McConnell said the team is not expected to return to the United States for 10-14 days. Jackson, an environmental engineer, climbed Mount Rainier more than 50 times as a guide during the 1980s and reached the summits of Mount McKinley in Alaska and Aconcagua in Argentina. Schertz, a physician, was one of two climbing doctors on the expedition. He was a member of the 1988 Northwest American Everest Expedition and part of the first American ascent of Cho Oyu in the Himalayas in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Health Officials Investigate Bacteria Blamed in 11 Denver-Area Deaths
DOC.TEXT: A rare, virulent form of strep is on the rise in at least six states and has been blamed for 11 Denver-area deaths, investigators trying to determine who else is at risk said Thursday. Another 29 cases have been reported in Denver in the last six months. The fatality rate is about 25 percent, health officials say. Investigations were under way in parts of Colorado, Alabama, Arizona, California, Maryland and Ohio, where severe strep clusters have been reported. Since Sept. 1, 40 severe strep case have been reported in those states, said Dr. Ben Schwartz, an epidemiologist in the CDC's respiratory disease branch in Atlanta. Forty severe strep cases have been reported since Sept. 1, Schwartz said. ``The strep bacteria has been around a million years and we're learning more about it to prevent people from getting it. It's actually rather mundane,'' Dr. Roger Gollub, epidemic intelligence service officer for the Colorado Department of Health, said in Denver. The outbreak ``has nothing to do with (common) strep throat,'' Gollub said. ``It's just the strep organism is involved.'' All the victims were elderly and suffering from other illnesses, too, Gollub said. Common strep symptoms are a sore throat, swollen glands and fever. They can be treated with penicillin. The severe form of strep is characterized by a sudden onset of a very high fever, chills, shock and low blood pressure. There also may be skin or muscle infections and pneumonia, the investigators said. The severe form, known as group A streptococcus bacteremia, gets past the body's primary defenses and enters the bloodstream through injury, infection from a surgical incision, or other ways that are still unclear. Much of the information on the disease that's been collected by the U.S. Centers for Disease Control has come from Denver, said Schwartz. Nationally, cases of severe strep have occurred at a rate of five per 10,000 population per year. Health officials around the country ``have expressed interest in working with us and we think it gives a good geographical, rural-urban mix to the investigation,'' Schwartz said. ``It's not because there have been any problems in those areas; it just gives us a better picture.'' Health officials started investigating the bacteria a year ago when a cluster of cases was noticed in Denver. ``A year ago a very smart, perceptive infection control nurse at a local hospital noticed nine cases in a six-week period and since then we have been looking into it,'' Gollub said. Schwartz said he did not want people getting the impression that they can die from strep throat or that the disease is rampant. ``The important thing to realize is that strep throat is very common, all kids get it and this is actually strep throat season,'' he said. ``Parents should really not be worrying that it is going to be turning into the severe disease.'' But, Schwartz said, if a parent believes that his child has strep throat, it should be diagnosed and treated. A Denver doctor is working with the World Health Organization to investigate a possible link with a reported strep outbreak in Europe. Schwartz said the CDC also is in contact with European health officials and has heard of some problems in Scandinavia and England.

DOC.HEAD: Pegasus Rocket Successfully Delivers First Payload into Space
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to CORRECT attribution in 2nd graf to chase plane pilot sted bomber pilot; ADDS quote from bomber pilot and Vice President Quayle; CORRECTS altitude to 43,000 sted 40,000 feet. Picks up 6th graf, `The 41,000-pound...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto EAB1
DOC.TEXT: An experimental Pegasus rocket was blasted into space Thursday from a B-52 and successfully delivered its first satellite payload into a polar orbit, officials said. ``Pegasus is on its way,'' F-18 chase plane pilot Jim Molka radioed to controllers at 12:11 p.m. as the 50-foot rocket was dropped from its perch beneath the jet's right wing. ``It looked like a little shuttle heading toward the sky,'' bomber pilot Gordon Fullerton said. Twelve minutes later, tracking crews at the Ames-Dryden Flight Research Facility at Edwards determined the 440-pound satellite had successfully reached orbit 368 miles above Earth. ``Everything went according to the mission profile,'' said C.J. Fenrick, spokesman for Ames-Dryden. ``This is a big step for the Air Force, NASA and private corporations interested in space.'' Vice President Dan Quayle praised the mission's success. ``Today's Pegasus launch marks an important achievement for the emerging commercial launch industry,'' Quayle said in a statement. ``This initiative holds great promise for not only the aerospace industry but for the U.S. space program as well.'' Strapped beneath the right wing of the gleaming white and silver bomber, Pegasus was flown to 43,000 feet over the military's Western Test Range in the ocean off Southern California. The 41,000-pound rocket was released and appeared to fall free for five seconds, then streaked into space trailing a fiery ribbon of smoke. The delta-winged first-stage booster flew to 200,000 feet, then second- and third-stage rocket engines ignited to carry Pegasus into low orbit to eject it and its Navy satellite. Developed by Virginia-based Orbital Sciences Corp. and Delaware-based Hercules Aerospace Corp., Pegasus was designed to put small satellites into orbit at low cost. It has been called the poor man's satellite booster. ``You are watching history, guys,'' Orbital Sciences spokeswoman Barbara Zedina told reporters. ``I can't believe it. You go over this so many times in your mind. It's wonderful.'' The estimated cost of a Pegasus launch was between $6 million and $8 million, a fraction of the cost of an Atlas or Titan rocket firing, officials said. The Pentagon and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration want to use Pegasus for military and science satellites, but Pegasus also is expected to attract business from companies, foreign governments and university scientists who need a cheap way to put small payloads in orbit. In addition to placement of the Navy communications satellite, two other missions were accomplished, said Jan Bodanyi of the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency. Remaining on the frame was an instrument package to send data back to scientists about the stress on Pegasus and its payload as it goes through the atmosphere and into space, Bodanyi said. Two canisters designed to release chemicals to produce an artificial ``northern lights'' effect also were aboard. Barium, mixed with a small amount of strontium, released over central Canada will allow NASA scientists to study the resulting glowing space cloud to learn more about the Earth's magnetosphere and ionosphere. Skies were clear when the rocket-bearing jet took off at 11:04 a.m. from the Mojave Desert military base 60 miles north of Los Angeles. The mission was scrubbed Wednesday because of rainy weather.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament to Convene Next Week to Approve Peres-led Government
DOC.TEXT: The parliament speaker announced Thursday that he would convene the legislature next Wednesday to approve the new government pieced together by Labor Party leader Shimon Peres. Peres wanted parliament, which is in recess, to convene Sunday, allowing the rival Likud bloc less time to win back a lawmaker who defected to Labor's side and to convince smaller left-wing parties to withold support for Peres. Before announcing his decision, the speaker, Dov Shilansky, consulted with fellow Likud colleague Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir after the attorney general ruled parliament must be convened ``as soon as possible.'' He told army radio he reached his decision on Wednesday out of religious, not political, considerations. Shilansky said Sunday was ruled out so observant Jewish parliament members could be home for a religious ceremony preparing themselves for next week's Passover holiday, which commemorates the exodus of Israelites from biblical Egypt. Meanwhile, Peres met with leaders of three left-wing parties to urge them to return to his new government so the Middle East peace process could continue. The parties control 10 of the 120 seats in parliament but have been critical of Labor's tactics in trying to form a new government. On Wednesday, Peres informed President Chaim Herzog he had succeeded in stitching together a ruling coalition. The announcement came two weeks after he was assigned to replace Shamir. Shamir lost a no-confidence vote March 15 in a crisis triggered by a dispute over U.S. conditions for holding Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. Peres forced the showdown with Shamir, who was reluctant to accept the U.S. proposals on forming a Palestinian delegation. Peres declined to reveal who would be in his coalition, saying secrecy was needed to woo other supporters. He is believed to have only 61 or 62 members of the parliament pledged to support his leadership. If Peres succeeds, it would be the first time since 1977 that the left-of-center Labor ruled without sharing power with Likud.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Say More Calcium Doesn't Prevent Bone Weakening
DOC.TEXT: Bone-weakening osteoporosis cannot be prevented by gorging on calcium-rich foods, University of Michigan researchers said Thursday. ``We found that adults with high calcium intakes didn't lose less bone and that adults with low calcium intakes didn't lose more bone,'' said Stanley Garn, a professor of nutrition at the university's School of Public Health. ``The more bone you have, the more you have to lose,'' he said in a news release from the university. ``You don't create more bone by stuffing calcium into young women any more than you create more muscle by stuffing steak into football players.'' The study was based on comparisons of X-ray measurements of 745 adult men's and women's hand bones taken from 1963-65 and again in 1985, the Ann Arbor university said. The subjects also reported their eating habits, focusing on calcium and phosphorous intake. Osteoporosis, a softening of the bones, tends to begin with women in their early 40s and with men in their 50s regardless of their calcium intake, the researchers said in a study presented Thursday at a joint meeting of the American Association of Physical Anthropology and the Human Biology Council in Miami. The results were consistent with earlier studies in which Garn and other researchers found that entire populations with high calcium intake as part of their everyday diet suffered bone loss comparable to groups eating a predominantly low-calcium, rice-based diet. Dr. Richard Mazess, professor emeritus of medical physics at the University of Wisconsin, endorsed the findings. ``They're entirely in accord with the rest of the scientific evidence to date,'' Mazess said in a telephone interview. ``The overwhelming evidence is that calcium has very little to do with bone loss, except in people with marginal intake under 400 milligrams a day.'' The average American's diet supplies 600-800 milligrams of calcium daily, Mazess said. Calcium supplements might benefit those receiving less, he said, but increasing consumption of dairy products, the most common source of calcium, carries higher levels of cholesterol and coronary risk. Exercise may help women prevent the disease, but the most effective treatment is estrogen therapy beginning with menopause, when the loss of bone mass tends to accelerate, Mazess said. ``It's not a calcium-deficiency disease,'' he said. The Michigan study also found no relationship between cigarette smoking, alcohol or the use of anti-hypertensive drugs and the amount of bone loss.

DOC.HEAD: Pastor Says List Acted out of Corrupted Religion
DOC.TEXT: A former Sunday school teacher killed his wife, three children and mother in 1971 out of a corrupted religious faith, his former Lutheran pastor testified Thursday. ``I think John's problem was he knew doctrine but he didn't know faith,'' the Rev. Edward Saresky, pastor at Faith Lutheran Chuch in Rochester, N.Y., said on the fourth day of John E. List's murder trial. List, 64, a strictly raised Lutheran who attended Saresky's church in the 1960s, ``didn't trust God'' to help him, so he tried to help himself out of his problems, the pastor said. ``But that was a corruption,'' he said. ``Sin is never justified.'' Defense attorney Elijah L. Miller Jr. acknowledges that the former accountant shot to death his wife, Helen, 46, their children Patricia, 16; John, 15; and Frederick, 13; and his mother Alma, 85; at their 19-room Westfield mansion on Nov. 9, 1971, but contends List was insane. List was unable to deal with his family's diminishing religious ties and the social turmoil of the 1960s and 1970s, Miller said. He called clergymen and List's family members to paint a picture of List's troubled youth and his family's troubles. The Rev. Herman Mayer, a pastor in Bay City, Mich., told of the hard-working religious community in Frankenmuth, Mich., where List's family emigrated as missionaries from Germany in the 19th century. ``They had values, I would say, (of) good citizens, to be upright, also to be prosperous,'' said Mayer, a robust 93-year-old cleric. List's mother ``looked after him constantly'' as a boy and was concerned about his safety when he played, said cousin Ralph List, of Frankenmuth. He had few friends, and was born to a 60-year-old father, the cousin said. Saresky said he saw tensions in the List home when List worked for Xerox in Rochester from 1961 to 1964. List was working long hours and failing to keep up with the company's expectations of him, the pastor said. Saresky said he heard Helen List unfavorably compare List with her first husband, a Green Beret who fought in the Korean War. ``She commented that if John were half the man her former husband was, they wouldn't have the troubles they were having,'' Saresky testifed. Betty Jean Syfert said her sister, Helen List, dominated the marriage. She acknowledged under questioning by Assistant Union County Prosecutor Eleanor Clark that Mrs. List told her husband she was pregnant when they married, but she didn't have a child that year. Mrs. Syfert said Mrs. List's daughter by her first marriage became pregnant at 16, causing tension in the family. Soon after, Mrs. List started drinking, she said. On a visit to their home, Mrs. Syfert said she found her sister confined to her bedroom, dirty and disheveled in an unkempt house. Mrs. List also inexplicably fell from her chair, and defense lawyer Miller indicated she frequently had to be taken to the hospital for falls. ``I had no earthly idea of what was going on with her or the house,'' said Mrs. Syfert. The attorney has said that Mrs. List was dying of syphilis at the time she was killed. List was arrested in June in Richmond, Va., where he had been living a new life under a different name.

DOC.HEAD: Polish President to Visit Moscow Next Week
With AM-Soviet-Republics
DOC.TEXT: Polish President Woijech Jaruzelski will arrive next week in Moscow for an official four-day visit, the Soviet news agency Tass announced Thursday. Jaruzelski's visit will take place April 11-14, it said. No further details were given. The announcement came two days after the Soviet government closed the frontier between Lithuania and Poland, the Baltic republic's only border that does not adjoin the Soviet territory. Lithuania declared independence from 50 years of Soviet rule on March 11, entering into a bitter confrontation with Moscow. Soviet officials have also complained that Polish representatives were treating Lithuania as a separate state. ``Such an action ... we cannot but see as intervention in the internal affairs of the U.S.S.R.,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Yuri D. Gremitskikh told a press briefing Wednesday. ``We assume that will be taken into account by the Polish side.'' Despite their displeasure over Lithuania, the Soviets are looking to Poland as an example for a radical economic reform _ in essence the transition of a state economy to a market economy, reportedly being considered in the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Driver Steers Truck into Army Foot Patrol
With AM-Israel-Politics
DOC.TEXT: A Palestinian driver deliberately steered his truck into an army foot patrol Thursday and seriously injured a soldier, the army said. In that and other incidents in the occupied territories, two Palestinians were killed and 18 Palestinians and one Israeli were injured, reports said. An army statement said soldiers fired on the truck in Nablus in the West Bank, wounding the driver in both legs. Israel radio said the injured Israeli was a reserve officer standing 20 feet from the road when he was struck. Youths began stoning the soldiers after the incident and the troops fired, wounding at least three Palestinian teen-agers, Arab witnesses said. Soldiers shot and killed two Palestinians during stone-throwing clashes with youths in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, Arab hospital officials said. Fourteen other Palestinians were reported shot and wounded in scattered other clashes with troops in the occupied lands. One victim was a 2-year-old boy hit in the head with a rubber bullet, Arab doctors said. In Nablus, the truck with a West Bank license plate careened into the army patrol near the Askar Palestinian refugee camp on the city's northern edge. ``It seems it was on purpose, that it was an attack,'' said an army officer, who spoke on condition of anonymity. An official army statement said the soldier was in serious condition and an investigation was under way. The wounded driver and three passengers in the truck were arrested, the army said. Immediately after the incident, soldiers fired rubber and plastic bullets at stone-throwing youths, witnesses said. Doctors at Al-Ittihad Hopital said the three people hurt included two 14-year-olds struck with rubber bullets. The army sealed off the area and declared a curfew on Askar, ordering the camp's 8,000 residents to stay home, Arab reporters said. In the Gaza Strip, Narwas Saleh el-Argeh, 23, was fatally shot in clashes with a military patrol in the Rafah refugee camp, hospital officials said. Arab reporters said news of his death sparked rioting in the camp. In West Bank city of Ramallah, Mustafa Ali Jaro, 16, died after being struck in the head by a rubber-coated steel ball used by the army for riot control, hospital officials said. Arab reporters said Jaro, from nearby Jalazoun refugee camp, was shot during clashes in the main square of Ramallah, six miles north of Jerusalem. The army confirmed the shootings and said troops fired on both occasions when they came under a hail of stones. The deaths brought to 672 the number of Palestinians killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians during the 27-month-old uprising against Israeli occupation. At least 202 other Palestinians have been killed by fellow Arabs, most as suspected collaborators. Forty-three Israelis also died in the violence.

DOC.HEAD: Number of Rioters Dwindles in British Prison Uprising
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT name to Taylor. Picks up 4th, `The Home...'
DOC.TEXT: The self-styled leader of the 5-day-old uprising at Strangeways Prison said Thursday that inmates had not meant to cause the riot that devastated the jail complex, killed a prisoner and injured 49 people. Shouting to be heard over the din of a police helicopter hovering above his rooftop post, Paul Taylor told reporters a sit-in at the prison chapel was the plan on Sunday when he grabbed the priest's microphone and urged others to act. ``At no time did anyone have any willful intention that we would develop into a riot situation,'' Taylor, 28, yelled through a makeshift megaphone to journalists below. The Home Office, which runs Britain's prisons, said four more prisoners surrendered Thursday. Prison governor Brendan O'Friel said fewer than 40 prisoners remained inside Strangeways. Barry Cuttle, a member of the negotiating team trying to persuade prisoners to surrender, said 20 to 25 inmates remained on the loose inside the 122-year-old prison. At a news conference Thursday, O'Friel reiterated his commitment to negotiations to end the mutiny, calling them ``our main weapon.'' Ivor Serle, chairman of the local chapter of the Prison Officers Association, said Thursday, ``I can rule out the use of force, if it takes a month we are not going to go in and bring them out. I'm certain some of them want to surrender but they're being persuaded not to.'' Serle said 10 inmates are unaccounted for. O'Friel said a search of most areas of the prison found no bodies, but added he ``could not rule out the possibility of fatalities.'' Some prisoners from Strangeways said after being transferred to other prisons that they had seen bodies inside the prison. Reports persisted of prisoners being hanged and tortured by fellow inmates. But the only death confirmed was that of prisoner Derek White, 46, who died in a hospital from injuries suffered in Sunday's riot. Thirty-six other inmates were injured and 13 prison guards were hurt.
