Walter Scott, 46, a guard who had been on duty during the riot, died Thursday, apparently after suffering a heart attack, the Home Office said. It said Scott was not directly involved in combating the riot. Home Secretary David Waddington began an inquiry into the riot and siege. Rioters overpowered guards during Sunday chapel service, seized their keys and gained access to other prison areas. Inmates' relatives say overcrowding, unsanitary conditions and prisoners locked in their cells for up to 23 hours a day added to tension. Strangeways was built in 1868 to hold 970 men. On Sunday it held 1,648.

DOC.HEAD: Grandma Gets Credit For Weaning Boy From Ventilator
DOC.TEXT: A loving grandmother wouldn't give up despite what doctors said, and helped her injured grandson learn to breathe on his own again. Through her persistence and doctors' doubt, Dolores Anderson helped 9-year-old Lortray Gordon learn to breathe for up to 10 hours a day without his ventilator. ``They said there was no way this kid could live. I refused to hear that stuff,'' Mrs. Anderson said. ``They said he'd always be on a ventilator,'' she said. ``They wanted me to put Tray away into an old folks' home. I said: `No way, forget it.''' Janna Jacobs of the National Spinal Cord Injury Association near Boston said it is unusual for a family member to accomplish what Mrs. Anderson did. ``What a brave lady,'' Ms. Jacobs said. ``I admire her spirit and courage.'' ``The credit belongs to the grandma,'' said Dr. Jim Hillman, one of the boy's doctors. While visiting relatives in Vero Beach in November 1986, the boy darted into traffic and was hit by a car. His injury is called a ``hangman's fracture'' because that is where a noose hits in a hanging. The fracture was in an area of the spinal cord that controls breathing. He spent two months in a coma in a Vero Beach hospital, then was transferred to a Tampa hospital where he underwent six operations in seven months. He then went to a spinal cord center in Atlanta for six months. ``A lot of people had written him off,'' said Peggy Berger, director of nurses at West Shore Hospital where Gordon later went for treatment. ``His grandmother said, `No, you're not going to put him aside' ... she was right.'' Mrs. Anderson said she talked to Gordon about taking him off the ventilator. He couldn't say anything, but she said he indicated he wanted to try. On the first try, she took the air supply away for five minutes. His diaphragm, the muscle that moves the lungs up and down, had atrophied from disuse but strengthened as she increased the time off the machine each day. In two months, when the boy could be off the ventilator an hour and a half a day, Mrs. Anderson told doctors and social workers what she had done. ``Everybody was in shock. They said, `He can't breathe on his own.' I said, `Come over and see for yourselves.''' To help his recovery, doctors sent Gordon to West Shore Hospital, which specializes in the rehabilitation of patients on ventilators. After five months, he can breathe on his own long enough to make it through a school day. Mrs. Anderson is appealing for donations to pay for a van to carry Gordon to school in Hillsborough County, where officials say he will be the school system's first student to need the assistance of a ventilator.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu: Trade Accord Will be `Painful' But Worth It
With AM-US-Japan Trade
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said Friday that carrying out some of the economic reforms agreed to in Washington talks with the United States will be painful, but could ultimately improve the lives of the Japanese. At a news conference, Kaifu called the reforms a duty that ``Japan must discharge as a responsible member of the international community.'' He said the reforms would benefit not only the United States and Japan, ``but also the whole world, serve to prevent the rise of protectionism and thus contribute to the steady development of the world economy.'' ``I ask for the understanding and cooperation of the people of my country,'' Kaifu said. On Japan's promise to revise laws protecting small retailers, Kaifu told reporters the situation was ``severe,'' but added, ``I believe it is important for me and all of you to think of the viewpoint of consumers' interests.'' Influential associations of small shopkeepers have resisted changes that would make it easier to open new large-scale retail stores, both Japanese and foreign, a process that now can take 10 years. The United States contends larger stores are more likely to sell foreign products. ``The Japanese measures included in the interim report (on U.S.-Japan negotiations) have been attained after undergoing a difficult domestic process, and their implementation may, in some cases, be painful,'' Kaifu said. ``It is my conviction, however, that they are essential in furthering Japan's own national interest.'' ``The interim report reflects the maximum measures that our country can take at this point. We will make the whole picture clearer in the final report,'' due in July. Kaifu said Japan also should express its opinions more openly. ``I think we have exchanged frank opinions with the U.S. negotiators. That is a way in which Japan can contribute to the rest of the world.'' Japan said the United States contributed to its $49 billion trade imbalance with the Japanese because of its large budget deficit, low savings rate, short-term corporate planning and relatively weak education system. U.S. negotiators promised efforts to remedy these problems. U.S. officials have also argued the changes sought in Japanese business practices would benefit Japanese consumers, who pay some of the world's highest prices as a result of a complex distribution system and a web of government restrictions. Some Japanese commentators have berated their government for relying on U.S. and other outside pressure to make reforms it is too weak to push through on its own. They also say such reforms could strengthen Japan's economy in ways that would make it an even more formidable international competitor. Foreign Minister Taro Nakayama said Friday, ``Against the background of the serious large-scale trade imbalance, the present Japan-U.S. economic relations, unless managed properly, are in danger of suffering grave damage, posing a threat of undermining the mutual trust which lies at the foundation of the overall relationship between the two nations.'' He said the reforms have ``significant bearings upon the improvement of the quality of life and the advancement of consumer interests in Japan.'' Among Japan's pledges was one to spend more on public works such as housing, sewers, parks, airports and port facilities. The United States, counting on such spending to boost Japan's demand for foreign goods and services, had sought a definite spending target, but Japan said it would decide yearly expenditures flexibly to avoid overheating the local economy.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Japan Complete Historic Trade Pact
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf pvs with 3 new grafs to provide Kaifu comments from Tokyo; DELETES final 3 grafs pvs to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Japanese negotiators on Thursday announced completion of an unprecedented agreement pledging to reduce trade frictions by making broad-based reforms in the economies of both countries. The agreement, reached after four days of marathon discussions, set forth a complex set of proposals aimed at lowering America's huge $49 billion deficit with Japan by attacking structural barriers to trade. Under Secretary of State Richard McCormack, the leader of the U.S. negotiating team, said the talks had produced ``substantive progress'' in resolving trade differences between the two economic superpowers. A White House statement praised the agreement as ``an important way station along the road leading to a strengthened U.S.-Japan relationship.'' In Tokyo, Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said carrying out some of the deep economic reforms promised in the talks could be painful, but in the end would improve the lives of the Japanese. Speaking at a news conference, Kaifu called the reforms a duty that ``Japan must discharge as a responsible member of the international community.'' ``I ask for the understanding and cooperation of the people of my country,'' Kaifu said. The talks were unprecedented in their scope because they aimed not at boosting sales for specific foreign products but at correcting broad barriers to trade in both countries. For the first time, representatives of sovereign states drew up detailed lists of the economic shortcomings in the other nation and demanded changes. Japanese critics of the effort complained that the United States was trying to scrap centuries of Japanese tradition and remake the country into the image of the United States. The Bush administration insisted that its recommendations would benefit Japan by increasing competition in a country where consumers now pay some of the highest prices in the industrial world. The Japanese had their own list of complaints against the United States, citing America's huge budget deficit, low savings rate and short-term planning by U.S. companies as restraints on U.S. productivity. The administration chose not to accept the most politically sensitive Japanese recommendations to limit Americans' use of credit cards, boost gasoline taxes and scrap tax deductions for home mortgages. Instead, the administration pledged to increase efforts to improve America's education system and pointed to proposals the White House already is pushing to cut the federal budget deficit and to provide tax credits for increased personal savings. The 22-page U.S. section of the report primarily recycled previous administration proposals including its effort to get Congress to enact a cut in the capital gains tax as a way of fostering investment. However, the 32-page Japanese section contained a number of sweeping proposals to revamp how businesses is conducted in Japan. Among the pledges made by the Japanese: _To deregulate Japan's complex goods-distribution system, including a gradual relaxation of restrictions on the establishment of large retail stores. Such a move would allow U.S. and other foreign retailers to open outlets in Japan. _To increase enforcement of antitrust laws with tougher penalties to discourage bid-rigging and other collusive practices by Japanese corporations. _To boost government spending on public works projects, thus expanding the volume of work on which American firms could bid. The talks on broad barriers to trade, known as the Structural Impediments Initiative, were launched by the administration in July. Until this week, they had made little headway. But Kaifu, seeking to lessen growing anti-Japanese sentiment in Congress, promised Bush at a summit meeting in early March that he would make lowering trade tensions a top priority for his government. Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont. and chairman of a Senate trade subcommittee, said he was impressed with the newfound willingness by the Japanese to make concessions but he and other members of Congress said it was critical for the Japanese words to be followed by action. ``I am encouraged that some first steps have been taken on the Structural Impediments Initiative. But these are only first steps,'' Baucus said. ``Much remains to be done.'' Sen. John Danforth, R-Mo., said he was concerned because there was no enforcement mechanism to make sure Japan lives up to its commitments. ``In any commercial agreement with Japan, seeing is believing,'' he said. Senate Finance Committee chairman, Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, said he was not yet convinced that Japan was willing to ``put an end to its longstanding protectionist practices.'' ``Put me down as a skeptic who has seen too many agreements in which the results didn't match the rhetoric,'' he said in a statement. ``U.S.-Japan trade agreements _ and we had a lot of them throughout the 1980s _ were like nothing so much as a drugstore cowboy: all hat and no cattle.'' Since the Bush-Kaifu meeting, there has been a flurry of activity in trade negotiations. Agreement were announced in the last two weeks to expand the opportunity for sales of American-made telecommunications equipment, satellites and supercomputers in Japan. Some saw the concessions as an attempt by Japan to keep from being put on a ``hit list'' of the countries with the worst barriers to trade for the second year in a row. The administration faces a congressional deadline of April 30 for releasing a new list of target countries.

DOC.HEAD: Bus Bomb in India Kills 10
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in a bus Thursday at Panipat town outside Punjab, killing 10 people, United News of India reported. No immediate indication emerged as to who was responsible, but the bus began its run in Haryana state near the Punjab border. Sikh separatists have killed more than 540 people so far this year in Punjab. In Parliament, a bill calling for a six-month extension of federal rule in Punjab was passed in the Lok Sabha, or House of the People, the lower house. The government-sponsored bill must also be approved in the Rajya Sabha, or Council of States, the upper house, to become law but approval is a formality because all parties have expressed their support. Punjab was placed under federal administration in May 1987. On Tuesday, at least 29 people died when a bomb blamed on Sikh extremists exploded as Hindus were parading through a crowded vegetable market in the Punjab town of Batala to celebrate the birthday of the Hindu warrior-god Rama. Police said at least three more people were killed by Hindus who rioted after that bombing. The UNI news agency said Sikh extremists on Wednesday shot and killed three state policemen returning from the funeral of a constable who died in the Batala bombing. It said six other policemen and several relatives of the constable were wounded in the attack near Tetherke. Batala, a predominantly Hindu town, has been a frequent target of Sikh militants who want to establish a separate nation for their religious sect in the prosperous northern farming state of Punjab.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Reported in Marianas Islands
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `The quake...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE attribution, add report on damage to moorings; picks up 7th graf pvs, `On Tuesday...
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook a section of the Marianas Islands on Friday and rattled windows 200 miles away, authorities said. There were no reports of injury or serious damage. The quake occurred at 7:15 a.m. (5:15 p.m. Thursday EDT) and registered 7.4 on the Richter scale, according to Bruce Presgrave, a spokesman for the National Earthquake Information Service in Golden, Colo. The epicenter was 138 miles northeast of Saipan near the island of Anatahan in the western Pacific. ``A reading of 7.4 would make it a major earthquake, but the only information we have is that it was felt on Guam,'' Presgrave said. ``We've had no reports of damage at all.'' ``We felt it for about 10 seconds; everything shook,'' said Andrew Mazella, program director at radio station KSAI in Saipan. The quake rattled windows and dishes in Guam, 220 miles southwest of the epicenter. The quake slammed a 15-foot wave into Tinian, a tiny island south of Saipan and pushed 5 feet of water into houses on Tanapag, a village on Saipan island, said Felix Sasamoto, civil defense coordinator for the islands. Some moorings broke loose in Tinian but no other damage was reported, Sasamoto said. On Tuesday, all 21 residents of Anatahan, closest to the epicenter, abandoned the island after a volcano there showed signs of erupting. A Navy crew from Guam was checking the volcano Friday, but geologists said the quake and volcanic activity apparently were unrelated. ``This is different from the volcanic activity that has been occurring in the islands,'' said Presgrave. Anatahan and Saipan are part of the Northern Marianas chain just north of Guam, about 1,500 miles east of the Philippines. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of 6 on the Richter scale can cause severe damage in the local area. A 7 reading is a ``major'' earthquake, capable of widespread heavy damage; 8 is a ``great'' quake, capable of tremendous damage. The San Francisco earthquake of 1906, which occurred before the Richter scale was devised, has been estimated at 8.3 on the Richter scale.

DOC.HEAD: Official Rallies Prevent Marches in Tiananmen on Day of Mourning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with square reopened to public on Friday. Picks up 4th pvs, `In HOng...'
DOC.TEXT: Authorities staged all-day rallies in Tiananmen Square on Thursday, China's annual day for mourning the dead, preventing unofficial visits to the symbolic center of last year's crushed democracy movement. It was the second time in a week city officials held official activities in the square as an excuse for closing it to the public. The method appeared successful. There were no reports of attempts to lay wreaths near the square or otherwise honor the hundreds and possibly thousands of people killed June 3-4, when the army opened fire on pro-democracy protesters and retook the square where they had camped. Authorities reopened Tiananmen Square without fanfare on Friday, with police standing guard or strolling around, continuing a heavy presence in the area. In Hong Kong, however, an estimated 20,000 people marched in honor of the Beijing dead, many carrying banners or bouquets of flowers. A wreath was left from Chai Ling, a leading activist in the Beijing uprising who escaped to the West last week after 10 months on the run in China. ``Patriotic heroes will live forever,'' read a banner on the wreath. Thursday was China's annual Qingming, or Clear and Bright Festival, when families traditionally visit graves to mourn their dead. Chinese dissidents abroad, through faxes and mailed leaflets, urged Beijing residents to stroll through Tiananmen Square on Qingming in memory of the slain protesters. Early in the week, however, Beijing authorities issued orders curbing even normal mourning activities, such as group visits to crematoriums. The Beijing Daily newspaper published a letter Sunday from a city official warning residents to pass Qingming in a ``civilized and healthy'' way and not ``take advantage of the opportunity to create distubances.'' Schools and factories told people to not to wear traditional signs of mourning, such as black armbands or white flowers. Some colleges suddenly announced special, mandatory political lectures, apparently in an effort to keep students occupied. Authorities bused thousands of high school-age Communist Youth League members into Tiananmen Square in the morning. They paid homage to China's revolutionary martyrs and listened to a lecture on China's past struggles against foreign imperialists. In the afternoon, primary school members of the Young Pioneers, wearing their insignia red handkerchiefs around their necks, marched onto the square in formation to hear more patriotic speeches. Both the Youth League and the Young Pioneers try to foster Marxism among young people. Members of the People's Armed Police, a paramilitary unit, stood guard on the square's perimeter. Dozens of ordinary police patrolled adjoining streets, making sure members of the public did not try to enter. They yelled at foreigners who tried to photograph the ceremonies. The city also held official rallies in the square Sunday, another day when overseas dissidents suggested Beijing residents hold protest strolls there. The next three months include many other dates when memorials or protests might seem apt. April 15 is the one-year anniversary of the death of ousted Communist Party leader Hu Yaobang, a relative liberal. It was his death that first caused Beijing college students to take to the streets, initiating seven weeks of marches for democratic reform. Beijing college campuses were quiet Thursday. Regular campus security guards checked identification at the gates of Beijing and Qinghua universities, but no other uniformed police were visible. Students played tennis and volleyball in the warm spring sunshine. None was willing to talk about last year's protests. ``The mood is tense ... But everyone agrees it won't be possible to try for political change until after (senior leader) Deng Xiaoping dies,'' said a teacher, speaking on condition of anonymity. The 85-year-old Deng led China out of its radical leftist Cultural Revolution and introduced market-style economic reforms. But he approved last year's violent crackdown on political dissent and insists China cannot develop its backward economy unless the Communist Party maintains tight political control. The Hong Kong protesters chanted ``Don't forget June 4!'' and ``Democracy will win!'' as they marched through the British colony, which will revert to Chinese rule in 1997. Wearing yellow headbands, the crowd laid wreaths at a makeshift monument set up at a downtown park. A book of condolence was also placed there for the people to sign their names. The signatures will be burned during a candlelight vigil June 4.

DOC.HEAD: Vance To Head Economic Mission to Poland
DOC.TEXT: Former Secretary of State Cyrus Vance will head a mission to Poland next month to help set up a stock market and other free-market institutions, the Bush administration announced Wednesday. Vance, who served under former President Jimmy Carter, and John Whitehead, who was deputy secretary of state in the Reagan administration, will chair a committee that will send American volunteers to Eastern Europe to help with economic changes in countries moving away from communist systems. Missions will go later to Hungary, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and other Eastern European countries, the U.S. Agency for International Development (AID) said in a statement. Jerry Lipson, a spokesman for the agency, said he knew of no plan to go to the Soviet Union. ``This practical initiative offers a unique opportunity to provide at the working level assistance to Eastern European nations which have chosen democracy and free-market economic systems for their future,'' the announcement quoted Vance as saying. He is now the presiding partner in the New York law firm of Simpson, Thacher and Bartlett. The agency said his mission will consist of two teams. One will focus on setting up financial markets. Fledgling stock markets already exist in Hungary and Yugoslavia, and there have been discussions on setting one up in Poland. The other team will work on improving the Polish banking system.

DOC.HEAD: Bush-Gorbachev Summit Set for May 30, Spurring Treaty Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines a0764, a0770, a0969; edits throughout to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will meet for a superpower summit in the United States beginning May 30, U.S. and Soviet officials said Thursday as the two sides broke new ground on Germany and on the Middle East. Accepting the principle of unifying East and West Germany, the Soviets edged away from their demand that the merged country be neutralized, U.S. and Soviet officials reported at the end of a long day of bargaining on tough regional issues. And, in another potential breakthrough, the Soviets said they would consider restoring diplomatic relations with Israel and permitting the direct flight of Jews to Tel Aviv if they had assurances the refugees would not be settled on the West Bank and in East Jerusalem. Earlier, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said several major agreements could emerge at the summit, including a long-sought Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty to limit long-range nuclear weapons. But Bush said merely that the summit would provide ``time for a lot of dialogue and a lot of discussion.'' Officials on both sides acknowledged that in the more than seven weeks remaining it would be difficult to forge agreements across the board of U.S.-Soviet relations. But a group of U.S. and Soviet regional experts, working at the direction of Secretary of State James A. Baker III and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze, achieved surprising progress on Germany, the Middle East and also the wars in Angola and Afghanistan. The Soviets insisted, as they have in the past, that the pace of merging East and West Germany is too fast. However, a U.S. official told reporters, ``we also got the impression a neutral Germany is not the only answer to security questions there.'' Confirming the development, a Soviet official briefing separately said ``we think neutrality may be the answer, but we invite people to supply us with other ideas.'' He said Moscow's aim was simply that a unified Germany should ``be no danger to its neighbors.'' In the Middle East, the Soviets continued their attack on Israel for settling Jews on the West Bank and in East Jerusalem, territory that the Arabs held until the 1967 Six-Day War. However, the Soviet offer to resume relations with Israel, which were suspended in 1967, and to open direct flights of refugees to Tel Aviv provided they do not settle in the disputed lands ``was a different kind of response than we heard before,'' a U.S. official said. The briefings, held for reporters in a State Department auditorium, were conducted under rules that prohibited identifying the officials further. On two other troubled fronts, Angola and Afghanistan, the U.S. officials said the Soviets had shown an interest in elections as a way of ending wars in the countries between forces backed by the two superpowers. to limit long-range nuclear weapons. Earlier, Soviet negotiator Yuri Nazarkin said of the possibility of signing a U.S.-Soviet pact on long-range nuclear weapons, ``Taking into account (the summit is) in seven weeks, it's impractical, I think, to expect it (the treaty) is going to be signed at the summit.'' Fitzwater said the summit _ Bush's second meeting as president with the Soviet leader _ would be a ``tough love'' encounter, with the crisis in Lithuania a central topic. Bush and Gorbachev last met early in December in a storm-tossed shipboard summit at the Mediterranean island of Malta. Since then, pushes for independence in Lithuania and other regions of the Soviet Union _ and the Soviet response to them _ have strained superpower relations. Simultaneous announcements of the summit came from the White House and the Soviet news agency Tass early Thursday as Baker and Shevardnadze were holding their second day of meetings on arms control and other issues. ``There's still a lot of work to do, particularly in light of the fact that the summit will begin on the 30th,'' Baker told reporters. ``So we have our work cut out for us.'' Shevardnadze, who will meet with Bush on Friday, echoed Baker's remarks. ``There is very little time, only seven weeks,'' he said. Both the Washington and Moscow announcements gave the summit dates as May 30 to June 3. However, Fitzwater said all five days might not be used. ``It could turn out to be a two or three-day summit, depending on travel schedules,'' he suggested. U.S. officials were also vague on whether the meeting would take place entirely in Washington, or at some other location as well _ such as the president's oceanside home in Kennebunkport, Maine. Fitzwater said that the crisis in Lithuania would ``undoubtedly be an issue'' at the summit and that the president intended to raise it. ``If anything, Lithuania makes the summit even more important,'' the spokesman said. ``I would characterize this summit more in terms of demonstrating the kind of tough-love working relationship that we were able to develop with the Soviet Union by virtue of four or five summits,'' he said. Gennadi Gerasimov, the Soviet spokesman, indicated that Baker had energetically raised U.S. concerns about the use of Soviet force in the breakaway Baltic state in his sessions with Shevardnadze. ``There was a serious, hardball exchange of opinions on this subject,'' Gerasimov told reporters. Senate leaders who met with Shevardnadze Wednesday night said he told them Gorbachev faced heavy pressure at home, including criticism for not being tougher on Lithuania. Fitzwater said that trade with the Soviet Union also would be discussed at the summit, possibly including conditions under which the United States might lift the Jackson-Vanik trade sanctions in place since the mid 1970s to protest Moscow's restrictions on emigration of Soviet Jews. Gorbachev is seeking access to Western credit and improved trade relations. Bush and Gorbachev might also set final terms for reducing U.S. and Soviet troops, tanks and other conventional forces in Europe, Fitzwater suggested. But a treaty would be finalized at a 35-nation summit meeting later in the year. The two leaders also might initial an agreement for a phased reduction of American and Soviet chemical weapons, Fitzwater suggested. An international ban depends on agreement among more than a score of nations negotiating terms in Geneva.

DOC.HEAD: Government Calls Ex-Manager of Imelda's `Piggy Bank' as Witness
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 9 grafs to UPDATE with former bank official testifying that examiners threatened to close bank if millions withdrawn by Imelda Marcos not replenished, EDIT to conform; picks up 7th graf, `Mrs. Marcos...' Fe Roa in 4th graf is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A former officer of the Philippines government-owned bank testified Thursday that examiners threatened to close the bank in 1982 if millions of dollars withdrawn by Imelda Marcos were not replenished. Oscar Carino, vice president of the New York branch of the Philippine National Bank until 1984, testified that the bank provided the former Philippine first lady with an average of $100,000 in cash every time she visited New York. He said the debit at the bank prosecutors contend Mrs. Marcos used as her personal ``piggy bank'' climbed from $500,000 in 1973 to as much as $22 million in 1984. State examiners threatened to close the bank, he said. Instructions for the withdrawals came from Mrs. Marcos' private secretary, Fe Roa Jimenez, Carino said. Carino earlier testified that he met with Philippines president Ferdinand Marcos at the Malacanang Palace in Manila before he took the job in 1973. When he asked the leader for any special instructions, Carino quoted the late Marcos as saying, ```You go there. You will be hearing from us.''' Carino said he then met with former bank president Roberto S. Benedicto, a Marcos associate, during a stopover in Las Vegas on his way to New York. ``He told me he would be sending us instructions and warned me against the auditor not being very good about keeping confidential transactions under wrap,'' Carino said. Mrs. Marcos, 60, is charged with racketeering, conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction for allegedly embezzling more than $160 million from the Philippine treasury to buy New York real estate and artworks. Her co-defendant, Saudi financier Adnan Khashoggi, is charged with mail fraud and obstruction for allegedly backdating documents to help the Marcoses hide their ownership of four Manhattan buildings. Marcos also was charged in the 1988 indictment but died in exile in Hawaii last September. Benedicto is one of five fugitives named in the indictment. In earlier testimony, the curator of a private art collection purchased by Mrs. Marcos in 1981 said he found many of its valuable items in ``horrible condition'' during a search of her daughter's home seven years later. Morton J. Bernstein then surprised her attorney by testifying under cross-examination that he held the former Philippines first lady personally responsible for the damage. Bernstein testified that he had served for two decades as manager of the art and antiques collection owned by the late philanthropist Leslie R. Samuels, and could identify every one of its paintings, figurines, 17th and 18th century furniture pieces and other items. Bernstein testified that later, the FBI asked him to go to California to identify Samuels collection items found at the small estate of Mrs. Marcos' younger daughter, Irene Araneta. Bernstein said he found the items in ``horrible condition,'' with priceless pieces of furniture stacked in a damp, dirt-floored barn. He said mirrors were cracked, tables damaged, and some statues had fingers broken off. ``It was heartbreaking,'' he said. ``But you are not blaming Mrs. Marcos, are you?'' asked Gerald Spence, Mrs. Marcos' attorney. Bernstein paused, then replied, ``Yes, I do.'' Spence, visibly taken aback, asked why. ``Somebody had to supervise it _ whose fault was it?'' Bernstein replied.

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Meets for 1st Time, Empowers De Maiziere to Form Gov't
DOC.NOTE: Eds: 3 grafs SUB for 8th graf, `The gathering' to UPDATE with Washington developments. Picks up 9th pvs, `Forty years...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BER2,4,6
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's first freely chosen Parliament declared the nation a democracy on Thursday and began building a political system that will lead it to unification with West Germany. The lawmakers, elected March 18 in the nation's first democratic ballot, convened for the first time and formally dismantled the Communist system that ruled four decades. Meeting in the Palace of the Republic built by the former Stalinist regime, the 400-member Parliament began rewriting the constitution to mirror that of West Germany. The new legislature and the government it creates could be East Germany's last as a sovereign state because of the moves toward unification with West Germany. The Parliament empowered Christian Democrat leader Lothar de Maiziere, whose party holds the most seats in Parliament, to build a new government from the 11 parties represented in the legislature. Dr. Sabine Bergmann-Pohl, a Christian Democrat, was elected president of Parliament and urged that lawmakers ``do justice to our responsibilities and that we soon sit in a common German Parliament.'' Bergmann-Pohl said legislators must work with their West German counterparts to merge the nations and bring the capital of a single Germany back to a united Berlin. Some heartening news also came from Washington late Thursday. U.S. and Soviet officials who are bargaining on regional isssues there said the Soviets, accepting the principle of unifying the two Germanys, edged away from their demand that the merged country be neutralized. A Soviet official told a briefing, ``We think neutrality may be the answer, but we invite people to supply us with other ideas.'' Thursday's gathering at the Palace of the Republic was rich in symbolism and was the culmination of the revolt that toppled the former Communist regime in October. But the shape of de Maiziere's government and the pace of reunification will likely be worked out in backroom negotiations. ``Forty years of difficult times have ended in this moment,'' said Lothar Piche, 63, the oldest member of Parliament. ``God support our German fatherland.'' The first thing the 390 lawmakers in attendance did was elect Bergmann-Polh to be Parliament's president. Others seeking the post were outgoing Communist Premier Hans Modrow, who leads a rebuilt pro-democracy party that finished a distant third in the March elections. He finished third in the voting for Parliament president, behind Social Democrat Reinhard Hoeppner. The Parliament also created an office of president to be a ceremonial head of state and abolished the old Communist collective body, the Council of State. Bergmann-Pohl will serve as head of state until a president is elected by Parliament. De Maiziere will likely be the premier, or prime minister, and will lead talks in the coming days on forming a new Cabinet. If de Maiziere is successful in bringing together the disparate political groups, Parliament will then reconvene April 11 and vote on his Cabinet nominations. De Maiziere leads an alliance of three parties that has been trying to form a coalition with the more left-leaning Social Democrats and a smaller group of liberal lawmakers. His Alliance for Germany won the most seats in the March 18 elections, campaigning on the need for fast unification with West Germany. But it needs a broad coalition to ensure the two-thirds vote necessary in Parliament to enact constitutional changes required for unification. While the Alliance favors quick reunification with West Germany, the Social Democrats support a slower pace. Despite their differences, the East German parties are united in their opposition to a proposal regarding the establishment of a single currency for East and West Germany. The West German central bank wants to trade East marks for West marks at a 2-1 exchange rate. East Germany is demanding a 1-1 exchange to help offset widespread uneployment and rising costs once the nations are merged. Thousands protested the 2-1 proposal in the East German cities of Halle, Neubrandenburg, Magdeburg, Dresden, Gera and Cottbus on Thursday, the government news agency ADN reported. About 50,000 people rallied in Leipzig, where mass protests against the old Communist government began last fall. ADN said the Leipzig protesters were demanding that West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl live up to promises of prosperity for East Germans. Kohl campaigned hard on de Maiziere's behalf and promised that East Germans would be protected as unification proceeded. East Germany's many inefficient and obsolete industries are having difficulty competing with the flood of Western products already available to East Germans. According to ADN, 40,000 East Germans lost their jobs in March. West Germany said Thursday it is pressing ahead with its plans for making the West German mark the East German currency by summer. In Bonn, Finance Minister Theo Waigel told reporters government ministers are examining a 50-page draft proposal for replacing East Germany's nearly worthless currency. Waigel said the recommendation for a 2-to-1 conversion rate was not discussed by the ministers Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Philadelphia's Minority Set-Aside Declarded Unconstitutional
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ruled Thursday that the city's program for giving minority-owned businesses preferred status is unconstitutional. The so-called ``set-aside'' program called for at least 15 percent of budgeted city contracts were go to minority-owned businesses and 10 percent to female-owned businesses. Businesses in which minorities or women held at least 51 percent ownership also were eligible for set-aside contracts. A coalition of contractors sued in 1989, contending that the program discriminated against them because of their non-minority status. U.S. District Judge Louis C. Bechtle's order permanently enjoins the set-aside program. He said it violates the Fourteenth Amendment of the U.S. Constitution, which guarantees the rights of citizens. City Solictor Charisse R. Lillie said the city would appeal and is asking for a stay. Philadelphia contracting firm owner Barbera Bushing said, ``I think that's really too bad. The male-owned businesses really don't care about hiring women. ``It's already hard for women to get into it. This decision makes it even tougher,'' she added. John H. Widman, an attorney for the contractors, said he did not think minority firms would be hurt by the decision. ``Now we can focus on what contracting is all about and that is skills, price, and expericence.'' Widman said. Mayor W. Wilson Goode has praised the program, which was established in 1982 under former Mayor William J. Green. Bechtle said he based his decision on a 1989 U.S. Supreme Court ruling that threw out Richmond, Va.'s program of setting aside 30 percent of city construction contracts for minority-owned businesses. The Supreme Court ruled that past discrimination would have to be well documented before a program could constitutionally be enacted to correct discrimination. They ruled that discrimination did not exist simply because 50 percent of the Richmond population was black and only two-thirds of 1 percent of the contracts went to black-owned business. Philadelphia's minority set-aside program was aimed at correcting a ``pattern of past and present racial, sexual and economic discrimination,'' according to the ordinance's preamble.

DOC.HEAD: Military Rolls Into Michoacan, Opposition Demonstrators Ousted
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with 14 of 17 city halls closed, 80 arrested, attorney general's quotes. CORRECTS that seven died in Guerrero sted 10. Picks up 11th pvs, `The PRD...'
DOC.TEXT: Armored vehicles rolled into Michoacan state as opposition supporters were ousted Thursday from city halls they had shut down in December to dramatize election fraud charges against Mexico's ruling party. Demonstrators from the Democratic Revolutionary Party (PRD) were dislodged from 14 of the 17 city halls closed since the disputed December municipal elections, according to news reports Thursday evening. At least 80 people were arrested but there was no violence, the reports said. The army refused to acknowledge the controversial operation in the rugged farming state known as a PRD stronghold. ``We don't have any information on this. Absolutely nothing,'' said Second Lt. Jimenez, a Defense Department spokeswoman in Mexico City who declined to give her first name. A presidential spokesman who demanded anonymity said state judicial police had dislodged the demonstrators. He said the army did not take part. But the government news agency Notimex said military police had ``peacefully'' removed demonstrators, some of whom were armd, from all but three of the city halls by Thursday evening. Notimex said 80 protesters had been arrested. Mexico's attorney general said there was no violence. ``There hasn't been even one blow nor one drop of blood,'' Attorney General Enrique Alvarez del Castillo was quoted as saying by the private Televisa TV network from the state capital of Morelia, 150 miles northwest of Mexico City. The PRD issued a statement saying there could be a ``bloodbath'' in Michoacan. Seven people died in February and in March in neighboring Guerrero state during election fraud protests and the eviction by police of PRD supporters from occupied city halls. The PRD says the ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party or PRI, which has ruled Mexico 61 years, cheated it out of victory in the December elections in both states. Armored vehicles entered Michoacan Wednesday, according to witnesses and news reports. The action came the same day the PRI governor called on federal and state authorities to intervene if the PRD did not relinquish the city halls. The fraud protests have brought Michoacan to the edge of ``anarchy,'' Gov. Jaime Genovevo Figueroa Zamudio said in a letter published in Mexico City newspapers. The PRI invariably denies election fraud allegations and often makes countercharges of violence against the opposition, especially the leftist PRD. The question of whether the opposition gets a fair shake at Mexico's polls remains unresolved. Mexico, unlike Panama under strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega or Nicaragua under the leftist Sandinistas, does not permit international election observers. Television news aired film of military vehicles rumbling through the streets of Morelia. Five armored vehicles began patrolling Ciudad Hidalgo, 110 miles northwest of Mexico City, on Wednesday, said Hector Edmundo Tinajero Gonzales, editor of the local newspaper El Clarion. He said he had similar accounts from Apatzingan. The official news agency Notimex said PRD sympathizers were ousted at city halls in Apatzingan, Ciudad Hidalgo, Brisenas, Chavinda, Huandacareo, Cotija and Jacona at midday Thursday. The government newspaper El Nacional announced the end of the city hall occupations before it happened. It said PRD protesters voluntarily disbanded Wednesday at all 17 city halls after ``talks with army officials.'' The story said nothing about army deployments. Army intervention in political disputes is as touchy a subject for the Mexican government as vote fraud. Interior Minister Fernando Gutierrez Barrios issued a statement Thursday saying the ``federal presence'' in Michoacan had been ``reinforced'' to avoid violence on the part of the PRD. Michoacan has been a problem for the PRI since the 1988 presidential race, when native son and PRD founder Cuauhtemoc Cardenas came in second to President Carlos Salinas de Gortari in an election still clouded by allegations of vote fraud. Nearly half of Michoacan's 110 city halls were occupied by Cardenas supporters after the national elections to protest alleged vote fraud and demand the replacement of the PRI governor. In one of his first officials acts after taking office in December 1988, Salinas replaced the governor. The move failed to pacify the PRD. There was further occupations after the July 2 state elections in which PRI claimed a majority in the state legislative races over PRD fraud charges.

A Juvenile Court judge on Wednesday refused to allow an 11-year-old boy to visit the younger brother he was separated from when their adoptive parents decided the older boy hadn't ``bonded'' well with them. Juvenile Court Judge Arthur N. Hamilton transferred a lawsuit asking that two boys be able to visit each other to the court's chancery division, which he said was the more appropriate forum. Cook County Public Guardian Patrick Murphy, who brought the lawsuit on behalf of the 11-year-old boy, argued that the judge should act because the situation was an emergency. ``Rick wants to see his brother and he wants to see him now,'' Murphy said. Murphy told reporters later that the two boys have seen each other just once since Rick went to the group home Nov. 20 just before Thanksgiving. A lawsuit filed by Murphy last week charges that the adoptive parents separated Rick _ not his real name _ and his 8-year-old brother, whom they adopted in 1984. It seeks $50,000 in damages for Rick. The lawsuit says the parents, called Joseph and Pamela Doe in the lawsuit, returned him to state custody because he hadn't ``bonded'' well with them. Hamilton said he would not issue a ruling on the visitation because Chancery Court handles injunctions. Hamilton said he also thought it would be quicker if Murphy went back to the judge who originally denied visitation to get that judge to change his ruling. Juvenile Court Judge Walter Williams on March 9 approved the parents' petition to surrender their parental rights to Rick and ruled at that time there would be no visitation. Murphy said that while he pursues the injunction for visitation in the chancery court he also would go back to Williams next week and ask the judge to change his mind. Advocates for children say that the case is unusual because damages are being sought from adoptive parents and the case involves siblings who have been separated. Bill Pierce, president of the National Committee for Adoption in Washington, D.C., called the case ``extremely rare.'' Murphy said the lawsuit was unusual because parents usually don't separate adopted chidlren. ``It's every little boy's nightmare,'' Murphy said after filing the lawsuit. ``Rick's parents told him they were going to put him into an orphange and they did it. It's like telling a kid you're going to send the bogey man after him and then doing it.'' Murphy said the boy, who is in a foster home, blames himself. The parents' attorney, Mary C. Martin, did not comment after the hearing.

DOC.HEAD: Prisoners Riot, Protesting Overcrowding Conditions
DOC.TEXT: Prisoners protesting overcrowded conditions rioted in two prisons Wednesday, taking over a building and burning mattresses, authorities said. Three inmates were injured at the San Sebastian Prison on the south side of the capital, said Red Cross spokesman Jorge Arroyo. He gave no further details. About 150 San Sebastian inmates took over a building, set fire to mattresses and destroyed furniture, said Rafael Gutierrez, director of police patrols. Police threw tear gas to restore order, he said. A riot at the Women's Prison a short while later was quelled quickly, authorities said. The prisoners have been complaining to the government for months about overcrowding. They are asking for better food and prompt legal decisions.

DOC.HEAD: Rock Hudson's Ex-Lover Files $22 Million Libel Suit Over Depiction in Book
DOC.TEXT: Rock Hudson's ex-lover claimed Wednesday in a $22 million libel lawsuit that he was maliciously portrayed as a psychotic criminal by the authors of a book about the late actor. Marc Christian, who won $5.5 million from the Hudson estate a year ago in a landmark AIDS lawsuit, said in a Superior Court lawsuit filed by celebrity lawyer Marvin Mitchelson that he was shamed by the book's depiction of him. The Tom Clark and Dick Kleiner book ``Rock Hudson, Friend of Mine,'' released last month, referred to Christian as ``a criminal, a thief, an unclean person, a blackmailer, a psychotic, an extortionist, a forger, a perjurer, a liar, a whore, an arsonist and a squatter,'' the lawsuit said. Mitchelson said the portrayal was false and that Christian was asking $11 million in general damages and $11 million in punitive damages for a loss of ``his reputation, shame and mortification.'' ``He's just not going to sit still for it,'' Mitchelson said. ``We asked them to take out all the passages we felt were libelous and they didn't take them out.'' In addition to Clark and Kleiner, the lawsuit names New York-based Pharos Books as defendants. Martha Clark, a spokeswoman for the publisher, did not return a phone call seeking comment. ``The written statements are libelous on their face because Christian is charged with improper and immoral conduct,'' Mitchelson said. ``They aren't backed up by any facts at all. ``The most scurrilous one of all was that Marc knew Hudson had AIDS at the time Hudson learned he had it,'' the attorney said. ``It says he might have known it before Hudson knew.'' That issue was prominent in Christian's suit against the Hudson estate. A jury ruled in February 1989 that Hudson was guilty of ``outrageous conduct'' for concealing his AIDS diagnosis from Christian, his lover for two years. Christian said he didn't learn of the actor's illness until a few months before Hudson, 58, died on Oct. 5, 1985. ``I thought I was a dead man,'' Christian testified about the terror that gripped him in the wake of the disclosure. Although Christian didn't contract AIDS and has tested negative for the presence of the virus, the judge and the jury found he deserved damages. It was a unique ruling in personal injury law on sexually transmitted diseases. The jury ruled Christian should get $21.5 million, but Superior Court Judge Bruce Geernaert ruled the amount excessive, deciding last April that it should be whittled down to $5.5 million. Mitchelson said Christian has received $600,000 so far, but the rest was tied up in appeals by the Hudson estate. He expects an appellate court decision by the end of the year.

DOC.HEAD: Cabinet Approves Plans for Massive Power Cuts, Four-Day Work Week
DOC.TEXT: The Cabinet on Wednesday ordered a four-day work week for government employees and approved major electricity cutbacks in Manila to cope with a critical power shortage. Under the plan, government offices will close on five consecutive Mondays starting April 23. The government urged major private companies to close on those Mondays and said electricity to large commercial users would be shut off during those days. Factories will lose power for four hours one day each week, the government said. Residential districts will continue to have daily power cuts of up to four hours. The state-run National Power Corp. (NPC), which generates electricity for sale to distributors, said the cutbacks were necessary because of power plant repairs and a drought that has reduced water levels at hydroelectric stations. ``The situation clearly calls for some sacrifice from all sectors,'' the government said in a statement. ``Realizing the seriousness of the situation, business and industrial groups have reached a consensus that power needs to be rationed on an equitable manner based on essentiality.'' NPC spokesman Alex Dizon said 12 of 22 power plants on Luzon, the main Philippine island, were not operational. He said some were undergoing regular maintenance, others were being repaired for damage sustained during a typhoon last year while others could not operate because of low water levels at hydroelectric stations. The 22 plants generate 2,982 megawatts, with at least 80 percent consumed by the metropolitan Manila area. Metropolitan Manila, which has a population of about 8 million, suffered frequent power outages last year until military dissidents launched a nine-day coup attempt against the government of President Corazon Aquino on Dec. 1. Rebels cited the power crisis as an example of alleged government incompetence. Officials of the power corporation had complained that they predicted the crisis as early as 1986 but that Mrs. Aquino's government stalled on their request to invest in new generating facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Pilot Strike Cripples Nepal Flights
DOC.TEXT: More than 100 pilots and crew members of the state airline staged a one-day strike Wednesday, forcing officials to cancel all domestic and international flights. The strike was to protest alleged human rights violations by the government and to express support with an ongoing movement for restoring multiparty democracy in the Himalayan kingdom. The Royal Nepal Airline Corp. pilots came to the airport wearing uniforms and carrying placards that read: ``Pilots Against Human Rights Violation.'' Some flight attendants and a few technicians also joined the strike, which was announced earlier this week. Government officials were not available for comment. ``We have cooperated with the government all along (but) now we are protesting because of the deplorable situation in the country. We want normalcy to return,'' said copies of handwritten statements distributed by the pilots at the Tribhuvan Airport. ``We can't just sit down and watch the events in the country as spectators,'' the unsigned statements said. The government says at least 16 people have been killed in clashes between demonstrators and police after the democracy movement was launched on Feb. 18. The movement leaders, the Nepali Congress Party and a coalition of left-wing parties, demand restoration of multiparty system in the non-partisan legislature called the Rashtriya Panchayat or the national assembly. The government rejects the demands, saying its proponents are trying to impose their system on a nation that already has a working democracy.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Sides Suspend Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with talks recessed; picks up 5th graf, `The strike...'
DOC.TEXT: Federally mediated negotiations to end a 2-day-old strike by 11,000 hospital workers at the nation's largest health maintenance organization recessed Wednesday with no progress reported. Negotiators for striking hospital workers and Kaiser Permanente agreed to resume their talks Thursday afternoon, said Tom Ramsay, spokesman for Local 399 of the Service Employees International Union. Both sides gathered at 1 p.m. Wednesday at the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service office, and met through the afternoon, said Kaiser Permanente spokeswoman Mary McCaughey. The strike by technicians, maintenance workers and licensed vocational nurses at the nation's oldest and largest HMO began at midnight Monday. The walkout affects hospitals in Anaheim, Los Angeles, West Los Angeles, Panorama City, Woodland Hills, Harbor City, and Bellflower, and more than 40 satellite medical offices. Kaiser said it had reduced the number of patients to an average of 47 percent of full occupancy at the seven affected hospitals. Some of the medical offices were closed. A similar session supervised by federal officials ended Saturday with no settlement, a day after the workers rejected a union negotiating team's recommendation on a $44 million, three-year contract offer. The company had guaranteed a 5 percent raise the first year and 3 percent raise the second and third years. Top pay for a licensed vocational nurse under the old contract was $13.01 per hour, according to Kaiser. Workers are demanding higher wages, but have not revealed their demands in detail. The Pasadena-based HMO has more than 1.5 million members in Los Angeles, Orange and Ventura counties, the areas affected by the strike. Kaiser Permanente, like other HMOs, offers its members medical care for a prepaid, fixed price, rather than on a pay-per-visit basis. Its emergency services were unaffected, but some patients had appointments postponed or moved to open clinics, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Hundreds Demonstrate in Support of Museum Exhibit
DOC.TEXT: About 1,000 people rallied Wednesday in support of a museum threatened with obscenity charges because it plans to exhibit sexually graphic photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe. The demonstrators at the downtown rally one block from the Contemporary Arts Center carried signs reading ``Censorship is Obscene'' and ``Greetings from Censornati.'' Police are investigating the six-week exhibit that opens Friday, and have said they reserve the right to shut it down. Sheriff Simone Leis Jr., a vetern anti-smut campaigner, has said nine of the 175 photographs in the show, depicting sadomasichistic and homosexual sex acts and nude children, may be criminally obscene. The controversy has produced an outpouring of support for the exhibit, Arts Center officials said. More than 3,000 tickets have been sold for the opening night. Margaret Landing, a secretary attending Wednesday's rally, said it was her first protest. ``I wouldn't have gone (to the museum) before this,'' she said. ``But who are they to say what I can't see? Now, I'm going.'' Art students from the University of Cincinnati carried a banner reading ``If You Give Artists Freedom of Expression, Soon Every American Will Want it.'' The Arts Center sued local and county authorities last week, seeking a jury verdict on whether the pictures violate community obscenity standards. A judge has set the first hearing in the case for Friday. Lawyers for the museum asked Wednesday for a judgment without trial in the museum's favor. They said all of the exhibit is constitutionally protected because it is legitimate art, and submitted supporting affidavits from officials at other museums. Some people who have seen the pictures say they are shocking but do not appeal to prurient interest. The Arts Center plans to run the nine photographs in a separate room that minors will be prohibited from entering. The Mapplethorpe pictures led Congress last year to limit federal support for the arts after Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., labeled them obscene. They later were shown without incident in Washington, D.C.; Philadelphia; Chicago; Boston; Hartford, Conn., and Berkeley, Calif. Mapplethorpe died of AIDS in March 1989. Leis has led community groups who closed all adult bookstores in Cincinnati. Then a prosecutor, in 1977 Leis prosecuted publisher Larry Flynt for pandering obscenity. Flynt was convicted, but a new trial was ordered and charges were dropped in 1985. The director of the Arts Center's board of trustees resigned last month because of pressures on his employer, a bank.

Lithuania's secessionist government has accused the Kremlin of backing forces bent on its overthrow, but also appeared to improve the climate for formal talks by expressing a willingness to make major concessions. ``The Soviet Union, with the aid of its army, supports a small group of its political supporters which is attempting to restore the old structures of the Soviet administration,'' Lithuania's Parliament said in a statement Wednesday. ``There is therefore a threat to overthrow the legally elected authority and the government,'' said the statement, broadcast on Lithuanian radio. In London, however, the republic's de facto spokesman expressed a willingness to agree to concessions including a continued Soviet military presence, the retention of current economic ties with Moscow and a referendum on independence. The announcement came from Algis Cekuolis, a foreign affairs adviser to Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis, and was the first such public offer from the Lithuanians.

Scientists have arranged 35 atoms to create what is probably the world's tiniest advertisement, attaining a precision that may one day lead to development of new materials and far faster computers. It took 22 hours of moving atoms one by one to create the letters ``IBM,'' researcher Donald Eigler said. The design, about 660 billionths of an inch long, is featured in a report by Eigler and Erhard Schweizer, who did the work at IBM's Almaden Research Center in San Jose, Calif. The report is in today's issue of the British journal Nature. Physicists called the work a significant step that demonstrates that individual atoms can be arranged with high precision.

The fiery crash of a small plane may have been caused by a struggle for control of the aircraft by a passenger dying of brain cancer and bent on suicide, investigators say. ``We thought we were investigating an air accident, and it has turned into something else,'' police spokesman David Grimm said Wednesday. The twin-engine plane plowed into a Boulder neighborhood Sunday, setting a house and garages ablaze and killing pilot James Wilford ``Bill'' Layne, 56, of Aurora and his passenger, Gordon Larry Hood, 45, of Atlanta, authorities said. Grimm said out-of-state acquaintances of Hood's said he had discussed plans to commit suicide by way of a fiery plane crash over Colorado because of terminal cancer.

``Putting out a newspaper without promotion is like winking at a girl in the dark _ well-intentioned but ineffective,'' said press mogul William Randolph Hearst. His quotation adorns an exhibit, ``The American Journalist: Paradox of the Press.'' It opens today at the Library of Congress and winks, in full self-consciousness, at the American press in every manifestation from feisty Hearst to feisty Benjamin Harris, America's first newsman. Harris published the first American newspaper on Sept. 25, 1690. It lasted one issue before it was closed down by the British authorities. The sole surviving copy was flown back from London for the exhibit. The show, underwritten by a $325,000 grant from the Gannett Foundation and running through Aug. 12, coincides with the 67th annual meeting of the American Society of Newspaper Editors, whose members gathered at the library Wednesday night to celebrate the occasion.

Latin American cocaine barons stymied by Washington's war on drugs are relying more and more on European ports to get their merchandise to U.S. streets, police say. Moreover, officials say, all across Europe police seizures of cocaine have at least doubled in the past few years and the drug is challenging heroin as the narcotic of choice on the continent. Last month, the National Police Intelligence Service published figures that show cocaine seizures in the Netherlands to have risen dramatically over the past three years. Dutch police confiscated 7,700 pounds of cocaine in the first three months of this year alone _ more than double the 3,120 pounds seized in all of last year and almost three times the 1,130 pounds in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: At the Tower of London, Armorers Preserve an Ancient Craft
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RESTORES dropped ``the workshop of'' in 1st graf
DOC.TEXT: Much lies behind the Tower of London's mustached Beefeaters, cobblestone lanes and ravens, including the workshop of Ted Smith and son, armorers, who preserve an ancient craft from extinction.yal Armory craftsmen and five assistants restore and conserve the 40,000 pieces of armor in the Tower collection. Smith, 62, will retire in 1992 and is passing on his knowledge of makin The two Rog and repairing armor to his 26-year-old son, Christopher. Behind a bright red door, away from the crown jewels and the 2 million tourists who flock to the 900-year-old Tower each year, the Smiths work together on a replica of a knight's fighting helmet made in northern Italy in 1460. Their one concession to modernity is a propane torch. All other materials and methods are authentic to the time. Medieval armorers used cumbersome coal forges. A propane torch makes it easier to work on those awkward lance-rests and chanfrons. ``We had a small forge for awhile, but it blew up a couple of times and, with a gallery directly above us, it wouldn't have been practical,'' Ted Smith explained. Ibrahim Nafei, a Mubarak confidant and editor of the leading newspaper Al-Ahram, expressed the government position: ``There can be no invalidation of the People's Assembly.'' The constitutional argument is part of a political tug-of-war that began almost as soon as Mubarak took office. A major issue has been the regular extension of an emergency enacted after Sadat was killed. It gives the executive branch wide powers of arrest and search without warrant, and bans strikes and demonstrations. Opposition parties want the law scrapped, but the government says it is a vital tool against Moslem extremists. The latest extension runs until spring 1991. Mubarak has not said whether he will disband the People's Assembly. An aide, Mustafa el-Fiki, said the president ``will act at the right time in the light of litigation,'' indicating he might await the Constitutional Court ruling. The constitution gives a president the right to dissolve parliament only with the electorate's approval in a referendum. In 1987, Mubarak called a referendum before the court upheld Khalid's suit against parts of the election law. The voters endorsed dissolution and elections two months later, in April. After the People's Assembly nominated Mubarak for a second six-year term in October 1987, voters approved him in another referendum. At the time, the political consensus that Mubarak dissolved parliament quickly because the presidential nomination was nearly at hand. This time, no such urgent business is pending.

DOC.HEAD: How to Remember the War, in a Way
DOC.TEXT: Are you nostalgic for slipping through the blackout to the alley door, savoring haute rutabaga and other joys of dining out in Nazi-occupied Paris? Drop in at The Curfew. Le Couvre-Feu, as the ``living theater'' restaurant is known in French, is near Montmartre and does not let diners in through the blackened street door on Rue Philippe de Girard. A young man in knickers and visored cap whispers: ``Go around to the back alley.'' Inside, the ambience changes to what might be the set of a Jean Renoir film _ zinc bar, photos of 1940s movie idols like Clark Gable and Humphrey Bogart, red banquettes, old black telephones. Proprietors Lulu and Maurice, played by actors, rush forward to ask if you've had any trouble getting there. A kir, or white-wine cassis, appears on the bar. Lulu is Catherine de Ville, who wears a flowery period dress but was born after the war. Edouard Bouzy, who plays Maurice, was born in 1938 and remembers little of the war years, except that ``we rarely had good food to eat.'' They do a lively job of re-creating the Resistance atmosphere. They take orders, shout at their ``children'' _ also actors _ and occasionally break into song. Their renditions of ``A la Bastille'' and ``Rue Saint-Vincent'' bring smiles or tears to customers old enough to remember the war. Many younger diners know the words well enough to join the singing. Bouzy learned the prewar skill of rolling cigarettes, so a burned-out butt hangs from the corner of his mouth. The restaurant, opened four months ago, is the idea of Roland Petitprez, who developed similar restaurants in Madrid. ``Every period has its own form of joie de vivre,'' said Petitprez, who was a little boy during the war. He remembers going to a restaurant much like the one he has made. ``We went after dark, when the curtains were closed, and we were able to eat treats like chicken and fried potatoes _ the produce smuggled in by farmers,'' Petitprez said. An antique radio blared the music that signaled wartime news broadcasts of the British Broadcasting Corp. Hidden radios were turned on across France to hear how the Allies were doing. Guests of Le Couvre-Feu chose more or less authentic food from the menu. ``Herring and potatoes are a period dish that I loved,'' said a patron, Carla Acquanegra, who remembered growing up during the German occupation. She pronounced the rabbit dish ``delicious and quite true to tradition,'' but noted that such food ``really was scarce for people like my family. We didn't have any relatives raising food in the country.'' Vegetables of the period included rutabaga, leeks and ``topinambours'' _ Jerusalem artichokes, which were served so often during the war that Carla now tends to avoid them. At one point in the evening, the lights went out, a loud knocking came at the door and an ``idiot nephew'' of Lulu and Maurice tumbled in, spilling ill-gotten ``black market'' goods on the floor to much scolding from Maurice. The party resumed. Lulu sang Piaf-style. Some diners jitterbugged. Jerome Mingueneau, the 30-year-old chef, emerged from his basement kitchen. ``I used a 1938 Cordon Bleu and other old cookbooks to re-create the traditional bourgeois and bistro styles,'' he said. Mingueneau's pate is from a 1796 recipe. Carla chose creme caramel, a typical dessert of the period, but another guest had a rich chocolate mousse. ``There was absolutely no chocolate until the Liberation,'' Carla said. Customers pay the equivalent of $52.50 for the show and dinner. Those who prefer a quiet meal without the dramatics can have lunch for about $16.50. Most patrons are French, but English and Americans come. Even some Germans visit The Curfew. ``They're welcome here, and seem to like it,'' Petitprez said.

DOC.HEAD: Ecologists Applaud Choice for New Environment Minister
DOC.TEXT: Defenders of nature say the appointment of Jose Lutzenberger, a noted ecologist, as Brazil's environment minister could signal an end to wanton destruction of the Amazon rain forest. The choice of Lutzenberger, 63, was seen as a victory for conservationists, who claim the government has done little to stop slash-and-burn devastation of the Amazon. He was named by President Fernando Collor de Mello, who took office March 15. By 1988, ranchers and farmers had destroyed about 8 percent of the rain forest in the 2 million square miles of Amazon wilderness, said U.S. researcher Philip Fearnside of the National Institute of Research in the Amazon. Carbon dioxide produced by the burning is believed to add to the ``greenhouse effect'' warming the Earth's surface. ``Lutzenberger is the right man in the right place; nobody else has his credibility,'' Johan Dalgas Frisch, head of the Wildlife Preservation Association in Sao Paulo, said in an interview. Antonio Carlos de Oliveira of the ecology group Oikos said: ``He is superimportant, a legend. We all have the greatest respect and admiration for him.'' Lutzenberger seeks radical changes in Brazil's environmental policy. He favors solar, wind and other natural forms of energy over the huge hydroelectric complexes of recent decades. A Rio newspaper made the wry comment that Lutzenberger was so radical about protecting nature that he even opposed lawn mowers. The new environment minister told The Associated Press: ``We have to question the fundamental doctrines of modern industrial society, which is geared to the needs of the powerful. We're not saying give up technology, but go a different way.'' In his first week on the job, Lutzenberger spoke out against the controversial Northern Rim project, which would create army posts to guard Brazil's vast jungle border. He also promised to review a decision that allowed gold miners to settle on land claimed by the primitive Yanomami Indians. Prospectors have invaded Yanomami land in the remote western Amazon state of Roraima, devastating the forest and bringing disease and death to the Indians. After consulting with Lutzenberger and visiting the area, Collor ordered the dynamiting of clandestine air strips on tribal land and said the Northern Rim project would be redirected toward protecting the environment. ``We must remove the prospectors, but we also must give them decent living conditions,'' Lutzenberger said. ``They are not there because they're bad or want to destroy.'' Lutzenberger, a descendant of German immigrants, is an agronomist with a degree from the University of Louisiana. In the 1970s, he resigned as a chemical company executive to join the ecology movement and helped found Brazil's first environmental protection group. Later, Lutzenberger established an environmental consulting firm. He pushed for tougher laws on pesticide control and for installation of anti-pollution filters at a cellulose plant in his native Rio Grande do Sul state, in southern Brazil. Lutzenberger was among the first to sound the alarm about the Amazon. ``This problem concerns all of humanity,'' he told reporters shortly after becoming environment secretary. ``It concerns the continuation of life on this planet. This requires not just plans for preservation, protection or parks. It requires fundamentally rethinking our economic programs.'' He appealed for help from industrialized countries. ``We must establish now an intensive and continuing dialogue between the governments of the First World and the Third World on how we can collaborate to save the last jungles,'' Lutzenberger told the journalists. One way, he said, is to write off part of Brazil's $114 billion foreign debt against programs to preserve the Amazon. Brazil has rejected such ``debt for nature'' swaps on grounds they violate national sovereignty. Of that, Lutzenberger said: ``The idea is to find ways to reduce the debt in exchange for the preservation of Amazonia by our government. There is not the slightest intention to `internationalize' the Amazon.'' A key test of his strength is likely to be a proposed highway from the western Amazon through Peru to the Pacific. Lutzenberger opposes the highway, but Peru and governors of Brazil's Amazonian states say it is vital to economic development in the region. Most of the governors supported Collor for president. ``The important thing to watch is how much power he has. Let's see what happens when he conflicts with the highway lobby,'' Fearnside, the U.S. researcher, said in a telephone interview from Manaus, in the Amazon jungle 3,000 miles northwest of Rio. Some fear Lutzenberger's well-known temper and firm convictions could work against him. ``If he's very radical, Collor will be pressured to get rid of him,'' Frisch said.
