DOC.HEAD: ABC's ``Twin Peaks'' Not So Pointed Pointed
DOC.TEXT: Billed as slightly twisted and preceded by enough hype to fill a railroad hopper car, David Lynch's ``Twin Peaks,'' a cutting-edge soap opera for prime time, will open Sunday on ABC with a two-hour premiere. Admirers of his cinematic oeuvre _ oeuvre is French for ``whole bunch of stuff'' _ may say ``Peaks'' has subhematomal echoes of his neo-noir ``Blue Velvet'' but not the nonlinear Greco-Roman postmodernism of ``Eraserhead.'' Well, okay, some critics do talk that way. But gee, this series, which starts its regular Thursday run next week, really seems more like a beautifully filmed Pacific Northwest edition of ``Peyton Place'' set in avant-garde mist. Full of slightly askew moments and characters, it also is rife with little visual bumps to tip you that Things Are Not Always What They Seem. It's an admirable effort to battle cable by offering something different in network TV. ABC deserves a cheer for that. But Sunday's premiere, directed and co-written by Lynch, occasionally edges close to plumb boring. At times, you fear there has been a ruling that the director, not the play, is the thing. The proceedings occur in Washington, near the Canadian border, in a small make-believe logging town called Twin Peaks. This hamlet, surrounded by lovely, cloud-shrouded woods, appears to be nice, peaceful, normal. But all that starts changing early on, when a fisherman discovers the plastic-wrapped body of a slain high school homecoming queen. Naturally, her no-good, leather-jacketed boyfriend is a prime suspect. Unlike the usual TV epic, the show's early moments contain leisurely digressions and characters that aren't firmly and immediately established. That's not all bad. But it wears thin after awhile. One gets a tad impatient waiting for things to get moving and for the stylistic fog to lift just a little. Those who wait, and they should bring lunch, eventually will learn that there is a killer at large, apparently a sadist and rapist who preys on high school girls. A serial killer? Maybe. Or maybe not. Ominous ambiguity is a major part of the proceedings. Bit by bit, you learn that Twin Peaks is full of dark secrets, subplots and furtive sex between consenting adults, high school kids or a combination thereof. But that's not enough nowadays. So, by golly, there's also surrealism here, although it's the low-key kind, nothing really far out. For example, nobody suddenly up and shoots his morning's Wheaties. Too bad. That would give the show a cereal killer. On the bright side, there is a sheriff's deputy who cries every time he's at a murder scene. Also a deranged-looking psychiatrist who laughs about his dark secret. And a group of potential land investors from ... Norway. There also is a lovely, mysterious Chinese woman. She has what seems to be a light secret. Not so two townsfolk, one a brutalized minor, the other a trucker; they prove to be advertisers in a swinger's magazine. This being the TV version of Lynch's auteur theory, there are various examples of his celebrated eccentric vision _ like a nighttime shot of a traffic light changing from green to amber to red. Hmm, symbolic. Other auteur highlights: a bad rich girl's feet in saddle shoes; a flickering light in a morgue, and a dreamlike fight in a biker bar as a soft-rock vocalist gently sings. Meanwhile, back at the plot, the main event is an investigation of two things _ the homecoming queen's murder and the rape and attempted murder of another high school girl. The investigators here are Sheriff Harry S. Truman (of course) and FBI agent Dale Cooper, played by Michael Ontkean and ``Blue Velvet'' graduate Kyle MacLachlan, respectively. The sheriff is the strong, calm type. The young, razor-sharp agent is a tad weird, amazed at all the Douglas firs he sees, and constantly dictating all manner of things into his tape recorder, included a misquote of W.C. Fields. Ontkean and MacLachlan are first-rate. In fact, all the actors in ``Twin Peaks'' are good. But the only thing that truly keeps the show interesting is Angelo Badalamenti's always-moving score. It's a solid plus, even though mostly played on a synthesizer, a machine that is to music what helium is to combustion. Because of all the hoopla about ``Twin Peaks,'' the show doubtless will get a large, curious audience _ at least in its first hour _ on opening night. But unless Thursday's continuation of the plot is an improvement over Chapter One, the series that began as a rare network display of avant-garde may soon wind up as a video museum piece.

Elsewhere in television ... CAN WE TALK IMMEDIATELY?: Starting April 30, the syndicated ``The Joan Rivers Show'' will be broadcast almost live _ with a seven-second delay so any naughty bits can be blipped immediately. Each show previously was shown two to three weeks after it was taped. The idea is to take advantage of River's topical humor abilities, a spokesman says. Of the 146 stations now carrying her talk show, 35 will carry the live version, with the others taping it for same-day broadcast. The show also will start featuring top gossip columnists from newspapers and magazines on a once-a-week basis. Every Monday, one chosen gossip columnist will relay uplifting lowdown to Rivers' viewers.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Company Reforms Emerge As Hot Political Issues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This is another in a series of stories planned in advance of 20th anniversary observances for Earth Day this month.
DOC.TEXT: Even an environmental debacle like the Huntington Beach oil spill generates its own kind of gallows humor, including this joke among residents: Question: What do you get when you mix oil and water? Answer: Politicians. In this case, it seemed as if there were one politician for every barrel of oil washing up on Surf City U.S.A. So many politicians took to the blackened sands of Huntington Beach to condemn the Feb. 7 spill from the ruptured American Trader tanker that Mayor Tom Mays had to ask them to go through his office first so they wouldn't interfere with the cleanup. In this election year, talking tough against the oil companies, with proposals to ban offshore drilling and to enact strict tanker safety measures, adds up to smart politics. For the first time in a decade, environmentalists, politicians and even some oil industry executives expect this 20th anniversary year of Earth Day to bring sweeping reform to the oil industry. The reform movement is being pushed by oil spills in Alaska, California, New York, New Jersey and Louisiana and a growing feeling among Americans that more should be done to protect the environment. Possible changes include requiring double hulls and bottoms on tankers, shifting shipping lanes farther offshore, better charting of the ocean bottom, improving procedures for oil spill cleanup, and putting a fourth year-long moratorium on new offshore drilling. ``The interest in the general public in protecting the coastline is at an all-time high,'' declared Ann Whitfield, executive director of the Florida Public Interest Research Group. The oil industry, meanwhile, worries about an overreaction that could stifle U.S. oil production and return the country to the days of oil embargoes and gas lines. But even many oil officials concede more must be done to avoid spills and to minimize damage when they occur. ``While it is impossible to guarantee that future accidents will never happen, we are committed to working to prevent them and to improving the industry's safety record,'' said James Benton, executive director of the New Jersey Petroleum Council. Benton spoke at a recent meeting between oil executives and officials of New York and New Jersey, where four major spills in the first 10 weeks of 1990 dumped almost 730,000 gallons of heating oil and heavy crude into the Arthur Kill and Kill van Kull waterways between New York City and northern New Jersey. The first major reform is under consideration in Washington. Legislation pending in Congress would require double hulls and double bottoms on tankers. Engineers speculate that a double hull could have prevented the Huntington Beach spill, apparently the result of the tanker striking its own anchor, and lessened the effects of the Exxon Valdez disaster, in which the tanker ripped open on a reef in Alaska's Prince William Sound. Eyes are also on President Bush, who pledged in his campaign to be the ``environmental president,'' to see whether he will try to reinstate oil and gas drilling in federal waters after the moratorium expires this year. The issue is of particular importance in California, where oil companies have proposed developing millions of acres off the coasts of central and Northern California. Off Florida, companies want to drill in tracts north of the Keys. Many member of Congress say that if Bush decides to resume additional drilling, they are prepared to seek another moratorium. ``The administration is in a quagmire in the sense that the politics of California, a very crucial gubernatorial race and the president's own commitments in the state are in conflict with president's gut instincts as a former oilman on offshore drilling,'' said Rep. Leon Panetta, D-Monterey. Some of the most active work on oil industry reforms is going on at the state level. Even before the Huntington Beach spill, the environment was a hot political issue in California. All three candidates for governor _ U.S. Sen. Pete Wilson, state Attorney General John Van de Kamp and former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein _ have tried to one-up each other in pledging love for Mother Earth. Wilson, a Republican, is a longtime opponent of offshore drilling, so much so that his stance strained relations with the White House in the early months of the administration. In addition, state Controller Gray Davis and Lt. Gov. Leo McCarthy say their re-election is important to maintain their 2-1 lock on the three-member State Lands Commission _ and a virtual ban on additional drilling. ``I'm a strong environmentalist and I'm committed to remaining a good steward for California's magnificent coastline,'' Davis said. ``It doesn't take a genius to see that if you change one or two people on that board you change the direction of California's coast.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Tues PMs, April 10

For Release Monday PMs, April 9, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Times Square Plan: Miracle or Mirage?
DOC.TEXT: After nine years of bickering, 42 lawsuits, design changes and false starts, a $2.5 billion plan to sanitize tawdry Times Square is about to become reality. Or is it? The 42nd Street Development Project says groundbreaking is in sight; opponents say it might never come to pass. ``Is it alive or dead? I don't think anybody knows,'' said Kent Barwick, president of the Municipal Art Society, a non-profit organization that analyzes and addresses aesthetic issues affecting New York City, particularly architecture and planning. Not a single spade of dirt has been turned in the government-backed project, but the mere promise of it has helped trigger brisk construction by private developers elsewhere in the neighborhood. Critics say that means the development project has served its purpose and should just fade away. The project's parent, the state Urban Development Corp., wants to replace run-down buildings in the historic entertainment district with four office towers, ranging from 32 to 57 stories and glitzed up with signs, lights and mirrors. A merchandise mart and new hotel are on the back burner. The idea is to discourage drug dealers, muggers, con artists and prostitutes. ``There's a sense that Times Square has become a more menacing place,'' said sociologist William Kornblum of the City University Graduate Center, who has studied the district for 12 years. In 1988, 2,246 felony crimes were reported on 42nd Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue, an area of just over a block. Safety was a major concern of Madeline ``Dominique'' D'Anthony, proprietor of the Harmony burlesque theater, when she moved three years ago to the artsy Tribeca area, near Wall Street. Her landlord had sold the building at 48th Street and Broadway where she'd done business for 10 years. ``Just because I'm in the burlesque business doesn't mean I like 42nd Street,'' she said. ``I was offered a rental situation there but didn't take it, because I'm not walking down that block.'' D'Anthony, who strives to keep her business ``tasteful'' _ no barkers, unseemly pictures or neon `Girls! Girls! Girls!' signs outside _ said it's wrong to blame the crime on the sex industry. ``Volume is what attracts crime,'' she said. ``When you put all those places together, you create a high-traffic situation _ drug pushers, pickpockets, they get lost in the crowd. ... ``When I left Times Square, I noticed immediately that my good customers stayed with me and the riff-raff stayed in Times Square. My girls said the same thing,'' she said. Barwick blames the blight on real estate speculation. ``Since everybody had been led to believe for generations that the area would be creamed to make way for high-rise offices, people weren't taking care of their buildings,'' he said. Still, critics say flooding Times Square with office workers in suits would douse the vitality and offbeat flavor of one of the world's most famous entertainment districts. ``I think the Times Square cacophony is a delight, a visual riot,'' said Stephen F. Wilder, a member of Community Board 5, a volunteer advisory board of area residents and business people. ``It's truly the one place in the city, historically, where different classes and races and kinds of people came together,'' said Barwick. ``Cities need such places for their spirit and soul and their economies.'' ``Times Square still has a national and international cachet,'' agreed Kornblum. ``One hears, when you interview people on the streets as we do, a sense of disappointment in some circles: how did it get to be this shabby? But the whole of Times Square _ the lights and the glitter _ has the capacity to get people's blood rushing.'' Some say the redevelopment would eradicate appealing old architecture and wipe out cheap entertainment, especially for low-income patrons. Depending on whom you ask, it would cause midtown real estate values to plummet _ or drive them up, affecting business costs and livelihoods in the adjoining Garment District. Brian Kell, spokesman for the 42nd Street project, said the groundbreaking for the towers now is targeted for early next year. On Thursday, the state Court of Appeals refused to hear a suit by Wilder that sought further review of the project under state environmental guidelines. Kell predicted his side also would win two final lawsuits within a few months. One, a suit against the Metropolitan Transportation Authority before the state Court of Appeals, concerns bidding procedures for Times Square subway reconstruction. In the other, before a federal court, a realty company is trying to stop the project on grounds, among others, that it lacks a public purpose. After the disposition of the last two suits, Kell expects state Supreme Court Justice Stanley J. Parness to rule on the 42nd Street Development Project's request to condemn 34 theaters, book stores, video shops, T-shirt shops, mom-and-pop grocery stores and other properties. The developers for the Urban Development Corp. project _ the Prudential Insurance Co. and Park Tower Realty _ can cancel the deal any time after June 21, said Gary Rosenberg, attorney for the Durst Organization, which filed three suits against the project. ``We believe they have an absolute right to walk at that point with no liability,'' Rosenberg said. ``We think they will.'' He said there are no tenants for the proposed office towers. ``We expect that at this point everybody is looking for a way out. You need a good face-saver,'' Rosenberg said. But supporters say developers are committed to the project. ``Until it is redeveloped, the cancer will remain in the center of Times Square,'' said Gerald Schoenfeld, chairman of the Shubert organization and head of the Mayor's Midtown Citizens Committee. ``It is essential to legitimate theater. It is essential to the image of New York. It is essential to the ... community. It is essential to tourism.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday PMs, April 9

For release PMs Friday April 6
DOC.HEAD: Foreign Brokers Making Points Amid Tokyo's Stock Woes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: John Cunniff is on assignment.
DOC.TEXT: Foreign brokers, who had a hard time riding the bulls on the Tokyo stock market, are wrestling the bears with greater success. Nearly all the 50-odd foreign brokerages in Tokyo reported losing money during the late 1980s. The 22 with seats on the Tokyo Stock Exchange paid huge sums to get there, and the others faced vast start-up costs as well. As of March 1988, for example, 14 of the top 20 foreign houses were in the red. But having absorbed the one-time expenses and gained market experience, many are well-positioned to capitalize on a plunging market. While many decline to specify profits for the first quarter, a period of sharp decline in Tokyo stocks, they claim an edge in research, experience with bear markets and facility in hedging techniques. At the French house of W.I. Carr, Deputy Branch Manager John Price said, ``For the first three months of the year, we're showing profits on all our books.'' This resulted, he said, from caution, diversification and a concentration on advising institutional investors overseas on how to deal with turbulent Japanese stocks. ``When market times are very rough, we do quite well,'' Price said. He said the firm had kept its exposure to stocks down to about 30 percent of its in-house limit during the plunge, while doing well with alternative investments, such as options and futures. ``We're not complaining,'' Price said. American firms have deeper experience in trading futures contracts based on stock market indexes and in arbitrage. Using computers, they spot profit opportunities in rapidly shifting gaps between futures and spot prices for stock indexes. ``Options in futures provide a tool for dealing with the downside market,'' said Kevin Parker, chief of futures trading at Morgan Stanley International. Parker said volume on the spot market had been very light, making it difficult to sell shares without a loss. ``You can't sell stocks, but there is ample opportunity ... in futures to hedge portfolios, and many institutions have done just that,'' he said. Trading in stock-index futures began in Tokyo in September 1988 but became really active only this year. Parker attributed this to expanding price swings in the market since January, rising to ``over five times the historical average'' in recent days. Mike Morizumi, a strategist with Merrill Lynch Japan, said one result of the market's slump has been to bring his firm's research capabilities into prominence. ``Over the past three years ... just about any company in any sector showed pretty good earnings and sales. Looking at the fine print in the balance sheets back then didn't make much difference,'' he said. But the nearly 30 percent loss on the stock market has created widely divergent trends among Japanese companies, Morizumi added. Japanese competitors are formidable in sales strategy, he said, but their research is often subordinated to sales tactics. In contrast, since the market reversal began, ``we've made a lot of sales points with our research,'' Morizumi said, especially with Japanese clients whose former brokers had led them to believe the bulls would run indefinitely. Foreign brokerages largely relied on foreign clients in the past. But this is clearly changing. Betty Wu, a broker at Hong Kong-based SBCI Securities (Asia), said foreign institutional clients had turned increasingly sour on the Tokyo market this year. ``Some have sold out their entire portfolios,'' she said. Thus, she said, her company has emphasized domestic sales. ``We've been doing well,'' Wu said, ``because we've been very successful in hiring Japanese sales people ... who have a very solid client base.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for PMs Friday April 6

For Release Friday AMs, April 6, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Shortage Of Dutch Nuns and Priests Sparks Foreign Imports
DOC.TEXT: Nuns, monks and priests once were a common sight in Dutch schools and hospitals, but some are now being imported from the United States and elsewhere to keep alive Roman Catholic orders and clergy. Six nuns from the order of Poor Clare in Roswell, N.M., came to this Dutch village in March in a series of foreign arrivals that has already brought parish priests from Poland and a university pastor from Spain. Reform-minded Catholics worried about the American nuns' reputation for conservatism denounce the plan as ``reactionary'' and say it won't work. But the church leadership hopes the project will mean deliverance for an ailing Poor Clare monastery in Eindhoven, 25 miles away, where 14 nuns, aged 48-100, haven't seen any newcomers since 1984. The American sisters will move into a recently renovated convent, and move to Eindhoven if they succeed in attracting young Dutch nuns. Only 12 Dutch women and 50 men took holy orders or the cloth in 1988, while 898 died and 43 quit, according to a report compiled by the Catholic research institute KASKI. More than 21,000 people in this nation of 14.8 million are members of a Catholic religious order, but about three quarters of them live in retirement, the report said. ``Faith in all of the Netherlands has been put on the back burner,'' said Sister Celine, a spokeswoman for the Eindhoven Poor Clare Monastery of the Immaculate Conception of Mary. ``If we don't have any new vocations we won't be able to keep this up much longer.'' About 60 Poor Clare nuns still live in the Netherlands, where they are part of what used to be an intensely Catholic social fabric setting its stamp on much of the nation's southern half. In the 1950s, schools, hospitals and homes for the elderly here were staffed by nuns and priests, and southern Dutch politics were dominated by the Roman Catholic People's Party, now part of Premier Ruud Lubbers' Christian Democrats. But the era that followed saw rapid economic growth and the development of a welfare state that took over most of the charitable work that had been traditional church territory. Today, only 15 percent of the Netherlands' 5.5 million nominal Catholics are regular churchgoers, according to the KASKI report. ``The social role of the religious orders has been taken over by the state ... health care, education, looking after the sick, they don't have anything left to them in those areas,'' said Kees van Hasselt, spokesman for Bishop Johannes ter Schure of the southern diocese of Den Bosch, who supports the Elshout project. ``Young people can sign up as (foreign) aid workers'' instead of becoming missionaries, Sister Celine agreed. ``They get more opportunity to study, to get better jobs (and) to enjoy themselves'' in the secular world. However, the Elshout project has pitted Bishop ter Schure, a pro-Vatican hardliner, against liberal Catholics who regard it as an attempt to yank them back to the straight and narrow. ``It's a reactionary plan, part of Den Bosch's policy of turning back the clock,'' said Peter de Rijk of the May Eight Movement, which spearheaded opposition within the Catholic Church to the 1985 Dutch visit of Pope John Paul II. De Rijk noted that the sisters from Boswell will be living in strict separation from the outside world. Dutch Clarissan nuns no longer observe that statute, which once made the Poor Clare order one of the most ascetic groups in the Catholic Church. ``This is no way to restore monastic life. It's certainly not a method that we would approve of,'' said Ton Smits of the Dutch Monastic Association, which represents all Catholic religious orders. The liberal response is similar to widespread criticism triggered by the 1988 arrival of three priests from the pontiff's native Poland, and of a Spanish university pastor in 1982. ``We are daughters of the church, very loyal to the Holy Father,'' said a spokeswoman for the Roswell group, Mother Mary Francis. ``We're coming to serve, not to argue. I hate anybody to be suspicious of us.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, April 6

For Release Friday AMs, April 6, and Thereafter
DOC.TEXT: The heads of two major Protestant denominations say they were outraged that heavy Panamanian civilian deaths ``were virtually ignored by our government and media'' in connection with the December U.S. invasion. The Rev. Paul Sherry of the United Church of Christ and the Rev. John O. Humbert of the Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) voiced their criticism in a joint letter to officials of the Latin American Council of Churches. The U.S. church leaders said they had been concerned at the ``cruelty of Gen. Manuel Noriega,'' who removed from Panamanian rule in the invasion, but the churchmen added: ``We do not support an action that represents such a flagrant violation of national sovereignty and disregard for human life.'' The letter charged ``around 2,000 Panamanians'' were killed in the U.S. military action. Panamanian authorities say 314 Panamanians died, 202 of them civilians, and 23 Americans.
Despite the hardness of wooden pews, 42 percent of regular church-goers in Great Britain say they sometimes fall asleep in church, a survey found.
Xavier University has conferred honorary doctorates of humanities degrees on the six priests-professors slain by military-garbed raiders last Nov. 16 at the Jesuit university in San Salvador.

The United Methodist Division of Higher Education is recommending a special emphasis on campus ministry, saying it has declined for the last 20 years but is vital to the future of U.S. culture. ``Stakes are high for the church and the nation,'' a working paper said. It said the 1990s will bring ``several new and portentous ingredients'' to society of wide influence and that they ``converge on the college campus.''

The Lutheran World Federation reports that a census in Iceland found that 253,482 Icelanders _ 92.9 percent of the population _ are affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church of Iceland. Roman Catholics numbered 2,367, while 3,364 declared themselves non-religious.

A poll of readers of the monthly U.S. Catholic finds that most of them want Roman Catholicism to reverse its bans on birth control and the ordination of women and married men. ``After all, we know that some of the apostles were married,'' wrote one reader, Lorrainie Free of Smyrna, Ga. The majority, however, supported the church position against abortion and premarital sex. The magazine is published by the Claretian order.

Poland's Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki says Poland stands ready to assist in the transfer of Soviet Jews to Israel. Recalling that Jews in Poland have been ``an important part of our history, tradition and culture,'' Mazowiecki told an American Jewish Congress dinner: ``Just as in the Middle Ages, Poland did not evade giving help to Jews persecuted in other countries, so today Poland will not evade humanitarian assistance to Jews emigrating from the Soviet Union.''

The National Association of Evangelicals charges the New Age movement with ``shallow pop-psychology of self-indulgent self-affirmation'' and ``synthetic blending of half truths'' in a ``spiritual world that it does not understand.'' The criticisms came in a resolution at the association's annual convention. It installed the Rev. E. Edgar Johnson, general secretary of the Church of the Nazarene, based in Kansas City, Mo., as new president for a two-year term.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, April 6

DOC.HEAD: Senate Republicans on the Offensive in 1990 Elections
DOC.TEXT: The numbers say this election year should be a good one for Democrats to strengthen their hold on the Senate. But since candidates and not numbers win elections, it's the GOP that's on the offensive. ``We have a better crop of challengers this time than we've ever had,'' said Sen. Don Nickles, R-Okla., chairman of the National Republican Senatorial Committee. ``I'd be happy and pleased and I think we would say we've done a good job if we stay the same'' in Democratic strength, said Sen. John Breaux, D-La., chairman of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee. By tradition, an off-year election bodes well for the party that doesn't control the White House. And from a distance, it looks like this one should follow the pattern. Democrats have a 55-45 majority in the Senate, but the Republicans have more seats at risk. Of the 34 Senate seats on the line, the GOP must defend 18 and the Democrats 16. Three incumbent Republicans are retiring, heightening the apparent Democratic opportunity. But seven months before the election, it appears the Democrats have failed to recruit many top-flight candidates while the GOP has succeeded. That gives Republicans hope they can narrow the Democrats' majority this year and perhaps reclaim control of the Senate in 1992. In all three cases where Republican senators are stepping down this year, GOP House members have stepped forward as candidates and are the early front-runners. In Colorado, where Sen. Bill Armstrong is retiring, Rep. Hank Brown hopes to step into the breach. Popular Rep. Robert Smith is running for the seat being vacated by Sen. Gordon Humphrey in New Hampshire. And in Idaho, Rep. Larry Craig is seeking to succeed Sen. James A. McClure. Four other House Republicans are taking the far riskier leap into races against incumbent Democrats _ creating potentially the hottest Senate contests in the nation. The Iowa Senate campaign already is steaming as Republican Rep. Tom Tauke challenges incumbent Democrat Tom Harkin. In Illinois, GOP Rep. Lynn Martin has had help from President Bush in her challenge against Democratic Sen. Paul Simon. In Rhode Island, Republican Rep. Claudine Schneider is trying to unseat a popular but aging Democratic Sen. Claiborne Pell. And in Michigan, Republican Rep. Bill Schuette is in a primary fight against conservative activist Clark Durant for the right to challenge Democratic Sen. Carl Levin. Another close race is shaping up in Nebraska, where former Republican Rep. Hal Daub, who failed in a Senate bid two years ago, is challenging Democratic incumbent Sen. J. James Exon. Another Democratic incumbent that Republicans consider vulnerable is Sen. Max Baucus of Montana. The list of Republican challengers there includes Lt. Gov. Allen Kolstad. Meanwhile, no Republican senators who are seeking re-election appear to be in serious trouble so far. Poll results suggest that GOP Sens. Jesse Helms in North Carolina and Mitch McConnell in Kentucky are vulnerable, but potential Democratic challengers still are fighting among themselves in both states. Although some House Democrats flirted with entering Senate races, none did. And in several cases, popular present and former state office holders passed up seemingly good opportunities to move to Washington. The Democrats tried hard to recruit candidates ``but their efforts just seemed to come up a little bit short,'' said political analyst Charles Cook. Finding a good Senate candidate is mostly luck of the draw and ``this time, the Republicans got all the breaks,'' he said. The result is apparent security for the GOP _ even a slim chance of taking control of the Senate if they can sweep all of the close races _ while ``Democrats have too many seats close to the edge,'' Cook said. A 50-50 split would give Republicans control, because the Republican vice president would break tie votes. If the Republicans trimmed the Democratic majority to less than two or three seats after this election, the GOP would be in a good position to retake the Senate in 1992 when 20 Democrats and only 14 Republicans face re-election. There is talk of two more races being added to the 34 scheduled this fall. Hawaii Democrat Spark Matsunaga has cancer and must be brought into the Senate chamber by wheelchair to vote. Although he has not indicated he will resign, potential successors have been quietly eyeing his seat. A Senate Ethics Committee investigation of Sen. Dave Durenberger's personal finances has led to speculation that the Minnesota Republican might resign if serious charges were brought. Breaux, who leads the Senate Democrats' campaign committee, said his lack of Senate challengers from the House isn't the handicap the Washington cognoscenti make it out to be. ``Who's to say that House members are better candidates than people who are not from Washington and can run against the mistakes and the problems that Washington is in fact responsible for?'' he asked. Breaux acknowledged, though, that he's hoping for some upsets. One race where he sees potential is Democratic businessman Ted Muenster's bid to oust Republican Sen. Larry Pressler in South Dakota. The Democratic drive to hold the line this year is fueled by the specter of 1992. ``I'm running down the track looking over my left shoulder and then I turn and look over my right shoulder,'' said Breaux, who faces re-election himself in two years. Neither Breaux nor Nickles saw an overriding national theme in this year's races. Breaux said the abortion issue could help Democrats in several pro-choice states where the Republican candidate has an anti-abortion stance, as is the case in Iowa and Michigan. It also could give Democrats an upset, perhaps in New Hampshire or Oregon, where anti-abortion incumbent Mark O. Hatfield is being challenged by Democratic businessman Harry Lansdale. Nickles discounts abortion's role in the next election. Republican gubernatorial losses in New Jersey and Virginia last fall may have been due to anti-abortion stands because ``Republicans did a poor job responding,'' and that won't happen this time, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Resurrection of Nations
Part I: Rise of Eastern Europe From Despotism
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto Illustration
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: An unexpected resurrection of nations from totalitarianism has swept Eastern Europe in recent months, reintroducing long-trampled freedoms and reducing international distrust. The first story in a five-part Easter series, ``Resurrection of Nations,'' examines the surprising upheaval and its religious threads.

In a blink, the landscape heaved and the world changed. People could hardly believe it. Amazed, incredulous, they saw a new reality dawning over the earth, surmounting old fears and fatalism. The grim, immutable facts of their existence were suddenly not what they had seemed. That baffled astonishment among Eastern Europeans at their burst from bondage also resonates in the recorded reaction to the resurrection of Christ and the liberating word of Easter. ``It has indeed been miraculous, a miracle that happened in the souls of people,'' said the Rev. John Meyendorff, a scholar of the Russian-derived but independent Orthodox Church in America. ``It has been a resurrection from a long deadening of individual creativity and the God-given dignity of being human for millions of people.'' No one could have predicted its suddenness and sweep, he said. ``I never thought I'd live to see it. People are finding it hard to believe.'' An ``idle tale,'' he apostles scoffed at first reports of Christ's resurrection. It made no sense, the buried restored to life? They couldn't conceive of it until it confronted them, directly and plainly. Likewise, it had seemed impossible that half a continent coumenon, the Berlin Wall _ that barrier of cold war that for three decades had divided humanity, literally and figuratively _ at last came tumbling down Nov. 9. Among rejoicing throngs, an East German friar said with a chuckle, ``The iron curtain is not so much iron anymore.'' The wall's demise and the rest of the whirlwind that freed nations and eased superpower antagonisms symbolically reflected a Scripture passage on Christ's crucifixion and resurrection: ``For he is our peace, who has made us both one, and has broken down the dividing wall of hostility.'' The changes came in tidal profusion in the Soviet Union and its satellite countries, one after another, like some pent-up force breaking loose, uncontainable, overflowing, toppling tyrants, unleashing multitudes from their chains. Almost magically, the changes came generally without violence, in so-called ``soft'' or ``velvet'' revolutions. ``Not by might, nor by power, but by my Spirit, says the Lord of hosts,'' the biblical prophet Zechariah said. Just as Christ's resurrection defied logic, so on another plane did the breakthrough of nations. The sweeping transformation of 1989 contradicted all prior analyses and predictions. It went against the prognostications of the keenest thinkers and the gloomiest doomsayers. ``It is difficult to think of any series of developments more astonishing,'' said Roman Catholic historian-theologian Richard McBrien. Harvard historian Richard Pipes wrote: ``The recent events there have surpassed the wildest fantasies of any observer of Soviet affairs who was willing to go on record.'' The facts, those grim facts of life in the Soviet bloc, were suddenly turned upside down. Just as the crucified arose, Eastern Europe's long coerced and silenced millions lurched forth into the exhilarating, yet bewilderingly unfamiliar light of new freedom. ``We are like children waking from a nightmare in the middle of the night,'' Emilian Mercan, a member of the hastily formed provisional government of Craiova, Romania, said after the mid-December collapse of the harsh Ceausescu regime. ``All we want is reassurance that it won't happen again.'' Gradually, the countries of Eastern Europe are permitting such gifts to the spirit as the freedoms to speak out, assemble, organize and vote. But the daybreak atmosphere, like life itself, is loaded with risk and uncertainty. ``It happened so quickly,'' said Petar Darliev, a Bulgarian imprisoned for nine years who at 74 is helping plan the country's first multiparty elections in 45 years, scheduled for June. ``The hard part starts now.'' It ``is a peculiar drama, which no Earthling could have written,'' said previously imprisoned playwright Vaclav Havel, chosen to be Czechoslovakia's president by a new parliament in December. General elections are set for June 8. Of the times before the crucifixion, the apostle Paul wrote, ``We know that the whole world has been groaning in travail until now.'' For much of the 20th century, the globe has been groaning, caught in a tightening nuclear stranglehold, with no apparent way to escape. But the metamorphosis provided by Christ has come, in a different order, for nations. Writing after Christ rose from the tomb, Paul said, ``So then you are no longer strangers and sojourners, but fellow citizens ... and members of the household of God.'' The pace and scope of the changes have left statesmen and pundits groping for reasons, scrambling to adjust to the transfigured scene. They came in such a mounting crescendo as to seem almost sheer revelation. ``One sees evidence of divine providence in human events like this,'' said church historian Robert T. Handy. ``Who could have thought it would happen?'' Handy, historian emeritus of New York's Union Theological Seminary, said he was ``worried about a backlash. We're still dealing with politics.'' But he cited church involvement in Eastern Europe's reform movements in saying: ``The ferment for freedom has always been very strong in the Jewish-Christian tradition. It boils up again and again, and has throughout history. It can be put down, but it boils up again. .. . ``The hand of God can be seen in these developments,'' Handy added. ``God does work in history.'' So do people, what Scripture calls God's co-workers. Jesus, in giving up his life for a greater one at Easter, said people would have to endure oppression and pain, but a better time beckoned. ``You will be sorrowful,'' he said before his death at the hands of an occupation military regime that dominated a subjugated people. ``But your sorrow will turn into joy.''

DOC.HEAD: Resurrection of Nations
Part II: Change at the Core
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto Illustration
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: All at once, democratic processes have come alive in the Soviet Union, its monolithic communist system starting to crumble after 72 years of regimentation. That enormous change at the core of communism, the Soviet Union, is the focus of the second story in a five-part Easter series, ``Resurrection of Nations.''

When Secretary of State James A. Baker III met with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze in Wyoming last fall, they exchanged gifts. Baker gave cowboy boots to Shevardnadze, who presented Baker with an enameled picture of Jesus teaching the people. ``You see,'' Shevardnadze remarked, ``even we communists are changing our world view.'' Recalling the incident later, Baker surmised that some innate ``resurgence of faith'' may have been at the roots of the revolutionary changes sweeping Eastern Europe. The lightning-like reformation that has flashed over the Soviet colossus and its peripheries is ``so striking that it marks the beginning of a new era something is happening at the churches.'' In the land where 15th century reformer Martin Luther fired his protest against Rome's ecclesiastical domination, the churches became havens, rallying places and an umbrella for political as well as religious voices of reform. ``No other social force in the country had independence from the state and party'' and could thus supply space for dialogue and inspiration, said pastor Werner Widrat of Lutheran Gethsemane Church in East Berlin. Bolstering their peaceful tactics, the pre-demonstration services often included Scripture readings from the Beatitudes: ``Blessed are the peacemakers. ... Blessed are those who are presecuted for righteousness sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven.'' The churches had adopted the non-violent tactics of Martin Luther King Jr. and Mohandas Gandhi. Typical of church messages issued in the crisis was this from Thuringia's Lutheran Bishop Werner Leich: ``I beg you ... no matter what happens, do not deviate from the principle of non-violence. ... Do not let yourselves be intimidated any longer. ... No renewal in the truth can come about unless we are willing to be bold and make sacrifices. ... God has given us the spirit of strength. ... Our present way will not be easy. But we shall succeed. ... Let us stand together.'' Crowds in Bitterfeld and elsewhere sang the American civil rights anthem, ``We Shall Overcome.'' Communist ruler Erich Honecker, whose iron-fisted rule lasted 18 years, was deposed Oct. 18. The Berlin Wall was opened Nov. 9. On Jan. 14, church mediators stopped the storming of East Berlin's secret police headquarters. Church leaders were credited for a pivotal role in the whole affair by world leaders, including Secretary of State James A. Baker III and former West German Chancellor Willy Brandt. In ensuing sessions of the caretaker government, New Forum, church figures led the transition prior to last month's elections. East Berlin Lutheran pastor Rainer Epplemann, an early leader in church opposition to the regime, served as minister without portfolio in the interim government. He also headed the Democratic Reawakening Party, allied with the March 18 winning coalition favoring reunion with West Germany. At the same time, Lutheran pastor Christian Fuehrer of Leipzig's St. Nicholas Church warned against resurgent nationalism and obsession with Western riches, saying: ``The Coca-Cola culture is taking over and people are rushing blindly to change one set of chains for another.'' And in a gesture of basic Christian compassion, Lutheran Bishop Gottfried Forck of Berlin-Brandenburg temporarily sheltered the fallen Honecker. He and his wife, Margot, were declared ``homeless'' after a court ruled that the 77-year-old dictator's illness prevented jailing him on charges of high treason. Forck arranged for them to stay in two spare rooms at the home of Lutheran pastor Uwe Homer, noting that the shelter was offered in the spirit of Christian mercy to sinners. The broad turn to democracy started earlier and proceeded more gradually in Poland and Hungary. In Poland, visited three times by the pope, stubborn strikes and demonstrations in 1980 gave birth to the Solidarity labor union, the first in Eastern Europe. The union, backed by the church, was outlawed in 1982 under martial law. Its leader, Lech Walesa, was arrested and other union leaders were driven underground, but the union maintained pressure on the government. The pressure, coupled with a disastrous economy, forced negotiations last year that led to the June 4 elections when Solidarity swept into control of parliament. In May 1988, Hungary ousted its puppet party boss, Janos Kadar, who had ruled for 32 years, ever since Soviet tanks crushed a Hungarian uprising in 1956. A national catharsis came June 16, 1989, when bodies of executed leaders of the revolt, including that of Prime Minister Imre Nagy, were exhumed from unmarked graves and reburied with honors. In January 1989, Hungary cut the electrified barbed wire along its border with Austria, opening it to vacationing East Germans and others fleeing communist oppression. All Soviet troops are to be withdrawn from Hungary by June 30, 1991, and last month's multiparty elections were seen as the advent of working democracy. God ``gives power to the faint,'' wrote the biblical prophet Isaiah. They ``shall renew their strength, they shall mount up with wings like eagles.''

DOC.HEAD: Resurrection of Nations
Part IV: Rise of `Wenceslas'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The rout of communism spread swiftly but peaceably to Czechoslovakia. The fourth story in a five-part Easter series, ``Resurrection of Nations,'' concerns the Czech surge to freedom and the rise of a `Wenceslas' heritage, as well as Bulgaria's repudiation of communism.

He was a beloved king, Wenceslas, sainted and celebrated in song and story, elevated to Czechoslovakia's throne in 922 in a popular uprising against an anti-religious tyrant who had seized power by force and murder. A statue of the good king presides over Prague's historic gathering place, Wenceslas Square, where 10 days of huge protest marches culminated Nov. l7 in the overthrow of another dictatorship and the choice of another leader named Wenceslas. That is the Latinized form of the Czech name ``Vaclav,'' which is the first name of Vaclav Havel, the repeatedly imprisoned playwright and straight-talking dissenter against authoritarianism, now the country's president. Plainly surprised, even awestruck at the spontaneous rise of the populace against 40 years of Soviet-armed communist rule, Havel called it one of those strangely true contradictions, ``the power of the powerless.'' This is the sort of paradox manifested in the Easter events, the crucifixion of Jesus, his disciples scattered, in hiding, but then his resurrection in glory. ``He was crucified in weakness, but lives by the power of God,'' Scripture says. On a temporal level, the sweeping overturn of communism across Eastern Europe has brought another kind of rebirth, also astounding. ``It's a spiritual resurrection,'' said Olga Hruby, Czech-born editor of the U.S. documentary journal, Religion in Communist Dominated Areas. ``Freedom had been buried for a long time. Now it's alive. ``People ... underwent terrible agonies and suffering. Now they have been restored to citizenship and given back their spiritual freedom. They've been resurrected.'' In cobblestoned Wenceslas Square, a half-mile long and 200 feet wide in the ``golden city'' of medieval towers and baroque domes, Havel's Dec. 29 elevation to the presidency was greeted by firecracker salutes, streamers and an embracing, singing throng. ``Your government, my people, has been returned to you,'' he said in his first televised address to the nation Jan. l, paraphrasing a 17th century Moravian religious reformer, John Amos Comenius. ``Everywhere in the world, people were surprised at how these malleable, humiliated, cynical citizens of Czechoslovakia ... found the tremendous strength to cast off a totalitarian system in an entirely peaceful and dignified manner within a few weeks,'' Havel said. ``We ourselves were surprised at it.'' Proclaiming amnesty for political prisoners and those convicted of non-violent crimes, he urged people ``to help them in a Christian spirit ... to find in themselves what our prisons could not instill: repentance and a desire to lead a good life.'' Havel, 53, who served five years in prison for criticizing repressive rule, ascribed the new freedom to the suffering of others who had struggled courageously in the Soviet Union, East Germany, Hungary, Poland and elsewhere. Referring to the years of persecutions, with many dying in prisons, many executed and thousands of lives destroyed, he said, ``It was these great sacrifices which wove ... the backdrop of our newly charged freedom. ``All human suffering concerns each human being'' he said. This is a biblical principle, that humanity is interlinked and that abuse of anyone, anywhere, imperils everyone, everywhere. Christianity holds that those who share the cross of Christ, in bearing their own cross for others, share ultimately in his triumph of resurrection. ``Upon him was the chastisement that made us whole,'' Scripture says. Czechoslovakia's aging, once imprisoned Catholic Bishop Frantisek Tomacek helped lay the groundwork for upheaval in 1985, gathering 600,000 signatures on petitions demanding religious freedom. When the November demonstrations prompted beatings and arrests, Tomacek risked new arrest by recalling the previously ignored plea and commending ``this huge protest against injustices committed against us for decades.'' All around, he said, countries ``have broken out of the prison of totalitarian systems. We must not wait any longer. It is necessary to act.'' Such encouragement helped push crowds in Wenceslas Square to a half million despite 20-degree weather. ``For the first time we aren't scared anymore,'' exclaimed Martin Jestrik, a cinema student and demonstration organizer. The undaunted marchers forced out the communist autocrat, Milos Jakes, and the entire party resigned Dec. 3. It was replaced by a provisional non-communist coalition, Civic Forum, whose initial moderator and chief spokesman was he once imprisoned Catholic priest Vaclav Maly. In the Prague demonstrations, he leaped to the platform and led demonstrators in the Lord's prayer. Freely competing political parties were authorized and a new cabinet was installed Dec. l0, involving several prominent Christians. Among them were Jan Carnogursky, a Catholic lawyer freed from prison in November, as deputy premier and Czech Brethren theologian Josef Hromodka as vice president. Havel, seen making the sign of the cross at worship services in St. Vitus Cathedral celebrating the downfall of communist rule, told an interviewer: ``I have observed that our revolution, thanks to its heavenly director, has several elements of classical drama and theater of the absurd.'' In customary black denims and sweater at his rather disarrayed third-floor offices in Hradcany castle, he grinned, puzzling over his ``curious passage from jail to the castle.'' With mail piled on the floor and young assistants bustling about, he occasionally called time out. ``Let's all laugh for a minute.'' A papal visit to Czechoslovakia is scheduled April 21-22, and multiparty elections are set for June 8. Havel got the Soviets to agree to remove their troops by July 31, 1991. Concurrent with Czechoslovakia's renewal, presistent demonstrations in Bulgaria, initially crushed, forced out the communist ruler of 35 years, Todor Zhivkov, on Nov. 10. He is in prison charged with murder and other crimes. Subsequent demonstrations in December demanded greater democracy. A score of opposition groups hopes to end communist control in June elections, the first in 45 years. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, visiting the Bulgarian capital of Sofia on Feb. 10, told a cheering crowd, ``You are the people who have brought Bulgaria to a new age of democracy.'' Havel, addressing Congress in Washington on Feb. 21, observed, ``It is all very extraordinary.'' He added: ``The only genuine backbone for all our actions, if they are to be moral, is responsibility _ responsibility to something higher than my family, my country, my firm, my success.'' If ``this voice'' of conscience is put ahead of politics, economics or whatever, he said, the new leadership ``can't go far wrong.'' A sign seen in Prague ticks off a timetable of the accelerating democratic upsurges: ``Poland l0 years, Hungary l0 months, East Germany l0 weeks, Czechoslovakia, 10 days, Romania, 10 hours.'' ``The bows of the mighty are broken,'' records the prophet Samuel, ``but the feeble gird on strength.''

DOC.HEAD: Lady Porter Shakes Up Wealthy, Traditional Westminster
DOC.TEXT: Margaret Thatcher is not the only grocer's daughter to disturb the old order. Lady Shirley Porter is trying to dust the cobwebs off Westminster, which includes Buckingham Palace and Westminster Abbey. As leader of Westminster City Council since 1983, Lady Porter has struggled to make one of Britain's richest municipalities run as efficiently as her father's supermarket chain. The sprawling metropolis of London has no citywide government or mayor. Each of the 32 boroughs elects its own council, which in turn picks a leader. Westminster's 60 councilors are up for election in May. Lady Porter, wholeheartedly embracing Prime Minister Thatcher's free- market revolution, has sold the borough's garbage collection and recreation facilities to private contractors. Since she became head of the council, more than 9,000 council-owned apartments have been sold to their occupants as part of a national effort to turn tenants of public housing into property owners. She is an international expert on litter and often is seen walking around her bailiwick, picking it up. Lady Porter entered politics in 1974 specifically to tackle trash, and lists her recreations in Who's Who as ``cleaning up London'' and ``waste-hunting.'' Her animated brand of radical conservatism invites frequent comparisons with Mrs. Thatcher, who grew up above her father's grocery store. Sir Jack Cohen, Lady Porter's father, parlayed an East London vegetable stall into the Tesco supermarket chain and imbued his younger daughter with his motto: ``You can't do business sitting on your armchair.'' Lady Porter became head of Westminster Council as a free-market Conservative determined to eradicate the socialist structures that had long dominated local government in Britain. Her strong-willed, sometimes autocratic style has inspired allegations of financial mismanagement, most notably after Westminster sold three old cemeteries for the equivalent of 8 cents each. Critics claimed it was a case of desecrating the dead to cut costs. In addition to councils, some boroughs have ceremonial Lord Mayors. Westminster's handles the extensive ritual associated with a 400-year-old district in the heart of a pageantry-loving country. An American-style mayor is more to Lady Porter's taste, and she would like to be one. She said it's the best way to ``cut through the bickering and the red tape and serve the interests of the people.'' She sees her goal as saving Westminster from becoming home to only the very rich and very poor. Lady Porter says she wants to give Westminster back to the middle classes, ``to encourage them to stay so that we don't finish up like New York.'' A recent survey by the magazine Harpers and Queen said Lady Porter was the 20th richest woman in Europe, with an estimated personal fortune of 50 million pounds ($84.5 million). Her title derives from the knighthood of her husband, Sir Leslie Porter. Lady Porter's family background was reflected in her comment recently to a meeting of foreign journalists: ``We believe in services to the customer. We are a service-oriented council. It's in my blood that people should be treated as customers.'' Her 170,000 customers are Westminster's permanent residents. They include the members of the royal family, who live at and around Buckingham Palace, and the prime minister, currently Mrs. Thatcher, who lives down the road at 10 Downing Street. Every day, the population is swollen to more than 1 million by tourists, shoppers and workers who throng the Oxford Street shopping district, West End theaters, Hyde Park, Victoria Station, the Houses of Parliament, the government offices of Whitehall, and the local church, Westminster Abbey. They leave enough litter to fill Trafalgar Square to the height of Admiral Nelson's column five times a year. Westminster claims no council has done more than Lady Porter's to fight rubbish. Prince Philip, who once accompanied her on garbage inspection detail, has taken to greeting her at social functions by calling across the room: ``How are the litter bins?'' Businesses pay for the upkeep of 500 garbage cans, and 31 uniformed wardens can fine litterers of 10 pounds ($17) on the spot. A telephone hotline is planned for residents to report litterers, noise and curb-fouling dogs. Permanent residents get discounts on tourist attractions. Residents can deal with officials by telephone or fax and ``one-stop services'' mean the availability at one counter of everything from election registration to parking permits. Westminster is among the first British boroughs to introduce glass recycling bins. The National and Local Government Officers' Association said 70 ranking officials had quit the Westminster government since Lady Porter took over. One was Chief Executive Rodney Brooke, who left last year with a retirement package said to be worth 1 million pounds ($1.7 million). Brooke's retirement deal enhanced a controversy already swirling around the sale in 1987 of the three rundown and unused cemeteries. The council said it wanted to save 450,000 pounds ($760,000) in annual maintenance. The cemeteries, on prime development land, have been resold several times. Scotland Yard's fraud squad found no criminal wrongdoing after a year of investigation, but the district auditor's report concluded the council had no authority to dispose of the cemeteries. Westminster Council is suing the lawyers who advised it on the sale. Opposition Labor Party councilors also have attacked the council for building Britain's most expensive parking lot _ 100 spaces in Soho that cost 4 million pounds ($6.76 million) _ and for giving grants to private landlords to repair luxury apartments.

DOC.HEAD: Books and Authors: A Sabra Faces the Holocaust
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: When David Grossman got married, a distant aunt turned up at the ceremony with a Band-Aid hiding the number tattooed on her arm. It was as though being a concentration camp survivor was something she should hide, something that brought shame and should not surface at a happy celebration. ``It was awful,'' the Israeli novelist recalls. Memories such as that permeate ``See Under: Love,'' the 36-year-old author's hugely ambitious attempt to portray the Holocaust as it has filtered through to Israel's post-Holocaust generation _ the sons and daughters who had no direct experience of the horror, yet are profoundly influenced by its legacy. Published in the original Hebrew in 1986, the novel has just appeared in English to rare acclaim from British critics. ``See Under: Love'' is a sprawling book, innovatively constructed, bursting with literary magic, and in the end strangely upbeat. The opening 86-page section alone is what George Steiner in The Sunday Times called ``one of the great feats in modern fiction.'' It tells of Momik, a lonely, precocious 9-year-old growing up in the Israel of 1959, among parents and neighbors who survived the Holocaust. An ordinary kid would hunger to know the Facts of Life. Momik searches for the facts of death: Why will nobody tell him what exactly happened ``over there''? What is this thing they call ``the Nazi beast''? What are those tattooed numbers _ secret codes? ``Momik tried everything to wash Grandfather's arm, but the number stayed fixed, which gave Momik an idea that maybe the number wasn't written from the outside but from the inside, and that convinced him more than ever that there was somebody there inside Grandfather, and the others too maybe, which is how they call out for help. ...'' Someone tells him that ``the Nazi Beast could come out of any kind of animal if it got the right care and nourishment,'' so he keeps caged rodents in the cellar, trying to make the beast spring from one of them and be tamed. In the second section, Momik is a young author trying to write about the Holocaust. He is convinced that he has finally grasped its meaning _ that he must be tough, unloving and pessimistic, to be ready when it happens again. ``If I ever had a child,'' Momik tells his wife, ``the first thing I would do in the morning would be to slap his face. Just like that. So he'll know there's no justice in this world, only strife.'' Part 3 is about Momik's grandfather, Anshel Wasserman, once a famous writer of children's stories who is now in a concentration camp. Neigel, the Nazi commandant who grew up on Wasserman's books, makes him tell him a story every night. Wasserman's cunningly woven stories coax a spark of humanity out of Neigel that drives the Nazi to suicide. This sequence leads into the final section in which Grossman attempts to tie the threads together in an inventive, encyclopedic format and deliver the book's ultimate message of love and hope. The book is full of allusions, double-meanings and magical fantasies: of the Wandering Jew as a salmon forever swimming toward its beginnings; of a Messiah whose gift is to relieve people of their past; of the baby Kazik who lives an entire human life from birth to death in 24 hours; of Anshel Wasserman himself, blessed, or cursed, with a strange inability to be killed by gas or bullets. Comparisons to Guenther Grass, Salman Rushdie and Gabriel Garcia Marquez are inevitable, and have been made by some critics. Writing about the Holocaust is not easy. One of the finest survivor-authors, the Israeli novelist Aharon Appelfeld, has made his mark in Holocaust literature by writing not about the atrocities, but around them, believing that ``the Holocaust is a flame too hot to be touched.'' ``That's perhaps because he went through the fire,'' Grossman said in an interview during a visit to London. ``My feeling was that my own life would go up in flames if I didn't put my hand in the fire, because there was a fire there all the time, and I knew I wouldn't understand it until I put my hand in it.'' Grossman and his parents did not go through the Holocaust. But like Momik, he grew up ``with these silences always around me.'' The Israel of his youth was not yet ready to delve into the horror. It was too busy absorbing immigrants, building an army, making the desert bloom. Its role model was the fighting Israeli, not the Jew being led to the gas chamber. Incidents such as the one involving the aunt and the Band-Aid were typical, he says, of how ``the survivors themselves collaborated with this denial. They felt themselves to be the symbol of the weak Jew ... in this new, advanced, slightly arrogant, militaristic Israel.'' At school, he says, ``I learned more about the French Revolution than I did about the Holocaust.'' But the complexes rubbed off all the same. ``I know how much I have to fight against things in myself,'' says the bespectacled, slightly built Israeli. ``I also feel the footprints of this fear of annihilation, this suspicion toward everyone. I have to invest so much energy to NOT distrust people, to take them on faith, to enjoy life, just to live.'' Clearly, he succeeded. His other well-known book, ``The Yellow Wind,'' was an agonizing account of Palestinian life under Israeli occupation, and he has campaigned hard for Israel to talk to the Palestinians. He was sacked from his job at Israel Radio over an order forbidding the broadcast of PLO voices, and reinstated after a public outcry. Government censors briefly barred school-age audiences from viewing a play based on ``The Yellow Wind.'' ``We survived (the Holocaust) in order to live, and now we live in order to survive,'' he says. ``To live, you have to be flexible _ to accept changes and turn them to your advantage. The survivor can't accept changes ... to open up, to take a risk _ these are abilities that have atrophied among us.''

DOC.HEAD: Taiwanese Demand Policy Changes Because of Pollution
By ANNIE HUANG
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Residents alarmed by pollution are demanding the government change policies that helped create an economic miracle, but also led to environmental disaster. ``Taipei residents inhale so much dirty air they have almost become vacuum cleaners,'' said Lin Pi-yao, a chemistry professor at Tunghai University. Blockades of factories, protest rallies and marches have become ordinary events in Taiwan. Demonstrations have forced some businesses to close and others to consider moving overseas. The government has promised billions of dollars will be spent to clean up the mess. ``We shall no longer allow certain people to make a fortune by having others sacrifice their right to a better environment,'' said Eugene Chien, head of the government's Environmental Protection Administration. ``Most of our factories have begun to enforce better pollution control, but people want to see the results quickly. They don't trust any commitments.'' Such comments are new from a government that has gone all out to build a prosperous export-oriented economy while doing little to force pollution control on industries. Policies that helped take this densely populated island of 20 million to the rank of 13th in trading volume also made Taiwan arguably one of the world's filthiest places. Official reports say 34 percent of the rivers are polluted and little clean water is found outside the remote highlands of central Taiwan. ``Most villagers ... have virtually given up protecting the rivers, which have become drainage ditches for factories,'' said Shih Hsin-min, professor of chemical engineering at National Taiwan University. A perpetual haze envelops Taipei, the capital, caused by pollutants that include exhaust from 1 million cars and motorcycles used by the city's 3 million people. Cases of pollution by individual factories have attracted wide attention. Chinese Petroleum Corp., a state-owned concern, hooked 20,000 nearby residents to a piped water system because their well water was so polluted by oil that it became flammable. A survey by a doctor at National Taiwan University Hospital found symptoms of lead poisoning in half the 64 workers at a battery recovery factory in Keelung port on the north coast. Thirteen of 32 children at a nearby kindergarten suffered mental retardation the doctor attributed to pollution from the plant. A chorus of protest began in 1987, when the lifting of martial law after 38 years made demonstrations legal and allowed greater freedom of expression. Many of the 7,500 demonstrations held since martial law ended have had anti-pollution themes. Protesters have conducted hunger strikes and dumped dead fish at the doors of government offices. Villagers have held lengthy sit-in blockades of several factories accused of polluting the environment, forcing some plants to close and others to pay compensation. Construction projects have been delayed or halted because of the outcry, including important petrochemical plants and power stations. Taiwan's largest conglomerate, Formosa Plastics Group, responded to protests at the proposed site of an ethylene plant by saying it might move some manufacturing facilties to mainland China. Officials say they fear hundreds of textile and plastic firms that rely on the conglomerate's products might follow. The government has announced plans to clean up state-run factories, but there is concern that modernizing equipment at the aging plants may not help much. The 10 major state-run companies, involved in oil refining, power generation and steel and fertilizer production, have announced plans to spened the equivalent of $3.4 billion on pollution-control equipment in the next four years, nearly double the figure for the previous four. Some private companies have other solutions. The China Gulf Plastic Corp. in Miaoli, a northern city, has provided residents with gas masks in case of a large chlorine emission. Environmentalists are not impressed with official efforts to clean up. ``The government still gives top priority to economic development,'' said Lin, the chemistry professor, who also heads the Taiwan Environmental Protection Union. Critics of the government claim factories rarely are closed for violating anti-pollution laws and are allowed to pay fines instead, which are much cheaper than buying equipment to reduce pollution. Some environmentalists want the government to phase out industries that cause the worst pollution. They say it might cause a brief economic slowdown, but would boost the cleaner, high-technology ventures officials view as a key to future development. ``Environmental protection can go hand in hand with economic development,'' said Shih, the National Taiwan University professor. ``They don't have to contradict each other.''

There's no narrator. ``In the musical, Sondheim's lyrics and music are a narrative voice, particularly the title song which echoes throughout the evening,'' Wager says. ``What Sondheim's score really did was to internalize the experience, the ironic, pathetic, dramatic experience of the Kaufman and Hart play. He gave an emotional response to it.'' Two full drafts were written before the Arena production went into rehearsals. They were complicated by the fact that Wager severely tore ligaments in his leg just before rehearsals started in New York. He did much of the rehearsals from a wheelchair or using crutches. What the trio tried for was a much cleaner and simpler story, making the reasons Franklin sold out much clearer and more believable. And they pretty much succeeded, according to the critics. While the reviews were mixed, the version done at Arena's Kreeger Theater is likely to be the one that will be done in the future by colleges, other regional theaters, community theaters and amateur groups. ``Steve and George have decided that this is the version they would like to see published, that the musical has finally found its right shape and form,'' Wager says. ``And to me that could be no greater reward.''

DOC.HEAD: Arnold Schwarzenegger makes Directorial Debut on Television
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Arnold Schwarzenegger has the muscle, so to speak, to direct one of his own movies, but he didn't want to make his debut on such a major project. Instead, he directed a 30-minute episode of ``Tales From the Crypt'' for Home Box Office, which will be seen Saturday as part of a trilogy of the ghoulishly witty series taken from the 1950s comic book. ``Although you have a chance to walk into a top spot of directing, because of where you are in your career, I didn't feel comfortable with that,'' Schwarzenegger said. ``I wanted to start at the bottom, as I did in body building and in acting,'' he said. ``I wanted to learn. I didn't want to start out with a big movie and fall on my face.'' Schwarzenegger's episode, ``The Switch,'' stars William Hickey as a very rich, very old man who keeps swapping body parts with a younger man to get a beautiful young woman to marry him. It also stars Rick Rossovich and Kelly Preston. Richard Tuggle and Michael Taav wrote the script from a story originally published in the ``Tales From the Crypt'' comic book. HBO's ``Tales From the Crypt'' has made it a practice to attract hot directors or high-profile people looking for a chance to direct. Its directors have included Walter Hill (``48 HRS,'' ``Johnny Handsome''), Robert Zemeckis (``Back To the Future,'' ``Romancing the Stone''), Richard Donner (``The Omen,'' ``Superman''), Howie Deutch (``Pretty In Pink''), Christopher Walas (``The Fly II''), Richard Greenberg (``Little Monsters'') and Peter Seaman and Jeffrey Price (writers of ``Who Framed Roger Rabbit?''). Hill, Zemeckis and Donner are among the series' executive producers. ``The people at `Tales From the Crypt' were all friends of mine and people I had worked with before,'' Schwarzenegger said. ``They knew I was interested in directing. I'd been mentioning it for the last two years.'' Next, he said, he'd like to try his hand at directing a television movie. His only previous experience with a TV movie _ and only dramatic appearance on television _ was a role as Mickey Hargitay in the 1980 movie ``The Jayne Mansfield Story.'' As for directing himself in a movie, Schwarzenegger smiled and said, ``I don't know if I could handle directing myself. I'd have to have some serious educational talks first with people who've done it, like Clint Eastwood and Warren Beatty and Sylvester Stallone.'' The opportunity to direct came after he had completed ``Total Recall,'' a $40 million-plus futuristic thriller filmed in Mexico City, due out this summer. Schwarzenegger spoke in his office in a converted warehouse near the beach in Venice. Behind his desk is one of seven identical paintings of his wife, NBC newscaster Maria Shriver, done by Andy Warhol. Pictures and mementos from such movies as ``Conan the Barbarian,'' ``Red Heat,'' ``The Terminator,'' ``Commando,'' ``Predator'' and ``Twins'' are everywhere. There also are pictures of President Bush with Schwarzenegger, an active Republican supporter despite his marriage into the Kennedy family. He also is chairman of the President's Council on Physical Fitness and Sports. Did directing have any surprises for him? ``The biggest surprise was how tired I was at the end of the day,'' Schwarzenegger said. ``My feet were almost falling off. I was on my feet 15 hours a day, directing and choreographing scenes, running to wardrobe, checking with special effects and working on every aspect of the picture. ``After I saw it all put together I was surprised at how important casting was. Each actor pulled off his part so well because he was perfect for the role,'' he said. Schwarzenegger directed the episode in eight days with no problems. But he had to call in help for the editing. ``I got it down to 31 minutes, but it had to be 26 minutes,'' he said. ``You work so hard on those scenes you can't brutally cut them. You have to step back and let someone who isn't as emotionally involved come in and cut it. It made it a better show.'' His next project is another comedy, ``Kindergarten Cop,'' with Ivan Reitman, who directed ``Twins,'' at the helm. ``I've been wanting to do something with kids. I'm very good with kids,'' said Schwarzenegger, who recently became a father with the birth of Katherine Eunice. ``I play a tough cop who goes undercover as a kindergarten teacher and finds that his iron discipline doesn't work on the kids.'' Despite the fact that he'll do ``Terminator II'' in the fall, Schwarzenegger said his film roles have changed in recent years. ``It's a reflection of where my career started and where it's going,'' he said. ``When you're struggling to get started, there are only certain things the studios think you're capable of doing. And only certain directors are willing to work with you. ``But when you successfully pull off certain roles, it gets more interesting. You get offered better scripts and more creative directors want to work with you. I don't have to pull off my shirt and flex my muscles.''
