DOC.HEAD: Restructuring Seen As Strengthening Baxter
DOC.TEXT: Baxter International Inc. will emerge a stronger player in the medical supply business after paring its workforce by 10 percent and shedding a fifth of its plants, according to industry analysts. Baxter announced those cuts Wednesday as part of a restructuring that also includes the sale of several marginal businesses and creation of a separate division for diagnostic products, part of which it may sell to the public. Industry analysts said the cost-cutting measures were long overdue following years of belt-tightening in the medical industry as providers have striven to contain health-care costs. ``Hospitals have been pushed up against the wall in terms of the cost cuts they've had to make and that's affecting the suppliers to the hospitals as well,'' said Jerry Fuller of Duff & Phelps Inc. in Chicago. Analyst Joseph Francis of Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. said the austerity measures, while unexpectedly severe, were ``very positive'' for Baxter's future. ``What will emerge is a much leaner company in a very competitive market,'' Francis said. ``This should dramatically improve their earnings power.'' Baxter said that over the next three years it plans to lay off about 6,400 of its 64,300 employees and close or sell 21 of its approximately 100 manufacturing plants in 24 countries, including 46 in the United States. Spokesman Geoffrey Fenton would not identify the plants slated for closure but said Baxter already has begun to notify those that will be affected. ``These decisions are in the best long-term interests of all of our constituencies,'' Chairman Vernon R. Loucks Jr. said in a statement. ``Baxter must keep evolving to help its customers meet their objective of providing high-quality health care while controlling costs,'' Loucks said. The company also said it planned to raise prices on many products and channel more money into research and development. Baxter, based in the Chicago suburb of Deerfield, said it would post a first-quarter net loss of $375 million to $400 million, or $1.50 to $1.60 a share, after taking a pre-tax charge of $566 million for the restructuring. The company said the changes will generate annual pre-tax savings of up to $275 million by 1993 and help Baxter achieve annual growth of 15 to 18 percent in operating income over the next several years. Baxter boosted profits by 15 percent last year to $446 million on sales of $7.4 billion. The company's common stock fell 25 cents Wednesday to $24.37{ a share on the New York Stock Exchange. Fenton said the layoffs included 500 people already cut from the corporate headquarters staff. He declined to identify the manufacturing businesses that Baxter intends to sell, saying arrangements had not been completed. He said Baxter may continue to distribute products of those businesses even if it no longer owns them. Baxter said the businesses to be sold had total sales of about $140 million last year. The company said it will establish a separate subsidiary for its diagnostics-products business and is considering selling a minority interest in the subsidiary to the public. Diagnostics accounted for $1.4 billion of Baxter's sales last year. The company said it was committed to diagnostics products and to in-home health care, a growing market that Baxter latched onto via its 1987 acquisition of Caremark Inc. Caremark was heralded last year for innovation as the sole distributor of clozapine, a schizophrenia drug that the company delivers to patients' homes weekly. The company also monitors the patients for potentially toxic side effects of the drugs. Despite such innovations, Baxter's core business remains the manufacture of basic hospital supplies _ gowns, intravenous solutions and surgical supplies _ and the distribution of healthcare products manufactured by others, said James Fenger, an analyst who follows the company for Kemper Financial Services Inc. Baxter said its latest moves were consistent with the strategic plan it has been pursuing since it acquired the American Hospital Supply Corp. in 1985 and Caremark.

DOC.HEAD: Bank Says It Will Cut 5,600 Jobs
DOC.TEXT: Bank of New England Corp. is cutting 5,600 workers and slashing $300 million in costs, but the troubled company admits that even with the cuts its future is in doubt. The bank, operating under government orders for more than a month, announced the cost-cutting plan Wednesday. But the institution also filed federal documents this week saying it expects to see an increase in troubled loans. Furthermore, the bank acknowledged its future may hinge on whether the slumping New England economy continues to decline. ``Continued deterioration in the New England economy and the real estate market could adversely impact the corporation's recovery efforts,'' the bank said. The job reductions, which will lower the workforce by about one-third, will come through a combination of layoffs, attrition and asset sales. The bank also has frozen hiring, eliminated financial bonuses and suspended raises for bank officers. Analysts said that although the moves should strengthen the bank, its footing remains extremely shaky. The bank gave a similar assessment in documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission this week. ``If the corporation is unsuccessful in addressing the corporation's current difficulties, it is likely that external assistance from third parties and@or regulatory authorities will be required,'' the bank said. Bank of New England lost more than $1 billion last year, due largely to bad real estate loans. The bank said that in addition to $2.2 billion in non-performing assets reported at the end of 1989, it had $1 billion in loans that were still performing but where borrowers were experiencing some financial difficulty. The bank said it expects non-performing assets will increase in the first quarter. That could be a sign that problems could be spreading outside the bank's real estate portfolio into other business loans, said Gerard Cassidy, an analyst with Tucker Anthony Inc. ``The key is the economy,'' he said. ``The New England economy is not cooperating.'' The bank said it would lay off about 1,700 employees and would notify them over the next several days. ``These decisions were difficult and they are painful for all of us,'' bank Chairman Lawrence K. Fish said in a letter to employees. ``But difficult as these steps are, it is essential that we take them now to assure our future viability and our ability to rebuild as a stronger, though smaller, Bank of New England,'' he said. ``At the same time, our primary concern as we rebuild is customer service and maintenance of the highest possible credit quality,'' Fish said. An earlier staff reduction plan was canceled by Fish after he was named chairman on March 9. At the time, he ordered a thorough review of the organization's direction, structure, and personnel needs. Personnel cuts, asset sales and other measures are expected to reduce annual operating expenses by approximately $300 million, the bank said. Bank officials said the action was being taken as part of a strategic plan outlining new directions for the corporation. Details of the plan are expected next week. The bank last month announced it had signed federal orders that set tight guidelines for lending practices and other operations. James Moynihan, senior vice president of Advest Inc. in Boston, predicted the bank eventually will sell off all its subsidiaries in Connecticut, Maine and Rhode Island. ``In order to survive, they will have to become a Massachusetts-only bank,'' he said. The results, if successful, would be a ``very competitive bank'' with assets below $20 billion, compared with a $32 billion level last year. The bank said its new strategic plan will try to concentrate on primary banking and lending businesses. Other operations will be eliminated, including processing services, large corporate banking outside of New England, leasing and discount brokerage services. The bank also disclosed that it was being sued in federal court in Pennsylvania by the Penn Mutual Life Insurance Co., which has a $10 million, 14 percent Bank of New England bank note due in 1996. Penn Mutual maintains the bank's asset sales breached covenants in the note. The insurance company asked the court to order the bank to speed up its principal payments. The bank also faces a lawsuit from shareholders who claim company executives misrepresented the bank's financial status by not disclosing the mounting troubles sooner last year.

DOC.HEAD: Bill Would Merge Wall Street, LaSalle Street Watchdogs
DOC.TEXT: Proposed legislation to end the turf battle between the federal agencies that oversee stock and futures markets would create a single Markets and Trading Commission. A bill to merge the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission was introduced Wednesday but even supporters concede it faces rough going. Meanwhile, the chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the SEC proposed a bill to curb abuses in the low cost, high risk ``penny stock'' market. The CFTC, which regulates the futures exchanges, and the SEC, which oversees the securities industry, have been squabbling over which agency has authority to regulate so-called ``hybrid'' products, such as stock index futures. The proposed new agency would be phased in over a two-year period and one division would still deal exclusively with physical commodities such as metals, oil and farm products like wheat, pork bellies and soybeans. Rep. Dan Glickman, D-Kan., who co-sponsored the bill with Rep. Dennis E. Eckart, D-Ohio, said the legislation does not seek ``to create a super SEC or a super CFTC. It is not a takeover of one agency by the other.'' Glickman is a member of the House Agriculture Committee, which oversees the CFTC, and Eckart sits on the Energy and Commerce Committee that keeps tabs on the SEC. They said committees in both ther Senate and House with jurisdiction over each agency would retain their oversight authority _ despite the merger. Congressional oversight has been a stumbling block to previous merger efforts and may remain so. ``It moves around the furniture and puts them all in one room but I'm not sure if it gets you any benefits,'' said Rep. Glenn English, D-Okla., chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the CFTC. ``I think its unnecessary. It's a kick in the face of the commodities industry to suggest that they will lose their identity and lose their uniqueness,'' said Rep. E. Thomas Coleman, R-Mo., the ranking minority member of the subcommittee. The CFTC-SEC rivalry heated up after a federal appeals court ruled last year that CFTC has authority over a financial product with any aspect of a futures contract _ including stock index futures. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady has proposed stripping the CFTC of some or all of its authority over financial futures. And SEC Chairman Richard C. Breeden has said that at the very least, the SEC should have authority over stock index futures. Glickman and Eckart said their bill ``is a wholesale reorganization of how the government oversees these markets.'' But a spokesman for the CFTC, David Gary, said ``we see no no need to combine the agencies.'' The penny stock reform bill proposed by Rep. Edward Markey, D-Mass., would require that all penny stocks be traded through an automated quotation system. Penny stocks, inexpensive but highly risky securities that usually aren't listed on stock exchanges, are legal, but they are usually issued by new companies with untested or uneven track records. That makes them risky _ and often prone to fraud _ because information about their earnings history is hard to come by or confirm. State-level securities regulators have said penny stock fraud costs U.S. investors $2 billion a year. The proposed legislation would ban ``blank check'' stock offerings and ``blind pool'' penny stocks, which offer stock to the public in companies that plan to engage in mergers and acquisitions _ but without clearly stating their business goals.

DOC.HEAD: Say Icahn Resurfaces as Possible Buyer of Eastern
DOC.TEXT: Trans World Airlines owner Carl Icahn has resurfaced as a possible buyer of Eastern Airlines, whose unsecured creditors have stepped up pressure for a sale, sources said. Icahn and associates held informal discussions recently with representatives of Goldman, Sachs & Co., financial advisers to the committee of Eastern's unsecured creditors, said the sources, who spoke Wednesday on condition they not be identified. The talks have been preliminary and the notion of an Icahn bid for Eastern has not yet ``ripened,'' one source said. Eastern spokesman Robin Matell declined to comment on the matter. Icahn was said by his office to be unavailable for comment, and aides at Goldman, Sachs didn't return phone calls. Goldman, Sachs is said to have told the committee recently that TWA wasn't interested in bidding for Eastern, but a source close to the company said there is some interest. The creditors' committee, exasperated by Eastern's mounting losses, voted Tuesday to reject the airline's latest reorganization proposal and seek the appointment of a special trustee to sell Eastern. The creditors have been soliciting possible buyers behind the scenes in recent weeks, sources say. Icahn, a corporate investor who took TWA private in October 1988, appears to have emerged as the leading potential buyer, the sources said. They suggested he might bid for Eastern in concert with other investors. Icahn's interest in Miami-based Eastern goes back at least to September 1988, when members of Eastern's Machinists union met with him about a possible bid. After Eastern's Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing on March 9, 1989, and the subsequent collapse of an attempted buyout led by ex-baseball commissioner Peter V. Ueberroth, Icahn was the unions' favorite to buy the airline. Machinists, pilots and flight attendants struck Eastern on March 4, 1989. Icahn was TWA's ``white knight'' in 1986, buying the airline in a $440 million deal to thwart an attempted takeover by Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp. Industry analysts have noted a potential compatibility between Eastern and TWA. Easter operates mainly between the Northeast and Florida and Atlanta, while TWA is strongest in trans-Atlantic operations. But Icahn backed off from Eastern last May. TWA said then it needed more time to discuss with its unions the feasibility of integrating the TWA and Eastern workforces and was not prepared to submit a formal bid. Eastern, battered by the strike, continues to report losses and is having difficulty attracting passengers. The airline has sold more than $800 million in assets with the approval of a U.S. Bankruptcy Court, and would now be valued at far less than the $464 million offered by the Ueberroth group. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland has approved Eastern's agreement to sell its valuable Latin American routes to American Airlines for $349 million. The transaction still must be approved by the Transportation Department, which is expected to decide by Friday. TWA has problems of its own, including a steep rise in operating expenses. It recently reported a net loss of $298.5 million in 1989, compared with a profit of $249.7 million the previous year. Icahn has been pushing in recent months for wage concessions, seeking $80 million in wage and benefit cuts from pilots, for example. Some believe Icahn wants to leave the airline business altogether. He is the largest stockholder of USX Corp., and recently asked the shareholders for a non-binding vote on a proposal to spin off the steel division. There has been speculation that he could move to take over all of USX.

DOC.HEAD: Pension Fund Trustees Disappointed After Exxon Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Trustees of New York City and California pension funds who want Exxon Corp. to act now to prevent future environmental accidents like the Alaskan oil spill didn't hear what they wanted from the company's chairman. ``We did not get any concrete commitments'' other than a promise of a future meeting, said Elizabeth Holtzman, the New York City comptroller. But she called Wednesday's session with Chairman Lawrence G. Rawl ``useful, the beginning of a dialogue.'' Officials of the funds, which are some of Exxon's biggest shareholders, requested the meeting because of concern about the impact on the company's earnings _ and ultimately the price of their stock holdings _ from accidents like last year's disastrous Alaska oil spill. California Comptroller Gray Davis said he was disappointed Rawl did not agree to follow any of several suggestions made by the pension fund officials. ``We did not come away with any specific promises,'' said Davis. ``However, I know we got his attention.'' The officials said they asked Exxon to take several steps, including annual environmental audits. They asked the oil company to examine its operations, identify high-risk procedures and show what actions are being taken to reduce those risks. They also asked for creation of special response teams to deal with environmental accidents and asked Rawl to send letters to Exxon employees urging them to confidentially report any environmental problems at company facilities. Davis also asked Rawl to go to Alaska to inspect the damage caused by the Exxon Valdez spill in Prince William Sound, which killed wildlife and fouled miles of coastline. The meeting also was attended by Paul Quirk, executive director of Massachusetts' pension fund board. The pension funds of California, Massachusetts and New York City hold a combined 14 million Exxon shares, or slightly more than 1 percent of the company's outstanding stock. Pension funds and other institutional investors with big stockholdings have become more active shareholders in recent years on environmental issues, corporate takeovers and other matters. ``Exxon has to get off the dime, has to make a clear commitment to environmental safety. Otherwise our beneficiaries will get the short end of the stick,'' Davis said. Exxon issued a statement after the meeting, saying Rawl had noted that ``shareholder returns have been excellent in the recent past despite 1989.'' Holtzman and Davis said Rawl told them he would respond to their suggestions before the company's April 25 annual meeting. But the pension fund executives said they were concerned about the future. ``Exxon has many different kinds of operations, and unless they identify other areas of environmental risk and correct them beforehand, it could cause other disasters and could affect the company and our shares,'' Holtzman said in a telephone interview. Davis, also interviewed by telephone, said, ``By setting aside revenue every time there's an accident, Exxon can't compete with the rest of the industry.'' Exxon's stock has been largely flat in the year since the Alaska spill. It traded in the $45 range at the time of the accident. The stock was down 62{ cents to $46.50 a share in late New York Stock Exchange trading Wednesday. The cleanup of the Exxon Valdez spill so far has cost the company nearly $3 billion. Exxon set aside $1.3 billion last year, but the company still faces more than 170 civil suits brought by fishermen and others who claim they suffered losses because of the Alaska spill. Exxon also has been indicted by the federal government on charges related to the spill. That likely will increase the company's legal bills and could result in fines against Exxon. Suits also are pending from the Jan. 1 heating oil spill in the Arthur Kill waterway between New York City and New Jersey.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Regain After Early Plunge; Dollar Down
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index plunged more than 1,000 points this morning on rumors some small brokerages faced bankruptcy, then regained most of its losses as large securities firms moved to support the market, traders said. The dollar ended sharply lower against the Japanese yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average closed at 28,249.06, down 193.88 points, or 0.68 percent. It dropped to 27,354.00 at the end of morning session _ 1,088.94 points, or 3.83 percent, below Wednesday's close. The Nikkei index fell 316.78 points on Wednesday. Katsumi Nishikido, a trader with Nippon Kangyo Kakumaru Securities Co., attributed the index's afternoon rebound to active buying by major securities firms to support the falling market. He said that in early trading, a lack of buy orders meant no prices could be put on about 100 stocks that have been the target of speculation or manipulation. Yasumasa Shinagawa, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co., attributed this morning's plunge to reports of ``a collapse of speculator groups'' that were said to be in financial trouble. Local news reports, confirmed by a broker who refused to be named, said more than 30 minor brokerages had been left with massive losses by speculators who were unable or unwilling to pay for their buy orders. The broker said his firm had been informed of the problem by stock exchange authorities. Some speculative issues inched up in the afternoon as other issues were bought back, Nishikido said, ``but speculative issues have not hit bottom yet.'' He said about 200 such speculative issues are listed on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, and about 70 are among the 225 issues in the Nikkei index. Speculative issues can be easily identified by wild price movements unrelated to market trends, Nishikido added. ``Those speculative issues started plunging late in February, and now they are doing terribly,'' he said. The price of Kagoshima Bank shares, identified as one such issue, ended at 860 points today, down from almost 3,000 points in early March. A broker, who requested anonymity, said Kagoshima Bank shares had been manipulated by a Tokyo hotel owner. Generally, speculators remain behind the scenes in the market, and some are generally thought to have close links to organized crime. Tokyo Stock Exchange executive Kazuhiro Nagakawa told reporters in a hastily called news conference after the morning session, ``I would like to ask investors not to panic because of a series of speculations flying around the market.'' An offiicial in the stock exchange's investigative arm said it had been watching the price fluctuations of such issues. ``We have cautioned our member securities houses about this problem, among other things,'' he said, speaking on condition of anonymity. But he said ``the issue is basically a problem between securities firms and their customers. We are trying not to make a big fuss about it. ... If we did, it might make the market performance even worse.'' While major securities firms generally avoid speculators, small securities firms are more likely to become involved with risky investors in order to increase their business. Takaaki Okada, spokesman for the Securities Dealers' Association of Japan, said he had heard of the reports but that the association had not confirmed any bankruptcies among securities houses. ``We think the situation has not been serious enough to warrant any official measures or public announcement,'' he said. Okada ruled out the possibility of bankruptcies of accredited Japanese financial institutions because ``the Finance Ministry will offer take some actions by the time a company gets into trouble.'' An official at the ministry also denied reports about bankruptcies, and said it will take preventative measures to protect securities firms and banks. Masahiro Umemori, an analyst with Nomura Securities, said the market, already in a pessimistic mood, overreacted to the news reports. Meanwhile, on the foreign exchange market, the dollar closed at 157.90 yen, down 1.00 yen from Wednesday's close of 158.90 yen. It opened at 158.32 yen and ranged between 157.45 yen and 158.35 yen. Dealers attributed the yen's recovery to growing sentiment that a correction is under way after the dollar's surge to the 160-yen level, and to position adjustments before the weekend meeting of finance ministers from the Group of Seven industrialized nations in Paris. Benchmark No. 119 Japanese government bonds ended trading at 86.55 points, up from Wednesday's close of 86.45. Their yield was 7.240 percent, down from the previous day's 7.260 percent. Analysts said stability in the bond market was a positive sign.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Down, Gold Up
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was mixed against key currencies in European trading this morning after dropping sharply against the Japanese yen in Tokyo. Gold prices were higher. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 157.90 yen, down 1.00 yen from Wednesday's close. Later in London, the dollar traded at 157.60 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday's prices, included: 1.6987 West German marks, down from 1.6999; 1.5030 Swiss francs, down from 1.5060; 5.7100 French francs, down from 5.7120; 1.9140 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9115; 1,251.00 Italian lire, up from 1,249.50; and 1.1675 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1672. In London, the British pound was quoted at $1.6458, compared with $1.6416 late Wednesday. Gold dealers in London fixed a recommended price of $378.10 per troy ounce this morning, up from $374.50 per ounce late Wednesday. In Zurich, the bid price was $377.75 per troy ounce, up from $374.50 late Wednesday. Gold was not traded in Hong Kong, where all financial institutions were closed for the Chinese Chingming, or Remembrance of Ancestors Day, holiday. Silver shot up in London to a bid price of $5.16 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $5.02.

Edward C. Oelsner, retired president of the United States Navigation Company, died of leukemia Monday at his home. He was 75. He was associated with the company, which represented steamship companies from around the world, from 1937 until his retirement in 1979. His father founded the company in 1911. He was a former president of the American Shipping Society.

Vernon Davis, publisher of the Maryland Cracker Barrel magazine and former editor of The (Hagerstown) Morning Herald, died Sunday of a heart attack at age 65. Davis joined The Morning Herald in 1942 as a reporter. After service with the Army Air Corps in Italy during World War II, he returned to The Morning Herald and was later promoted to assistant editor. He left in 1960 to become public relations director at Fairchild Industries and Mount St. Mary's College. Davis became publisher of the Cracker Barrel, a historical magazine that covers western Maryland, in the mid-1970s.

C.R. Smith, who helped build American Airlines into one of the world's largest airlines and was commerce secretary under President Johnson, died Wednesday in Washington after a long illness. He was 90. In 1928, he went to work for Texas Air Transport Inc. as treasurer of the air mail carrier. He became vice president of the company, which later was merged into a predecessor company of American Airlines. Smith became president of American in 1934. He left American in 1968 to join the Cabinet during the last year of Johnson's administration. He was called back by American and served as interim chairman and chief executive officer in 1973-74.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Approves MiniScribe Sale
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has approved the sale of the beleaguered MiniScribe Corp. to a California computer disk drive manufacturer for $46 million despite a higher offer from another firm. U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Charles Matheson late Wednesday issued a court order approving the sale to Maxtor Corp. of San Jose, Calif., following his receipt of Maxtor's outline of the financial and management details for MiniScribe. Richard Rifenburgh, president of the Longmont, Colo.-based MiniScribe, said Maxtor's operations provided the best complement to MiniScribe of all the companies that expressed interest. ``It's the best possible situation for MiniScribe employees,'' he said. Maxtor's bid to buy the firm included a commitment to retain MiniScribe's operations in Longmont, which was one reason its proposal was favored over an estimated $51 million bid from Wearnes Technology Ltd., which is based in Singapore. MiniScribe filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the U.S. Bankruptcy Code Jan. 1 after failing to settle numerous lawsuits that alleged the company's past management committed fraud. Its debts total about $110 million. Last month, company officials told Matheson they were running out of money to keep plants operating and asked for the stepped-up court-ordered auction. Attorneys worked through the night on negotiations with Maxtor, Wearnes and Standard Chartered Bank of Hong Kong, MiniScribe's lead lender. Before a courtroom packed with more than two dozen MiniScribe employees and numerous lawyers, attorney Patrick A. Murphy detailed Maxtor's original $40 million bid, consisting of $20 million in cash and $20 million in common stock. The proposal covers substantially all of the assets of MiniScribe, including its subsidiaries in Hong Kong and Singapore. Maxtor also planned to send managers to Longmont's MiniScribe's office and put up $30 million in working capital between now and the proposed closing date July 1. But Murphy asked for a recess after hearing the terms of Wearnes' bid, which included $46.5 million in cash, plus about $4.5 million in accounts receivable and cash in the two Far East subsidiaries. Wearnes' proposed a closing date in May. Maxtor returned with a $41.5 million offer, plus the accounts receivables and cash in the Far East subsidiaries. Gerald Munitz, attorney for Standard Chartered Bank, said the creditor supported Maxtor's bid because there was a greater certainty for employment in the Longmont area. George Scalise, Maxtor's president and chief executive officer, said the proposal was based on the premise that MiniScribe would remain open for business. No decision has been made yet on whether there would be layoffs at the firm, or whether Maxtor would change MiniScribe's name, he said. In the interim, MiniScribe would be operated as a subsidiary. ``For the most part, it will remain a stand-alone operation,'' he said. ``This is such a tough task to take on. If the doors had been closed, we would have had to reassess it.'' Attorney Glen Keller said MiniScribe received at least 111 inquiries from companies interested in purchasing the disk drive manufacturer. Commenting on the unusual court-ordered auction process, Matheson said he approved the step because it was clear that MiniScribe would not have been able to continue operations without an infusion of cash. Richard Yen, president of Wearnes' operations in the United States, said he was disappointed with the outcome, but wouldn't challenge the court's decision.

DOC.HEAD: Ryan Wins Surprisingly Easy Conformation
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 11th graf, bgng: After the, to CORRECT name of senator calling for investigation
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Labor lawyer T. Timothy Ryan Jr. is preparing to tackle what many consider the toughest financial job in the country: regulator of the nation's 2,500 savings and loans. With Senate confirmation by an unexpectedly lopsided 62-37 vote Wednesday, Ryan takes over as director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. Seventeen Democrats joined all 45 Republican senators in voting for him. His five-year term likely will be the critical period in determining whether thrift associations survive as a separate industry. They lost a record $19 billion last year. After he is sworn in, probably on Monday, Ryan will be responsible for administering toughened financial standards enacted last August as part of President Bush's savings and loan bailout. He will decide which institutions stay in business and which are seized by the government. Democrats opposed to his nomination said the 44-year-old attorney, who has specialized in pension and employee benefit law, is ill-prepared for the task because he lacks banking experience. Ryan was chief attorney for the Labor Department early in the Reagan administration and worked in the presidential campaigns of Bush and Gerald R. Ford. ``He's an outstanding lawyer as far as I know and an outstanding person,'' said Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D.. ``That's not the question. This man has no experience in the financial services industry and this job is the biggest financial services job in the world.'' Ryan's admission that he tried marijuana and cocaine 17 years ago as a law student figured little in the debate. Only Ryan supporters raised the subject during the six-hour debate. White House lobbyist Tom Korologos said the vote marked a turning point in the political treatment of youthful drug experimentation by government appointees. ``It's going to be difficult to make it an issue from now on,'' he said. After the vote, several legislators took to the Senate floor to condemn the leak of Ryan's confidential FBI report. Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., called on the Senate Ethics Committee to investigate. The administration lobbied hard for Ryan, with Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady making daily calls. The administration portrayed him as an experienced manager who had authority over 600 lawyers at the Labor Department and helped clean up irregularities in the Teamsters union's Central States Pension Fund. ``I don't think you have to be a thrift insider ... to take the job of overseeing the savings and loan industry,'' said Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas. ``Let's face it. It's the insiders ... who got us where we are today, drowning in a cesspool of unbridled greed and fiscal irresponsibility.'' The victory margin was wider than both Democrats and Republicans predicted. ``The White House has an awful lot of clout and they certainly used it,'' said Sen. Howard M. Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, who opposed Ryan. ``The secretary of the treasury was working the halls of Congress and working them well.'' Ryan, in a statement released after the vote, thanked Brady and said, ``I look forward to working closely with the Congress in addressing the problems of the thrift industry.'' The appointment removes a constitutional challenge to the administration's S&L bailout. A federal judge ruled two weeks ago that the agency's officials lacked authority to seize failed institutions. The decision was delayed by an appeals court, but only until April 11. In case Ryan was defeated, Riegle had prepared legislation that would remove the basis of the legal challenge and allow President Bush to appoint an acting director without challenge.

DOC.HEAD: Industry Shows Best Environmental Face; Greenpeace Grumbles `Greenwash'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBs lead and 13th graf, `Some exhibits...,' to CORRECT that light uses one-fourth of energy of normal bulb, not one-fourth less; picks up 14th graf, `That's equivalent...
DOC.TEXT: There is an $18 light bulb that lasts seven years and uses only one-fourth of the energy. And a solar powered car. And don't forget Mr. R.E. Cycle, a dummy made of recycled plastic bottles and bags. In two large tents stretching more than a block in the Capitol's shadow, corporate America is showing off its best environmental face in a five-day technology fair. Some environmentalists were hardly impressed as the fair opened Wednesday on the national Mall. Several members of Greenpeace handcuffed themselves to a support pole near the Du Pont Chemical Co. exhibit. They were among 19 Greenpeace members who were arrested for demonstrating without a permit, according to the U.S. Park Police. ``Corporate America has begun a campaign to paint themselves green,'' said Peter Bahouth, executive director of Greenpeace USA. A Greenpeace banner proclaimed: ``Don't Be Fooled _ Industry Greenwash.'' Bahouth complained that while some of the exhibits by more than 100 companies and trade associations might be environmentally beneficial, many of the same companies are guilty of pollution and environmental neglect in other aspects of their businesses. But organizers of the fair _ dubbed Earth Tech _ maintained that many of the exhibits demonstrate business' interest in making environmental improvements. ``I don't think that you can make anything these days without using energy or polluting the environment. The question is how much,'' said Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., co-chairman of the fair's organizing committee. The Earth Tech program was said by organizers to have cost about $1 million, mostly paid by exhibitors. The participants included Fortune 500 companies such as Du Pont and AT&T but also some lesser knowns such as Oil Stop Inc., which says it has invented a new type of boom to capture oil spills _ the ``self-energizing oil containment system.'' It's so compact, said company official Richard Lazes, that a 5,000-foot spool could be put on a tanker and unwound within minutes. That much boom would have surrounded the Exxon Valdez, he said. While several oil companies ``are excited about it, they've made no commitment yet,'' he added. Producers of solar, thermal and wind-generated energy were prominent, as were companies in the rapidly growing industry of waste management and disposal _ and, of course, recycling. Some exhibits approached the exotic: a solar-powered car that had traveled across the country; a model of a ``wind plant'' to show that wind power already is generating millions of kilowatts of power in parts of California; and the $18 electric bulb that lasts seven years, won't break and uses one-fourth of the energy than a conventional bulb. ``That's equivalent to not burning 400 pounds of coal over the life of the bulb,'' said Steve Waxman of Philips Lighting Co. The ``Earth Light'' isn't available in hardware stores yet but may soon be, he said. At the Du Pont exhibit, displays touted the company's efforts to push for plastic recycling. That's where visitors could find Mr. R.E. Cycle _ his limbs made of beverage and detergent bottles, a torso of a recycled plastic bag and his head a milk bottle, also of recycled plastic. He sat on a wood-like bench made of plastic waste. At another booth, the American Wood Preservatives Institute and the National Timber Piling Council passed out saplings wrapped in paper and ready for planting. The industry over the years has been criticized by environmentalists for polluting in its production of chemically treated lumber products. But they too had a good environmental story to tell, noting the longevity of treated lumber. ``Treated Wood Saves Trees,'' read the white and green buttons next to the rows of saplings.

DOC.HEAD: Bank President Guilty in S&L Fraud Trial
DOC.TEXT: Two top executives of the collapsed Flushing Federal Savings and Loan Association were convicted of conspiring with four others to drain the thrift of nearly $8 million. Flushing Federal's collapse in 1985 from bad loans represented one of the largest S&L failures in the Northeast, with losses of $100 million, and was a precursor of the widespread insolvency in the nation's thrift industry. A federal jury in Brooklyn on Wednesday convicted Carl Cardascia, Flushing Federal's president, and Ronald J. Martorelli, an assistant vice president and chief loan officer, of misapplying funds in knowingly granting bad loans. The jury deliberated 3{ days following the nearly three-month-long trial. Prosecutors had charged in a 64-count indictment that in exchange for kickbacks, stock and other favors the bankers approved millions of dollars in loans in 1984 to an admitted con man, Michael Rapp, and three of his associates, including Jilly Rizzo, a longtime friend of Frank Sinatra. Rizzo was one of four borrowers convicted in the scam. The defendants face up to five years on each of the numerous charges when they're sentenced June 20 by U.S. District Judge Jack B. Weinstein. ``The fraud was born when Michael Rapp and Carl Cardascia struck a deal. Six months and 21 lines of credit later, Flushing Federal was out $7,730,000,'' said the prosecutor, Assistant U.S. Attorney Steven M. Gold. Gold described Cardascia, 51, as a man willing to violate virtually any banking regulation, ``if you can fill up his jacket pocket fast enough.'' Cardascia's lawyer, Joseph Ryan, told the jury that his client was a victim, not a co-conspirator. ``He's a bad, bad banker,'' Ryan said of Cardascia, who started out as a teller at Flushing Federal. ``Mr. Cardascia is guilty of his own ineptitude.'' Cardascia was convicted of scheming with Rapp, a career criminal and master con artist who boasted of his illegal stock-market exploits in the 1970s in his book ``The Wall Street Swindler.'' Rapp, who testified for the prosecution, pleaded guilty to defrauding Flushing Federal and a Florida bank and is serving a 15-year prison term.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Grants Preliminary Injunction Against Railway Workers Strike
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ordered a union to cancel strike plans against Conrail, saying a walkout would greatly hurt the public and other railroads. In granting a preliminary injunction Wednesday to Conrail, U.S. District Judge Franklin S. Van Antwerpen said a strike by the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees would ``harm the public good.'' ``Because of the inter-connected nature of the railroad business, any stoppage on Conrail inevitably affects other carriers, including Amtrak and the commuter rail operators,'' Van Antwerpen wrote. Conrail provides freight service, but its rails are used by the other railroad companies in the District of Columbia, Canada and 15 northeastern states. In some states, the judge wrote, Conrail is the largest freight carrier. If the strike were to occur Friday as planned, he wrote, ``the effect on the public good would be so great, and so obvious, that it needs no further elaboration.'' He added that ``Conrail will suffer substantial and irreparable injury'' if the strike occurred. The union represents about 500 employees in eastern Pennsylvania, northern New Jersey and New York state. It has been negotiating with Philadelphia-based Conrail since 1988. ``We're disappointed with the decision,'' said Jed Todd, the union's general chairman for Pennsylvania. ``This has been going on since June 1, 1988. That's why we're a little aggravated.'' He added that the union was still evaluating the judge's ruling to determine the next step. Conrail spokeswoman Pat Linskey said the railroad company had no comment on the decision. The dispute centers on wages, hours, benefits, safety and job security. The union, represented by attorney John Clarke Jr., argued that Conrail has been bargaining in bad faith. But the judge wrote Wednesday that both sides appeared to be negotiating properly under the existing collective bargaining agreement.

DOC.HEAD: Eastern Files for Changes in Pilots' Contract
With PM-Eastern-Icahn
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Airlines said it asked a bankruptcy judge to impose a new long-term contract on its pilots union because of an impasse in negotiations and cost reductions needed to emerge from bankruptcy. The filing Wednesday will at least provide a chance to air the union's dispute with Miami-based Eastern in court, said E.J. Breen, spokesman for the Air Line Pilots Association. ``At least, it isn't a slam, dunk,'' Breen said of the airline's contract request. ``We go in and argue our case.'' But the pilots union feared its members could end up with no contract at all, he said. The pilots have charged that Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp., is out to break the union. In announcing the filing, Eastern said it was frustrated that negotiations with the pilots' union since the last permanent contract expired in July 1988 had not led to a new agreement despite federal mediation. ``We are reluctantly forced to resort to the established bankruptcy process to resolve an otherwise intractable problem,'' said Thomas J. Matthews, senior vice president of human resources and the company's chief labor negotiator. The request came after the pilots union last weekend approved a four-month interim contract that included 25 percent pay cuts for working union pilots. The interim contract, retroactive to March 1, does not affect the salaries of pilots hired after Eastern's machinists, pilots and flight attendants began their strike on March 4, 1989. The jobs of the newly hired pilots are under court challenge from the pilots union. The striking pilots and flight attendants ended their walkout in sympathy with the machinists in November. Eastern currently has some 1,800 pilots. Matthews said the interim pact ``falls woefully short'' and claimed the carrier's proposed contract is needed to pull Eastern out of Chapter 11 bankruptcy. ``It's a total package that would offer savings in excess of $50 million a year,'' said Eastern spokesman Robin Matell. ``It covers wages, benefits, working conditions and an emphasis on increased productivity. ``The negotiations have been dragging out, not going on,'' Matell said. ``This way, by going through the bankrupcty court, it will be resolved in one way or another.'' A sticking point in negotiations is the union's efforts to have union pilots hired back by Eastern. But the airlines has said it has no openings. Under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, the court has up to 21 days to schedule a hearing and another 30 days to rule on Eastern's application. Eastern's proposed long-term contract calls for 20 percent pay reductions for all pilots for the first six months of the agreement, Matell said. The company would restore half the cuts in the following six months, he said. The pact also includes some temporary pension plan concessions and boosts pilots' monthly flight hours from 52{ to about 60.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Disappointed With Japan's Efforts on Semiconductors
DOC.TEXT: Japan must redouble its efforts to meet the objectives of a 1986 agreement on increasing the foreign share of Japan's semiconductor market, U.S. trade officials said Thursday. ``We're disappointed. We think the progress thus far has been unsatisfactory,'' a U.S. trade official told reporters. Under rules of the briefing none of the officials may be identified. ``The heat is on,'' said another U.S. official. ``We're looking for results across the board under the original agreement.'' With 16 months left before the 1986 bilateral semiconductor agreement expires, U.S. officials say they want Japan to increase efforts to help foreign chip producers boost their current 12.9 percent share of the market to 20 percent by 1991. The United States contends this was agreed to in the pact. Japanese officials have said the 20 percent figure was merely a goal. Foreign chips, which are mostly American, held 8.6 percent of the Japanese market at the time of the agreement. The two countries completed a regular review of the pact Wednesday. The officials said most major Japanese semiconductor users have adopted plans to increase their foreign share of chips, a step they found encouraging. But foreign manufacturers supply only 3 percent of the chips used in Japanese consumer electronics products and 3 percent to 5 percent of those used in Japanese cars. By contrast, U.S. producers supply 70 percent of the chips used in European autos, the officials said. They added that Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry is ``candidly and sincerely'' working to put the agreement into practice. Under the agreement, Japan also pledged to stop unfair pricing of computer chips overseas, called dumping. U.S. officials say Japan has kept that promise. During a regular review of the agreement, which is held two or three times a year, Japan told the United States its efforts to buy more foreign semiconductors will suffer if Washington charges that chips face trade barriers in Japan under the ``Super 301'' clause of the U.S. Omnibus Trade Act. The clause requires U.S. trade officials to prepare an annual ``hit list'' of trade barriers faced by U.S. products, together with a deadline for a negotiated resolution aimed at getting the barriers eliminated. That priority list is due April 30. If negotiations fail, the United States can impose penalties. The U.S. government is considering placing semiconductors on the list, in response to requests from American chip makers, the U.S. officials confirmed. U.S. semiconductor industry groups say their limited sales success in Japan shows that restrictions exist against foreign chips, while Japanese companies have called for U.S. suppliers to make greater sales and quality-control efforts. A Japanese official said Japanese companies were making serious efforts to buy more U.S. semiconductors, particularly for automobiles and electronic products.

DOC.HEAD: Air Quality Survey Shows Millions Live in Polluted Areas
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Top 7 grafs new to update with EPA report. Picks up 3rd graf pvs: Some participants. Deletes last 2 grafs pvs to shorten.
DOC.TEXT: House negotiators worked on details of new clean air legislation today as the latest government air quality survey showed 121 million Americans living in pollution exceeding federal health standards. The Environmental Protection Agency also said in its annual assessment of air quality that the urban smog problem became 15 percent worse in 1988 compared to the year before, partly because of an exceedingly hot summer. That year is the latest for which data is available. The survey showed 121 million people lived in areas in which air pollution exceeded the health standards for various pollutants, including smog. The agency statistics, some of which had been reported previously as preliminary data, showed emissions of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide both increased slightly while levels of carbon dioxide and dust or dirt declined somewhat. The emissions are largely the product of automobile travel, industrial releases or the burning of fossil fuels by electric power plants. The report shows that over the past decade pollution levels have declined considerably, but it also ``shows the magnitude of the air pollution problem still remaining,'' said EPA Administrator William K. Reilly. The EPA released the annual report two days after the Senate approved a comprehensive air pollution control bill and as members of the House Energy and Commerce Committee continued closed-door negotiations on clean air legislation. The House talks lasted late into the evening Wednesday. Some participants in the bargaining, speaking privately, said the matter was close to being resolved, possibly today. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., chairman of the committee, has said he wants a final committee vote on the complex, expensive and controversial clean air bill by the end of the week when Congress goes on Easter recess. After the Senate approved a sweeping air pollution control bill on Tuesday, the focus shifted to the House where the bill languished in Dingell's committee for months. Committee members have worked out compromise agreements on several provisions dealing with controls on urban smog. But the thorny issue of acid rain controls was kept for last. Many Midwest congressmen contend that a ``cost sharing'' arrangement must be worked out to help utilities in the region cut sulfur dioxide emissions from some of the country's dirtiest coal-fired electric plant. According to committee sources, Rep. Philip Sharp, D-Ind., who has led the cost-sharing fight, floated a revised proposal Wednesday calling for a complex allocation of ``pollution allowances'' to help the Midwest and utilities in other areas where there is fear that new pollution controls might inhibit future expansion. Both the House and Senate bill call for broad-ranging emission controls on automobiles, factories and electric power plants in an attempt to reduce pollution from acid rain, urban smog and toxic industrial chemicals. Utilities would have to cut annual sulfur dioxide emissions nearly in half, or by about 10 million tons, by the year 2000. Neither industry nor environmentalists have been happy about the Senate legislation, approved 89-11 on Tuesday, and each side has hoped to push for changes in the House bill. The environmentalists have called for stronger smog controls than provided by the Senate bill, while industry has complained that requirements dealing with toxic chemical releases and acid rain are too tough.

DOC.HEAD: Japan Making Concessions in Trade Talks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with talks continuing, may end today; both sides say progress is being made. Picks up 6th graf pvs `If the ...'
DOC.TEXT: Progress is being made in talks aimed at crafting an unprecedented deal to reform the basic economies of Japan and the United States, according to negotiators who hope to wrap up the four days of discussion today. A leading congressional trade expert, Sen. Max Baucus, D-Mont., told reporters that he understood the delay was caused by the complexity and number of details being reviewed and questions over the wording of the proposal. Baucus said he understood the discussions were close to ending with release of an interim report reviewing the progress so far. Both sides insisted that progress was still being made even though the discussions seeking to correct broad based structural barriers to trade have lasted two more days than originally planned. Baucus praised the Japanese for being willing to make concessions, but he said the real test of the agreement would be in its ability to actually reduce America's huge trade deficit with Japan. President Bush had words of praise for the Japanese as well, marking a turnabout for the administration, which until recently had been blasting Japan for its intransigence on the trade issue. U.S. Trade Representative Carla Hills said the length of the discussions did not indicate any unexpected roadblocks, but she did sound a warning Wednesday about what could happen if the discussions did not succeed. ``If the Japanese do not open their second largest market in the world, there will be enormous political pressure to restrict those (trade) opportunities that have given them so much,'' she told an audience of American manufacturers. ``It will kill the goose that laid their golden egg.'' The talks are unprecedented in their scope because they aim not at boosting sales of specific products but at correcting broad barriers to trade in both countries. The effort has prompted Japanese critics to charge that the United States was trying to remake their nation and scrap centuries of tradition. However, the Bush administration, which began the discussions last July, has maintained that its proposals would benefit Japanese consumers by increasing competition and thus lowering retail prices, currently among the highest in the industrial world. Bush met Wednesday with Nubuo Matsunaga, a special emissary from Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, and afterward the White House issued a statement praising Kaifu's role in bringing about a new spirit of cooperation. In the past 10 days, U.S. and Japanese negotiators have settled disputes involving sales of American-made telecommunications equipment, satellites and supercomputers. Baucus, chairman of the Senate trade subcommittee, told reporters Wednesday he was impressed by Japan's efforts. ``I am willing to bury the hatchet with Japan if Japan is willing to open its markets,'' he said. ``Congress is quite hopeful about the new attention given in Japan to resolving trade issues.'' The administration is facing a congressionally imposed deadline of April 30 to decide which countries to target under a second round of negotiations aimed at removing trade barriers. The trade committee of the National Association of Manufacturers urged the administration Wednesday to put Japan on the trade ``hit list'' again, regardless of the outcome of the current talks, to keep pressure on Kaifu's government. ``The Japanese have out-negotiated us in the past by making promises where there is no follow-up,'' said NAM President Jerry Jasinowski. Negotiators involved in this week's discussions were preparing an interim progress report outlining reforms each side is willing to make, with a final report scheduled for early July. Among the changes expected to be offered on the Japanese side were proposals to increase enforcement of antitrust laws, boost spending for public works projects and relax restrictions on the establishment of large retail stores in Japan. On the U.S. side, the administration was not likely to agree to Japan's suggestions to boost U.S. competitiveness by restricting Americans' use of credit cards, hiking the gasoline tax and eliminating tax deductions for home mortgage payments. However, the administration was expected to point to efforts to provide expanded tax credits for personal savings, improve the U.S. education system and balance the federal budget.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Calls for Targeting Food Aid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with committee voting to substantially change foreign food-aid program. Picks up 10th graf pvs `Leahy said ...'
DOC.TEXT: The Senate Agriculture Committee voted today to substantially change the government's foreign food aid programs to better help the world's hungriest people and encourage emerging democracies. The legislation, approved on voice vote, would provide food grants to the poorest countries, reorganize the food aid bureaucracy and allow the president more leeway in giving food to nations whose governments he wants to bolster. The bill will be the agricultural trade portion, or title, of the 1990 farm bill that will go the Senate floor. The House Agriculture Committee has not acted on foreign trade. ``This title makes the most dramatic change in American foreign food policy in a quarter of a century,'' said committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., who coauthored the measure with Sen. Richard Lugar of Indiana, the panel's ranking Republican. Ann Veneman, deputy undersecretary for international affairs and commodity programs, said the committee's staff worked with the Bush administration to write the bill. ``There are areas where we did not agree, but nothing so major it can't be worked out,'' she said after the committe voted. The programs provided for in the bill would cost an estimated $1.5 billion annually, which would be paid directly from the budget and by money received from repayment of debts on previous food loans. The amount is comparable to previous years. Leahy said the bill would make the government's international food aid system ``more reflective of the realities of today.'' ``It also gives the United States powerful new weapons in providing critical food aid to emerging democracies in Eastern Europe, Central America and worldwide,'' he said. The legislation would establish a ``food for freedom'' program under which the president could donate food to countries trying to set up democracies, and spend up to $100 million for agricultural necessities such as fertilizers and transportation. Poor countries least able to produce their own food would be eligible for food grants and forgiveness of debts incurred through previous food loans. Currently, food is sold to poor countries at reduced interest rates over a 40-year term, but that only makes a bad debt situation worse for those countries, Leahy and Lugar said. About $12 billion is owed to the United States through agricultural programs, Lugar said. ``We think we have an interest in part of that debt and would like in the case of the most desperate countries to offer some relief,'' he said. Leahy said the debt forgiveness proposal is aimed at the drought-stricken countries of sub-Saharan Africa. Sen. Chrstopher Bond, R-Mo., said some parts of Latin America also should be included in the grant and debt forgiveness plan, but Leahy responded: ``There's only so much debt forgiveness we can do. Countries you are talking about have the ability to raise food.'' The legislation makes food grants part of an ongoing policy for the first time. Previously, food has been given away on an ad hoc basis or in emergencies, said an aide to the Senate committee. Leahy said the bill also would clean up mismanagement and bureaucratic red tape that frustrates the aid programs. Five agencies _ the Agriculture, State and Treasury departments, the Office of Management and Budget and the Agency for International Development _ all now have a say in how food aid is distributed. The bill would put AID in charge of the grant program and make USDA responsible for the sales program aimed at developing new markets. The Agriculture Committee accepted an amendment by Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., requiring the Agriculture Department to spend at least $900 million in fiscal 1991 on the Export Enhancement Program and removing the ceiling that has existed on the program. Kerrey said the administration needed the provision to use in international trade talks against countries that heavily subsidize their own exports to the detriment of the free market. Under the program, exporters are given bonuses that bring down the cost of U.S. products to foreign countries. USDA decides which countries qualify for those sales.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mixed; Wheat Retreats
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade with wheat giving up some of the strong gains posted in the three previous sessions. Wheat futures surged Wednesday amid fears of a weekend freeze in the U.S. winter wheat region and concerns about tight deliverable supplies. The freeze fears have lessened somewhat but tight-supply concerns persist following a Wall Street Journal report that Minneapolis investor Irwin Jacobs owns about half the wheat available for delivery against the May futures contract. Jacobs told the Journal he no longer holds any futures contracts on wheat and is not trying to squeeze the wheat market. Jerry Zusel, manager of Balfour Maclaine Corp.'s floor operations at the Board of Trade, said wheat traders are more worried about the possibility of frost damage to the newly sprouted winter wheat crop in the central and southern Plains. Stronger export demand supported the corn market while higher soybean meal prices helped to boost the beans. In early trading, wheat futures were } cent to 1} cents lower with May at $3.69 a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to \ cent higher with May at $2.68\ a bushel; oats were { cent lower across the board with May at $1.51} a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 1{ cents higher with May at $5.92{ a bushel. Cattle futures were mostly higher while pork futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle were unchanged to .12 cent higher with April at 78.67 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .23 cent higher with April at 82.50 cents a pound; live hogs were .25 cent lower to .08 cent higher with April at 54.82 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .05 cent to .17 cent lower with May at 54.90 cents a pound. DOC.HEAD: Kodak To Pay $1 Million Fine Over Environmental Violations
DOC.TEXT: Eastman Kodak Co. was fined $1 million today after pleading guilty to two misdemeanor violations of state environmental laws. Kodak was charged with illegally disposing of contaminated soil in 1986 and of failing to report a leak of a toxic solvent for five days in 1987. City Judge Herman J. Walz accepted the plea agreement, but said he questioned the wisdom of granting Kodak officials and directors immunity from prosecution. The agreement lets ``people who have participated in criminal acts go unpunished,'' Walz said. ``It is the opinion of the court that (corporate) officers and employees should also be prosecuted.'' Kodak was fined $997,500 for its illegal handling of the contaminated soil. Assistant Attorney General Paul McCarthy said Kodak hired an unauthorized company to haul away nearly 50,000 pounds of soil contaminated with silver. The incident was one of a series of violations by Kodak, McCarthy said. Kodak was fined the maximum penalty of $2,500 for failing to report a spill of 5,100 gallons of methylene chloride until five days after it had been discovered.The chemical is considered a probable human carcinogen by the Environmental Protection Agency. State officials were expected to announce later today an agreement that will require Kodak to pay another $1 million to settle civil charges brought by the state Department of Environmental Conservation. The Rochester Democrat and Chronicle reported that state officials also will announce a legally binding consent order requiring independent experts to conduct an environmental audit of Kodak's chemical operations. Sources familiar with the terms of the order said Kodak will pay for the study, the newspaper reported. The sources said the state environmental agency will insist the audit be performed by a consultant group with no close ties to Kodak or the state. The attorney general's office has been investigating Kodak's contamination of ground water at its Kodak Park manufacturing facility for nearly two years. A special grand jury has been looking into Kodak's possible environmental violations since January. It has subpoenaed more than 80,000 documents from the company.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Production Down This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 189,862 cars and light trucks this week, down from last week's 225,077, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 250,056 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 110,245 cars this week, compared with 135,907 a week ago and 159,295 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 79,617, compared with last week's 89,170 and last year's 90,761. Canadian automakers were to build 22,936 cars this week, up from 22,484 a week ago but down from last year's 21,980. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 20,919, compared with 21,016 a week ago and 21,985 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: Fewer Companies Plan To Increase Capital Spending, Study Says
DOC.TEXT: Fewer U.S. companies plan to increase their capital spending budgets this year compared with 1989, according to a national survey released Thursday. Dun & Bradstreet Corp. said 41 percent of the 5,000 companies it polled plan to spend more on capital projects in 1990, down from 46 percent that planned bigger budgets last year. Despite the decline, Dun & Bradstreet economist and chief statistician Joseph Duncan said capital spending remains at relatively high levels. ``While U.S. firms are less ambitious, they continue to increase investments to replace plant and equipment,'' he said. The survey, which was conducted in December and January, showed that 25 percent of the companies planned to cut capital spending this year while 35 percent said they would maintain spending at 1989 levels. Among industries, the service sector and the construction industry were particularly bullish about increasing spending. Forty-five percent of the companies in both categories said they planned to spend more money this year than last. Larger companies are more likely to increase their capital spending annually. According to the survey, 50 percent of the companies with over 10,000 employees will spend more, while 37 percent of those with fewer than 500 employees were planning increases. ``Smaller businesses are more sensitive to fluctuations in the business cycle, particularly with respect to higher interest rates,'' Duncan said. The survey was based on a sample of 5,000 companies drawn from Dun & Bradstreet's database, which includes information on more than 9 million U.S. companies and was statistically representative of companies of all sizes in all industries.

DOC.HEAD: Two Former Wall Streeters Form Alternative Employment Firm
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: As a single mother balancing a high-pressure job on Wall Street, Suzanne Rinfret Moore remembers working 12-hour days and organizing her son's birthday party from a hotel phone while out of town on business. The pressure selling government bonds to institutions was so intense that Moore ``felt like I had to write a detailed memo about why I needed to leave for three hours'' to attend a school play. After years of juggling, Moore quit her job at J.P. Morgan Securities Co., where she rose to vice president, to form her own business. She now works fewer and more flexible hours trying to help other Wall Streeters strike a similar balance between their roles as professionals and parents. Moore teamed with college chum Karen Strauss Cook, both 37, to form Alterna-track Inc., a specialized search firm that matches top professionals in the financial services industry with part-time or temporary work. Working out of a midtown Manhattan office, it's a kind of sophisticated Kelly Girl service for Harvard MBAs, takeover lawyers and corporate accountants. Nearly 90 percent of Alterna-track's candidates are women. Moore and Cook, a mother of two who, for a six-year stretch was the only woman equity block trader at Goldman Sachs & Co., had plenty of contacts to tap. To confirm their hunch that women are hungry to cut back on grueling hours but are afraid to admit it to hard-driving employers, Moore and Cook sent hundreds of questionnaires to high-level women in financial services companies. The response was even more resounding than they anticipated. Within a few months they amassed a pool of more than 300 resumes, mostly from women interested in everything from flexible time to job-sharing to contract work. Their research paralleled a wealth of data already available. For example, a poll of 1,000 men and women conducted last year by the executive search firm Robert Half International Inc. showed 78 percent would sacrifice rapid career advancement if it meant spending more time with their families. The demand for the type of talent Alterna-track offers also partly reflects the increased role women are playing in the American labor pool. Many employers are finding that to hire and retain the most talented, they must offer flexibility. Labor Department statistics show 57.6 percent of women age 20 and older are in the workforce. By the year 2000, 47.5 percent of the workforce will be female, vs. 42.5 percent in 1980 and 38.1 percent in 1970, says the Hudson Institute, a research group that has studied American labor trends. Moore and Cook launched a crusade to get employers to, in Cook's words, ``retain the person during a critical few years'' when childrearing is at its most intensive. ``If an intelligent employer could hold their hand, they'll be back on track again,'' Cook said. The retention of valued employees is worth more than a little inconvenience. For example, Moore and Cook said it costs about 150 percent of an employee's annual salary to replace that employee. Besides the cost, employees have been ``groomed ... they know the company vertically,'' Moore said, and companies should realize that knowledge could take years to replace. In addition to assembling a rich resume pool, Moore and Cook are targeting corporations, banks and financial firms from the Fortune 500 level on down. So far, however, 60 percent of Alterna-track's business clients have called the firm unsolicited, asking for a presentation of services and job candidates. ``One major company we've talked to said it is losing three times as many women as men in the 30-35 age category,'' gutting its middle management ranks, Moore said. But Moore and Cook aren't robbing Merrill Lynch to pay Shearson. On the contrary, most of the women they place come from large firms but are teamed up with much smaller firms that need top talent but can't pay top salaries on a full-time basis. One recent match put Cynthia McClintock, a former associate in Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.'s corporate finance department, at Ampton BCS Investments L.P., a merchant bank with fewer than a dozen employees. ``The problem with a small service business like this is that you kill yourself by adding expensive staff,'' said partner Laurence Strenger, who selected McClintock from five Alterna-track candidates. ``It would be imprudent if we started adding people at multi-hundred-thousand-dollar salaries,'' he said. ``Here we have someone with a Harvard MBA on a piece-work basis. It's marvelous.'' Strenger has called McClintock to work on three more projects. For McClintock, whose first child is due in June, it meant getting a head start on ``part-time work that will make sense later on.'' For their efforts, Moore and Cook receive 30 percent of a placed applicant's annual compensation. It may not sound like much, but the average woman in their pool is earning about $150,000 a year. That average candidate is about 35 years old, has been on her job for about eight years and has between one and two children. Cook noted that it's usually after the second child that women just give up on their jobs. Cook resigned from Goldman Sachs just before the market crash of 1987 when her youngest was 2 with a feeling of ``guilt that I was not giving as much to the firm and also not having enough time with my kids.'' Moore and Cook aren't sure how the recession at major investment houses will affect their business. They know, however, that ``the pressures have multiplied five-fold on Wall Street,'' Moore said, stressing working mothers even more. This year they have placed five professionals and expect to place another five in the next few weeks, three of whom will cover for women taking maternity leave from a major consumer products company. When those women return, Alterna-track's candidates are likely to share jobs with them. By midyear, Moore said she expects to have placed up to 30 professionals. To keep pace, Alterna-track has hired a director and will open a Los Angeles office in June. Other sites under consideration are London and Chicago, but Moore said there's no reason the company can't go nationwide. Despite the expansion, Moore says she'll still have time to take an afternoon off to go play tennis with her 9-year-old son, and Cook and can still go ice skating in Manhattan's Central Park with her boys.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Slightly Higher
DOC.NOTE: EDS: RECASTS throughout to UPDATE with later activity, closing indices; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished slightly higher Thursday after a lackluster session on London's Stock Exchange. Investors were content to sit on the sidelines, waiting for a new trading account to begin Friday afternoon, traders said. The exchange divides trading into two-week and three-week periods for accounting purposes. Traders said investors still were considering the ramifications of the Tokyo market's gyrations. ``Players haven't got a clear picture of what's happening in Tokyo, so they're saying they'd rather not risk the money,'' said a chief dealer. Wall Street offered the London market little leadership, with the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials up just a few points as London trading came to a close. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 7.9 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,239.5 at the close, its best level for the session and well above its low of 2,222.0. The Financial Times 30-share index was up 6.6 points at 1,756.3 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index rose 3.51 points to close at 1,209.28. Volume was a moderate 499.5 million shares, down from 505.4 million on Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Survey: U.S. CEOs More Concerned About Domestic Competition
DOC.TEXT: More than three-quarters of chief executive officers of U.S. companies contacted in a survey said their greatest competitive threat comes from other domestic companies, not foreign businesses. About 70 percent of the more than 1,100 CEOs polled on behalf of Continental Bank of Chicago also said their companies' competitiveness is most strongly influenced by factors within their control. About 51 percent of the executives said U.S. business is at least as competitive, if not more so, with foreign business as it was 10 years ago. Looking ahead, seven of 10 CEOs said they believed U.S. business will maintain or improve its competitive position with foreign business over the next 10 years. About 75 percent of those surveyed believe U.S. companies are as good as or better than foreign competition in terms of marketing expertise and management quality. Two-thirds said U.S. product quality is superior, while the American work force was seen as stronger than foreign counterparts by 60 percent of executives. Foreign companies were judged better than or equal to U.S. businesses only in terms of operating costs, by 66 percent of CEOs, and product price, by 65 percent. Fewer than one-third of the executives said they believed their companies were likely to establish joint marketing or distribution agreements with foreign companies within the next five years. About 23 percent already have such agreements. Sixty percent of the CEOs said foreign investment in the United States has helped improve U.S. competitiveness. Nearly all the executives said a low level of worker training and education is the most serious obstacle to building the United States' competitive strength, followed by a short-term focus on earnings by companies. The survey of 1,136 CEOs of companies with sales of under $10 million to more than $5 billion was conducted during 1989's fourth quarter by Beta Research Corp. of Syosset, N.Y. The survey has a statistical margin of error of plus or minus 1.35 percentage points.
