DOC.HEAD: Soybean Futures Gain On Export Strength; Grains Close Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures closed slightly higher Thursday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid export speculation, while grain futures finished mixed in a relatively quiet session. Soybean exports from Brazil to Europe have been slowed by confusion over economic reforms launched last month in the South American country, prompting speculation that importers may turn to the United States to meet their needs. In other export developments, analysts said the Soviet Union is rumored to have bought recently as much as 1 million metric tons of corn. They said some of those purchases may have been reflected in Agriculture Department announcements this week of a total of 220,000 metric tons of U.S. corn sold to unknown destinations. By law, the USDA must report export sales of at least 100,000 tons of grain. Joel Karlin, a grain-market analyst with Research Department Inc. in Chicago, said the Soviets may have made other purchases in amounts smaller than 100,000 tons. Wheat futures fell slightly after three days of strong gains linked to fears of a weekend freeze in the U.S. winter wheat region and concerns about tight deliverable supplies. At the close of trading, wheat futures were } cent to 2{ cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $3.69 a bushel; corn was 1 cent lower to } cent higher with May at $2.69 a bushel; oats were \ cent to 1 cent lower with May at $1.52 a bushel; soybeans were unchanged to 3 cents higher with May at $5.94 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Stock Speculators, Manipulators Hurt Badly by Falling Market
DOC.TEXT: Stock speculators, long a shadow force in the Tokyo Stock Exchange, have been hurt badly by the market's recent heavy plunges, traders said Thursday. Rumors that financially strapped speculators have in turn pushed small brokerages close to bankruptcy caused a temporary plunge of more than 1,000 points Thursday in the exchange's chief index. One broker said more than 30 minor brokerages had been left with massive losses _ $190 million according to news reports _ by stock manipulators who were unable or unwilling to pay for their buy orders. The broker, who refused to be named, said his firm had been informed of the problem by stock exchange authorities. Traders said the rumor sparked Thursday morning's selloff in which the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average plunge more than 3.83 percent from Wednesday's close. Exchange officials later denied the bankruptcy rumor in an unusual quickly called news conference. Aided by support from large securities and investment trust firms, the Nikkei rebounded to finish the day down 193.88 points, or 0.68 percent, at 28,249.06. Speculators in the Tokyo Stock Exchange generally remain behind the scenes, buying up shares of targeted companies to push up the price _ sometimes with the use of false rumors _ and then dumping them to make profits. The number of such investors is unknown. Some of these speculators are believed to have close links with gangsters. The Daily Yomiuri newspaper said Thursday that Japanese gangster syndicates have raked in huge profits by investing in stocks. Traders said many of the speculators were going broke because they had bought stocks using borrowed money repayable at high rates of interest. Some speculators have begun using a tactic called ``teppo,'' or gun _ the placement of false buy orders for their own shares in an attempt to get rid of plunging stocks that nobody else wants to buy. The speculators never intend to pay for the shares, dealers say. ``Some securities companies have lost money by buying shares for imaginary figures without cash payment,'' said Hisao Yasuda, a trader with Nikko Securities Co. ``This could be the end of the speculators.'' Yasumasa Shinagawa, a trader with Yamaichi Securities Co., called the Nikkei's early plunge Thursday a sign that speculator groups were collapsing because of financial trouble stemming from the market's nearly 27 percent drop so far this year. At the end of Thursday's trading, about 24 percent of the approximately 1,160 issues on the stock exchange's first section still had no price quotations, indicating that no trades had occurred during the day, said Nikko's Yasuda. He said many of the untraded issues had been manipulated by speculator groups. Issues that are the focus of speculators can be easily identified by wild price movements unrelated to market trends, said Katsumi Nishikido, a dealer with Nippon Kangyo Kakuaru Securities Co. Traders say speculators have targeted about 200 issues listed on the first section of the exchange, about 70 of which are among the Nikkei's 225 issues. The price of Kagoshima Bank shares, identified as one such issue, ended at 860 points Thursday, down from almost 3,000 points in early March. Under Japanese rules, payment for stock orders is not due for four days. As a result, brokerages are vulnerable to losses from speculative excesses. ``Everybody remembers the Black Monday stock crash. They all expected the market to rebound like it did then,'' said one broker. As a result, the market rapidly became overbought, he said. Ordinarily, clients are given thorough initial credit checks, but follow-ups are rare, the broker said. Traders said smaller, unlicensed securities firms could go broke in the current market because they are more likely to be involved with risky investors, whereas major securities firms generally avoid speculators. A Nomura Securities official said major brokerage houses don't process buy orders from speculator groups unless they receive cash payment. The ``big four'' securities companies _Nomura, Yamaichi, Daiwa and Nikko _ are believed to control about 60 percent of the shares traded on the Tokyo Stock Exchange. Of 272 securities firms with licenses from the Finance Ministry, 124, including 22 foreign firms, are members of the exchange. An official in the exchange's investigative arm said, ``The issue is basically a problem between securities firms and their customers. We are trying not to make a big fuss about it. ...If we did, it might make the market performance even worse.'' Takaaki Okada, spokesman for the Securities Dealers' Association of Japan, ruled out the possibility of bankruptcies of accredited Japanese financial institutions because ``the Finance Ministry will offer to take some actions by the time a company gets into trouble.''

DOC.HEAD: Market Not Expecting Much Help for Yen from Other Industrial Nations
With AM-Japan-Markets Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Many in Japan's financial markets are not expecting much help for the falling yen from Saturday's meeting in Paris of the finance chiefs of seven advanced industrial nations. In the past, Japan's trading partners have worried about a cheap yen, which makes Japanese goods less expensive and more competitive abroad, contributing to this nation's huge trade surpluses. Now, Japan is concerned that the weaker yen is raising dangers of domestic inflation by making its imported fuel and raw materials cost more. But analysts say Japan's partners in the Group of Seven are likely to do little more than state a general commitment to stable exchange rates. While a lower dollar tends to make U.S. goods more competitive against Japanese products, they add, the United States has been concentrating recently on other approaches to narrowing its $49 billion deficit in trade with Japan. To help fight its own inflation dangers, they say, the United States is happy with a strong dollar. ``Nobody except Japan is worried about the weak yen,'' said Minori Takeuchi of Chemical Bank. ``West Germany would prefer a strong mark ahead of currency union'' with East Germany, she added. In addition to Japan, the United States and West Germany, the others in the group are Britain, France, Italy and Canada. Just in case the meeting does decide on action to shore up the yen, which has fallen about 10 percent this year, Tokyo market players have been reducing their dollar holdings in the last three days. The dollar closed Thursday at 157.90 yen, down more than two yen from its closing of 159.95 yen on Monday, its highest in more than three years. ``Market players began to reduce their dollar holdings just in case the G-7 meeting comes up with something they had not predicted, although nothing special is expected at the moment,'' Mamoru Tabata, a dealer with Mitsui Taiyo Kobe Bank, said Wednesday. On the other hand, there has been speculation that the United States was declining to support the yen as part of attempts to pressure Japan into making concessions in this week's trade talks in Washington. In those talks, Ms. Takeuchi said, the United States is pressing the Japanese government to spend more on public works, figuring that ``if the government spends more, the United States can export more'' here. Japan's central bank has been using interest rate increases to try to head off inflation and support the yen. Higher interest rates tend to make a nation's currency more attractive, although they also tend to discourage stock investment - a problem for Japan amid a stock market plunge of more than 25 percent so far this year. In its latest move, on March 20, the central bank raised its charge for loans to commercial banks by one percentage point to 5.25 percent. Citing a possible reason for the Group of Seven to support the yen, Yoichi Itoh, chief corporate service officer at Sumitomo Trust and Banking, said, ``I think the United States might judge that higher Japanese interest rates might force U.S. interest rates up, and that some kind of currency stability will be necessary to stop Japanese interest rates from rising further.'' At the end of March, the dollar rose 6.43 yen in nine trading days. Foreign exchange traders said the Tokyo market was disappointed that Japanese Finance Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto's meeting with U.S. Treasury Nicholas Brady on March 23 had produced no tangible new measure to support the yen. At a news briefing on Tuesday, Hashimoto said the dramatic changes in Europe, rather than exchange rates, would be the main focus of the Group of Seven meeting. He said the meeting was not being held to draft policies to deal with the recent instability in Japanese markets. At a news conference last week, Yasushi Mieno, governor of the Bank of Japan, said it was hard to understand why the yen was falling when Japanese interest rates, adjusted for inflation, were higher than U.S. interest rates and Japan still was running large trade surpluses. He suggested that tensions in the Soviet Union and developments in Europe were boosting the dollar, considered a safe haven currency.

DOC.HEAD: Upjohn Gets OK to Sell Anti-Baldness Drug for Women in Britain
DOC.TEXT: The Upjohn Co. has received approval from the British government to begin pitching its anti-baldness drug to women, company officials said Wednesday. Studies show that Regaine, sold as Rogaine in the United States and Canada, is at least as effective in treating hair loss in women as in men, Upjohn officials said. The 2 percent minoxidil solution is sold by prescription for men in 63 countries; about 20 of them also have approved it for women. Upjohn is awaiting approval from the U.S. Food and Drug Administration to sell Rogaine for women in the United States. Company spokeswoman Laura Harwin said the solution and application are the same for men and women. The approval, received Tuesday, just allows the company to broaden its marketing. In the United States, an estimated 30 million men and 20 million women experience hereditary hair loss. The cause of hair thinning in men and women is often the same: age, heredity and the presence of the hormone testosterone, Harwin said. The results differ, however. While many men eventually are left with a horseshoe-shaped fringe of hair, women usually see a general thinning over the top of the head. Marketing experts at Upjohn estimate about 34 percent of women between the ages of 20 and 60 experience at least mild hair thinning. Though Upjohn does not release sales figures for individual products, analysts say the drug has been slow to catch on among men in the United States, partly because of its mixed results. It has been shown in testing to grow hair in about 39 percent of young men who are in the early stages of balding.

DOC.HEAD: US Saves Little, Some Others Even Less
DOC.TEXT: Americans often are accused of having lost the Yankee love of thrift, but the International Monetary Fund says people in some other countries are saving even less _ notably in prosperous northern Europe. It predicted that the trend will continue as the world's population ages. Older people have less to save for. ``The negative trend in national saving rates experienced by all the major industrial countries since the early to mid-1970s has raised serious concerns about the prospects for strong and sustainable growth in the world economy,'' said the latest issue of the ``IMF Survey,'' dated March 19. It appears every two weeks. The warning is based on a report by a team under Bijan B. Aghelvi, senior advisor in the fund's research department at its headquarters in Washington. When people put money into their bank accounts, the banks relend it to industry for building the factories that will produce more goods and jobs in the future. If savings are too small, industry has to borrow from other countries. Governments also save _ or, more often, ``dis-save'' by going further into debt. When a government spends more than it collects in taxes, it has to borrow from the savings of its citizens or from other countries. Its taxpayers then have to pay interest on the debt. The United States is a prime example on both counts. Americans of the future will have to pay interest to other countries on the billions being borrowed by Americans today. The most recent figures come from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) in Paris. In 1988 the average American household saved only $4.40 out of every $100 left after it paid taxes. But Americans were not the greatest spendthrifts. The average Swedish household did not save at all: it drew on past savings or went into debt at the rate of $3.60 for every $100 it earned. ``Dis-savings'' of $1.20 per $100 were also reported from average Norwegian families and $1.40 from those in Finland. Dutch households saved only $2 of every $100. Of the major industrial countries the Japanese were the top savers: $15.20 out of $100. Even the thrifty Japanese have loosened up: in 1976 their figure was $23.20. The average West German family saved $15.10 of every $100 in 1975 and only $12.60 in 1988. Another study sponsored by the fund warns that a country's capital will be consumed unless money is set aside to replace it, and more must be put aside as the population grows.

DOC.HEAD: Publisher: Loss of Features Caused Circulation Drop
DOC.TEXT: The publisher of the Dallas Times Herald testified Wednesday that the paper lost thousands of readers and advertising strength when the rival Dallas Morning News struck a deal for 26 syndicated columns and comics that had appeared in the Times Herald for years. Publisher John Buzzetta was the first witness in the Times Herald's $33 million antitrust suit against The Dallas Morning News over transfer of the Universal Press Syndicate columns. After The Morning News' parent company, A.H. Belo Corp. formed a joint venture with the Kansas City-based syndicate last year, UPS canceled the Times Herald's contract for the features. ``I was shocked,'' Buzzetta testified, referring to the cancelation notice. ``I'd never seen something like this happen. ``Here, in one fell swoop, I was going to lose some of the best features this newspaper had published for years and years. I thought I was going to have some serious losses.'' Buzzetta tallied the circulation losses at 9,000 to 10,000 daily readers and more than 15,000 on Sunday. The Times Herald had been posting increases in circulation before Universal Press canceled the features, said Buzzetta, who bought the paper in 1988. But afterward the paper began to lose ``loyal readers'' faithful to such features as Dear Abby, Erma Bombeck and Doonesbury, which were moved to The Morning News. ``If you lose features, it means you lose some really loyal readers, and circulation goes down,'' he said. If circulation declines, advertising follows, he said. The newspaper gets 90 percent of its revenue from advertising sales and 10 percent from newspaper sales, he said. Court documents indicate The Morning News attracts 60 percent of the circulation and newspaper advertising in Dallas. Buzzetta said a newspaper economist hired by the Times Herald quantified the damage of losing the features at $33 million. The Times Herald also is seeking unspecified punitive damages from Belo and The Morning News. In opening statements, Morning News attorneys maintained the Times Herald has made circulation gains since losing the features. Buzzetta said some of the circulation losses were recouped through special promotions, particularly a lottery. But he said the promotions have been expensive _ costing $1.5 million so far _ and do not have the same lasting power to attract and keep ``loyal readers'' that features have. The Times Herald attorneys said they will try to prove The Morning News conspired to lure the features from the Times Herald in hopes of destroying newspaper competition in the Dallas market. Morning News lawyers, however, maintain it was just fair competition to purchase rights to the comics and columns. The joint venture, called Universal-Belo, also is developing television shows based on syndicate comic characters. The Times Herald has challenged that agreement in a pending request for the Federal Communications Commission to revoke the license of Belo's WFAA-TV, the top-rated station in Dallas.

DOC.HEAD: Money Funds Fell To $390.49 Billion in Latest Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 507 money market mutual funds fell $293.6 million in the latest week to $390.49 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline in the seven-day period ended Wednesday, followed a $1.36 billion drop to $390.78 billion the previous week. That total originally was reported as $391.62 billion but the Washington-based mutual fund trade group subsequently revised it down further to reflect asset adjustments in newly reporting funds. The Investment Company Institute said that in the latest week, assets of 246 general purpose funds rose $226.0 million to $133.23 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds dropped $570.1 million to $165.79 billion, and assets of 159 institutional funds rose $50.5 million to $91.47 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds fell in the week ended Tuesday to 7.67 percent from 7.69 percent the previous week, according to Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield rose to 7.67 percent from 7.66 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was 45 days, unchanged from last week, Donoghue's said. Separately, the newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts remained unchanged at 6.25 percent as of Wednesday compared with a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, also was unchanged, at 5.05 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.88 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 7.89 the previous week. Yields were 8.03 percent on 1-year CDs, up from 8.02 percent; 8.05 percent on 2{-year CDs, up from 8.04 percent; and 8.09 percent on 5-year CDs, up from 8.08 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Lower
DOC.TEXT: The energy futures market lost more ground Thursday as concerns about overproduction by OPEC depressed prices of crude oil and other petroleum products. Gasoline was the biggest loser. The contract for May delivery of unleaded gasoline settled 1.57 cents lower at 63.29 cents a gallon on the New York Mercantile Exchange, after falling 1.02 cents Wednesday. Other contract months also lost more than a penny a gallon. Another refined petroleum product traded on the Merc, May home heating oil, slipped 0.71 cent to 53.31 cents a gallon. The contract tumbled 1.48 cents on Wednesday. The May contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, settled at $19.43 per 42-gallon barrel, after losing 52 cents in Wednesday's session. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery closed at $1.615 per million British thermal units, down from $1.620 Wednesday. The contract began trading on the Merc earlier this week. Bob Baker, a senior energy analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., attributed the drop in prices to reports that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was producing as much as 24 million barrels of oil a day, far above its 22-million-barrel daily quota. ``We're not going to see $20 oil with this level of production,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed in Dull Trading
Precede: LONDON-BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar finished mixed Thursday in dull trading on world currency markets. Gold prices fell in the United States after rising overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $374.80 a troy ounce, down $2.30 from late Wednesday. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold of $375 an ounce, down $2.75. The dollar's only significant move came against the Japanese yen. The dollar lost one yen against the Japanese currency in Asian trading and fell further as trading shifted to Europe and later to the United States. Dealers stressed that trading was quiet overall. Investors remained on the sidelines while awaiting the weekend meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations and Friday's release of U.S. unemployment figures for March. Finance officials from the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada were planning to meet in Paris to review international exchange rates. ``There was a feeling earlier in the week that there would be no new policy initiatives (coming out of the meeting), but now the market's getting a little more nervous,'' said Ron Holzer, a vice president at Harris Trust & Savings Bank in Chicago. Dealers said they had expected the dollar's decline against the yen following speculation that monetary authorities might take action to prop up the sagging Japanese currency. In Tokyo, the dollar closed at 157.90 yen, down 1 yen from Wednesday. Later in London, the dollar was quoted lower at 157.74 yen. In New York, the dollar closed at 157.50 yen, down from 158.88 yen on Wednesday. In London, the British pound rose to $1.6427 from $1.6416 late Wednesday. In New York, one pound cost $1.6420, more expensive than Wednesday's $1.6406. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6997 West German marks, up from 1.6995; 1.5015 Swiss francs, down from 1.5040; 5.7150 French francs, up from 5.7095; 1,249.50 Italian lire, up from 1,249.00; and 1.1684 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1673. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday's rates, included: 1.6997 West German marks, down from 1.6999; 1.5010 Swiss francs, down from 1.5060; 5.7155 French francs, up from 5.7120; 1.9123 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9115; 1,250.50 Italian lire, up from 1,249.50; and 1.1685 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1672. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $377 a troy ounce, up from $374.50 late Wednesday. In Zurich, Switzerland, the metal rose to a closing bid of $376.50 an ounce from $374.50 late Wednesday. Gold was not traded in Hong Kong, where all financial institutions were closed Thursday for the Chinese Ching Ming, or Remembrance of Ancestors Day, holiday. They will reopen Friday. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery finished at $5.141 a troy ounce, down from $5.160 on Wednesday. But in London, the metal rose to a late bid price of $5.18 an ounce from $5.02.

DOC.HEAD: Money Supply Rises
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended March 26, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,273.4 billion from $3,268.3 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,070.3 billion from $4,067.1 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, rose to a seasonally adjusted $804.8 billion from $802.5 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 6.2 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 2.9 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,248.2 billion, a 6.4 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,057.1 billion, up 3.1 percent, while M1 rose 5 percent to an average of $799.8 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks fell $1.75 billion. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $244 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $140 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $928 million in the two weeks ended Wednesday, up from $575 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $302 billion in the two-week period ended April 4, down from $304.2 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Broker Association Rule Out for Comment
DOC.TEXT: Federal futures regulators on Thursday took another step toward regulating groups of traders known as ``broker associations,'' to prevent possible trading abuses like those uncovered in Chicago last year. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission voted unanimously, 5-0, to submit for public comment, a proposed rule that would provide a legal definition of broker associations and require them to register with the exchange at which they do business. Broker associations have been loosely defined as formal or informal groups of futures traders formed to provide more capital to finance trades and more people to handle them. But the CFTC's Division of Trading and Markets concluded in a study disclosed last January that broker associations ``may increase the potential for certain types of trading abuses.'' The study was an outgrowth of an undercover investigation of trading at the Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange _ the nation's two largest futures exchanges _ which resulted in the indictment of more than 40 traders. Only five of the 13 futures exchanges have rules defining broker associations, and of those, only three: the Chicago Mercantile Exchange; the Commodity Exchange or COMEX and the Coffee, Sugar & Cocoa Exchange, require broker associations to register. CFTC staffers believe, and commission members agreed, that keeping tabs on broker associations will help them deter abuses in the trading pits. ``I believe very strongly that we identify and register these groups and I also agree that it gives a big assist and augmentation to our surveillance program to have this information,'' said Commissioner Kalo A. Hineman. In other matters, the CFTC, which oversees the futures markets, voted to seek public comment on a clarified commission interpretation of what types of ``hybrid'' financial products are exempt from CFTC regulations. Hybrids contain elements of both futures contracts and securities. The interpretation, issued last year, specifies what types of institutions and products are exempt from CFTC regulation. As defined in the CFTC's proposed rule, ``broker association'' refers to two or more exchange members who share: responsibility for executing customer orders, profits or losses from trading activities or access to each other's unfilled customer orders. The rule would bar participation in the trading activities of a broker association unless the association is registered with the market or exchange. Interested parties would have 60 days to comment on the proposed rule before the CFTC takes a final vote on implementing it.

DOC.HEAD: Avon Miffed by New Chartwell Stock Purchases
DOC.TEXT: Avon Products Inc., which late last month reached a truce with the investor group Chartwell Associates L.P., said Thursday that Chartwell's recent additional purchases of its stock were inappropriate. The Avon board responded to Chartwell's stock purchases by voting Thursday to amend the cosmetics company's share rights anti-takeover plan. The change essentially is meant to discourage Chartwell from buying more Avon stock. The amendment lowers the threshold at which an element of the rights plan becomes effective. It will apply when anyone acquires more than 12.5 percent of Avon's outstanding voting stock, rather than 20 percent. Chartwell had said earlier in a filing to the Securities and Exchange Commission that it raised its stake in Avon's common stock to 16 percent. Its holding of Avon's voting stock expanded to about 12 percent. The group, which includes affiliates of Mary Kay Corp., oil heir Gordon Getty and the Fisher real estate family of New York, said it bought more than 3.45 million shares of Avon common stock between March 27 and April 4, increasing its total holding to 9.05 million. The partnership said it has spent more than $312 million from working capital to acquire its Avon interest. Avon said in a letter to Chartwell that the purchases could interfere with an agreement under which Avon plans to nominate two Chartwell candidates to its board at its annual meeting May 3. In return for the board seats, Chartwell had agreed to drop its proxy fight to win four seats on Avon's board of directors. Under the settlement, the Avon directors are establishing a committee to consider ways of boosting value for Avon stockholders. Members of the special panel will be James E. Preston, Avon's chairman and chief executive officer, three incumbent members of the Avon board and the two Chartwell nominees. The panel will examine alternatives to maximize value, such as a recapitalization, asset sales, an outright sale of Avon or a leveraged buyout. Preston said in the letter that the board is concerned Chartwell's new purchases will ``prejudice the ability of the special committee to consider all the alternatives'' in carrying out its assigned task. ``In addition, the board believes that such purchases will have adverse consequences on our operating businesses and could be unfair to other shareholders,'' Preston said. The letter was sent to Richard Fisher, a member of Chartwell. It was released by Avon's headquarters in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Computer Company Drops CFC Chemical in Cleaning Process
DOC.TEXT: Digital Equipment Corp. announced Thursday it has developed a new process to clean computer circuit boards that does not use chemicals believed to damage the Earth's ozone layer. Company officials making the announcement at Digital's Augusta plant, where the process was developed, said Digital is making the technology available to other companies as a gesture of Digital's environmental commitment. The Maynard, Mass.-based company the nation's second-largest computer maker after International Business Machines Corp. Even before Thursday's announcement, some companies expressed interest in the new process, Augusta plant manager Bob Jackson told reporters and business representatives. In the past, Digital, like many computer makers, used solvents containing chlorofluorocarbons to remove dirt and residues left by the manufacturing process from printed circuit boards. The debris was removed through chemical reactions with the solvent, but CFC's were released into the air when the solvent evaporated. Digital has developed a process in which minute droplets of water are sprayed on the circuit boards from rotating arms. A key to the technology is a nozzle reducing the size of the droplets, which are able to clean underneath components. The circuit boards are washed with a light detergent, then rinsed twice and blown dry. The process is ``exceptionally simple,'' said Dana Duncan, an engineering supervisor and one of those who developed the technology. Equipment for the process has been installed at Digital plants in Augusta and Hong Kong, and plants in Singapore and Taiwan are being retrofitted, said Mike Hasty, a process engineering manager who also worked on the technique. Digital is providing information on the new technology through the Industry Cooperative for Ozone Layer Protection, a joint venture between the federal Environmental Protection Agency and industry. The venture promotes worldwide reduction of chlorofluorocarbons. Digital said it has been working on the CFC-reducing process for two years. Reduction of CFCs, which are also used in refrigeration, foam blowing and aerosols, will aid in efforts to counter global warming, known as the ``greenhouse effect,'' scientists say. CFCs are believed to break down the protective ozone layer surrounding the Earth.

DOC.HEAD: Two Investment Firms Buy Big Chunks of Northrop
DOC.TEXT: B-2 bomber builder Northrop Corp. says two investment firms have purchased large amounts of its stock, which has dropped from the $50-per-share level in the mid-1980s to $15. The firm Sanford C. Bernstein has acquired 8.1 percent of Northrop's 47 million common shares and Delaware Management Co. 6.3 percent, according to proxy material mailed to shareholders in advance of Northrop's annual meeting May 16. It was unclear whether Bernstein and Delaware Management were holding shares in trust. Bernstein has sole voting power over only half its 3.8 million shares and Delaware management over only 1.3 million shares of its 2.9 million shares, the proxy said. The aerospace company has been considered vulnerable to takeover because of its depressed stock price, although analysts said a buyout would be complicated because insiders hold large blocks of stock. The holdings ``would make it very hard for any outsider to mount an unfriendly takeover,'' said Wolfgang Demisch, the head of research for UBS Securities in New York. Northrop finished at $15 a share Wednesday on the New York Stock Exchange, unchanged from Tuesday's close. At that price, the 47 million common shares could be purchased for $705 million _ a bit more than the $530 million pricetag for a single radar-evading, bat-winged B-2 stealth bomber.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Futures Sink, Reflecting Large Supplies
DOC.TEXT: Petroleum futures prices fell sharply Thursday on the New York Mercantile Exchange, dropping for the third straight day amid perceptions that gasoline and crude oil supplies are outstripping demand. On other commodity markets, soybeans surged while grains were mixed; copper futures fell; precious metals retreated; and livestock and meat futures were mostly higher. West Texas Intermediate crude oil futures settled 26 cents to 43 cents lower with the contract for delivery in May at $19.43 a barrel; heating oil was .71 cent to 1.16 cents lower with May at 53.31 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 1.05 cents to 1.71 cents lower with May at 63.29 cents a gallon. Analysts said there was no change in supply-and-demand factors Thursday to account for the selloff. But traders have turned increasingly bearish amid signs of a rising crude oil production and steady stockpiling of gasoline. Indications of apparently strong gasoline demand helped support the petroleum markets last month, but some analysts now believe the market misinterpreted the signals. ``It appears to me that some of the strong demand of the past couple of weeks was simply some inventory building,'' said Jim Ritterbusch, energy analyst with PaineWebber Inc. in Chicago. With many refineries now gearing up to increase gasoline production for the summer driving season, he said, ``we could be flooding the market with gasoline a month or two down the road.'' Ritterbusch said OPEC crude oil production is approaching an eight-year high, which is one of the factors that caused crude oil for near-term delivery to slip below $20 a barrel Wednesday. Most market experts foresee steady or falling crude prices through the spring. Soybean futures surged into the close of trading on the Chicago Board of Trade amid expectations for new export sales, while grain futures finished mixed. Soybean exports from Brazil to Europe have been slowed by confusion over economic reforms launched last month in the South American country, prompting speculation that importers may turn to the United States to meet their needs. In other export developments, analysts said the Soviet Union is rumored to have bought as much as 1 million metric tons of corn recently. They said some of those purchases may have been reflected in Agriculture Department announcements this week of a total of 221,000 metric tons of U.S. corn sold to unknown destinations. Wheat futures settled } cent lower to \ cent higher with May at $3.70 a bushel; corn was { cent lower to 2 cents higher with May at $2.70\ a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to { cent higher with May at $1.52} a bushel; soybeans were 3{ cents to 5{ cents higher with May at $5.96{ a bushel. Copper futures extended their losses on New York's Commodity Exchange despite reports from Peru indicating a 25-day-old strike against the Southern Peru Copper Corp. had not been settled. News reports on Wednesday said the strike was over, but those accounts were later denied by the government and the company, which said it was still in the process of presenting a proposal to workers. Copper futures finished 1.55 cents lower to .05 cent higher with April at $1.2195 a pound. Gold and silver futures fell on the Commodity Exchange in profit-taking after two days of gains. Gold settled $2.20 to $2.50 lower with April at $374.80 a troy ounce; silver was 1.9 cents to 2.2 cents lower with April at $5.141 a troy ounce. Cattle futures rallied strongly late in the session on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange on reports of higher prices paid for steers in western Kansas and light sales of fed cattle. Pork futures finished mixed in lackluster trading. Live cattle were .25 cent to .62 cent higher with April at 78.95 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .20 cent to .67 cent higher with April at 82.80 cents a pound; live hogs were .22 cent lower to .20 cent higher with April at 54.85 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were unchanged to .50 cent higher with May at 55.45 cents a pound.

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices drifted through a mixed session Thursday after a rumored financial storm in Tokyo failed to materialize. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had been down 17.34 points Wednesday, rose 1.80 to 2,721.17. Declining issues slightly outnumbered advances in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 703 up, 744 down and 540 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 144.17 million shares, against 159.54 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 175.91 million shares. Prices of U.S. stocks pulled back on Wednesday amid talk that the battered Japanese market might be hit with a fresh wave of selling overnight. As it turned out, Tokyo stock prices did decline sharply in early trading, but then recovered most of their losses. Analysts said that calmed some fears that pressure on stocks in Japan might soon start to exert an increasing influence in other markets around the world. But at the same time, brokers said, traders in this country were proceeding carefully in advance of Friday's monthly report on the employment situation. Estimates in the financial world call for an increase of perhaps 150,000 to 180,000 in nonfarm payroll employment for March, which would be considerably smaller than the gains reported for January and February. Among Japanese issues traded on U.S. exchanges, Matsushita Electrical climbed 7~ to 144{; Kyocera 3} to 100; Hitachi 7\ to 104\, and Honda Motor 1\ to 23[. Tandem Computers led the active list, down 4} at 22{. The company said revenues for the fiscal quarter that ended last weekend fell short of its target. Bank stocks were also notably weak, faced with what analysts described as the prospect of a long and arduous review by government regulators of lending practices in the industry. Bankamerica dropped 1\ to 26]; First Chicago 1 to 29; Citizens & Southern Corp. 1\ to 25\; Bank of Boston 1[ to 12}; Manufacturers Hanover 1[ to 30}, and Bank of New York 2{ to 31\. Gainers among the blue-chip industrials included Philip Morris, up } at 41\; American Telephone & Telegraph, up { at 41}; Coca-Cola, up [ at 77{; International Paper, up ] at 51\, and General Electric, up [ at 63]. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market lost $4.37 billion, or 0.13 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks slipped .16 to 187.15. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose .03 to 396.05, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was down .36 at 340.73. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market lost 2.00 to 433.42. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 361.23, up .11.

Judge Enjoins Torchmark From Soliciting Proxies for American General Board
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Thursday enjoined Torchmark Corp. from soliciting proxies for a slate of nominees for the board of American General Corp., a rival insurer. American General argued that Torchmark failed to comply with the advance notice provisions of American General's bylaws and should not be allowed to solicit proxies. American General contends the nominations closed March 3. U.S. District Court Judge David Hittner granted the preliminary injunction Thursday. Torchmark said Monday it would seek control of American General's board after it withdrew a $6.4 billion bid to purchase the Houston firm. ``American General said that its board would not consider our proposal until after its annual meeting on May 2, so the annual meeting has become a referendum on whether shareholders want the board to seriously consider proposals like ours,'' Torchmark President John T. Rotenstreich said Monday. American General had assets of $32.1 billion and common shareholders' equity of $4.1 billion at the end of 1989. The insurance and financial services organization has subsidiaries that operate in 50 states and Canada. Birmingham, Ala.-based Torchmark reported assets at Dec. 31 of $4.9 billion and common shareholders' equity of $795 million.

DOC.HEAD: UAL Board Meets Amid Reports Of Higher Union Offer
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 3rd graf to UPDATE with meeting continuing late Thursday night; picks up 4th graf, `The board.'
DOC.TEXT: Speculation mounted Thursday that UAL Corp.'s board of directors was close to accepting an employee buyout offer that reportedly had been sweetened to more than $200 a share . The board met Thursday in Chicago, UAL's headquarters city, amid reports that the three United Airlines union groups seeking to buy the carrier's parent company had raised their bid from an estimated $185 a share, or about $4 billion, to an offer valued at $200 to $210, or at least $4.36 billion. The board is believed to be seeking at least $200 a share. The directors have been negotiating with unions representing United's pilots, machinists and flight attendants in the two weeks since it rejected their $185-a-share offer. The board was still meeting late Thursday night, according to a source close to the meeting. No other details were immediately available. The board met at least twice by telephone earlier this week. A Wall Street takeover speculator and a source close to the union group cautioned Thursday that an agreement by the board to accept the employee offer would not necessarily mean a deal would be concluded quickly or even concluded at all. The Wall Street Journal reported on Thursday that the union group had sweetened its offer by adding a proposed sale of United's 50 percent stake in its Covia-Apollo computerized reservation system, valued at $500 million or more. UAL's stock fell $1 a share to $165.50 Thursday on the New York Stock Exchange. The takeover speculator, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said demand for UAL's stock has been blunted by concerns about the difficulty the union group may face in financing the deal and about the time it would take to complete a deal even if the board accepts the union offer. ``You have to be very concerned with the time frame,'' he said. The union group, which represents about two-third's of UAL's employees, proposed on March 19 the $185-a-share buyout, which would give UAL's entire workforce 75 percent ownership of the country's second-largest airline. The bid is supported by UAL's largest shareholder, Coniston Partners, which holds an 11.8 percent stake. Unless the board sells to the union group, Coniston says it will wage a proxy fight to oust UAL's board at the company's April 26 shareholders meeting. The bid is reportedly opposed strongly by UAL Chairman Stephen Wolf, who likely would be dumped if the workers gain control of the company.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Soar, Dollar Declines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning stock figures, adds comments and bond prices
DOC.TEXT: Share prices soared on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Friday morning, encouraged by the dollar's retreat against the yen. The Nikkei Stock Average of 225 selected issues rose 899.11 points, or 3.2 percent, to close the morning session at 29,148.17. The dollar started trading at 156.90 yen, down 1.00 yen from Thursday's close of 157.90 yen. The U.S. currency finished at 157.50 yen in New York overnight, down from 158.88 yen Wednesday. ``The market is almost dominated by buying orders,'' said Akiya Shimoda, an equity analyst with Yamaichi Securities. ``The yen's advance against the dollar is an encouraging factor.'' ``Many investors, including institutional investors, began considering that the index has reached its bottom level,'' Shimoda said. The index closed 193.88 points lower on Thursday after having been down more than 1,100 points at one stage amid rumors that some small brokerages might fail. As of Thursday, the index had fallen 27 percent so far this year. Shimoda said the general mood in the market had turned brighter after Thursday's afternoon session, when major institutional investors began buying actively to support the falling market. In currency dealings, the dollar was responding to ``position adjustments'' by participants prior to the weekend meeting of the Group of Seven industrialized nations in Paris. Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, said some participants expect ``there will be some policy initiative to defend the yen'' from the meeting of monetary authorities from the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada. Kagawa said there was ``no significant effect'' on the exchange market from Thursday's agreement between the United States and Japan pledging to reduce trade frictions by making broad-based reforms in the economies of both countries. The agreement, reached after four days of discussions in the Structural Impediments Initiative, set forth a set of proposals aimed at lowering the United States' $49 billion deficit with Japan by correcting structural barriers to trade. The yen's strength boosted Japanese government bond prices, lowering interest rates. The yield on the benchmark No. 119 government bond fell to 7.21 percent from 7.24 Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Approves Clean Air Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 6th graf to CORRECT committee vote to 39-4, sted 38-4.
DOC.TEXT: The House Energy and Commerce Committee overwhelmingly approved a far-ranging air pollution control bill late Thursday after resolving a dispute on how to deal with Midwest concerns over acid rain controls. The measure now goes to the House floor where it is likely to come up for debate early next month. The committee cleared the legislation by a vote of 42-1. Rep. William E. Dannemeyer, R-Calif., was the sole dissenter. Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., the committee chairman, called the bill ``significantly better'' in protecting the environment than a version approved by the Senate earlier in the week. The committee moved swiftly to approve the legislation after giving the nod to a compromise agreement aimed at easing concerns from Midwest congressmen over the high cost of acid rain controls. The acid rain compromise, worked out during three days of closed-door negotiations among committee members and staff, was approved by a 39-4 vote, erasing the last major roadblock to committee passage of the bill. ``The process has been rather curious,'' said Dingell, alluding to the lengthy private negotiations that eased the committee through several obstacles. ``We have negotiated rather than fought ... and it has worked,'' he said. The lopsided committee vote following Senate approval of its own clean air bill by an 89-11 margin earlier in the week put clean air legislation on track for congressional approval this year. Both bills call for sweeping emission controls on factories, automobiles and electric power plants by the end of the decade. The Bush administration has estimated the Senate legislation would cost $21.5 billion to the economy yearly when all provisions go into effect. The House bill has been said to be slightly cheaper. House Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash., had indicated that he wanted to begin floor action on the legislation in early May. Final legislation would have to be worked out in a conference committee because of differences between the House and Senate bills. ``This legislation is long overdue. ... It's a real victory for our lakes, lungs and resources,'' said Rep. Gerry Sikorski, D-Minn. The acid rain issue had dominated the three days of closed-door bargaining among members of Dingell's committee as members and staff worked under a deadline to try to complete action on the entire bill before Congress departs for its Easter recess Friday. Earlier the committee had reached a consensus on provisions dealing with curbing urban smog and controlling toxic industrial releases. ``A lot of blood was spilled in these debates,'' said Rep. Jim Cooper, D-Tenn., who vigorously opposed a cost sharing provision to help the Midwest. But the compromise received Cooper's support as well as that of all but four of the committee members, all from Texas: Reps. Ralph Hall and John Bryan, both Democrats, and Jack Fields and Joe Barton, both Republicans. As a way to help Midwest states pay for cleaning up dirty utility plants, the measure included a ``pollution allowance'' system and a 1-year extension for initial compliance under some circumstances. ``It allows us to recoup some costs,'' said Rep. Michael Oxley, R-Ohio. Nevertheless, Oxley said, ``This is a tough, tough bill for my part of the country and we're going to feel it for a long time.'' Critics of the measure have said it would cause electric rates to jump. More than 150 lobbyists representing everything from environmental groups to the steel industry gathered outside the House hearing room were the negotiations were being held, awaiting word of an agreement. The clean air legislation is aimed at imposing steep pollution controls on a broad range of industry, automobiles and coal-fired electric power plants to curb emissions of acid rain, smog and toxic chemicals. Earlier in the day, the Environmental Protection Agency released a new annual report that showed, as had previous reports, that federal air pollution laws are failing to ensure healthy air in more than 100 cities across the country. According to the EPA survey, which reported results on six pollutants during 1988, more than 121 million people lived in areas where the air did not meet federal health standards. The EPA assessment said the urban smog problem became 15 percent worse in 1988 compared with the year before, in part because of an exceedingly hot summer, and levels of sulfur dioxide and nitrogen dioxide increased slightly. Levels of carbon dioxide and dust or dirt declined somewhat. The emissions are largely the product of automobile travel, industrial releases or the burning of fossil fuels by electric power plants. The report ``shows the magnitude of the air pollution problem still remaining,'' said EPA Administrator William K. Reilly, adding that it reinforces the need for new, tougher air pollution controls. The Senate's approval of a clean air bill Tuesday was the first time either the House or Senate has passed tighter air pollution legislation since 1977. Emotional regional disputes have blocked progress on a bill for years, usually because of the high cost of reducing sulfur dioxide emissions from power plants. While most members of Congress, as well as the Bush administration, agree on a required 10 million ton reduction in annual sulfur dioxide emissions to curb acid rain, the dispute has focused on how much of a burden should be carried by the Midwest, where some of the dirtiest plants are located.
